Explaination: No credible reports claim that Queen Elizabeth II tested positive for COVID-19. Buckingham Palace recently said she remains in good health.
Label: False

Claim: Posting anything on coronavirus will be a punishable offense because the Disaster Management Act has been implemented.
Explaination: As per the Disaster Management Act, there is no provision that mentions that apart from government departments, no other citizen can be allowed to talk, update or share any news related to a disaster.
Label: False

Claim: 18 nations, including the US and the UK, want Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to be the leader of the task force to combat the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: While India is actively participating in global efforts to mitigate the damage being caused by the coronavirus, the claim that Indian Prime Minister has been chosen to head a global task force on the same is absolutely false.
Label: False

Claim: Video of Al-Aqsa mosque after Israel allows photography inside it.
Explaination: The video is not of Al-Aqsa in Jerusalem but Cave of the Patriarchs in Hebron.
Label: False

Claim: Chewing betel nuts can prevent COVID-19 infection.
Explaination: WHO has iterated that while some traditional medicines, western medicines, and home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence of a single medicine to prevent COVID-19 currently. WHO has confirmed that betel nut is carcinogenic.
Label: False

Claim: Says COVID-19 remains in the air for eight hours and that everyone is now required to wear masks “everywhere.”
Explaination: There are different definitions of what is considered “airborne,” and while COVID-19 is spread through the air via droplets, it isn’t believed to be as transmissible as typical airborne illnesses, such as measles. There is no evidence that the virus stays in the air for eight hours and there is no requirement for “everyone” to wear masks everywhere.
Label: False

Claim: While China built a hospital for 1,000 people in 10 days and everyone cheered, the Brazilian Army built field hospitals for 2,000 COVID-19 patients in only 48 hours, and nobody cared.
Explaination: Since the beginning of the crisis, the Brazilian Army helped to build one field hospital in Roraima with 80 beds, not 2 thousand. It took more than 48 hours to build and it is still not open. The Army also started working on adapting a hangar to serve as a hospital for COVID-19 patients, but the expected capacity is 70 patients.
Label: False

Claim: There is censorship against the use of chloroquine as a treatment.
Explaination: French scientist promoting chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine have created not only enthusiasm for this "treatment", but also accusations that the French government or the Big Pharma, are hiding this cure.
Label: False

Claim: Trupti Desai, a well known social activist from India, was arrested for illegally buying liquor during the COVID-19 lockdown.
Explaination: The video shown with the above claim is 7-months-old. Trupti Desai was detained by the Pune police after she threatened to offer a garland of liquor bottles to then CM Devendra Fadnavis.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 is no more harmful than the common cold.
Explaination: There is numerous evidence that COVID-19 is much more dangerous than the common cold.
Label: False

Claim: Video of empty hospitals is proof that the pandemic is not real.
Explaination: Hospital in Bologna confirms that the claim is false.
Label: False

Claim: Sneezing spreads droplets as far as 8 meters, and these droplets can stay suspended in the air for up to 24 hours. The velocity of sneezing is up to 35 meters per second.
Explaination: How long the coronavirus survives in the air depends on temperature, humidity, and the level of ventilation of the environment. Although droplets can travel and suspend in the air for a long time, the virus doesn't.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Someone asking people not to use air conditioning in hot weather as heat will kill the coronavirus.
Explaination: WHO debunked this claim and said that hot weather and exposing yourself to sun will not protect you against COVID-19. the true part in his claim is that he said isolation in home is good in fighting COVID-19
Label: Mostly false

Claim: COVID-19 pandemic is being used as an excuse to put microchips into babies.
Explaination: It's an old false claim, in circulation since 2014.
Label: False

Claim: The United States is “recruiting” doctors to confront COVID-19.
Explaination: The U.S. Embassy in Havana wishes to clarify that the US it is not recruiting foreign medical professionals to assist in the response to COVID-19. The announcement only covers individuals already approved and notified by the Department of Homeland Security
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 no longer considered a dangerous disease in the UK.
Explaination: The false claims misrepresents UK's system for disease classification.
Label: False

Claim: The video says that Italian elderly over 65 are taken into custody; Spanish elderly are asked not to leave home, and violators will be sent to a concentration camp.
Explaination: The video documents the violent arresting action toward protesters, which was conducted by the police in Baku, Azerbaijan, on October 19, 2019.
Label: False

Claim: 5G is the cause of the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: Neither 5G nor other means of electromagnetic transmission are causing virus epidemics.
Label: False

Claim: Costa Rica is at the peak stage of the virus.
Explaination: Health authorities and experts explain that it is impossible to determine exactly when the maximum point of infections of the novel coronavirus will appear.
Label: False

Claim: The Disaster Management Act 2005 is going to be implemented in India; no citizen is allowed to post any update or share any forward related to COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no such restriction on citizens to share any news or updates about the COVID-19 situation, as long as it is not false information.
Label: False

Claim: Christine Lagarde admits that something must be done about old people living for too long.
Explaination: C. Lagarde has never made the statement that is being attributed to her.
Label: False

Claim: A COVID-19 test in Germany is 37 times cheaper than in Croatia.
Explaination: The test costs approximately the same in both countries.
Label: False

Claim: People older than 60 are not given medical help in Italy anymore.
Explaination: Italian doctors are treating as many patients as they can manage, regardless of their age.
Label: False

Claim: Muammar Gaddafi predicted “they” will create viruses and sell us the cures.
Explaination: Gaddafi has not made the claim that's being attributed to him.
Label: False

Claim: Italian prime minister admits Italy is lost.
Explaination: The quote is made up and illustrated with the picture of president of Brazil Bolsonaro.
Label: False

Claim: People who got a flu shot are at a greater risk from COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no evidence that a flu vaccine makes things worse for COVID-19 patients.
Label: Misleading

Claim: 18 Italian people are illegally entering the Ivory Coast to flee the coronavirus.
Explaination: Ivorian authorities denied: they are tourists coming from different European countries, and none of them are Italian. They entered Ivory Coast before actions were taken to slow down of the epidemic.
Label: False

Claim: There is an old undocumented man that  “does not remember anything” hospitalized in the “La Paz Hospital”.
Explaination: The image was viralized in 2017 related with the same history, is not from now.
Label: False

Claim: The father of Pablo Iglesias, vice president of Spain, is hospitalized at the Clinical Hospital of Salamanca.
Explaination: The image is from 2016.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The government is not getting the test to detect COVID-19 from the company Genomica because it is run by the sister of a former opposition minister.
Explaination: The Ministry of Health has acquired the Genomica tests and also those of Cestest, another Spanish company cited in the viral messages. None produces quick tests, but kits to do PCR tests.
Label: False

Claim: Castilla La-Mancha prohibits the use of adapted diving masks in patients with COVID-19.
Explaination: The Castilla-La Mancha Health Service ensures that its use "is left to the professionals' discretion".
Label: False

Claim: Iranian child celebrity Anahita is suffering from COVID-19.
Explaination: The family of the girl denied the claim on the girl's instagram account. the girl also appeared on a video 30/3/2020 and is appearing healthy.
Label: False

Claim: A trucker assures in a video that he transports material to France and that it does not arrive in Spain because the government does not pay for it.
Explaination: The material that was sent to France was not for hospitals but office supplies.
Label: False

Claim: It is predicted that using Turmeric can cure coronavirus in India in a newborn baby suffering from birth defects.
Explaination: The baby was suffering from Anencephaly and was stillborn and has no connection with COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Antibiotic invented in Croatia cures coronavirus.
Explaination: There's no proof that the antibiotic in question has any effect against COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: The former mayor of Madrid, Manuela Carmena, has received a respirator at home in order to avoid “going to a public hospital”.
Explaination: The mayor and the company that supplies the respirators denied it.
Label: False

Claim: Coffins of people who died from the coronavirus.
Explaination: The images were from Lampedusa.
Label: False

Claim: Iberdrola, a Spanish electricity provider, offers a discount “for the coronavirus”.
Explaination: The company explained it was a discount for its users before the crisis.
Label: False

Claim: All communications between citizens will now be recorded by the government in France.
Explaination: It's a message that already existed in 2017. Spread in several languages, in 20+ countries.
Label: False

Claim: Arbidol is a miracle cure for COVID-19.
Explaination: Arbidol is among the drugs being tested to see if it can help in treating COVID-19 but there's no proof it can cure the disease.
Label: False

Claim: Indian state of Madhya Pradesh’s government has issued an order to shoot at sight due to failure at lockdown implementation.
Explaination: No shoot at sight order was issued by Madhya Pradesh Govt., the State government have issued a clarification regarding this.
Label: False

Claim: Hydroxychloroquine and Azithromycin are cures for COVID-19.
Explaination: There are hopeful trials but they are small, early and have methodological issues raised by experts. There is no controlled clinical trial. Some trials are ongoing.
Label: No evidence

Claim: Rubbing mustard oil on your nostrils can prevent coronavirus.
Explaination: Rubbing mustard oil cannot prevent coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: UN is giving humanitarian aid in coronavirus emergency.
Explaination: UN is not delivering food aid. The message is a phishing scam.
Label: False

Claim: PM Modi on 4/2/20 announced extension of a nationwide lockdown until 5/4/20.
Explaination: PM Modi has not made any announcement for extension of nationwide lockdown till 4 May 2020. The image is digitally edited.
Label: False

Claim: A video of a man committing suicide by jumping from a hotel in Italy after his entire family died because of the coronavirus.
Explaination: The video has been on the internet since December 2019. But, the first death due to COVID-19 was reported in January, 2020. So, there is no relation between the video and COVID-19. Also, the hotel in the video is in Spain.
Label: False

Claim: Photo of deer on Ooty-Coimbatore road during the current lockdown (COVID-19).
Explaination: It is an old photo. The photo is on the internet at least since 2014. It was taken in Japan, not in India.
Label: False

Claim: Indian Army has built a 1,000-bed hospital in Rajasthan in eight days for the treatment of COVID-19.
Explaination: The Indian Army has mentioned that the news that it is building a thousand-bed hospital for the treatment of COVID-19 in Barmer (Rajasthan) is false. Also, the photos in the post are old.
Label: False

Claim: Recent photo of PM Modi visiting a church and offering prayers to save the country from the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: It is an old photo. The photo was taken when Modi visited Sri Lanka in June 2019. He paid homage to those killed in the serial bombings at St Anthony's Shrine (Colombo, Sri Lanka).
Label: False

Claim: Photo of a vaccine developed by U.S. scientists for COVID-19.
Explaination: The photo shows a COVID-19 diagnostic test kit developed by Sugentech, a South Korean based company. It is not a vaccine. As on 23 March 2020, there is no vaccine for COVID-19. Also, Trump announced FDA’s approval of a coronavirus ‘test’, not a vaccine, developed by a company ‘Roche’ to increase and accelerate the country’s capacity to test for the virus.
Label: False

Claim: The video shows Muslims licking plates and spoons to spread the coronavirus.
Explaination: The video has been on the internet at least since July 2018. It was there even before the registration of first coronavirus case in the world.
Label: False

Claim: Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte broke down amid COVID-19 deaths in his country.
Explaination: The image in question is old. The man in the image is not Italy’s Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte but shows Brazil’s President Jair Bolsonaro who was overwhelmed while speaking about an attack on him
Label: False

Claim: The WHO reported that coronavirus lasts up to 8 hours on cabbages; thus, cabbage consumption should be restricted.
Explaination: WHO did not publish any such report.
Label: False

Claim: Recent photo of PM Modi visiting a church and offering prayers to save the country from the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: It is an old photo. The photo was taken when Modi visited Sri Lanka in June 2019. He paid homage to those killed in the serial bombings at St Anthony's Shrine (Colombo, Sri Lanka).
Label: False

Claim: Spraying with boiling water eliminates the new coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence that proves that boiling water eliminates the new coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: PM Modi announced internet suspension due to viral fake news related to COVID-19.
Explaination: The news bulletin image is digitally edited. No announcement of Internet ban was announced by PM Modi.
Label: False

Claim: The COVID-19 test kits from a Korean company are deemed suspicious by U.S. Congress.
Explaination: Not true. Some Korean media reported this because of a translation error.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Person who fainted at a subway station has COVID-19.
Explaination: It was not. It was another disease.
Label: False

Claim: A quarantined person fled from a facility in Daegu South Korea.
Explaination: The photos are manipulated.
Label: False

Claim: People of Italy throwing money on the streets as they felt that the money couldn’t save them from COVID-19.
Explaination: The photos are not related to the recent COVID-19 outbreak. They were taken in Venezuela, not in Italy. Some people threw the notes as they became valueless due to hyperinflation in the country.
Label: False

Claim: The flight which was chartered for Korean people by the Korean government only served Chinese people?
Explaination: It turned out to be a chartered flight for Chinese people by a Chinese travel agency.
Label: False

Claim: Video of Muslims gathered on roads despite the curfew to curb the spread of coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is from Ahmedabad (Gujarat) and was taken in December 2019. So, the video is of an incident that took place prior to the announcement of lockdown in Gujarat.
Label: False

Claim: Video of Muslims applying their saliva to plates and spoons to spread the coronavirus disease.
Explaination: The first coronavirus case in the world was registered in December 2019. But the video is found to exist on social media at least since July 2018.
Label: False

Claim: Video of a person infected with coronavirus committing suicide in New York.
Explaination: The video was taken in 2015. It shows a pregnant woman jumping off a building top after finding that her husband was having an affair with her mother.
Label: False

Claim: Ministry of Economy and Finance in South Korea and pharmaceutical companies had a secret meeting.
Explaination: There was no meeting.
Label: False

Claim: The Japanese Government gives out 40 masks to every household, free of charge.
Explaination: It didn't happen.
Label: False

Claim: Vitamin C can cure COVID-19.
Explaination: Not based on medical evidence.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The executive order to restrict worship in South Korea for prevention of epidemics is religious oppression.
Explaination: It is possible to forbid by Korean infectious disease prevention law.
Label: False

Claim: India TV telecasted news that Bollywood Actor Shahrukh Khan donated 450 million (45 Crore) Rupees to Pakistan Oil tanker blast victims.
Explaination: The video is a clipped version of India TV’s fact-check video. In the original fact-check video, India TV has debunked the same claim and concluded that Shahrukh has not made any donation to Pakistan Oil tanker blast victims.
Label: False

Claim: Photo of Kanika Kapoor meeting Prince Charles during her recent visit to the United Kingdom. Prince Charles tested positive for coronavirus just after the meeting.
Explaination: The photo was taken in 2015 when singer Kanika Kapoor attended the Elephant family charity, 'Travels to my Elephant', hosted by Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall.
Label: False

Claim: There is no way to forbid religious gatherings temporarily in South Korea to prevent the virus from spreading.
Explaination: They can be forbidden by the Korean infectious disease prevention law.
Label: False

Claim: A claim has circulated on social media that a “new virus” named hantavirus has emerged in China in March 2020. The posts were viewed hundreds of thousands of times as the world battled the spread of the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is false; scientists say hantavirus is not a new virus and was first detected during the Korean War in the 1950s; the US-based Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says the virus has almost exclusively been found to pass from rodents to humans, rather than from person to person.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus can be spread through fruits and vegetables.
Explaination: There is currently no evidence that food is a source or route of transmission of the coronavirus.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: Turning a severe person with coronavirus upside down can help them survive.
Explaination: Turning coronavirus sufferers upside down is being done in hospitals, and there are studies supporting its efficacy, but more scientific evidence is lacking.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: A photo of a group of people holding a banner that bears the Chinese and Malaysian flags has been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows Chinese doctors arriving in Malaysia to combat the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; the photo actually shows medical supplies donated by China that were delivered to a hospital in Malaysia.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A message warning of home thefts in Spain during quarantine by delivering subpoenas.
Explaination: There is no alert of this type of theft in the National Police of Spain and it is a hoax that has been recycling since 2011.
Label: False

Claim: A post that said coronavirus “was released by the Chinese Communist Party” and is a mixture of HIV and tuberculosis.
Explaination: There is no evidence that the coronavirus was created in a laboratory and it is proven that its incubation period is 14 days and not 27, as the text states.
Label: False

Claim: The health insurance fee in South Korea will increase because of the treatment cost for Chinese patients.
Explaination: The cost of treatment for foreigner will be paid from state budget, not insurance companies.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A tweet that stated that the former mayor of Madrid, Manuela Carmena, received a respirator at her home when she was ill with COVID-19.
Explaination: The former mayor of Madrid, Manuela Carmena, and the company accused of tweeting of delivering a respirator to her home denied that this was the case. She is neither ill nor received a respirator.
Label: False

Claim: A post has been shared multiple times on Facebook in March 2020 that claims China and Japan are “free” of the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is false; data from the World Health Organization (WHO) shows new cases continue to be reported in both countries.
Label: False

Claim: Novel coronavirus came to South Korea through a yellow sandstorm.
Explaination: The virus dies after staying in the air for some time.
Label: False

Claim: People in Italy are throwing money on the road because they are saddened by the fact that all the money in the world could not save their dear ones.
Explaination: Our investigation revealed that the photos are from Venezuela. Last year, bank robbers had thrown the old banknotes on the road to make the point that the currency of the country was worthless. It has nothing to do with coronavirus
Label: False

Claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook which claim it shows bodies of novel coronavirus victims being thrown into a ditch in Italy.
Explaination: The claim is false; the footage was taken from the 2007 US television programme Pandemic.
Label: False

Claim: South Korean presidential Blue House forbids the term “Wuhan pneumonia.”
Explaination: It was based on guidance of calling infectious disease from WHO.
Label: False

Claim: People from Wuhan can share a laundry room although they are in quarantine.
Explaination: People in Wuhan should clean their clothes in their room, by themselves.
Label: False

Claim: A claim that a trolley collector at a supermarket in the Australian state of New South Wales tested positive for the novel coronavirus in March 2020 has been shared hundreds of times in multiple posts on Facebook.
Explaination: The claim is false; the shopping centre where the supermarket is located said that it had no confirmed COVID-19 cases in March 2020; local health officials in New South Wales also did not report any confirmed cases in the suburb cited in the misleading Facebook posts in the final days of March.
Label: False

Claim: Over 500 years of Adhan (The Islamic Call to Prayer) ban lifted in Spain amid coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false. There was no ban in Spain on Adhan (The Islamic Call to Prayer) for over 500 years.
Label: False

Claim: Indian State of Kerala’s government is paying news channels to telecast CM’s interview.
Explaination: All these claims are raised by using some screenshots of sponsored posts in Asianet News fb page & some pics of CM's press meet which is broadcasted in different tv channels with a sponsored tag. But the fact is the sponsored program is not CM's press meet. That's a program called 'Naam Munnottu' to give awareness about the government's different projects and also to interact with the CM. The last episode was about Kerala's hard work to eradicate corona & for that they used a one minute portion from CM's press meet video. That pics was used in the fb post claiming gov giving money to channels to re telecast the press meet.
Label: False

Claim: Actor Vijay donated 3 billion (300 crore) rupees for coronavirus relief.
Explaination: It is fake news claimed using a fake news card of Dinamalar news channel. The channel has denied broadcasting such news.
Label: False

Claim: Shopping malls crowded in Italy during the pandemic.
Explaination: Old video from Brazil shared with false context
Label: False

Claim: An image of a doctor goes viral with the claim that Dr. Usman Riyaz died while treating coronavirus patients in Delhi, India.
Explaination: he photo that has been gone viral is of Dr. Riyaz Usman from Dubai. He is alive and healthy. He does not work in Delhi. He has put out a Facebook post rubbishing the rumors of his death. We also found that one Dr. Osman Riyaz has died in Pakistan due to COVID-19. We also confirmed with Delhi Health Department that no doctor has been died due to coronavirus in Delhi.
Label: False

Claim: Cuba sent 200.000 doctors across the world to help nations fighting against the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explaination: According to WHO and Cuban State Media, nearly 400,000 Cuban healthcare professionals working in 164 countries, out of them are only 50,000 doctors. Cuban government made this achievement in the past 50 years, not in a single year.
Label: False

Claim: Images of money thrown on streets by helpless Italians.
Explaination: Old image from Venezuela shared with false context.
Label: False

Claim: Russia released 500 lions to ensure people would stay inside houses.
Explaination: This photo was is from 2016, South Africa, part of a movie production.
Label: False

Claim: Government of an Indian state Madhya Pradesh ordered shoot-at-sight to enforce lockdown.
Explaination: Our research revealed that a screenshot of a news channel report is circulating without context. MP government has not given any such order. MP government and Jabalpur police clarified it on Twitter.
Label: False

Claim: High death rate in Italy is due to people taking Ibuprofen.
Explaination: Both universities cited as the source termed it fake news, while the WHO has said there isn't enough evidence against using ibuprofen in the treatment of COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: João Doria, governor of São Paulo, forbade doctors to give chloroquine to COVID-19 patients.
Explaination: Authorization for medication use in Brazil is not under state jurisdiction, but federal jurisdiction. Doctors are allowed to prescribe chloroquine for patients with severe cases of COVID-19 in Brazil since March 27. It is not different in São Paulo.
Label: False

Claim: An inmate who was released from prison under COVID-19 “humanitarian house arrests” was arrested again in Campo Bom. Police officers found more than 100 kg of cocaine in his house, and several guns.
Explaination: Campo Bom police officers did arrest a former inmate with 100 kg of cocaine in his house. His prior release had nothing to do with COVID-19. Actually, he had finished serving his term.
Label: False

Claim: Italians throwing money on streets amid COVID-19 crisis.
Explaination: This is an incident when a bank was looted in Venezuelan city of Mérida and old money notes had been scattered on the streets.
Label: False

Claim: Myanmar president and state counselor are under 14 days quarantine after meeting with a COVID-19 patient from Switzerland.
Explaination: State counselor addressed about the COVID-19 updates few hours the post is published. President office spokesperson U Zaw Htay has also confirmed to media that both president and state counselor is not in quarantine.
Label: False

Claim: Last picture of Indonesian Dr. Hadio Alo bidding farewell to his family.
Explaination: This image was uploaded in Malaysia and this is not related to Indonesia.
Label: False

Claim: Former MP Bimal Rathnayake made a comment stating that deceased Muslims from COVID-19 should be buried as per their customs and not cremated.
Explaination: Manipulated image to give the impression that MP Bimal Rathnayaka made a comment stating that deceased Muslims from COVID-19 should be buried as per their customs and not cremated.
Label: False

Claim: A table comparing COVID-19 stats for countries that did impose lockdown against countries that didn’t.
Explaination: Although the numbers are accurate, some of the countries marked as "not on lockdown" are actually on lockdown. Also, the comparison ignores all other factors, including initial response and current stage.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Students in America have to repeat the same grade next year.
Explaination: Stories about students having to repeat their grade originated on hoax sites.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Video shows Italy turning to Islam after giving up by the Italian authorities
Explaination: The video is from Hamburg protest in Germany in solidarity with Uyghurs, which was held 18 january 2020.
Label: False

Claim: President Donald Trump will announce that a scientist “finally found a vaccine to cure coronavirus.”
Explaination: Trump has not announced a vaccine to prevent COVID-19. As of now, there is no specific treatment for the coronavirus.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Two men identified as “the owner of Carrefour” supermarkets in Brazil in videos where they criticized lockdown measures.
Explaination: The largest shareholder of Carrefour holds less than 10% of the shares, so the company does not have a single owner. The men in the videos have no relationship whatsoever with the company.
Label: False

Claim: China gets meat from the dead bodies of coronavirus victims and transports it to Africa.
Explaination: The photos used in the claim came from different sources: 1. some from a store in london was selling for Resident Evil game 2. most images are sculptures made from bread  3. some photos are from burying ritual in China.
Label: False

Claim: There are two ways to wear a medical mask, depending on your purpose. If you are sick, put the white side on your mouth, and if you fear infection, wear it the opposite way.
Explaination: There is only one correct way to wear the medical masks: colored side on the outside.
Label: False

Claim: The COVID-19 epidemic is almost finished in the Netherlands. The government did not close a single shop. Tweeted initially by a former Bolsonaro minister, Osmar Terra, on 3/31/20.
Explaination: The COVID-19 epidemic is not anywhere near the end in the Netherlands, and the government did impose lockdown measures, although lighter than in neighbouring countries.
Label: False

Claim: As of 4/1/20, all coronavirus patients from Blumenau, Brazil, were cured.
Explaination: As of April 1st, there were 33 people still sick with COVID-19 in Blumenau.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 can be removed with a blow dryer on the nose or with a pot of boiling water.
Explaination: Home remedies to remove COVID-19 with a hair dryer or a pot with boiling water are false, dangerous and without any scientific basis.
Label: False

Claim: A video of a man, standing at a fresh food distribution center in Contagem, Brazil, claiming there was a shortage of food in Minas Gerais caused by lockdown measures. He claims the video was shot on March 31. The video was tweeted by Jair Bolsonaro, who later deleted it.
Explaination: The video was staged. It was shot while the place was being cleaned, so all the food stalls were taken away.
Label: False

Claim: A PSOL (Brazilian left-wing opposition party) state representative was arrested, heavily intoxicated, while attending a party during the COVID-19 lockdown in Niterói, Rio de Janeiro.
Explaination: The story itself is true, but the man is a member of PSL, Bolsonaro party until late 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Ronaldo Caiado, governor of the Brazilian state Goiás, was beaten up due to his lockdown decrees. A gallery of photos proves it.
Explaination: Pictures that support the claim were taken in 2013, and the man being kicked is just a lookalike.
Label: False

Claim: According to the Mexican Health secretary, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador has COVID-19.
Explaination: The health secretary did not confirm that the president has COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Water vapor inactivates COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no evidence supporting hot water as a preventive measure.
Label: False

Claim: Video of a waitress saying, “I lost my job. But I’ll sleep better knowing” that the coronavirus relief bill included funding for the Kennedy Center, refugee resettlement, PBS, and congressional salaries: “Thanks, Democrats.”
Explaination: The post accurately cites several provisions that are in the coronavirus relief bill passed in late March. But it’s misleading to suggest the financial needs of a laid-off waitress aren't addressed in the bill.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: World Health Organization condemned lockdown measures against COVID-19.
Explaination: WHO did not condemn lockdown. During an interview, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus acknowledge lockdown measures have serious economic impact, especially on the poor, but he did not say countries with epidemic focuses should abandon it.
Label: False

Claim: Brazilian Ministry of Health hinted that relatives of COVID-19 victims should doubt the death certificates.
Explaination: The recommendation, which circulates on social media as if it were official, was denied by the brazilian Ministry of Health's advisory and does not appear in the guidelines of the Brazilian government on the management of bodies in the context of the new coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Before reaching the lungs, the coronavirus remains in the throat for three or four days and at this time the person begins to cough and have a sore throat. If you drink a lot of water and gargle with warm water and salt or vinegar, you can remove the virus.
Explaination: The WHO does not include among its recommendations drinking or gargling with any liquid as a prevention method. Also, that can damage the throat.
Label: False

Claim: Lukewarm water with lemon or water with lemon and bicarbonate are preventive measures for COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence that hot water or vitamin C prevents COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows an empty Brazilian market and the cause of the shortage is the social isolation measures.
Explaination: The video, which have already been deleted by the Brazilian president, shows an unidentified man in front of the empty market complaining about the effects of the quarantine. The market (named Ceasa), however, is functioning normally, according to a note published on its website. According to the regional Association of Merchants, the misleading video was recorded on March 31 at a time when Ceasa was closed for cleaning.
Label: False

Claim: Water in Venice begins to become more crystalline, thanks to the ban in Italy by COVID-19.
Explaination: The event happened in Cagliari, Sardinia, 874 kilometers from Venice
Label: False

Claim: North Carolina “hospital beds are typically 85% full across the state.”
Explaination: Records show that NC hospitals are, on average throughout the year, between 60-to-75% full. However, medical professionals say Jackson is right that hospitals operate at maximum capacity during certain parts of the year, such as flu season.
Label: Half True

Claim: Should you take Ibuprofen to treat a fever from the coronavirus?
Explaination: World Health Organization does not recommend against the use of ibuprofen based on lack of medical reports showing any negative effects, and there is no published clinical or population-based data on this topic.
Label: Misleading

Claim: “We’ve got to give the American public a rough estimate of how long we think this is going to take, based mostly on the South Korean model, which seems to be the trajectory that we are on, thankfully, and not the Italian model.”
Explaination: The U.S. and South Korea have similar case fatality rates – Italy’s is higher – but all three countries have age-specific mortality rates that are about the same. Public health experts say the fatality rate wouldn't be the only or the most important metric used to determine when businesses may reopen.The growth in cases and hospitals’ capacity to treat new patients is the most important factor.
Label: Half True

Claim: The video of unprecedented stone rain in Rome suggests the fate of pro-Communist Italy.
Explaination: The video shows hail filmed in Zalau, Romania, on May 28. 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte said, “We have lost control, we have killed the epidemic physically and mentally. Can’t understand what more we can do, all solutions are exhausted on ground. Our only hope remains up in the sky. God, rescue your people.”
Explaination: The quote attributed to Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte is fabricated. The image accompanying the post shows the president of Brazil, not the Italian prime minister.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Video shows that the Italian government/Brisbane police used zombie robots/drones to chase their citizen and make them stay home.
Explaination: The video was a prank scene filmed in 2016 in Brazil.
Label: False

Claim: Kids are not allowed to say goodbye to their parents before being hospitalized for COVID-19.
Explaination: Kids are allowed to say goodbye to their families. If they die, 5 to 10 people are allowed at the funeral.
Label: False

Claim: The photo of a pornography actor is used to represent a health professional.
Explaination: Several publications on Facebook and Twitter, some with up to 24 thousand interactions, present Ángel Muñoz, popularly known as "Jordi el Niño Polla", as part of various teams to deal with the pandemic due to the new coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking alcohol beverages can help prevent COVID-19.
Explaination: Photo being spread online is of is a fake hospital news release saying alcoholic beverages would help reduce risk of getting coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Guatemala ombudsman wants citizens to pay for their COVID-19 tests.
Explaination: He said he wants the Government to allow testing also at private labs -currently only allowed at the National Public Lab- but he says as well that the Government should provide free test for the citizens.
Label: False

Claim: Ron Johnson said Americans should go back to work, because “death is an unavoidable part of life.”
Explaination: A summary of Johnson’s USA TODAY guest column implied he was calling for a widespread return to work. That’s an exaggeration, since Johnson supports continued social distancing and some business closures. But Johnson did refer to death being inevitable while noting the impacts a prolonged shutdown could have on employment and mental health.
Label: Half True

Claim: A boy is called COVID-19 in Monterrey, Mexico.
Explaination: Until March 18 we do not have records of people bearing that name in Monterrey, México.
Label: False

Claim: We’re in a battle against a virus that is in the air.
Explaination: The congressman said it in the context of the study on the stability of SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV-1 in aerosols and on various surfaces. But it was referred to the experimental circumstances tested and not in open spaces.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The number of new cases of COVID-19 is decreasing in Peru since the 3/19/20.
Explaination: Mrs. León used wrong figures according to official information and explanations by specialists of the Ministry of Health.
Label: False

Claim: People will not be allowed to organize a funeral for any family members who die of COVID-19. Instead, the state will take care of the disposal of the body.
Explaination: The rules around funerals have changed as gatherings are currently not allowed, but families are still allowed to look after funeral services for their loved ones without the involvement of the State.
Label: False

Claim: The WHO’s general director stepped back and said that social isolation should not be a measure in the fight against coronavirus.
Explaination: In the speech highlighted by the posts, the executive warns, in fact, that governments should consider the social and economic impacts of confinement on the poorest population, but does not advocate the end or relaxation of these measures. The statement was made by Ghebreyesus in a press conference in March 30 and, since then, it has been used by profiles aligned to "bolsonarism" as evidence of a supposed retreat from WHO towards a position close to Jair Bolsonaro opinion against social isolation.
Label: False

Claim: Vitamin C kills viruses.
Explaination: There is no evidence that vitamin C can kill viruses or helps against COVID-19.
Label: No evidence

Claim: Doctors and nurses in Italy are dying and are lying dead on the ground due to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The image does not depict dead doctors and nurses in Italy. It is a part of a demonstration by youngsters to spread awareness about coronavirus in Bogota.
Label: False

Claim: Five helicopters are spraying disinfectants over German cities.
Explaination: There are no helicopters spraying disinfectants over Germany and also no plans to do so.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus is a bioweapon by the USA, says German politician Wolfgang Gedeon in a Parliament speech.
Explaination: International scientists, the WHO and German Robert Koch Institute see strong evidence that the coronavirus is of natural origin and its outbreak related to bats.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: You have to take off your clothes and shoes outside and wash them with disinfectants. The virus sticks to the floor for nine hours and also spreads via the wind.
Explaination: The claims lack context or are unproven. It is sufficient to wash your clothes normally. There are no studies regarding the lifespan of the virus on the floor.
Label: No evidence

Claim: The army is patrolling all the streets, towns and villages in Ireland.
Explaination: New and unprecedented measures have been introduced to help curb the spread of the coronavirus, but the post false describes that those rules actually are. Police are patrolling parts of the country, but not all of it, and there are no plans at present for the army to patrol the streets.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: If you can hold your breath for more than 10 seconds, you are not infected by coronavirus.
Explaination: By holding your breath for 10 seconds, you cannot confirm whether you are infected with coronavirus or not.
Label: False

Claim: Leaving half an onion in your home will “catch” the coronavirus and prevent people from getting it.
Explaination: Onions are not a way to prevent the coronavirus from entering your home. The claim that onions can help prevent illness has been around since the 1930s.
Label: False

Claim: The Irish Prime Minister/Taoiseach Leo Varadkar has urged people not to use the Houseparty video messaging app due to security concerns.
Explaination: Prime Minister Leo Varadkar never said this. The tweet was doctored and is false. He did not say anything publicly about using Houseparty.
Label: False

Claim: In Hong Kong, people destroyed a 5G pole because of coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is from September 2019, it shows protesters tearing down a smart lamp because they fear surveillance.
Label: False

Claim: In India starting 3/24/20, all grocery, chemists and vegetable shops will be open from 9.00 am to 11.30 am and 4.30 pm to 7.00 pm. Anybody found moving around after this or opening any kind of outlet will be detained by the police. No home deliveries will be available.
Explaination: Delhi Police has clarified that the viral message on social media is Fake.
Label: False

Claim: By clicking on an italian YouTube song, you donate money to a hospital in Bergamo.
Explaination: Direct clicks are not giving out money, but the singer of the song on he video said he would donate proceeds.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Russian government has unleashed lions on the streets to impose a public curfew.
Explaination: The viral bulletin is digitally edited and the lion in the image was a part of a movie shoot from South Africa.
Label: False

Claim: American scientists have developed a cure for the coronavirus.
Explaination: The viral image on social media is not a vaccine for coronavirus but it is a COVID-19 test kit recently developed by South Korea.
Label: False

Claim: A video is going viral on WhatsApp and Sharechat claiming that the man and woman in the video are doctors who treated 75 coronavirus patients and now they both are infected by it.
Explaination: The claim associated with the video is false and misleading. They are not Italian doctors who treated 75 coronavirus patients and got infected but are actors from a Mexican television series called ‘Triunfo del Amor’.
Label: False

Claim: While everybody is busy with coronavirus, authorities in Görlitz, Germany, secretly brought asylum seekers into the city.
Explaination: It was not a secret mission but the normal transfer of 23 asylum seekers from an initial reception site. This happens regularly.
Label: Mainly false

Claim: Post claiming that Myanmar found COVID-19 treatment medicine called “chlorofos,” a medicine to treat malaria. The post also claims “chlorofos” is one of the WHO’s selected medicines to treat COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no evidence or recommendation from WHO for possible COVID-19 treatment using “chlorofos” but we found that “chloroquine” is used as a potential medicine in some countries. WHO has reiterated that there is no single medicine effective for curing COVID-19 as yet.
Label: False

Claim: In China there is now also an outbreak of the hantavirus, with a first recorded death.
Explaination: There is no "outbreak“, the hantavirus is an endemic disease in China with about 100 deaths every year. It is usually not transmitted from human to human.
Label: False

Claim: People in Italy have thrown all of their money on the roads outside saying that this money is useless to save them from death.
Explaination: The images doing rounds on social media are not from Italy but from Venezuela when the country was facing economic collapse in 2018.
Label: False

Claim: Supermarkets in Germany will only open two days a week. A screenshot shows a report from the media outlet Focus.
Explaination: Supermarkets are open like usual. The screenshot is doctored; Focus did not report this.
Label: False

Claim: Neem leaves can cure COVID-19.
Explaination: WHO has iterated that while some traditional medicines, western medicines, and home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence of a single medicine that treats COVID-19 currently.
Label: False

Claim: Sri Lanka’s KDU hospital will be dedicated to treat only VIP COVID-19 patients.
Explaination: Hospital director, Chief Epidemiologist and Defence Secretary all refuted the claim and said the hospital is ready to admit any patient.
Label: False

Claim: Turkey helped Italy with 200.000 masks and other equipment but nobody took notice.
Explaination: Important context is missing. It was not a humanitarian aid delivery. Italy bought 200.000 masks from a company in Turkey and they were blocked at the customs for more than two weeks before Turkey decided to let them be exported.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Hindu God Ganesha’s idol placed and worshiped inside an Italian Church.
Explaination: It is an old video of celebration of a Hindu Festival called Ganeshotsav in a Spanish church which is shared with misleading context.
Label: False

Claim: Post claiming that a nationwide committee to prevent, control and treat COVID-19 led by Myanmar state counselor was dissolved.
Explaination: The committee dissolved by the announcement made on 31st March from the president office is the central committee for prevention and treatment of COVID-19 led by a union minister, not the committee led by Myanmar state counselors.
Label: False

Claim: Indian police personnel beaten by a person while enforcing lockdown. Claim made through an image.
Explaination: The image is old and shared out of context to make a false claim.
Label: False

Claim: No deaths have been reported in Israel due to COVID-19 because they have found a cure for the disease. A solution of hot water, baking soda and lemon is the cure for COVID-19.
Explaination: There have been 15 deaths in Israel due to COVID-19 plus the solution of lemon, hot water and bicarbonate is not proven to cure COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Muslims intentionally licking the cutlery and plates to spread COVID-19.
Explaination: People shown in the video are of Dawoodi Bohra religion and people of these community do not waste food. That is why after eating, he lick all the utensils such as plate, spoon and bowl to ensure no food wastage and then wash the vessels.
Label: False

Claim: The ex-Health Minister Nikola Todorov, a lawyer by profession, is a consultant of the current Minister of Health for expert advice and expertise in the field of epidemiology.
Explaination: Denial about this information came from the Minister of Health himself, who explained that the expert epidemiologist and former VMRO-DPMNE minister is actually a doctor, Dragan Danilovski.
Label: False

Claim: A Chinese study is the definitive proof that chloroquine works.
Explaination: A widely shared video on social media claims that Chinese studies prove that chloroquine cures almost all of COVID-19 patients. Even though there have been some encouraging initial results, the researchers are in fact very cautious.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The maps shows the cases by provinces in Turkey.
Explaination: The data does not show the local cases but calculated on proportionality to population in every provinces. Turkish authorities do not announce the local figures yet.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows Muslim prayers in the White House, in Washington DC, due to the outbreak.
Explaination: The video goes back to 2017, inauguration ceremony of Mr. Trump.
Label: False

Claim: The text claims that mass media owners, called “Satanists” in the text, are forcing the public to voluntarily look for a coronavirus vaccine. It also describes the vaccine (which still does not exist) as: “A vaccine in which the beast’s mark is present in liquid form with nano-technology, and he will completely control the world and all people.”
Explaination: Regardless of their religious feelings, believers, and everyone else, should remain rational, sober, and informed for their own good only from relevant sources. Postings on social networks, if not from officials, no matter where they come from, should be taken with great care and checked before they can be trusted.
Label: False

Claim: A group of Muslim boys licking utensils to spread coronavirus.
Explaination: The people seen in the video are Dawoodi Bohras, who are licking the utensils in an attempt to follow their belief of zero wastage of food.
Label: False

Claim: A video has been viewed in multiple Facebook posts and claims to show a man wiping his sweat on the buttons of a lift in a residential block in Hong Kong.
Explaination: The claim is false; the footage has circulated in media reports about an incident in Thailand.
Label: False

Claim: Doctored image of President Donald Trump shared claiming he asked people to chant Hare Krishna Hare Rama.
Explaination: The claim is fake and the image is doctored.
Label: False

Claim: Indian Actor Kamal Hassan put under quarantine.
Explaination: Kamal Hassan and his party has issued an official statement saying there was a misunderstanding between officials as his daughter has self-isolated herself. It was presumed that Hassan had met his daughter in Mumbai. However, he did not meet his daughter and later the officials were also convinced about it and they removed quarantine poster from his wall.
Label: False

Claim: Italians bidding goodbye to the world because of coronavirus.
Explaination: The video dates back to November 2019 and has nothing to do with the coronavirus pandemic. It is actually from an anti-fascist protest held in Italy.
Label: False

Claim: Restrictions to transit by your ID-number due to coronavirus.
Explaination: Even there are some restrictions and schedules to transit and buy, there are not by ID-numbers in Venezuela. Text in Whatsapp mixes measures from Colombia, Bolivia and Ecuador.
Label: False

Claim: During the pandemic, Macedonian citizens will have no bread.
Explaination: The information was sharply denied by the Minister of Economy Kreshnik Bekteshi, who assured there is enough flour and wheat and imports from Serbia, Bulgaria and Hungary are also allowed.
Label: False

Claim: A photo has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows the bodies of people who died in Italy after they became infected with the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is false; the photo actually shows people participating in a 2014 art project in the German city of Frankfurt.
Label: False

Claim: After 23:30, the city will be disinfected by a helicopter and the doors and windows should be closed.
Explaination: This has not been announced by authorities. This hoax has spread in many other countries.
Label: False

Claim: If people get infected with COVID-19, they may not be able to fully recover.
Explaination: It is quite understandable that people with chronic illnesses and the elderly are at greater risk of this virus and this is repeatedly stated by the relevant institutions so that they can be more careful. But whether they will have, if they heal, lasting consequences, have not been confirmed, at least not by a single relevant global health institution.
Label: False

Claim: Multiple news reports circulating in Nigeria claim that Buckingham Palace has announced Britain’s Queen Elizabeth tested positive for COVID-19.
Explaination: Although the Queen’s eldest son was diagnosed with the disease, the Palace said the monarch herself is “in good health”.
Label: False

Claim: Video of a carrier who is allegedly moving medical supplies from Spain to France.
Explaination: In a video, a trucker shows a warehouse with boxes and ensures that they have medical supplies, such as gloves, masks, and that they will be transported to France. The boxes that the transporter shows inside a truck show brand of paper sheets, Fabriano. Not sanitary material.
Label: False

Claim: A sensationalist headline claiming that there is a new virus in China, the hantavirus.
Explaination: Passengers have been isolated and tested because of the suspicion that the coronavirus may be the cause of the deteriorating health of the passenger, not because of the danger of transmitting the hantavirus. The hantavirus first appeared in 1950, not nowadays.
Label: Misleading

Claim: There is a connection between the COVID-19 outbreak and 5G technology.
Explaination: There is no proven connection between the viral infections and radio waves.
Label: False

Claim: “Italians remove EU flag and put the flag of the PR of China,” the headline says, suggesting that such a phenomenon is happening in Italy … people are removing the flag of the European Union and are replacing it with the Chinese flag.
Explaination: Those were individual cases in which citizens or companies, in a revolt from the EU's attitude towards their country in the most difficult moments of the epidemiological crisis, have taken the EU flag off. But this is not a general trend.
Label: False

Claim: Iceland is testing its entire population.
Explaination: In Iceland, 3,5% of the population has been tested so far, according to the government. Iceland is doing a massive testing, with an average of 582 tests every day since mid-March. But even at this rate, it would take more than a year and a half to test all of the residents.
Label: False

Claim: Boil weed and ginger for COVID-19 victims, and the virus will vanish.
Explaination: There is no evidence supporting the claim that marijuana and ginger can cure COVID-19. To date, there is no specific treatment available for COVID-19, although clinical trials evaluating certain existing drugs are underway.
Label: False

Claim: Usefulness of homemade chlorine wipes.
Explaination: Chlorine or bleach is a disinfectant substance that can be used on surfaces but can damage the skin.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: COVID-19 was invented and patented years ago by the Institut Pasteur, a French medical research center
Explaination: The patent, filed in 2004, relates to vaccinal research on SARS-CoV-1, responsible for the SARS epidemic in 2002 and 2003, and not the SARS-CoV-2, that causes the current COVID-19 epidemic.
Label: False

Claim: A headline: “Latest News / Something Big is Happening in Europe.”
Explaination: This is blank text, no information, no facts, no source of information and nothing that can serve the reader. The purpose of this article is only to cause panic and to collect as many clicks as possible. The text is no longer available.
Label: False

Claim: A headline alleges that the first pregnant woman with coronavirus gave birth in Macedonia.
Explaination: The event did not happen in Macedonia, but in Serbia.
Label: False

Claim: Image of a 24-year-old doctor who died from the coronavirus.
Explaination: An image that says that doctor Francisco 'Paco' Pérez of the Hospital de La Paz in Madrid died at the age of 24 from the coronavirus accompanied by a photo of the porn actor Jordi 'el niño polla'.
Label: False

Claim: The following statement: “There are prisoners infected with the coronavirus; the state is hiding this fact.”
Explaination: This false information was denied by the Directorate for Execution of Sanctions and Minister of Health Venko Filipce, one day later.
Label: False

Claim: Army trucks are deployed in Paris and in other large French cities because of the coronavirus epidemic.
Explaination: Photos shared thousands of times on social media show military vehicles transported by truck on the highway near Paris. But the French Ministry of Armed Forces denies any link with the coronavirus epidemic and explains that it is a routine logistical operation.
Label: False

Claim: An email from Caixabank asking people to change data related to their account.
Explaination: An email allegedly sent by CaixaBank requesting account verification through a link in less than 24 hours to prevent unauthorized access. It is a case of phishing.
Label: False

Claim: A photo of the vice president of Spain in the hospital allegedly visiting his father sickened by the coronavirus.
Explaination: The vice president of Spain, Pablo Iglesias, did not visit his father at the Hospital Clinico Universitario de Salamanca, who is neither ill nor admitted. The photo is not current.
Label: False

Claim: Muslim azan was recited in Granada, Spain, for the first time after 500 years due to the outbreak.
Explaination: The video is from Azerbaijan and the voice belongs to Persian artist Mehdi Yarrahi. The video is manipulated.
Label: False

Claim: A message that claimed an electric company in Spain was offering 25% discount to its customers for the coronavirus.
Explaination: Iberdrola, an electrical company in Spain, carried out a 25% discount campaign to a sector of its customers. The campaign existed but not for all its clients.
Label: Partially false

Claim: People in Italy are threw away their money after they lost their family members to coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim along with the images is false. The images are old and are not related to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic in any way.
Label: False

Claim: 1 out of 3 people who died from coronavirus in Spain lived in a nursing home.
Explaination: The media outlet added data on deaths in nursing homes by autonomous communities in recent weeks, but mixes deaths with coronavirus with other deceased elderly people, it is unknown if they had the virus.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: Prof. Shenme Minzi from Zanjan University said lemon cure is helpful for COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no Zanjan University in China (it's in Iran), and no researcher named Shenme Minzi at all. Lemon contains vitamin C which is helpful to empower the immune system but does not cure the disease.
Label: False

Claim: The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act gives members of Congress a pay increase.
Explaination: No version of the coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act grant pay raises for members of Congress.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: The lockdown due to coronavirus has led to the reemergence of a large flock of birds at the riverfront in Ahmedabad.
Explaination: These birds are a regular site at the riverfront in Ahmedabad and the video has been shared with a false narrative.
Label: False

Claim: Old “Martinelli” and “Whatsapp Gold” hoaxes surface in Belgium in wake of Corona infodemic.
Explaination: Messages circulating on Whatsapp of people sharing "insider"-information (self-declared government officials) on the virus percolate quickly. A localized version of the Martinelli & Whatsapp Gold hoaxes surface in Belgium as well, adding further confusion and unrest.
Label: False

Claim: A satellite map by the Royal Dutch Meteorology Institute (KNMI) showed lowered nitrogen levels since the coronavirus crisis, which would supposedly indicate nitrogen levels in the Netherlands are unrelated to the Dutch agricultural sector.
Explaination: The satellite images only show nitrogen oxide levels (NOₓ) and leave out ammonia levels (NH₃), the compound which is responsible for the lion's share of nitrogen emission and is emitted predominantly by the agricultural sector.
Label: False

Claim: Two audio clips stating that the Mumbai police commissioner is going to enforce strict actions during the 21-day lockdown in India and that there will be a spike in cases after March 27, 2020.
Explaination: Mumbai Police officials denied that this audio was of the city police commissioner. The voices in both the videos were different.
Label: False

Claim: India has decided to extend its financial year to July 1 due to the current COVID-19 outbreak.
Explaination: The Income Tax department tweeted that the financial year has not been extended and that this gazette was for the collection of stamp duty on security market instruments through stock exchanges and clearing corporations.
Label: False

Claim: A claim on Facebook that began to circulate around Wednesday, 3/25/20, says putting a peeled onion in any room can remove “all viruses and bacteria including coronavirus.”
Explaination: Putting peeled onions in a room will not prevent COVID-19 or a coronavirus infection, according to the National Onion Association (NOA) in the US. There are no official cures or vaccines for COVID-19, according to the World Health Organization (WHO) as of Tuesday, March 31, though there are cures and vaccines in testing.
Label: False

Claim: WhatsApp group admins were detained for sharing coronavirus messages in Dadar, Mumbai.
Explaination: Mumbai Police spokesperson rubbished the claim that Mumbai police's cyber cell was registering cases against 52 WhatsApp group admins and called it fake.
Label: False

Claim: Health care workers union “suddenly finds a stash of 39 million face masks.”
Explaination: Health care workers’ union launched a nationwide search on March 21 for face masks and other protective gear that have been in short supply since the COVID-19 pandemic swept across the U.S. On March 26, the union announced that it had found a supplier with 39 million masks.
Label: False

Claim: In the Philippines, Senator Manny Pacquiao was the only senator who responded to the coronavirus crisis.
Explaination: Other senators, and not just Pacquiao, also responded to the outbreak by providing aid to frontliners and those affected by the enhanced community quarantine, among others.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows re-opened wet market in China .
Explaination: The video dates back to 2017 and recorded in Indonesia. Wet markets are currently closed down in Hubei.
Label: False

Claim: The brazilian Health Surveillance Agency approved chloroquine/hydroxychloroquine as a treatment for COVID-19.
Explaination: Unlike what publications on social networks suggest, the release of chloroquine for the treatment of COVID-19 did not occur unrestrictedly. Nor did the guarantee come from Anvisa (Brazil's National Health Surveillance Agency). In fact, an information note from the brazilian Ministry of Health published on March 27 authorized the use of the drug and indicated its dosage only for hospitalized patients in serious condition. In other words, the standard of the ministry does not allow the drug to be sold in pharmacies or prescribed by doctors for any treatment against the disease resulting from the new coronavirus.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Video clip of a massive stadium converted into a graveyard claimed to be scenes from Italy related to the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak.
Explaination: Scene from movie “Flu 2013” portrayed as scenes from Italy.
Label: False

Claim: Police in India lashed sticks at filmmaker Sudhir Mishra for not following the rules of lockdown.
Explaination: The viral video has been falsified based on the tweet made by Sudhir Mishra himself on the viral clip.
Label: False

Claim: Johns Hopkins University says coronavirus fatalities in Colombia are the third lowest in the world.
Explaination:
Neither Johns Hopkins University said that the fatality of COVID-19 in Colombia is the third lowest in the world nor the data that
ex congressman Alfredo Rangel gave in his tweet is correct.
Label: False

Claim: French professor Didier Raoult, big defender of chloroquine treatment, insulted ex-European MP Daniel Cohn-Bendit, after Cohn-Bendit criticized his scientific work.
Explaination: Professor Didier Raoult denied having insulted Cohn-Bendit on his real Twitter account.
Label: False

Claim: A drug for coronavirus has been found.
Explaination: Article is misleading. Research is still ongoing and it's too early to say that drug for coronavirus was found.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Polish government confiscated a coronavirus testing machine which was originally bought by a local hospital in Grodzisk Mazowiecki city.
Explaination: Article is misleading. Although hospital did indeed collect the money for buying the machine, it didn't buy it eventually as the machine was redirected to the city where it was much more needed. Polish government didn't take if forcefully or confiscated it as articles were suggesting.
Label: Partially false

Claim: French professor Didier Raoult, director of IHU Marseille, told Africans not to take “Bill Gates’ vaccine” against coronavirus because it is “poisonous.”
Explaination: The IHU Marseille has denied that its director made such comments, and there is currently no vaccine or approved treatment. If scientific research is underway, no vaccine should be released until at least next year.
Label: False

Claim: Marathi newspaper reports a conspiracy theory of coronavirus being a bioweapon.
Explaination: The conspiracy theory is actually picked up from a Reddit thread which hosts contests for fictional stories that are inspired from real events.
Label: False

Claim: The Indian Army has been called to control seven areas in Mumbai that are not following the 21 day lockdown and are out of the Mumbai police’s control.
Explaination: The Mumbai police has not called in the army and the seven areas are duly following the lockdown prescribed by the government.
Label: False

Claim: Interferon, that has been bought by the Venezuelan and Salvadoran governments, are proven effective in treating coronavirus.
Explaination: Before they even registered cases of people infected with COVID-19, the Venezuelan and Salvadoran governments went ahead and bought the antiviral called Interferon to "cure" possible future patients. But there is still little scientific evidence in regards to the efficacy of this medicine, and it cannot be used for all infected patients.
Label: False

Claim: Two malaria medications work to treat COVID-19.
Explaination: President Donald Trump announced that the FDA already has a treatment for COVID-19. In his announcement, he mentioned two drugs used to treat malaria as well as an antibiotic. However, a comprehensive review of available scientific evidence shows hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine have not yet shown sufficient efficacy for treating respiratory disease caused by the novel coronavirus. These medications are still in early-phase clinical trials for treating the disease.
Label: No evidence

Claim: The WHO admitted the coronavirus is transmitted because it is in the air for 8 hours.
Explaination: Using a real CNBC link claimed the opposite of what WHO discovered and found.
Label: False

Claim: You shouldn’t open your windows.
Explaination:
A study published in the New England Journal of Medicine warned that the novel coronavirus remains viable for up to: three hours floating in the air, four hours on copper coins, a whole day on cardboard surfaces and as long as two or three days on plastic surfaces or stainless steel faucets. This scientific data went viral on social media as an oversimplified, false message: “The virus no longer spreads simply by being in contact with infected people or in places where the infected have been. The virus is now in the air. We have entered a new phase, ” reads an audio message sent around on Whatsapp. 

However, research by the United States National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases published in the New England Journal of Medicine mentions no such new phase. To date, the World Health Organization (WHO) reports that the viability of the novel coronavirus in the air does not imply that the contagion is like measles, which can live up to two hours in the air where an infected person has coughed or sneezed.
Label: False

Claim: Voice message of a so-called ombudsman that says that internet may collapse in Argentina.
Explaination: The official ombudsman denied that the message came from his office and the national institute of communication advised for a rational use of internet but did not recommend to stop sending videos via Whatsapp.
Label: False

Claim: Venezuelan YouTuber Ruby Demestoy talked about Event 201, Bill Gates and VIH and SARS conspiracies.
Explaination: Well-known conspiracies and many other lack of precise scientific information.
Label: False

Claim: Italian priest died, refusing to use respirator as he sacrificed it to a younger person.
Explaination: He didn't sacrifice the respirator. He didn't use it due to medical preconditions.
Label: Partially false

Claim: The new coronavirus COVID-19 is a US biological weapon against China and Italy ; Milorad Dodik, the Serb member of the BiH presidency, is infected with COVID-19.
Country: North Macedonia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina
Explaination: Considering the impact of novel coronavirus on the US people, such a claim doesn't make any sense. It's also completely unfounded. Radovan Kovačević debunked the false news about Milorad Dodik being infected with COVID-19.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A post with photos claiming that COVID-19 infected patients in Italy are left in the street.
Explaination: The photos were from a hospital in Croatia after the earthquake struck the capital of Zagreb on March 22.
Label: False

Claim: About 1,000 people wait to enter the Military Medical Academy (VMA) in Belgrade for examinations.
Explaination: People came for routine check-ups and only their temperature was measured. Many people were only accompanying those who went for a check-up and were not allowed to enter thus causing queues outside.
Label: False

Claim: A statement says: “Serbs have ‘lion’s genes’ that protect them from coronavirus, unlike Italians who have ‘weaker genes'” by pulmonologist Branimir Nestorovic.
Country: North Macedonia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina
Explaination: Nestorovic claims that he did not say such a thing, nor did he think Serbs had superior genes, but only different ones, and that such a "statement" was filled by the tabloid.
Label: False

Claim: Myanmar’s former military junta donated Ks 1000 Lakhs to COVID-19 fund.
Explaination: The list of donors in The Mirror daily circulated on March 26 shows no name of former military junta or current army chief or former president.
Label: False

Claim: Gargling with Betadine kills germs or reduces their numbers in the throat before they go down to the lungs, and a statement by Eleni Jamarely, professor of infectious diseases, claims that HIV is transmitted more easily from the new coronavirus through the spoon at communion.
Explaination: This is incorrect because, according to the CDC, HIV infection in such a case is possible only if a person has an open wound in the mouth. Also, gargling with Betadine is dangerous because it is not said which "Betadine" product you should gargle. There is a special "Betadine" mouthwash product, whose efficiency on the novel coronavirus has not been proven yet and which can cause allergies to some people. Any other type of Betadine product can have counter-effects.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Video of police roughing up civilians claimed to be police in Spain enforcing a lockdown.
Explaination: The video is originally from Baku, Azerbaijan from a protest in October 2019.
Label: False

Claim: There is now a COVID-19 cure from the USA.
Explaination: It was a test kit from South Korea, that was shared as an American-made vaccine for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: The virus can be overcome by drinking hot water every 15 minutes, avoiding cold drinks and ice cream, going out in the sun to kill the virus, and with the “self-diagnostic guideline” — if you hold your breath for 10 seconds and then you do not cough, you do not choke, you do not feel any tension in the lungs, you have no cystic fibrosis in the lungs and the situation is reversible.
Country: North Macedonia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Greece
Explaination: All of this misinformation has nothing to do with the truth, because the virus not only enters the oral cavity but also the nose, so drinking hot water will not carry the virus to the stomach. Viruses are destroyed at higher temperatures than those normally tolerated by humans, and even sun exposure and body heat have no effect.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 is a secret American weapon aimed for depopulation purposes.
Explaination: Article is based on debunked conspiracy theories.
Label: False

Claim: Viral video shows a man having great difficulty breathing. Even the medical team keeps a safe distance from this man. These videos are shared as a patient suffering from COVID-19.
Explaination: Upon investigation, we found out that all three clips are from Indian State of Gujrat. The man seen in the clips is mentally unstable. Health Authorities from the state confirmed that the man does not have coronavirus infection.
Label: False

Claim: pH level of coronavirus varies from 5.5 to 8.5 and to beat the virus, we should consume more alkaline food.
Explaination: Speaking to The Quint, Dr Shaheed Jameel, a leading virologist said that viruses do not have pH values.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) can prevent COVID-19.
Explaination: The US FDA has however approved the drug for treatment of COVID-19 as this anti-malarial drug might ease some symptoms. However, it is not proven to build resistance and prevent COVID-19 and its use without Doctor's prescription is not recommended.
Label: Misleading

Claim: If you are infected with the new coronavirus, for high fever you should not take Ibuprofen (Brufen) or Paracetamol. Adults should drink a strong black coffee every few hours.
Country: North Macedonia, Greece, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina
Explaination: There are no clinical trials or practice data that would suggest that brufen should not be taken with COVID-19 infection. The Specialist pneumophysiologist and family medicine doctor, Dobrinka Granzov - Kozlina. debunked the fake news about drinking coffee against coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Harvard scientists explain: Here’s how you can cure the coronavirus yourself before the vaccine comes out and a WhatsApp message states: “The Ministry of Health has approved an immediate 350 euro reward for those staying home.” The first child that lost his life because of coronavirus.
Explaination: The "information" contained in the WhatsApp message was denied by the Minister of Health and Social Affairs. The link didn't bring to an existing page. The British media article was about an infected child, not a child who lost his life. There is no exact data so far, but according to WHO, children are less at risk of coronary heart disease when they catch the novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Tamil Nadu Govt ordered to re-open TASMAC bars.
Explaination: A fake screenshot has been used to make the claim.
Label: False

Claim: A drug called Favipiravir is a cure for coronavirus, and people are advised not to go inside their homes wearing shoes because they can bring the infection home.
Country: North Macedonia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina
Explaination: Favipiravir may help treat those who have mild symptoms of COVID-19 but not those who are more severely ill. The director of the Spanish Center for Emergency Coordination Fernando Simon said on 16 March that there was no need to leave shoes out of the home. The same opinion holds the head of the Italian Institute of Health, Silvio Brusaferro, and Fabrizio Preljasko, a virologist at the University of Milan.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: A post on Facebook and Twitter claims an official advisory was issued by Singapore’s Ministry of Health about the first symptoms of the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; a spokesperson for the Singaporean health body told AFP it had not issued the purported advisory.
Label: False

Claim: A video has been have been viewed thousands of times on Facebook alongside a claim it shows how to make a hand sanitiser that is effective in protecting against the novel coronavirus, COVID-19. The video appears to show someone mixing rum, bleach and fabric softener in a bottle before rubbing the solution on their hands.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A video of police arresting a man has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows police in Italy detaining a man who flouted a national lockdown during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the footage in fact shows police arresting a knife-wielding man in the Brazilian city of Sao Paulo.
Label: False

Claim: A post shared repeatedly on WhatsApp and Facebook claims a Chinese doctor has discovered that drinking tea is effective in curing and relieving symptoms of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is false; health experts say there is insufficient scientific evidence to show that drinking tea is effective in preventing or curing COVID-19 infections; as of March 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) has said there is no cure for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: A screenshot of a World Health Organization (WHO) webpage has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter and messaging app Line alongside a claim it shows international health authorities raised Thailand’s pandemic stage to a “level 4” during the novel coronavirus crisis.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A claim has been shared thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter that an emergency decree issued in Thailand due to the novel coronavirus pandemic included a strict curfew.
Explaination: The claim is false; the emergency decree declared on March 25, 2020 by Thailand’s prime minister did not include a curfew.
Label: False

Claim: Lemon and bicarbonate can cure coronavirus.
Explaination: Doctors and experts suggest that there is no medical evidence to corroborate the claim.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A web publication shared hundreds of times on Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp in Nigeria claims the government will pay each citizen 8,500 naira ($23.60) monthly to encourage Nigerians to stay at home in a bid to slow down the spread of the novel coronavirus.
