Explaination: The claim is false; officials have dismissed the claim, and the author of the viral publication admitted it was incorrect.
Label: False

Claim: Videos of a patient gasping for breath is shown as a patient from India.
Explaination: The video is not from India but Ecuador where the person was suffering from acute respiratory distress syndrome.
Label: False

Claim: Actor Vijay’s father criticized government for enforcing a curfew to abate COVID-19.
Explaination: The newscard shared to make the claim is fake. The news channel has not published any such news.
Label: False

Claim: Multiple posts on social media claim that schools in South Africa will reopen months from now in September, as a result of the increase in COVID-19 cases.
Explaination: The claims are false; the Department of Basic Education has not made any such announcement and refuted the claims.
Label: False

Claim: Several home-made cures for coronavirus, ; garlic / vodka / vitamin C treats coronavirus ; children do not transmit the coronavirus and “Serbs have lion genes”.
Explaination: There is no evidence as of now that ibuprofen (also commercially named Brufen or Advil) worsens symptoms, there is also no proof that vitamin C, vodka and garlic treat coronavirus. Epidemiologist Predrag Con states that children can spread the virus.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Santiago Abascal, general secretary of VOX (political party), allegedly didn’t respect the quarantine period after testing positive for COVID-19
Explaination: Santiago Abascal, secretary general of the VOX political party, respected the statutory quarantine periods after being positive by COVID-19 and did not skip the quarantine to go to the Congress of Deputies.
Label: False

Claim: Garlic can protect you from the coronavirus and the most vulnerable group are people with blood type A.
Country: North Macedonia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia
Explaination: Garlic can really help boost immunity, but it can neither protect nor cure because although it has antibacterial properties, the World Health Organization (WHO) has not confirmed that it can cure the new virus and also statistics show that 38 percent of those infected in the city of Wuhan in China had blood type A, but also that as much as 31 percent of the city's population is with that blood type.
Label: False

Claim: Supposedly according to the new decree issued by the Spanish government to regulate non-essential activities during confinement, customs officers must not work and therefore goods would not enter Spain.
Explaination: The decree published by the Spanish government to regulate the performance of non-essential activities during confinement authorizes the work of customs agents, as an essential activity.
Label: False

Claim: Inhaling the steam from boiled water with dissolved salt is an effective cure for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: As of Tuesday, March 31, there is still no cure approved to treat the novel coronavirus, but there are treatments approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) that may help ease the symptoms. Inhaling salt water steam is not among them.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus infections are linked to a lack of Vitamin D.
Explaination: There is no evidence that vitamin D reduces the risk of coronavirus infection. Some preliminary studies suggest that it could prevent it, but drawing premature conclusions about studies or publications can be a risk for the general population.
Label: False

Claim: In a seemingly careless message being sent as an e-mail, recipients in Greek are warned that if a company (shop) has to shut down because of the new coronavirus or staff illness or other reason, the sender must notify the sender of that message about the termination of the employment of an employee.
Explaination: This message contains an "attachment" that carries a high risk of being a malicious software, such as a virus, a Trojan, or other form of malware. The e-mail address is @gmail.com. No legitimate public institution (even a private company) will write to you from a gmail address or any other free service.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus patients in Italy are now on the streets because hospitals are no longer able to accommodate them.
Explaination: The photos were taken in the aftermath of the 5.4-magnitude earthquake that struck Croatia on March 22.
Label: False

Claim: A photo where Pablo Iglesias, vice president of the Spanish government, is praying in a Catholic church before beginning his COVID-19 quarantine.
Explaination: the image where Pablo Iglesias, vice president of Spain,  appears praying in a catholic church is a montage putting his face on the body of another person. The original photograph was published years earlier on the internet.
Label: False

Claim: Hospital La Paz in Madrid, Spain, is requesting blankets for patients admitted to the hospital.
Explaination: The authorities of the La Paz Hospital in Madrid, Spain deny having requested donations of blankets and bedspreads for patients admitted to their hospital.
Label: False

Claim: The WHO allegedly announced that face masks do not protect and are not effective for walking on the street.
Explaination: The WHO says that masks should be used rationally and appropriately due to the scarcity of this protection worldwide, not that it does not protect when going on the street.
Label: False

Claim: Keeping your throat moist will wash the coronavirus down to your stomach where the virus will die.
Explaination: Both the World Health Organization (WHO) and doctor Norberto Francisco, chief of clinical trials and research at the Lung Center of the Philippines, say that drinking water will not prevent a coronavirus infection.
Label: False

Claim: Lies spread by Serbian authorities about COVID-19. For example, the virus does not affect pregnant women, children and young people; no newborn is infected with the coronavirus; the virus does not last long on objects; the number of respiratory machines that Serbia possesses, etc.
Explaination: There have been cases of infected and pregnant and newborns as well as people of different ages, their claim is untrue. When it comes to persistence of the virus on different surfaces, according to the latest research from the US National Institutes of Health, it has a stable presence in aerosols for a duration of three hours, on copper up to four hours, can remain on cardboard for 24 hours and two to three days of plastic and inox.
Label: False

Claim: A photo making the rounds on social media claims to show people who have died from the coronavirus in Italy.
Explaination: The coffins in the photo are those of the victims of the Lampedusa maritime tragedy in 2013.
Label: Partially false

Claim: WHO has said, do not eat cabbage as it will increase the chance of coronavirus infection.
Explaination: WHO has not said anything that shows cabbage has any relation to coronavirus.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Not a single Muslim died of coronavirus in China.
Explaination: There is no such claim made by China so far that not a single Muslim has died of coronavirus. China has not released any list of people who have died in coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: A link offering registration for United States humanitarian aid to other countries for the coronavirus
Explaination: A web page called borrowed.xyz is faking CNN image with an alleged offer from the United States to give humanitarian aid vouchers to citizens of other countries. It is a case of phishing.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking bitter gourd juice cures the coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no proven evidence from any research so far which establishes that bitter gourd juice cures coronavirus.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: The Brazilian Government is handling a 600 Brazilian reais monthly COVID-19 emergency allowance to poor citizens. To access it, you need to fill out an official form (link to the form).
Explaination: Although the COVID-19 emergency allowance itself is a real thing, it has not been formally approved by the Senate yet (March 30, morning). The Brazilian government has not announced how it will be payed. The given URL redirects to a non-governmental internet address, registered abroad, quite possibly a phishing scam.
Label: False

Claim: Nevada Governor Steve Sisolak “has banned the use of an anti-malaria drug that might help cure coronavirus.”
Explaination: A Nevada emergency regulation restricts the prescription of chloroquine for COVID-19 patients in outpatient settings, but not in hospitals and emergency rooms. Gov. Steve Sisolak signed the order on the recommendation of state health officials, who said there is the potential for stockpiling the drug.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Ibuprofen ramps up coronavirus 10 times.
Explaination: There is no evidence that ibuprofen or other similar drugs exacerbate the disease. Instead, the notion is simply a hypothesis that has not been tested.
Label: False

Claim: Increase in cases of pneumonia in Mexico.
Explaination:
In Mexico, what has been verified is that it is false that the cases of pneumonia and bronchopneumonia have registered an increase so far in 2020, according to the last report from the authority in mid-March.
Although the rumor of the data of some supposed 70 deaths linked to the new coronavirus has spread in networks, data that some businessmen from funeral homes in the Toluca Valley, State of Mexico, reportedly provided; This has been ruled out by some authorities and even by the same source to which the report was attributed.
Label: False

Claim: Speaking of his restriction on travel from China, President Donald Trump claims: “I had (Joe) Biden calling me xenophobic … He called me a racist, because of the fact that he felt it was a racist thing to stop people from China coming in.”
Explaination: Biden has not directly said that the restrictions were xenophobic. Around the time the Trump administration announced the travel restriction,  Biden said that Trump had a “record of hysteria, xenophobia, and fear-mongering.”
Label: Mostly false

Claim: President Donald Trump claims he “didn’t say that” some of the medical equipment that governors are requesting, they don’t actually need.
Explaination: During the interview with Hannity, Trump said, “I have a feeling that a lot of the numbers (for ventilators) that are being said in some areas are just bigger than they're going to be. I don't believe you need 40,000 or 30,000 ventilators.”
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: “COVID literally stands for Chinese Originated Viral Infectious Disease.”
Explaination: COVID-19 is an abbreviation of “coronavirus disease 2019.” “CO” stands for “corona,” “VI” stands for “virus” and “D” stands for “disease.” The number 19 reflects the year the disease was identified — 2019.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Nancy Pelosi tried to secure taxpayer funds for abortion through a coronavirus bill.
Explaination: Pelosi never inserted abortion funding in a coronavirus bill. However, some conservatives said by failing to specifically say money couldn’t be used for abortions, that would leave open the possibility that federal money could be used for abortions.
Label: Misleading

Claim: An audio file from an alleged state official from Ceará, Brazil, named Ricardo Certi, asking the directors of a local TV station to criticize Bolsonaro and praise Ceará’s government COVID-19 policies.
Explaination: Ricardo Certi, the man who allegedly recorded the message, does not exist. There's not a single person with this name working for the Ceará state government.
Label: False

Claim: Says imposters in hazmat suits are going door to door in Stockton, California, saying they are checking residents for fever or COVID-19, but they “will enter your home and physically attempt robbery.”
Explaination: Posts around the nation warn people not to open their doors to imposters who say they are doing coronavirus testing but actually want to rob the residents. Like other such claims, this one about an alleged scam in Stockton, Calif., is false, according to police.
Label: False

Claim: A message from Brazilian Workers’ Party (PT), Gleisi Hoffmann, asking party affiliates to boycott the 600 reais monthly COVID-19 emergency allowance. Eligible PT voters should reject it and denounce it, since it is being paid by a “fascist government.”
Explaination: PT, as all Brazilian parties with seating representatives, voted for the COVID-19 emergency allowance, not against it. Gleisi Hoffmann published a text on her Facebook account denying this request.
Label: False

Claim: Governor of Maranhão, Brazil, Flávio Dino, giving food baskets to a crowd of poor people, in spite of recommendations against crowds during the COVID-19 crisis.
Explaination: The picture is from 2019. The man in the picture is not Flávio Dino, but Roberto do Posto, mayor of a small town in Maranhão.
Label: False

Claim: Luciano Hang, Roberto Justus (Brazilian businessmen, pro-vertical isolation tactics) and Eduardo Costa (singer, Bolsonaro supporter) donated 4 million Brazilian reais and 90 respirators to SUS (National Health Care system).
Explaination: Hang told us he donated 2 respirators to a hospital in his hometown, Brusque. Justus said he donated to "some initiatives" against COVID-19, but did not disclose the amount. Costa said he's trying to gather some businessmen together to purchase some respirators for Minas Gerais hospitals, but nothing concrete has happened so far (March 30). Thus, none of the statements are correct.
Label: False

Claim: Lions were released on Russian streets by Vladimir Putin to force people inside.
Explaination: This viral picture is from Johannesburg in South Africa and about four years old.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Most of the passengers in an Ethiopian airlines flight from Italy are infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: The viral video is of a mock drill from Senegal.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Schedules for the sale of milk, newspapers, grocery and medical stores have been issued by the Mumbai Police commissioner.
Explaination: It is a hoax. The Mumbai Police commissioner has not issued any such order.
Label: False

Claim: Aajtak news channel claims that consuming the herbal plant Tulsi will cure coronavirus.
Explaination: WHO has not confirmed anything about Tulsi that it cures coronavirus. Aajtak channel has not run anything like that. The viral photo with channel logo is fake.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: People rioting on the streets of London due to economic crisis in the wake of coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The viral video is almost nine years old and from the London riots in 2011.
Label: False

Claim: Due to the fear of coronavirus, Muslims in China are offering Namaz in the open street.
Explaination: The viral video is four years old and has no relation with coronavirus.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Italian PM said that the country has surrendered to the COVID-19 pandemic
Explaination: The quote attributed to Italian PM is made up.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Donald Trump said, “People are dying who have never died before”
Explaination: The quote has been on the internet for over a decade attributing it to different people at different times.
Label: False

Claim: Vaccines to cure COVID-19 are ready.
Explaination: Viral image is of a COVID-19 testing kit. A cure is still being researched.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Janta curfew or nationwide for 14 hours will break the chain of coronavirus spread and see a reduction of 40% of cases.
Explaination: There is no scientific proof to the claim as yet, that 14 hours curfew will break the chain of coronavirus spread and see reduction of 40 per cent cases.
Label: False

Claim: Bombay High Court is extending Maharashtra’s lockdown to April 31.
Explaination: The High Court had only extended its interim orders and not the lockdown.
Label: False

Claim: Professor Wong Kin-Chung offers tips to delay the progress of COVID-19: Rinse mouth with cold salty water; drink water and red wine; take Vitamin C; eat chicken soup, shiitake mushrooms, astragalus, codonopsis and ginseng.
Explaination: There is no evidence that those mentioned in the claim can prevent COVID-19. Plus, we are not able to identify Professor Wong Kin-Chung, a medical professor, doctor as well as a nutritionist in the USA, who allegedly made that claim.
Label: False

Claim: News graphic saying Indian prime minister has asked for the internet to be shut down in the country.
Explaination: The news graphic is photoshopped and fake. The Prime Minister did not make this statement.
Label: False

Claim: Image shows people falling on the streets of Wuhan.
Explaination: Upon verification, Misbar found that the image was from 2014.
Label: False

Claim: Three photos show coronavirus hospitals In China.
Explaination: Misleading Pictures.
Label: Misleading

Claim: North Korean leader will execute anyone who is infected with the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Execution of anyone infected with COVID-19 in North Korea. After researching the news, whether in the official North Korean agencies or international news agencies, we have not found a basis for the news source.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows a man travelling alone on a plane to China.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the image, and found that it belonged to a young man with Egyptian nationality, and he was not going to Beijing, but was returning from China to Egypt.
Label: False

Claim: “The Simpsons” has predicted the coronavirus since 1993.
Explaination: It was revealed to Misbar that the episode refers to a virus transmitted through a factory in Japan called the "Osaka" flu, and that the image circulated showing the name of the virus in the video clip is fabricated.
Label: Misleading

Claim: News of The death of Two Girls Infected With coronavirus In Northern Syria?
Explaination: An official source denied news that COVID-19 had arrived in Syria and had killed two girls in Aleppo countryside.
Label: Suspicions

Claim: Drinking tea can help cure COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no evidence that drinking tea can help mitigate the effects of the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: A Chinese market caused the new coronavirus (video).
Explaination: Video claims that a Chinese market brought the COVID-19. Misleading video.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A list of 10 claims about the coronavirus, allegedly from a doctor who worked in a hospital in Shenzhen.
Explaination: Most of the claims in the message are false and many are misleading. Drinking warm water will not protect you from getting the coronavirus, for example, and there is no evidence that the virus is killed by a temperature of 26/27 degrees either.
Label: False

Claim: America predicted the new coronavirus outbreak 9 years ago.
Explaination: America predicts COVID-19 9 years ago, and the proof is the movie "Contingent." This news is fake because of the clear difference between talking about intersections between the film's story and the spread of COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Videos showing police raids or army raids against people who don’t respect confinement measures in Algeria or Morocco.
Explaination: The video was shot on March 7th, 2020. It shows the dispersal of an anti government demonstration by the security forces, with no link with confinement measures or coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus fears in Germany result in large crowds outside the supermarket.
Explaination: The viral video is 9 years old and has nothing to do with COVID-19.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: China killed pigs over fear of coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is misleading.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Rapper Eminem contacted coronavirus.
Explaination: Viral post is a hoax. Eminem has not contacted coronavirus till the time of the article got published.
Label: False

Claim: Evacuation of Yemeni students by the Sultan of Oman in China.
Explaination: Misbar verified the news and turned out to be fake.
Label: False

Claim: China declares nuclear war on America.
Explaination: The news is false, as Misbar did not find a basis for it in the Chinese official media, or in the credible international media.
Label: False

Claim: The State of Qatar did not report any COVID-19 infections.
Explaination: Misbar found after verification that the Ministry of Public Health in Qatar announced the registration of a confirmed case of respiratory syndrome in the Middle East for a 65-year-old.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Iraqi Ministry of Health demanded to close the border With Iran because of coronavirus.
Explaination: The news is not true, as Misbar did not find it published in any official Iraqi media.
Label: False

Claim: The Egyptian Minister of Health announced a cure for coronavirus that is extracted from dates.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the authenticity of the news attributed to the Egyptian Minister of Health, and found that the image was first published on a Facebook page called Kolloh Rayeh, and it turns out that the same page was the one that designed the fabricated image and spread the news.
Label: False

Claim: No Confirmation That North Korea Executed An Official After Breaking The Quarantine.
Explaination: North Korea executes a commercial official suspected of being infected with the COVID-19, for breaking a quarantine and going to a public toilet. There is no evidence to substantiate the claim.
Label: Suspicions

Claim: Gaza Strip Is coronavirus-free.
Explaination: 17 cases of COVID-19 in the Gaza Strip.
Label: False

Claim: UNICEF circular on coronavirus prevention.
Explaination: Misbar checked the educational bulletin attributed to UNICEF and found it to be false, completely different from the original bulletin found on the official website of the organization.
Label: False

Claim: Map of the spread of coronavirus In the coming months.
Explaination: The map in circulation is spurious, as Misbar investigated and found to be from Worldpop organization.
Label: False

Claim: A fabricated circular for the Lebanese Ministry of Education regarding the end of the school year.
Explaination: The Lebanese Ministry of Education and Higher Education has announced the end of the school year for all different levels of education, after the outbreak of COVID-19 and the appearance of several cases. The mentioned circular is false and baseless.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows an Iranian man running after a cleric claiming to be infected with the coronavirus.
Explaination: Misbar found that the video has been published on Facebook since July 2017.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Images show the Great Mosque of Mecca empty.
Explaination: The images are fabricated.
Label: False

Claim: The Vatican confirms Pope Francis was infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: It was denied by the Vatican.
Label: False

Claim: Football player Alexis Sanchez is infected with the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Misbar checked the news and confirmed its falsehood.
Label: False

Claim: Photos of the Korean delegation infected with coronavirus in Palestine.
Explaination: Misbar verified the allegations and found that the delegation visited Palestine last January, according to the assurances of the tourer of the delegation, Ahmed Amayreh, which prompted some news sites, such as Ramallah News, to delete the photos and apologize.
Label: False

Claim: A child who died in Damascus was infected with the coronavirus.
Explaination: Misbar checked the circulating news, and found that the director general of Al-Mujtahid Hospital in Damascus, Dr. Samer Khadr, categorically denied any cases of COVID-19 infection.
Label: False

Claim: Kuwait boycotted the products of the Saudi Almarai Company.
Explaination: Misbar found it fake.
Label: False

Claim: Prince of Qatar is infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: The Emir of Qatar has been bedridden for several days, and his temperature is high, indicating that he had COVID-19. Misbar investigated the events narrated by Qatar Live, and found it just a story invented by the website.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A picture of the Chinese President in Wuhan without a mask.
Explaination: The Chinese president in Wuhan, China, without wearing a mask. The image is old and has been posted on the official Chinese news agency Xinhua website since October 2018.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A group prays in The Squares of Italy to get rid of coronavirus.
Explaination: Misbar verified the images circulated, and it was revealed that the prayers took place in Italy, although they were old, and some were published 11 years ago.
Label: False

Claim: The novel coronavirus after 2,600 times magnified.
Explaination: The image is enlarged to show mites, not coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: “The Eyes of Darkness” predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The Eyes of Darkness, published in 1981, predicts the emergence of the COVID-19. The author is already in the book's new edition talking about a biological weapon which is a virus called "Wuhan 400", originating from the same city in China. However, he did not mention COVID-19 or its main symptoms such as shortness of breath and high temperature.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Palestine, Egypt, or Lebanon have succeeded in developing a coronavirus cure.
Explaination: Misbar verified the news and found it fabricated, and it is circulated from time to time in the same formula, but with the change of the name of the country and the doctor.
Label: False

Claim: An Egyptian writer predicted the new coronavirus six years ago.
Explaination: The Egyptian writer, Dr. Ahmed Khaled Tawfiq, foretold the novel coronavirus, and published in his book "Shorbet Hajj Dawood" in 2014, an article about the presence of the virus in Egypt. Misbar has verified the news, which is misleading.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Qatar shed Iranian fruits fearing coronavirus.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the incident, and did not find any official country data on the disposal of any Iranian fruit on the market.
Label: Misleading

Claim: China did not apologize to Muslims in a song.
Explaination: Fake Translation.
Label: False

Claim: In Kuwait, he sneezed during Friday sermon, and the worshipers expelled him.
Explaination: Video showing how worshipers in Kuwait expelled a sneezing man during Friday sermon, for fear that he might have COVID-19. The video is misleading because it is old and have been circulationing before the appearance of the virus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Four cases of coronavirus were reported in the West Bank.
Explaination: 4 cases of COVID-19 were recorded among tourists in Beit Jala in the West Bank. Misbar checked the news and found that Ma'an News Agency had modified it with another news entitled "coronavirus In Bethlehem and The Ministry of Health Is Calling For Calm and Waiting For Instructions."
Label: Misleading

Claim: The Success of an Egyptian serum in treating coronavirus.
Explaination: China has officially announced the success of the Egyptian Serum to cure COVID-19. The Egyptian Ministry of Health denied the news.
Label: False

Claim: Arab medieval historian Abu Al-Hassan Al-Masoudi predicted the present crisis.
Explaination: Misbar verified several editions of the book Akhbar Alzaman, and did not find this text, which differs in the way he wrote poetry from the way Abu Hasan Almasoudi wrote his historical narration of Akhbar al-Zaman. Also, the number of pages in the largest editions did not exceed 280, so page number 365 does not exist as the fake posts claims, which was shared by dozens of pages and met with great interaction.
Label: False

Claim: Crown Prince of Abu Dhabi Mohammed bin Zayed is infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: Misbar has verified the prosecution and is likely to be false, as there is no official news so far about bin Zayed's infection with the virus.
Label: False

Claim: Former Iraqi President Saddam Hussein talks about the coronavirus.
Explaination: Fabricated Video of Former Iraqi President Saddam Hussein Talking About coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Syrians Are Gathering Regardless of coronavirus Outbreak.
Explaination: Misbar found that the photo is old, dating back to 2019.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Leader of North Korea Kim Jong-Un visits an infected woman without wearing a mask.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the picture which accompanied the claim, and it turned out to be old, dating back to April 2018.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The Italian medical sector is angry at Ronaldo.
Explaination: The first claim deals with attributing a tweet to a Spanish biology researcher who blames her government for the poor salary biologists receive, while the second claim deals with the content of the tweet itself that Cristiano Ronaldo receives one million euros, unlike doctors who receive 1,300 euros per month. The news is misleading.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Ronaldo Bought an island to isolate himself from coronavirus.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the news and confirmed its falsity, as Cristiano Ronaldo did not buy an island to isolate him with his family, and the fact is that after suspending the Serie A matches due to the outbreak of COVID-19, he returned to the Portuguese island of Madeira, his hometown in the Atlantic Ocean.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows the arrest of the first coronavirus case in Jordan.
Explaination: A video shows arresting of Tamer, the first Jordanian tested positive for COVID-19, after he escaped his quarantine. The spokesperson of the General Security Forces told Misbar that the video is fake, despite that they actually arrested Tamer in the 15th of March.
Label: False

Claim: Photo shows Palestinians’ solidarity with Italy.
Explaination: Misbar found that the photo showed Israel's solidarity, not Palestine.
Label: False

Claim: Bahraini women escape from quarantine.
Explaination: A video depicts Bahraini women escape quarantine and the police are chasing them. The video depicts part of the clashes that occurred between protesters and the Bahraini police during the protests that broke out in 2012.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Photo shows the solidarity of Italian people against the coronavirus.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the photo and found that it is old, dating back to 2013.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Emirati singer Ahlam’s Mask Is Crowned With Diamonds.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the claim and found that it is just a joke from a fan called Mannol, who shared a photoshopped photo of a mask crowned with diamonds.
Label: False

Claim: French Fans Cheered With Joy When President Macron Announced Holiday To Fight coronavirus.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the video and found it belonged to England fans during a football match between the Wales and England national teams.
Label: False

Claim: Ethiopian Plane Carries People Infected With coronavirus.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the video and found that it is misleading; it has nothing to do with COVID-19, and the plane in the video belongs to the Senegal Air, not Ethiopian.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Israeli Minister of Health provides information on coronavirus to Palestinians.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the claim and found that it is misleading; despite the existence of information on the Israeli minister of health website in Arabic, but all of it are preliminary in comparison with what it is published in Hebrew.
Label: Misleading

Claim: President Trump: Swiss company Roche discovered a cure for coronavirus.
Explaination: US President states that the Swiss company Roche have discovered a cure for COVID-19. The video is out of context and the claim is fake.
Label: False

Claim: Egyptian sterilization team dances to the beats of Bent Aljeeran.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the video and found that it is misleading; the video was shot in Iraq, not Egypt.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Video From The German Government To Its Citizens About coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is old, and it was posted in 2010 by the University Hospitals Birmingham Hospital via its online platforms.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Italian prime minister Conte: we lost control over the coronavirus, everything is in the hands of God.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the claim and found that it is fake; no such statement had been released from the PM on any official record.
Label: False

Claim: Photo shows a man was cured of COVID-19 by hydroxychloroquine.
Explaination: The image in question is from a 2019 brazilian RBS report, prior to the coronavirus pandemic and any case recorded worldwide. The man is Walter Hugo Balestra Pombo, a patient with pulmonary emphysema admitted to the ICU of the Moinhos de Vento hospital in Porto Alegre due to treatment for pulmonary emphysema.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Brazilian President declares “Gaza is the only coronavirus free city”.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the claim and found that the Arabic translation with the video is fake.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows a woman falling down in Jeddah.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the video and found that the woman is mentally unstable, which caused her to fall, according to Saudi authorities.
Label: False

Claim: Putin declares: “Comply with quarantine or face prison for five years.”
Explaination: Exaggerated sanctions to be on anyone who refuse to comply with the quarantine in Russia.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Pollution rate decreased in the aftermath of the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: Misbar found that the claim is misleading; the pollution rate did decrease in some cities.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Saudi English-language magazine Sayidaty addresses novel coronavirus since 2013
Explaination: The magazine addressed the middle east respiratory coronavirus back then, which means that the claim is misleading.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Coronavirus is nothing but Sarin Gas.
Explaination: Coronavirus outbreak is nothing but a cover for Sarin gas leaks from an American lab in Afghanistan, but this claim is false according to the WHO.
Label: False

Claim: The title of the article states: “The first pregnant woman with coronavirus in Macedonia gave birth.”
Explaination: The assertion in the headline that the first pregnant woman with coronavirus gave birth in Macedonia is false. Actually it is an event that happened in Serbia.
Label: False

Claim: Egyptian Health Minister arrive in Italy with secret coronavirus cure.
Explaination: Egyptian ministry of health denied any intention to visit Italy, and Misbar could not find any report published in the Foreign Policy regarding the claim.
Label: False

Claim: Israel’s Ministry of Defense said the best measure against the pandemic is isolating the elders.
Explaination: In the video, published on March 20, Naftali Bennett says that the most important thing to contain the COVID-19 crisis is that young and old do not live together. However, publications that disseminated the material omit that the minister himself corrected himself four days later, in a video published in his official account, and defended the massive lockout.
Label: Partially false

Claim: A video shows chaos in London while coronavirus spreads.
Explaination: Misbar investigated the video and it turned out to be old and dating back to August 2011.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Israel is fighting coronavirus without lockdowns and economic impact.
Explaination: Two emergency regulations have already been approved by Israel government that restrict the movement of people of all ages. It is also false that the country's economy and health system are not being harmed by the pandemic. The government estimated that, because of the disease, the country's GDP will not grow this year and warned of the lack of respirators in hospitals.
Label: False

Claim: The Brazilian government initiated the registration of Social Security withdrawals to fight the pandemic by WhatsApp.
Explaination: Besides such a fund does not exist, the link that accompanies the text on social networks leads to a suspicious address that can not only steal users' personal data, but also leave cell phones vulnerable to invasions.
Label: False

Claim: People looted a supermarket in São Vicente (city in Sao Paulo state) because of the lockout.
Explaination: It is old news that stores and supermarkets in the city of São Vicente, on the coast of São Paulo, were looted. The misinformation stems from a June 2013 brazilian TV Tribuna report.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Graphic shows that COVID-19 killed fewer people daily than other diseases.
Explaination: In addition to bringing old data (February 11), the graphic ignores that the number of daily deaths caused by the pandemic has been growing rapidly - the average daily mortality jumped from 78.7 in the first month of infection to 419.7 in the second. Experts consulted by Aos Fatos claim that the comparison with other diseases masks the severity of the current situation, because, even if the mortality of the new coronavirus is not the highest, it spreads very quickly and overloads health systems.
Label: Partially false

Claim: 232 kids died from COVID-19 in Italy in one day.
Explaination: According to the data from the ISS (Istituto Superiore di Sanità), an Italian government agency, until March 24 (most recent data), the country had not registered a child death due to the new coronavirus. In fact, the youngest victims in the country were in the 30 to 39 age group.
Label: False

Claim: The Brazilian doctor Drauzio Varella defends that the population doesn’t need a lockout.
Explaination: The video brings outdated information about the COVID-19 crisis and creates confusion by mixing real recommendations, how not to create panic, with others now ineffective, how to maintain normal life. Sites also amplify misinformation and use false titles to disorient. In a note on its website, the team that works with the doctor classified this type of disclosure as "disservice", which, according to them, is "confusing the population".
Label: False

Claim: H1N1 was more lethal than COVID-19 in Brazil.
Explaination: The pieces of misinformation are misleading when comparing the number of cases in the first weeks of COVID-19 in Brazil with the accumulated eight months of swine flu. In the 28 days since its arrival in the country, the new coronavirus infected 1,891 people and killed 34; H1N1 infected 627 people and killed one in its first month.
Label: False

Claim: One can get free masks from the government to fight coronavirus by filling this form in the web link.
Explaination: These are dubious web links. The government is not making any such offer.
Label: False

Claim: Actor Tom Hanks died due to coronavirus.
Explaination: This is a hoax. Tom hanks and his wife is recovering from coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: In the city of Lviv (or Vinnytsia), a coughing man was thrown out of the bus.
Explaination: The security service of Ukraine stated that the video is not related to the new coronavirus and was recorded well before the start of the pandemic or quarantine in Ukraine.
Label: False

Claim: French champion of chloroquine Didier Raoult is supposed to have said not to use Bill Gates’ vaccines.
Explaination: Raoult's team denies he made such a statement.
Label: False

Claim: Autohemotherapy cures COVID-19.
Explaination: Auto-hemotherapy it's not among the prevention or treatment measures for the new coronavirus recommended by national and international health authorities. In addition, documents from medical entities and Anvisa (Brazilian National Health Surveillance Agency) published before the COVID-19 pandemic already warned of the risks of the practice, which has no scientific backing and may offer health risks.
Label: False

Claim: The Brazilian government initiated the registration process for the coronavirus financial aid by WhatsApp.
Explaination: The message has been accompanied by links that can be used to steal personal data and redirect users to suspicious websites. The false information was denied by the brazilian government and Ministries of Citizenship and Economy.
Label: False

Claim: Garlic, onions and other traditional medicine recipes are treatments against the new coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no evidence that garlic can protect from the new coronavirus - WHO. As well as there is no support that traditional medicine can help with the new coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Blowing hot air through a hairdryer will cure coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no proven evidence that hot air application through a hairdryer will cure coronavirus.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: After coronavirus pandemic, Chinese president said it’s China’s time to lead the world.
Explaination: The excerpt highlighted today on social media, in fact, is from a speech by Xi on October 18, 2017 at the opening of the 19th Congress of the Chinese Communist Party, which takes place every five years. In the speech, Xi Jinping spoke about the achievements of his first government and said that he wanted to further strengthen China's role on the international stage.
Label: False

Claim: A viral post claiming there is a French state scandal about chloroquine, with 20 different claims.
Explaination: Most of the claims are false or out of context.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: China is supplying the Quran to people to read after the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: This is at least a seven-year-old video and has no relation to coronavirus.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Vaccine made by Roche Medical Company cures COVID-19 in 3 hours.
Explaination: It is not true that a vaccine against the coronavirus was discovered that cures the patient in three hours, as stated by publications circulating on the networks. The photo that accompanies the text is actually a quick test for the detection of COVID-19 produced by the South Korean pharmaceutical company Sugentech. There are no approved vaccines against the new coronavirus yet.
Label: False

Claim: Passengers at Delhi airport got agitated Wednesday morning as their passports were withheld by airport authorities.
Explaination: This incident took place a few days back at IGIA in relation to mandatory coronavirus screening
Label: half true

Claim: Brazilian government will apply fees to everyone who gets caught on the street after March 24.
Explaination: Although the brazilian Ministry of Health recommends that the population avoid agglomerations so as not to stimulate the spread of the new coronavirus, no legislation or regulation that prohibits the movement of people on the streets is contained in the Official Gazette of the brazilian Union, where all acts of the are published.
Label: False

Claim: Tokyo Olympics logo has been redesigned on the theme of social distancing.
Explaination: The Tokyo Olympics logo has not been redesigned.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: The text from a Macedonian website, and more specifically the headline, says that the leader of the French National Front, Marine Le Pen, is the first coronavirus victim in the EU.
Explaination: It is a bad translation from foreign media. Marine Le Pen has never stated that she is the first coronavirus victim in the EU. She said in an interview with the French edition of Russia Today that "the EU is a victim of coronavirus". This is very different from the text's claim that "Le Pen is a coronavirus victim".
Label: False

Claim: The viral image is of a doctor couple in Italy who gave their lives treating coronavirus patients.
Explaination: This photograph was taken in Barcelona airport, Spain. No such news report of the Italian doctor couple found.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Dolphins and swans return to Italy waterways after COVID-19 lockdown.
Explaination: Dolphins and swans are spotted on Italy's waterways and this has nothing to do with the coronavirus lockdown.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: A licensed guide from Rome and the Vatican named Katya tells what is really going on with the coronavirus epidemic in Italy.
Explaination: Several statements do not correspond to scientific facts and official statements.
Label: False

Claim: Woman burned her hands while putting on the stove due to high alcohol content in hand sanitizer.
Explaination: It is a hoax. Alcohol in hand sanitisers evaporate completely once applied on the hands.
Label: False

Claim: Bolivian former Health minister Ariana Campero used an image in a twitter post to criticize the government.
Explaination: The image is from Ecuador.
Label: False

Claim: A declaration by the director of the Center for Coordination of Health Alerts and Emergencies of Spain about tests of COVID-19 for health personnel.
Explaination: Fernando Simón, the director of the Center for Coordination of Health Alerts and Emergencies of Spain said that all the health personnel in contact with a infected colleague with COVID-19 during a public speech, this was denied by the Health Ministry, the protocols and the personnel.
Label: False

Claim: Live stream about the infected foreigners coming to Ukraine from Italy, which went viral.
Explaination: It turned out later that the people on that plane were not infected and some of the information by the speaker was lies.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Clapping together at 5 p.m. will create a vibration which will destroy coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no proven evidence that vibration created by collectively clapping can destroy coronavirus.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: An audio clip claiming to be of renowned heart surgeon Dr Devi Shetty is going viral on Facebook, Twitter, and WhatsApp.
Explaination: The viral clip has been falsely attributed to Dr Devi Shetty.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Video shows bats found under the tiles of many roofs in Hubei, China. They were the source of the coronavirus.
Explaination: The video was not taken in China. It’s an old video uploaded on 05 July 2011 by a Miami based roofing company called ‘Istueta Roofing’. The bats in the video were found under the tiles during the process of replacing a roof for a customer in Miami (US).
Label: False

Claim: The novel coronavirus can be cured by one bowl of freshly boiled garlic.
Explaination: World Health Organization (WHO) has issued a clarification that garlic may have some antimicrobial properties but there is no evidence that it can protect people from the 2019 novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Dettol sanitizer can kill coronavirus. The company knew about the coronavirus in 2019.
Explaination: The ‘Coronavirus’ mentioned on Dettol bottle is the previous strains of coronavirus, not the 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV). Also, Dettol manufacturer (‘RB’) has clarified that they do not yet have more details of the new virus and are not yet in a position to confirm levels of effectiveness against the new strain.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Photo of coffins of coronavirus patients who died in a single day in Italy.
Explaination: The picture is indeed from Italy but is seven years old and has nothing to do with the coronavirus outbreak.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Effects of the new coronavirus on an infected person’s lips.
Explaination: The video shared a effect of coronavirus on a patient lip is found to be on the internet at least since November-2019 i.e. before the recent epidemic broke out. So, it is not related to the recent coronavirus epidemic.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows coronavirus victims in China.
Explaination: The image is from Germany and it shows people lying down in a pedestrian zone, as part of an art project in Frankfurt, in remembrance of victims of the Katzbach Nazi concentration camp.
Label: False

Claim: Sex helps prevent coronavirus.
Explaination: No proves that sex can help fighting the new coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Hold your breath for 10 seconds to check if you have the coronavirus.
Explaination: The fact is that most young COVID-19 patients will be able to hold their breaths for much longer than 10 seconds, while on the other hand, many elderly without the virus won't be able to do it.
Label: False

Claim: Ministry of Home Affairs in India has directed people to not post anything related to coronavirus.
Explaination: The message has been undersigned by the Principal Secretary to the Home Minister but in reality there is no such post of person in the ministry.
Label: False

Claim: Italian PM broke down over coronavirus deaths in his country.
Explaination: The man seen crying in the picture is Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro and the incident has nothing to do with the COVID-19 outbreak.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Video of Canadian PM Justin Trudeau’s wife who is suffering from COVID-19.
Explaination: Woman seen in the video is not the wife of Justin Trudeau but a COVID-19 patient from London.
Label: False

Claim: The new coronavirus is a biological weapon.
Explaination: There is no evidence this claim is correct.
Label: False

Claim: Dr. Naresh Trehan has said that the Indian government is going to declare a national emergency.
Explaination: This is a hoax. Dr Trehan's office has not issued any such message.
Label: False

Claim: Video of police killing COVID-19 affected people in China.
Explaination: The posted video was edited with three unrelated clips to falsely claim that Police with arms are killing people. The Yiwu Police have clarified that the armed Police in the video were on their duty to kill a rabid dog. And, the last clip is related to an accident.
Label: False

Claim: Ibuprofen can be an aggravating factor; one should use Paracetamol instead.
Explaination: Based on currently available information, WHO does not recommend against the use of of ibuprofen.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The homeopathic drug Arsenicum Album 30 can prevent coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence to claim that Homeopathic drug 'Arsenicum album 30' can be used to prevent coronavirus. Even WHO doesn't list any medication that can prevent being infected with coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Videos show pigs being buried in China due to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The videos posted are old. They are in no way related to the recent coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Press Release on movement restriction for COVID-19 outbreak by National Security Council, PMO (India).
Explaination: The press release in the post was issued by the Malaysian Government, not by the Indian Government.
Label: False

Claim: Video of police in China taking into custody suspected COVID-19 patients in the country.
Explaination: The video shows Police in Hong Kong taking into control demonstrators who were protesting against the introduction of a controversial bill that would have allowed extraditions to mainland China.
Label: False

Claim: Gargling warm water with either salt or vinegar can eliminate coronavirus.
Explaination: The World Health Organisation (WHO) or Indian government has not mentioned anywhere that the gargling of warm water with salt or vinegar can eliminate coronavirus. Indian government’s Press Information Bureau (PIB) has also said that the message that was circulating on social media is fake.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus was found in meat (mutton).
Explaination: The photo in the post was edited. Also, the photo was taken five or six years ago. WHO and FSSAI have also mentioned that properly cooked meat can be consumed.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows the new hospital set up in China for coronavirus patients.
Explaination: The video is found to exist on the internet at least since 2018. So, the claim that it shows the new hospital set up by China for coronavirus patients is FALSE.
Label: False

Claim: Details of three coronavirus positive cases reported in Kothapet (Hyderabad, India).
Explaination: Dr G Srinivasa Rao (Director of Public Health, Telangana) has told FACTLY that the viral message is not true. Also, Rachakonda Police has tweeted that a FIR has been filed in the Chaitanyapuri PS (Kothapet area) on the person who spread the fake news.
Label: False

Claim: Images of BJP men smearing cow dung on one another after their party leader Suman Haripriya said cow dung may help cure coronavirus.
Explaination: Assam BJP MLA Suman Haripriya has made those statements on 02 March 2020. But the images are from ‘Goraihabba’ festival that was celebrated in Thalavadi (Tamil Nadu) on 30 October 2019.
Label: False

Claim: After husband tested positive for coronavirus, wife fled from Bangalore to Agra in India.
Explaination: The woman went to her parents place in Agra on 9 March, while her husband was confirmed positive for coronavirus on 12 March. Also, she didn't enter Bangalore city. Karnataka government has also clarified that the woman didn't flee to her parents’ place.
Label: False

Claim: Precautionary measures suggested by UNICEF.
Explaination: The viral message was not issued by the UNICEF. Some of the measures suggested in the message contradict the WHO’S view on COVID-19. Also, some have no scientific evidence.
Label: False

Claim: BBMP (Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike) will be spraying medicine in the air after 10 PM tonight in order to kill COVID-19.
Explaination: The BBMP Commissioner and the Mayor have clarified that the message is just a rumor and the BBMP has no such plans to spray any medicine for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus patients in China are caught by officials on a highway.
Explaination: The video in the post is the video of a ‘Mock drill’. The China SWAT team in the video is ‘practising’ to deal with coronavirus patients.
Label: False

Claim: European Health Organization (EHO) announced that eating beef can cure coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no official institution with the name European Health Organization (EHO). Also, no authority in the European Union has announced that eating beef will cure coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: This video shows goats affected by the coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is an old one. It was taken before the recent coronavirus outbreak. Also, the Minister for Animal Husbandry, Dairying and Fisheries has clarified that there is no evidence to show that eating mutton can transmit coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Scientists have found that drinking bitter gourd juice can cure coronavirus.
Explaination: The World Health Organization (WHO) or the Ministry for Health & Family Welfare (India) hasn't announced that drinking bitter gourd juice will cure coronavirus. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) has clarified that the message is ‘fake’.
Label: False

Claim: Government of India has announced a “National Lockdown” in the country from 3/20/20.
Explaination: No, the Government of India hasn't announced a ‘National Lockdown’ in the country from 20 March. PM Modi, in his recent address to the nation about the coronavirus outbreak, has asked people to practice ‘social distancing’ and to stay home as much as possible for the coming few weeks to combat COVID-19. Also, the Press Information Bureau (PIB) has clarified that the message is ‘fake’.
Label: False

Claim: Audio clip of a conversation claiming that Government of India will announce shutdown of the country in the coming days from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20 in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak
Explaination: PIB termed the audio clip of the phone conversation discussing ‘complete lockdown’ of the country from 15 April to 15 June as ‘fake’. WHO India has also confirmed that the audio is fake.
Label: False

Claim: People shouting “Allahu Akbar” in Europe after the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The video is not related to COVID-19 outbreak in Europe. The video was found to be on the internet since 13 January 2020, whereas the first COVID-19 case in Europe was reported on 24 January 2020. The video was taken in Germany, where the first COVID-19 case was reported on 28 January 2020.
Label: False

Claim: Video of Canada PM Justin Trudeau’s wife pleading for people to take COVID-19 seriously.
Explaination: The woman in the video is not Canada Prime Minister’s wife (Sophie Grégoire Trudeau). She is Tara Jane Langston, a waitress who contracted COVID-19 and undergoing treatment at Hillingdon Hospital in London.
Label: False

Claim: In the video, the woman who is asking to take the coronavirus seriously is the wife of the Prime Minister of Canada.
Explaination: The woman in the video is not Canada Prime Minister’s wife (Sophie Grégoire Trudeau). She is Tara Jane Langston, a waitress who contracted COVID-19 and undergoing treatment at Hillingdon Hospital in London. She took the video to tell people in her country that the coronavirus is serious.
Label: False

Claim: Video of the current situation in Italy due to coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is of an ‘Emergency Exercise’ at Blaise Diagne International Airport (Senegal) in November 2019. The mock drill was conducted to ensure if the crew can handle emergency situation at the airport.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus can live only up to 12 hours on any surface.
Explaination: According to a scientific study, coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) was stable on some surfaces (like plastic and stainless steel) for up to 72 hours (3 days). Also, on the WHO website, it can be read that virus ‘may persist on surfaces for a few hours or up to several days’.
Label: False

Claim: Reserve Bank of India (RBI) extended the year closing until 6/30/20.
Explaination: The normal financial year in India followed by the government & all other institutions including for taxation purpose is 01 April to 31 March. However, RBI’s accounting/financial year is from 1 July to 30 June. There is no change in the normal financial year.
Label: False

Claim: Image of the people who died of coronavirus in Italy.
Explaination: The photo is not related to recent coronavirus deaths in Italy. It was taken in Frankfurt (Germany) in 2014 as part of an ‘art project’ in remembrance of 528 Katzbach victims of the Nazi concentration camp.
Label: False

Claim: Kerala has asked NABARD for a loan of Rs 20,000 crore to deal with COVID-19.
Explaination: While it is true that the Kerala Government has announced a financial package of Rs. 20,000 crore to fight the pandemic, they have not asked NABARD for a loan of Rs 20,000 crore. They have requested for a special line of credit of Rs 2000 crore from NABARD under RIDF.
Label: False

Claim: Photo of the prime minister of Italy crying and expressing his helplessness that he couldn’t save coronavirus patients in Italy.
Explaination: The person in the photo is not the PM of Italy. He is Jair Bolsonaro, the President of Brazil. The photo was taken when he cried at an ‘Evangelical Thanksgiving Service’. The PM of Italy has not expressed helplessness that he couldn't save coronavirus affected patients in Italy.
Label: False

Claim: There is science behind Indian Prime minister Modi’s 5 p.m. clapping initiative: Clapping generates vibration which can kill coronavirus. Also, 3/22/20 is Amavasya.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence to prove that vibration from clapping hands can kill coronavirus. The Press Information Bureau of India has clarified that the message is fake. Also, Amavasya is not on 22 March 2020.
Label: False

Claim: Photo of a vaccine developed by U.S. scientists for COVID-19.
Explaination: The photo shows a COVID-19 diagnostic test kit developed by Sugentech, a South Korean based company. It is not a vaccine. As on 23 March 2020, there is no vaccine for COVID-19. Also, Trump announced FDA’s approval of a coronavirus ‘test’, not a vaccine, developed by a company ‘Roche’ to increase and accelerate the country’s capacity to test for the virus.
Label: False

Claim: Photos of coronavirus patients being treated on the road in Italy.
Explaination: The photos in the post are related to the earthquake in Croatia on 22 March. Patients at the hospital were evacuated because of the earthquake.
Label: False

Claim: Mustard oil prevents a person from getting infected with COVID-19.
Explaination: Neither World Health Organization (WHO) nor the Ministry for Health & Family Welfare (India) has announced that using mustard oil can prevent a person from getting infected with COVID-19. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) has clarified that the message is ‘fake’.
Label: False

Claim: A video showing a pile of corpses in Italy.
Explaination: The video in the post is not real. It was a movie clip from a 2007 mini-series called 'Pandemic'.
Label: False

Claim: Image of dead bodies of coronavirus victims in Italy.
Explaination: The image shows coffins containing the dead bodies of Lampedusa shipwreck victims. In 2013, a boat packed with around 500 African migrants caught fire and sank around half a mile from the Italian island Lampedusa leading to the death of more than 300 people.
Label: False

Claim: Iranian girl Anahita Hashemzadeh has contracted the coronavirus.
Explaination: Anahita Hashemzadeh hasn’t contracted coronavirus. In the comments section of her Instagram videos, her mother has clarified multiple times that she is ‘safe and healthy’ and the news regarding Anahita getting infected with coronavirus is ‘fake'.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 patients will not show symptoms for the first 14 days.
Explaination: On the WHO website, it can be read that the incubation period for COVID-19 range from 1-14 days. But, most commonly COVID-19 patients show symptoms in around five days.
Label: False

Claim: A video of a policeman taking down a man wandering during a “lockdown in Italy.”
Explaination: The video is from Brazil and it shows Police taking down an alleged knife-wielding-man in Sao Paulo on 19 March.
Label: False

Claim: Photo of deer on Ooty-Coimbatore road during the current coronavirus lockdown.
Explaination: It is an old photo. The photo is on the internet at least since 2014. It was taken in Japan, not in India.
Label: False

Claim: Another new disease called “hantavirus” in China.
Explaination: Hanta virus' has infected people in different countries for many years. That's not a new virus. In the US, between 1993 and 2017, approximately 728 people were infected with the virus which can be seen on the CDC website.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 was known to humans before its outbreak in 2020.
Explaination: The new SAR-CoV-2 virus (which cause COVID-19) was first reported in December 2019. All the old images and videos being shared on social media refer to the virus as coronavirus, not as SAR-CoV-2 (or COVID-19). coronaviruses were known to human decades ago. All the references made on social media were about the coronaviruses, a general term for various viruses which cause diseases ranging from the common cold to Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).
Label: Misleading

Claim: In a statement, Russian President Vladimir Putin said Russian citizens have to choose between quarantine and prison.
Explaination: Putin has not enacted this, although it is a possible punishment in Moscow and there is a bill that could send those who break the quarantine and cause infections to jail.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus (COVID-19) is a “mix of SARS, HIV, tuberculosis and malaria.”
Explaination: A WhatsApp audio assures this, but neither that statement, nor several others that he mentions, have scientific support.
Label: False

Claim: A WhatsApp chain cites real research on the survival of different coronaviruses in various materials and in the air.
Explaination: SARS-CoV-2 does last hours or days on some surfaces, others need to be studied. One of the studies cited found that the SARS-CoV-2 virus survives: Three hours dispersed in air, Four hours in copper, 24 hours in cardboard and Two to three days in plastic or stainless steel.
Label: True but

Claim: Claims that Colombian President Iván Duque approved collective dismissals of workers due to the emergency caused by COVID-19. Some of the messages attached as proof are screenshots of Resolution 0803 of 2020 of the Ministry of Labor.
Explaination: Government has not approved collective dismissals for coronavirus. Resolution 0803 of 2020 of the Ministry of Labor does not authorize collective dismissals. Other measures require the employee to agree.
Label: False

Claim: An image accompanies the text: The Italian Prime Minister wept when he recognized that they were losing the battle against the coronavirus.
Explaination: Message assures that the Italian leader cried over the situation of COVID-19 in his country, but the image that supposedly proves it is of Jair Bolsonaro from Brazil at a religious ceremony in 2019.
Label: False

Claim: A WhatsApp a video features Rabbi Dan Ben Avraham, International President of the Netzarita AMI Alliance, according to their Twitter. In the video, the rabbi says “the Israeli Minister of Health has officially declared that Israel has the coronavirus vaccine.” And “Israel has the vaccine already.”
Explaination: According to the WHO, the necessary safety approvals to bring a viable vaccine to market could take up to 18 months.
Label: False

Claim: Ecuadorean government gives money to people from Venezuela.
Explaination: The government doesn't give money to Venezuelans.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Three photos showing coffins lined up in an enclosed space have been released on social media with a message about the coronavirus pandemic in Italy. “This is Italy,” he said.
Explaination: The images correspond to migrants killed in shipwrecks in the Mediterranean in 2013.
Label: False

Claim: Audio message warns of the arrival of COVID-19 at Suba hospital in Columbia.
Explaination: Health entities in the capital confirmed that this is misinformation. So far, there are no cases of coronavirus in the Suba hospital.
Label: False

Claim: Video broadcast on networks allegedly shows the ‘first killed by COVID-19 in Ibagué’, in Columbia.
Explaination: The images were taken out of context. It is actually the first coronavirus patient in this city to be discharged from the hospital.
Label: False

Claim: China seeks court’s approval to kill 20,000 coronavirus p;atients.
Explaination: Post claiming China seeks court’s approval to kill 20000 coronavirus patients is fake.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus was created in a lab in order to destroy the Chinese economy. The vaccine is already available.
Explaination: Claims that the "mutation of the virus corona was caused artificially in the laboratory" and that it was a "biological war" and that the virus was "released to weaken the Chinese economy" are rated as conspiracy theories because there is no evidence or argument for them.
Label: False

Claim: Nostradamus predicted the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination:
In the book Prophecies of Nostradamus it doesn't say any of the words that are now being spread.
The prophecies that record the words "plague" and "dust" are different from the one that circulates in the image that went viral.
Label: False

Claim: Neuroscientist Rodolfo Llinás says that if you can last 10 seconds without coughing and without discomfort it means that there is no fibrosis in the lungs and therefore no coronavirus infection.
Explaination: Rodolfo Llinás claims that he has not said that and there is no evidence that these recommendations are effective.
Label: False

Claim: Audio from WhatsApp in which the head of Cardiology at the Gregorio Marañón Hospital states that we are in a moment of uncontrolled coronavirus infection.
Explaination: The public health authorities of the Community of Madrid have classified the audio that supposedly belongs to the head of Cardiology at the Gregorio Marañón Hospital as false.
Label: False

Claim: Madrid’s government has announced students will have to make-up classes during summer.
Explaination: Madrid's government hasn't announced the students will have to make-up classes during summer: the shared photo is fake.
Label: False

Claim: WhatsApp message suggests holding your breath for 10 seconds and drinking water every 15 minutes will fight the coronavirus.
Explaination: There are no medical and scientific evidences of this.
Label: False

Claim: CDC recommends men shave their beards to be protected against the new coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is based on a Centers for Disease Control chart created in 2017 to advise medical workers on the best practices for wearing "filtering facepiece respirators" during contact with viral patients. It was not intended for the general public - nor specifically for preventing the spread of coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Cocaine kills the coronavirus.
Explaination: Fake story was generated by a website that allows people to create their own news stories. Previously busted claim.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus found in broiler chicken
Explaination: No evidence to prove that Coronavirus found in the broiler chickens. WHO has clarified that meat cooked properly can be consumed.
Label: False

Claim: Viral claims propagating UNICEF message about coronavirus.
Explaination: Mr. Jeremy Sprigge, Communication Specialist of UNICEF Sri Lanka confirmed that “these messages are NOT UNICEF statements and henceforth FALSE” and that an official communication regarding the same would be published via UNICEF’s social media channels.
Label: False

Claim: China built a hospital in 48 hours to receive new coronavirus patients.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: Misleading

Claim: A man with a gas mask at a supermarket in Lugo (Galicia, Spain).
Explaination: The picture was taken in Austria, not Spain.
Label: False

Claim: In a video, a Chinese epidemiologist says there are millions infected.
Explaination: Same case of this Newtral verification: https://www.newtral.es/bulos-coronavirus-wuhan-casos-videos-teorias-conspiranoicas/20200225/.
Label: False

Claim: A monkey has been infected with coronavirus in this photo.
Explaination: The photo is a capture of a video taken at least two months before the first symptoms of COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: An elderly Chinese couple infected with coronavirus say goodbye while they are in a hospital.
Explaination: The elderly couple hospitalized for other conditions such as lung cancer and respiratory failure.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Bats that hide under Wuhan rooftops caused the COVID-19 outbreak.
Explaination: The video was filmed in Miami in 2011.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A 1981 book predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: There are coincidences, but it's not a prediction.
Label: False

Claim: China seeks approval from the court to kill over 20 000 coronavirus patients.
Explaination: There are a few inadequacies detected on the source’s website. Also, zero credible news platforms have published this claim. All these make the claim unsubstantial.
Label: False

Claim: Satellite images showing high levels of sulphur dioxide above China are possible evidence of mass cremations of people who have died from coronavirus.
Explaination: This is a forecast based on historical data. Full Fact analysis was mentioned in our article.
Label: False

Claim: China orders citizens to abandon/kill their pets as they can transmit coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no proof that Chinese authorities have ordered the killing of pets; however, there is proof that some Chinese authorities have approved killings of stray dogs and cats in order to stop the spreading of the virus. The WHO says that right now there is no evidence that the virus can be transmitted through pets.
Label: Partially false

Claim: A video says weed kills coronavirus.
Explaination: The news clip was created through a meme generator while the WHO has stated that there are no proven cures for the virus yet.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Video of Wuhan market where the new coronavirus started to spread.
Explaination: Video is from a market in Indonesia.
Label: False

Claim: Vitamin C and warm water with lemon can prevent COVID-19.
Explaination: Vitamin C has no known effect on the novel coronavirus, and neither does warm water with lemon.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese people convert to Islam because of COVID-19.
Explaination: It's an old video, not related to CoV.
Label: False

Claim: A convoy carrying vaccines against Covid-19 in South Africa was attacked in the streets.
Explaination: This video was recorded in August 2019, and shows a confrontation between local merchants and policemen, who came to seize conterfeit goods. There is still no vaccine against Covid-19.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A video viewed thousands of times in Nigeria and shared in multiple Facebook posts claims to show police in Spain rounding up people aged 50 and above to transfer them to quarantine centers amid the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the footage was circulating months before the outbreak and actually shows police in Azerbaijan detaining anti-government protesters in the capital Baku.
Label: False

Claim: There is already a vaccine for coronavirus, created in the U.S.
Explaination: The photo shared is actually of a testing kit.
Label: False

Claim: Walmart has adopted staggered shopping days based on age in response to the pandemic.
Explaination: Walmart has not restricted shopping days by age, except for weekly hour for senior citizens.
Label: False

Claim: Shanghai and Beijing had no cases of coronavirus.
Explaination: According to WHO, 583 cases of coronavirus were registered in Beijing and 526 in Shanghai as of April 3.
Label: False

Claim: Facebook user suggested that “frustrated Italians” are throwing away their money.
Explaination: The viral images have nothing to do with Italy. They have been around since March 2019, long before the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic. An article explains that the images were taken after hooded men robbed a bank in Venezuela and littered the streets with old currencies.
Label: False

Claim: World Bank classified Brazil as the “best country on COVID-19 combat.”
Explaination: The World Bank's document to which the publication refers doesn't make this statement. The text, which addresses risk management and trade facilitation in the midst of the pandemic, mentions only the temporary reduction in the import tax rate on antiseptic products adopted by Brazil as an example of “best practices for dealing with COVID-19”.
Label: False

Claim: Cattle vaccine is related to COVID-19, the current panic overblown by media.
Explaination: The viral post claims that the world has been using coronavirus vaccine on cattle for years and the current panic on novel coronavirus (COVID-19) has been overblown by media. When we investigated, we found that the vaccine being referred is for cattle, it is neither related with humans, not with COVID-19. The viral post is misleading.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Photo on biography of a boy who died from coronavirus.
Explaination: The photo is incorrectly attributed to this story and is of an entirely different person unrelated to COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: “The Chinese Communist Party is using Zoom as a way to spy on our citizens.”
Explaination: The claim is based on a report from researchers at the University of Toronto. But one of the researchers told us that while they identified security issues with Zoom, whether China has exploited the platform for espionage was not something they considered.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: A claim has been shared on Facebook and several Sri Lankan news websites that Muslims at a mosque in Sri Lanka reacted violently after authorities told them their gathering was in violation of the country’s novel coronavirus curfew.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; police and public health officials said that locals were in fact asked to gather at the mosque to receive tests to detect COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus. The scuffle that occurred at the event was sparked over fears that the testing site would make the village more susceptible to infections, they said.
Label: False

Claim: A doctor from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, releases audio saying isolation should be over since there are few patients with COVID-19 in the city.
Explaination: The person didn't identified itself and secretary of health said the person does not work in its hospital.
Label: False

Claim: A video of a Muslim fruit-vendor spitting on fruits to spread coronavirus.
Explaination: The video was shot in February 2020 by a man in Raisen district in the state of Madhya Pradesh (MP), but the first coronavirus case in Madhya Pradesh was detected on 20 March.  The posted video was taken much earlier than the first coronavirus case in the state.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Government of Telangana in India has released a new schedule of SSC Class-X Examinations. As per it, exams will be scheduled from April 20 to April 28.
Explaination: As on 07 April 2020, SSC board hasn't announced any schedule of SSC Class-X examinations. Satyanarayana Reddy (Director of the Examination section of the Board) has clarified that the messages with schedule of the exams are fake.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Video of a Muslim man spitting into the food packages to spread coronavirus.
Explaination: It’s an old video. While the first coronavirus outbreak was reported in China in December 2019, the posted video has been shared on the internet since April 2019. Also, the video is not related to India.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Pedro Sánchez, President of Spain, spies on the King after a rumor that hits Moncloa: Don Felipe, King of Spain, talks about changing the government.
Explaination: The king could not "change the Government" without being endorsed by the Prime Minister or Congress.
Label: False

Claim: Video of a train carrying the trucks with essential goods during the current lockdown in India. It’s a “brilliant idea” by Modi’s government.
Explaination: It is an old video. The video is being circulated on the internet at least since 2013. Also, a similar service is being offered by the Konkan Railway from many years.
Label: False

Claim: Adidas is donating shoes in a campaign against the coronavirus.
Explaination: On the website that impersonates Adidas, the URL redirects you to a supposed Chrome extension that has nothing to do with donating shoes for the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Dozens of dead bodies are stacked at Lenox Hill Hospital in NYC, and the media don’t want to show this tragic image of the pandemic.
Explaination: Even if you can see the outside of an hospital in NYC during the first seconds of the video, the second part with the bodies is recorded shows an hospital of Guayaquil, Ecuador.
Label: False

Claim: Stones were hurled at police in Gomtipur, Ahmedabad (India), when they went to search for suspects who attended the Nizamuddin Markaz event in Delhi.
Explaination: The police commissioner of Ahmedabad has clarified that the police were attacked while they were enforcing lockdown. Police were not searching attendees of the Nizamuddin Markaz event.
Label: False

Claim: Video of stone-pelting by people when health officials went to trace the Nizamuddin guys in Indore, MP.
Explaination: The video is an old one. It was taken in Ahmedabad in December 2019. It is related to anti-CAA protests.
Label: False

Claim: PM Modi has announced the extension of the All-India Lockdown until 5/4/20.
Explaination: No such announcement has been made by PM Modi or the government. The posted India Today screenshot is a photoshopped version of the original telecast of Modi’s address to the nation on 24 March 2020, where he announced the 21-day lockdown from 25 March 2020.
Label: False

Claim: PM Modi has announced the extension of the All-India Lockdown until 5/4/20.
Explaination: No such announcement has been made by the prime minister Modi or the government. The posted India Today screenshot is a photoshopped version of the original telecast of Modi’s address to the nation on 24 March 2020, where he announced the 21-day lockdown from 25 March 2020.
Label: False

Claim: People washing hands from the same pond before the prayers at Hazrat Nizamuddin is the reason for the spread of coronavirus in India.
