Explaination: While the first positive case of COVID-19 in India was detected on 30 January 2020, the video is available on the internet since December 2020 and cannot to linked to the events at Hazrat Nizamuddin.
Label: False

Claim: “Rivers in Oklahoma are full of catfish carrying the virus.”
Explaination: This Facebook post is a hoax.
Label: False

Claim: Images of gathering of BJP members in Madhya Pradesh on 23 March 2020 despite the existing lockdown in the State.
Explaination: The images show a gathering of BJP members at their party office in Bhopal (MP) on 20 March 2020. But the lock down was introduced in the State on 23 March 2020. So, the images are from an event prior to the introduction of lock down in the State.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter in April 2020 alongside a claim it shows the arrest of Indian activist Trupti Desai after she attempted to buy alcohol during a government-imposed lockdown triggered by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; this video has circulated in reports about Desai's arrest during a protest against the sale of alcohol in Maharashtra state in September 2019; the reports circulated months before the novel coronavirus was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.
Label: False

Claim: Indian Ministry of Tourism issued a notification that all hotels, restaurants, pubs etc will be closed till 10/1520. The notification further states that specifically north Indian restaurants should be closed till the given date else legal action will be taken against the owner of the restaurant.
Explaination: Ministry of Tourism has not issued any such order which states that all restaurants in India will be closed till 15th October 2020 in order to curb the spread of COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Says Nostradamus predicted the coronavirus in a 1551 passage about a plague spreading from the east.
Explaination: The format doesn't match Nostradamus’ typical quatrain predictions, and we couldn't find the words in collections of his prophecies.
Label: False

Claim: A video of a Muslim man spitting on police to spread coronavirus when he was being taken into custody.
Explaination: The person (Mohammed Sohail Shoukath Ali) in the video is under trial, he spat on police as they didn't allow him to eat the food brought by his family members. This has no reaction with coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Goodwill laid off all employees due to COVID-19.
Explaination: This is a generalization and hasn't happened everywhere.
Label: False

Claim: Video of Indian activist Tripti Desai’s arrest by police after selling bottles of liquor during lockdown.
Explaination: The video was taken in September 2019 when police took 'Trupti Desai' into custody as part of preventive action before the visit of the then Chief Minister of Maharashtra, Devendra Fadnavis, in Pune.
Label: False

Claim: Israeli recipe for lemon and bicarbonate drink is a coronavirus cure.
Explaination: There is no cure for coronavirus and this hasn't been scientifically proven to work.
Label: False

Claim: Alkaline food helps counter COVID-19.
Explaination: The OMS published an article denies these kind myths about COVID-19
Label: False

Claim: Says video shows “the Chinese are destroying the 5G poles as they are aware that it is the thing triggering the corona symptoms.”
Explaination: The video shows Hong Kong protesters tearing down “smart” lampposts because they feared they could be used to collect personal data from citizens.
Label: False

Claim: Says Goodwill used the pandemic “to fire all of their employees instead of laying them off.”
Explaination: Across the country, employees at local Goodwill organizations have been laid off or furloughed, but some operations have not shuttered, according to a Goodwill spokesperson.
Label: False

Claim: This video shows an FBI raid into a synagogue to requisition medical devices.
Explaination: FBI confiscated medical devices and masks into a private individual house in Brooklyn, whose owner had planned to sell with a high increase in prize.
Label: False

Claim: New york Jewish temple was found to hide medical N95 masks which is needed by hospitals.
Explaination: The masks were hidden by a person in his house, not a jewish temple.
Label: Partly false

Claim: Charles Lieber was arrested for participating in the creation of the coronavirus.
Explaination: Although Lieber's arrest is real, it had nothing to do with the coronavirus COVID-19. Scientific evidence suggests that the virus was not intentionally created.
Label: False

Claim: Video claiming you can’t catch coronavirus.
Explaination: Anyone can be affected by the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Ansa news has reported that former ECB Governor Mario Draghi will lead the Italian task-force against COVID-19.
Explaination: The Italian police has said that it's not the original version of the certificate, but a manipulated version of it.
Label: False

Claim: Brazilian army built 2,000 hospital beds in 48 hours.
Explaination: The Army is in fact helping on the construction of hospitals, but the number of beds built in such a short time is false.
Label: False

Claim: Charles Lieber, Harvard university professor, has been arrested for “creating and selling” the new coronavirus to China.
Explaination: Charles Lieber, who also worked for Wuhan university, has been arrested in January 2020, but his arrestation has nothing to do with coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Beijing and Shanghai have been preserved from the pandemia of COVID-19, proof that the virus has been created and used by China as a weapon.
Explaination: Both cities publicly announced cases of contamination in January, and this virus has a "natural" origin
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus was created in a laboratory.
Explaination: Scientific evidence points out that the virus was not "created".
Label: False

Claim: A yellow bracelet will be placed on people who “are seen outside their homes but not to go to work or get basic necessities.”
Explaination: The statement is false. But although the federal government has not said that some type of sanction will be applied to people who leave their homes without having to go to work or to buy basic supplies, the recommendation is to stay home.
Label: False

Claim: Netflix is ​​giving free access to its service during isolation from the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explaination: Netflix is ​​not giving free accounts for coronavirus. It is a phishing scam.
Label: False

Claim: This map shows that the spread of coronavirus epidemic is the same as 5G deployment on French territory.
Explaination: The map actually shows the deployment of optical fiber in France in december 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Myanmar health minister mentions that a vaccine for COVID-19 was found.
Explaination: There is no evidence of the health minister saying a COVID-19 vaccine was found. WHO has said that there is no single medicine effective to prevent or cure COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Barack Obama warned Africans against coronavirus vaccines.
Explaination: There is no evidence of Obama warning anyone against vaccines, whether for coronavirus or other diseases. And no vaccine against COVID-19 exists yet.
Label: False

Claim: Audio of Biden calling the coronavirus a hoax.
Explaination: The video was manipulated and is not real.
Label: False

Claim: Indian PM Modi announced a lockdown extension until 5/4/20 in India.
Explaination: No such announcement was made by PM Modi, the image is digitally edited.
Label: False

Claim: The French government has authorized euthanasia of old people suffering from COVID-19 with a new decree.
Explaination: The new decree changes the granting procedure of "Rivotril", a medicine which aim is to improve the palliative care of patients suffering in french nursing homes EHPAD. It is used to alleviate their pain - but not in any case to end up their lives.
Label: False

Claim: “President Duque uses a State helicopter to fly over Colombia with a priest and bless our territory with the Virgin Mary and the Blessed Sacrament. Amen #GrandeMiPresidente ”.
Explaination: The experts we consulted concluded that the viral video aircraft is a civil helicopter.
Label: False

Claim: Trump’s claim that he imposed the first travel ban on China.
Explaination: Nearly 40 countries imposed restrictions earlier than the USA but USA was one of the first large economic powers to do so.
Label: Three Pinocchios

Claim: A video shows a man spitting inside food packets during the coronavirus crisis.
Explaination: The video is old and out of context, the man in the video blew on the plastic bag to open it up..
Label: False

Claim: Soaking in the sea can treat COVID-19.
Explaination: As with the nature of other viruses, the novel coronavirus attacks cells in the body, not the surface of the body like the skin, so it cannot be cured simply by soaking in the sea. Until now, according to WHO, there is no drug or vaccine to cure or prevent COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: UK, USA have asked Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to lead a task force to tackle coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no such task force that the Indian prime Minister is heading. The Indian prime minister has been a part of the G20 and SAARC summits for their discussions on coronavirus. The WION's reporting was misinterpreted.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus does not cause a runny nose; is killed by temperatures above 26 degrees; causes lung fibrosis within days of infection; can be diagnosed by holding your breath for 10 seconds; and can be cured in the early stages by drinking plenty of water.
Explaination: Numerous claims circulating on social media tout untested diagnostic methods, preventions, treatments, and cures for COVID-19. While many of these are not harmful by themselves, they could potentially induce a false sense of security that causes individuals to ignore basic, tested precautionary measures such as frequent handwashing, disinfecting surfaces, avoiding touching the face, social distancing, and self-isolation when sick, which have all proven effective in slowing the spread of the pandemic.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Muslims are licking their plates to spread coronavirus and infect more people with the virus.
Explaination: The video is from three years ago depicting a Dawoodi Bohra practice of licking the plate clean so as to prevent any food from being wasted before washing and is not linked to the coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Italians threw away their currency on the streets due to COVID-19 deaths.
Explaination: The images are from Venezuela where vandals robbed a bank and threw the demonetised money on the streets.
Label: False

Claim: Facebook posts shared thousands of times feature a video of U.S. officials talking to reporters, with captions claiming they are announcing the arrest of a Chinese scientist.
Explaination: However, the footage has nothing to do with COVID-19 and scientists have refuted allegations the virus was deliberately created.
Label: False

Claim: People sneezing purposefully to spread coronavirus at Hazrat Nizamuddin mosque in Delhi.
Explaination: The video has been available on the internet since long. It has no connection to coronavirus.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: The coronavirus has been “released” by China […] it was purposely propagated by the Chinese themselves.
Explaination: All available data indicate that SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19, is of natural origin. Comparisons of viral genome sequences show that it shares a strong identity with similar coronaviruses that infect pangolins and bats. And further investigations of the SARS-CoV-2 genome suggest that the virus was not artificially created or propagated in laboratories. In the absence of evidence proving otherwise, the claim that SARS-CoV-2 was lab-created and intentionally released is not only unsubstantiated but also implausible.
Label: No evidence

Claim: A Spanish presenter shows a video from Italian television “from five years ago” in which journalists from the Italian public channel RAI tell about an experiment with a virus. According to the report, the experiment created a coronavirus from bats and mice to investigate the effect of this type of virus on humans.
Explaination: The RAI video from five years ago discussing an experiment with bats and a coronavirus does exist, but is unrelated to SARS-CoV-2, the cause of the current COVID-19 epidemic.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Coffee prevents coronavirus.
Explaination: Coffee does not prevent coronavirus. There are no specific treatments for COVID-19 as of now.
Label: False

Claim: A political assistant did not ask media outlets to defame Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro.
Explaination: People whose names were involved on the lie denied and the person who allegedly did that is not a worker of the government.
Label: False

Claim: A blog site publication stated that the president of Nigeria fired his chief of staff, further appointing Ajimobi as a replacement.
Explaination: Not only is there no media report to corroborate this claim, but the presidency also debunked it.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows EU flag was lowered in France to protest outbreak policies.
Explaination: The video dates back to May, 2019 before the outbreak. The politician who lower the flag had already a far-right anti-EU thoughts.
Label: False

Claim: A publication in Akelicious.net alarmingly announces that the Nigerian government’s conditional cash transfer program seeks to exempt Igbos, crediting its claim to the Minister of Humanitarian Affairs.
Explaination: Save the fact that the Ministry of Humanitarian Affairs expressly rebuffed these assertions, the site in question retracted the post.
Label: False

Claim: Aid released by the Brazilian government made a crowd gather in a bank agency.
Explaination: The picture that was shared on social media was old.
Label: False

Claim: Video allegedly exposing coronavirus’s secrets.
Explaination: From the CDC to doctors to international reports, none of the claims can be backed up with evidence.
Label: False

Claim: NYT invented the video of a doctor fighting coronavirus in hospital.
Explaination: The video is real and Dr. Colleen Smith does work at the hospital, unlike the Tweet claims.
Label: False

Claim: Alkaline diet protects against the coronavirus.
Explaination: Still no current cure and no medical evidence to support this claim.
Label: False

Claim: Assassination of the Tunisian doctor Mahmoud Bazarti after his announcement of finding a successful vaccine for COVID-19 in Germany.
Explaination: The photo in the claim is a Lebanese doctor called Elbazri. The photo could be found in a post about him on November 21, 2019. He didn't announce anything about a vaccine for COVID-19. There is no tunisian doctor with the name in the claim and there is no news about any successful vaccine ready to use for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: A couple of videos shared this month on Facebook purportedly show recent lootings in shops in South Africa, while the country undergoes a 21-day lockdown to minimize the spread of the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: However, both videos show footage of earlier looting incidents and were already circulating online last year.
Label: False

Claim: Video of Muslims being trained to sneeze purposefully to spread coronavirus.
Explaination: It is an old video. While the first COVID-19 positive case in India was reported on 30 January 2020 in Kerala, the video was found on the internet at least since 29 January 2020 and is being shared in the context of Pakistan. Also, the people in the video were not being trained to spread coronavirus. They are doing a type of ‘Zikr’, a Sufi ritual, which involves body movement and heavy breathing.
Label: False

Claim: Video of a train carrying the trucks with essential goods during the current lockdown in the country. It’s a brilliant idea by Modi’s government.
Explaination: It is an old video. The video is being circulated on the internet at least since 2013. Also, a similar service (Roll on - Roll off (RORO)) is being offered by the Konkan Railway from many years.
Label: False

Claim: Empty hospital lots and waiting rooms are indicative of a coronavirus hoax.
Explaination: No evidence cited, no authorities interviewed and didn't go into hospitals.
Label: False

Claim: A photo of a young boy has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and various websites alongside a claim that it shows a 13-year-old who died after contracting the novel coronavirus in the UK in 2020.
Explaination: The claim is false; the photograph has circulated in reports since 2017 about a teenager who died in Ireland.
Label: False

Claim: “Now, they’re doing tests on airlines — very strong tests — for getting on, getting off. They’re doing tests on trains — getting on, getting off.”
Explaination: The CDC is not testing passengers for COVID-19 as they get on or off airplanes and trains. The federal government is screening certain passengers at 13 airports.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Army deployed in Telangana, India, amid the COVID-19 outbreak.
Explaination: Post claiming army getting deployed in Telangana amidst COVID-19 outbreak is fake. The post is refuted by the Hyderabad Police Commissioner Anjani Kumar and Indian Army.
Label: False

Claim: A video purportedly showing COVID-19 victims in body bags strewn across the floor of a New York hospital was shared several thousand times in multiple languages on social media.
Explaination: The claim is false; the key footage was shot in Ecuador, not Manhattan, and a US healthcare spokeswoman said the allegations amounted to “abhorrent misinformation.”
Label: False

Claim: Video of dead bodies being piled up in Italy due to COVID-19.
Explaination: The video is not of a real-life incident. It is a clip from a 2007 TV series 'Pandemic'.
Label: False

Claim: 59 church congregation in Africa killed after drinking Dettol to prevent coronavirus.
Explaination: A priest in South Africa, Rufus Phala, had indeed told his followers to drink Dettol as a cure. However, the incident occurred in 2016, long before the emergence of the Corona COVID-19 virus in December 2019. Photos used to disseminate the narrative have also been circulating since 2016. In addition, no credible sources were found containing information on the existence of 59 church members in Africa Selatan who died from drinking Dettol because recently asked by Rufus.
Label: False

Claim: Indian Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) issued an order that sharing post about coronavirus on social media groups is a punishable offense.
Explaination: Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) has not declared that posting anything related to coronavirus on social media is a punishable offence. Also, the Press Information Bureau (PIB) has clarified that the Ministry of Home Affairs has not issued any such order.
Label: False

Claim: A hospital with 2200 beds was constructed in Gujarat, India, in just 6 days.
Explaination: A hospital with 2200 beds is not newly constructed in Gujarat for coronavirus patients. In four cities, government has arranged 2200 beds for coronavirus patients in hospitals that were already constructed
Label: FALSE

Claim: Inhaling hot water steam can kill coronavirus.
Explaination: While hot water steam inhalation may provide some temporary relief for the symptoms in some cases like common cold and flu, there is no scientific evidence to suggest that it can kill coronavirus. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) has also clarified the same.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Inhaling hot water steam can kill coronavirus.
Explaination: While hot water steam inhalation may provide some temporary relief for the symptoms in some cases like common cold and flu, there is no scientific evidence to suggest that it can kill coronavirus. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) has also clarified the same.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Image with the narration to claim that a huge number of Muslims were roaming in Beruwala City in Sri Lanka during curfew, risking the lives of many amid COVID-19
Explaination: The image was from a large Muslim procession held in March 2019.
Label: False

Claim: A list of 10 tips to combat coronavirus from the board member of Stanford hospital: COVID-19 patients don’t have a runny nose; drinking hot water can prevent infection with COVID-19.
Explaination: Stanford Health Care denied its board of directors had published this list. All the tips are typical misinformation around COVID-19 which was already debunked by fact-checkers.
Label: False

Claim: Information about a complete quarantine in Guatemala.
Explaination: Those were measures taken by the president of Bolivia, not the president of Guatemala.
Label: False

Claim: Guatemalan Ministry of Health is hiding a COVID-19 case in a hospital in the city of Amatitlán.
Explaination: There wasn't any hidden cases in Amatitlán.
Label: False

Claim: Lemon and bicarbonate heal COVID-19.
Explaination: According to WHO and Ministry of Health, a cure or treatment is yet to be found. Still, a specialist told us that consuming too much bicarbonate can be terrible for people with cardiovascular diseases
Label: False

Claim: A news story by Italian TV RAI proves coronavirus was created in lab by Chinese government.
Explaination: The news story is from 2015 and shows a Chinese study that created a hybrid of the coronavirus affects bats
Label: False

Claim: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, Director-General of the WHO, is against social distancing.
Explaination: A piece of a speech out of context of Mr. Tedros explaining the economic impacts of the social distancing does not mean he is against it.
Label: False

Claim: Claim that there have been tanks in the capital of Latvia, Riga, “while people are staying home.”
Explaination: There is no proof, that there have recently been tanks in Riga.
Label: False

Claim: A publication that affirms the coronavirus was created in the United States to kill elderly people and stop 5G development.
Explaination: A content published by the Kit Radio Internacional blog ensures that COVID-19 was created in a laboratory in Fort Detrick (Maryland, USA) to slow down the development of 5G technology and to kill older people. It's just another conspiracy theory.
Label: False

Claim: Two photos showing notes scattered on a street have been shared hundreds of times on Facebook and YouTube alongside a claim they were taken in Italy during the novel coronavirus pandemic. The posts claim Italians have thrown money out of their homes in a symbolic gesture to highlight that money is futile during the pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the photos have circulated online since at least March 2019 in reports about two separate incidents in Venezuela.
Label: False

Claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in Facebook posts alongside a claim it shows a Sri Lankan doctor who invented a rapid test kit for the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is false; the doctor seen in the video was being interviewed by an Australian television channel to discuss the benefits of rapid COVID-19 testing; the doctor told AFP he was not involved in the development of testing kits.
Label: False

Claim: Indian Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) issued an order that sharing a post about coronavirus on social media groups is a punishable offense.
Explaination: Press Information Bureau (PIB) has clarified that the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) has not issue any order stating that posting anything related to coronavirus on social media is a punishable offence.
Label: False

Claim: A post shared hundreds of times on Facebook claims that Didier Raoult, a French specialist in infectious diseases, is urging Africans “not to take Bill Gates vaccine” against coronavirus as it contains “poison”.
Explaination: This is false: the institute which Raoult directs denied he ever made these claims; moreover, no vaccine yet exists against coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Social media posts shared thousands of times advocate 10 methods to prevent a novel coronavirus infection, citing recommendations allegedly stemming from autopsies on COVID-19 victims, including in China, where the virus first emerged.
Explaination: The advice is misleading; experts say the list includes half-truths and outright falsehoods.
Label: Misleading

Claim: COVID-19 cannot spread in warm countries.
Explaination: The letter cites unknown individuals, and claims that the virus that causes COVID-19 can be fought off by eating chillies and ginger. The letter also claims that the virus can be destroyed at temperatures of 26 to 28 degrees.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 is an airborne disease.
Explaination: The World Health Organization has stated that the disease is primarily spread by contact with infected persons and contaminated surfaces where the virus has settled, rather than through the air.
Label: False

Claim: Queen Elizabeth II is infected with the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Buckingham Palace has only confirmed that Prince Charles is infected with COVID-19. There has never been an official announcement about the Queen.
Label: False

Claim: Italian streets are littered with Euro notes, as Italians throw cash away in coronavirus crisis.
Explaination: Photos showing money littering streets are of old Venezuelan currency dumped by robbers in March 2019.
Label: False

Claim: The video shows Italians praying to get rid of the coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is from Peru and was shot in December 2017 ahead of Peru parliamentary elections.
Label: False

Claim: Video tries to show coronavirus is fake and not dangerous.
Explaination: This is one of many similar conspiracy theories.
Label: False

Claim: The army is patrolling all the streets, towns and villages in Ireland.
Explaination: This is from a clear prank website.
Label: False

Claim: People of Italy throwing money on the streets because it can’t save them from COVID-19.
Explaination: The photos are old, they are not related to the recent COVID-19 outbreak. They were taken in Venezuela, not in Italy. Some people threw the notes as they became valueless due to hyperinflation in the country.
Label: False

Claim: A photo of COVID-19 patients lying on beds in an isolation ward in Pakistan.
Explaination: The photo is two years old and has nothing to do with COVID-19.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Video of Muslims being trained to sneeze purposefully to spread coronavirus.
Explaination: It is an old video. While the first COVID-19 positive case in India was reported on 30 January 2020 in Kerala, the video was found on the internet at least since 29 January 2020 and is being shared as that from Pakistan. Also, the people in the video were not being trained to spread coronavirus. They are doing a type of ‘Zikr’, a Sufi ritual, which involves body movement and heavy breathing.
Label: False

Claim: A video of a Doctor of Mumbai’s Kasturba hospital suggesting tea and hot water to cure COVID-19.
Explaination: The video is not of a Doctor from the Kasturba hospital and there is no evidence that tea and hot water can cure COVID-19.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Coronavirus is caused by 5G.
Explaination: Absolutely no sound evidence that 5G has anything to do with COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Filmmaker Sudhir Mishra getting beaten up by police during the lockdown for stepping out of home.
Explaination: The man getting beaten up by police is not filmmaker Sudhir Mishra.
Label: False

Claim: Breathing steam from boiling citrus peels prevents and cures coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no way to increase your body temperature to kill the coronavirus, according to the WHO. Nigerian medical experts agreed that there was no evidence for the video's claims.
Label: False

Claim: A new alcohol-free sanitizer has been developed by the Dedan Kimathi University in Kenya.
Explaination: The hand sanitizer developed by the Dedan Kimathi University actually contains alcohol.
Label: False

Claim: In Colombia, former Uribista congressman Alfredo Rangel wrote on Twitter some data attributed to the Johns Hopkins University about the new coronavirus, causing the current COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, he said that his lethality “in Colombia is the third lowest in the world, after Chile and Germany” and added that “it is less 10 times than in Italy, 8 times than Spain, 6 than in Iran and 5 than in France “
Explaination: The first part of the sentence is false, because it does not correspond to the data of the mentioned American institution. The second is questionable because, in most cases, the comparison was close to the data available at the time, but the academic authorities in the field consider that this type of analysis is premature.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Dr. Li Wenliang discovered coffee can cure coronavirus.
Explaination: Dr Wenliang didn´t treat patients with COVID-19 and there is no evidence of benefits of coffee or the contrary.
Label: False

Claim: President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya ordered credit reference bureaus to delist Kenyans who had defaulted on loans to protect Kenyans from the economic effects of COVID-19.
Explaination: President Kenyatta ordered the suspension of new listings for Kenyan citizens and businesses as one of the measures in response to COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Photo shows food being distributed to Rwandans during coronavirus lockdown.
Explaination: The photos of piles of bedding and food are not from Rwanda, and have nothing to do with any coronavirus lockdown. They are of goods distributed by a sheikh in the Gambia during Ramadan, in May 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Photo shows Italians prostrating themselves and praying to Allah, during the coronavirus crisis.
Explaination: The photo is from a Christian prayer vigil in Lima, Peru, on the night of 6 and 7 December 2019. It has nothing to do with the coronavirus, and doesn't show Italians converted to Islam.
Label: False

Claim: Food was discarded after Sao Paulo’s governor decree
Explaination: Recording was from February; the state decree, about social distancing and closing non essential services, did not affect the warehouse.
Label: False

Claim: Inhalation of hot steam can kill the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Inhalation of steam from hot water does not kill COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Big Pharma is behind COVID-19 deaths.
Explaination: There is absolutely no evidence the "Big Pharma" companies are behind the virus.
Label: False

Claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim it shows people rioting and looting shops in England during the coronavirus lockdown.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video has circulated online since August 2011 about riots in the British capital of London.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 is a hoax or scapegoat for economic disaster.
Explaination: Came from conspiracy-related source and data and many reports worldwide confirm deaths from coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Amid the coronavirus pandemic, Health Minister of India is playing Ludo.
Explaination: The picture is almost one year old.
Label: False

Claim: World Economic Forum is a “fascist cabal” manipulating coronavirus.
Explaination: This is a conspiracy theory.
Label: False

Claim: CBS aired wrong video footage of a coronavirus hospital.
Explaination: CBS retracted the error, saying it occurred due to editing. Conflated an Italian hospital with a NY one.
Label: False

Claim: Senegalese people flying back from Italy were killed on the spot at the Senegal airport.
Explaination: The video was about the full-scale test on airport security through simulated terrorist attacks at Blaise Diagne International Airport in Senegal on November 28, 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Whether microwaving face masks sanitizes them.
Explaination: Research shows that hydrogen peroxide will kill the virus on masks, but no proof has been found that microwaving kills the novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: An audio clip of Dr. Naresh Trehan cautioning people about the danger of COVID-19 in India.
Explaination: The audio is not of Dr. Trehan, nor has he ever said what is said in this audio recording.
Label: False

Claim: Politician Rahul Gandhi met a coronavirus patient in Waynad.
Explaination: The picture is from 2017.
Label: False

Claim: World Health Organization (WHO) has advised people against eating bakery items amid COVID-19 outbreak.
Explaination: WHO Sri Lanka' has debunked the claim and clarified that WHO hasn't advised people against eating bakery items. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) has also debunked the claim and clarified the same.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A post has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and on messaging app Line that claims Italy suffered a spike in novel coronavirus infections as a direct result of Italian citizens wearing shoes in their homes.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; health experts told AFP that wearing shoes indoors cannot directly cause COVID-19 infections; doctors recommend adopting through personal hygiene routines to lower the risk of COVID-19 infection.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Taking a flu shot causes false positive results on COVID-19 tests.
Explaination: The 2012 study cited in this claim only tested for coronaviruses that cause the common cold, but not COVID-19, which was not discovered until 2019. Furthermore, only one of 69 individuals who had received the flu shot tested positive for coronavirus—a frequency that precludes drawing a causal association between the flu shot and coronavirus detection.
Label: Incorrect

Claim: An ancient Egyptian food consisting of dry Corchorus Olitorius with lemon and garlic can prevent and cure COVID-19.
Explaination: WHO mythbusted that garlic have any therapeutic effect in relation to COVID-19, the person who said the claim came on another show and refuted his own claim by saying it can't cure or prevent COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Official news: in Naples people have used Tocilizumab, a drug that will cure COVID-19.
Explaination: The Italian Healthcare Ministry have authorized experiment to understand whether this drug can be effective against COVID-19 pneumonia. However, this research has not proved anything yet.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple Facebook, Instagram and YouTube posts which claim it shows people in China toppling a 5G tower because of fears that it cause the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video shows pro-democracy protesters toppling a smart lamppost in Hong Kong in August 2019, several months before the novel coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: WHO advisory asks people not to consume bakery items as they get contaminated by coronavirus easily.
Explaination: WHO has not issued any such advisory. Till now, there is no evidence that bakery items get easily contaminated by coronavirus.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Photo with a list of open community dining rooms in Bogotá.
Explaination: A list of community canteens in Bogotá is prowling on social networks, but it does not warn that these are not working in person and also omits the complete list.
Label: False

Claim: Inhalation of steam from hot water kills COVID-19
Explaination: Inhalation of steam from hot water does not kill coronavirus. There is no research conducted to support the same.
Label: False

Claim: A claim that India’s Ministry of Home Affairs has made it a “punishable offense” for citizens to publish posts on social media about the novel coronavirus has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp.
Explaination: The claim is false; India’s official Press Information Bureau said it had made no such law; an online search for the purported government minister who issued the alleged ban yielded no results.
Label: False

Claim: Did Kennedy Center give DNC $5 million after getting relief from coronavirus stimulus?
Explaination: At the time, no government relief funds had even been distributed yet, so it would've been impossible.
Label: False

Claim: An internet publication claimed that telecommunications company MTN is giving free internet data to people living in lockdown areas.
Explaination: MTN Ghana is not giving free internet data to its subscribers in the locked-down communities. The message based on which the story was written is from MTN Nigeria and meant for subscribers in that country.
Label: False

Claim: A photo of a Sri Lankan military hospital has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts alongside a claim that it has been reserved exclusively for the use of “VIPs” who test positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; Sri Lankan military and hospital authorities told AFP that the military hospital and the country's other medical facilities are being prepared for all COVID-19 patients.
Label: Misleading

Claim: As per Aajtak news channel, PM Narendra Modi announced a shutdown of internet services for a week.
Explaination: Screenshot is fake.PM Modi has not announced to shutdown internet services.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 not being blamed for deaths due to unrelated causes.
Explaination: Expert said there is incorrect information in this post.
Label: False

Claim: G-7 countries have asked Modi to lead them in preventing coronavirus.
Explaination: UK Prime Minister, US President and Australian Prime Minister have not asked Modi to lead the G-7 countries in preventing coronavirus disease as stated in the video.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A photo of a Sri Lankan military hospital has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts alongside a claim that it has been reserved exclusively for the use of “VIPs” who test positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; Sri Lankan military and hospital authorities told AFP that the military hospital and the country's other medical facilities are being prepared for all COVID-19 patients.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple Facebook, YouTube and Twitter posts alongside a claim it shows the Islamic call to prayer being heard in Spain during the COVID-19 epidemic for the first time in 500 years.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video was filmed in Azerbaijan in November 2019, before the COVID-19 pandemic; there has been no ban on the Islamic call to prayer in Spain in recent times.
Label: False

Claim: Photos of medicines from the US which will be only given to selected people by the Indian government in the name of COVID-19 treatment to eliminate them.
Explaination: The photos are neither related to India nor the US. The photos were taken at Kota Kinabalu International Airport (Sabha, Malaysia) when the health equipment donated by the Chinese Government reached the airport.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Bollywood actor Shahrukh Khan donated 45 Crore (450 million) rupees to Pakistan.
Explaination: The video is a clipped version of India TV’s fact-check video. In the original fact-check video, India TV has debunked the same claim and concluded that Shahrukh has not made any donation to Pakistan Oil tanker blast victims.
Label: False

Claim: Website offers a rapid test for COVID-19 to check yourself in seconds.
Explaination: The website depend mainly on fever to diagnose COVID-19 even you said you have all other symptoms including dry cough, dyspnea and fatigue. the algorism will still say you are ok and only having the common flu. the good part in the website is that it guide you when you have fever to go to hospital for treatment.
Label: Partially false

Claim: “The Kaaba opened again” or “the Hajj was not stopped.”
Explaination: As such, the Kaaba did not close. On February 27, the official website of the Ministry of health of Saudi Arabia in connection with the spread of the coronavirus in the list of measures taken provides for a temporary suspension of the small pilgrimage. In addition, the Minister of Pilgrimage and Umrah of Saudi Arabia, Mohamed Saleh Benten, officially announced on his Twitter page that the small Hajj has been temporarily suspended. However, residents of the city can get into the mosque.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Video of a heartbreaking story of an Italian/Greek couple. Regardless of the risk of getting infected, a guy took off his protective suit and kissed his fiancee. They both died on March 25.
Explaination: The video is an edited clip of a 2010 Mexican soap drama, Triunfo del amor.
Label: False

Claim: Last week, the Valle del Lili Foundation in Cali summoned a press conference to speak about a “Treatment of infection with coronavirus (COVID-19).” It was “a treatment option through two medications such as: Hydroxychloroquine and Azithromycin, which can rapidly decrease the growth and expansion of the virus in the patient, decrease the possibility of serious illness or respiratory failure, as well as the possibility of contagion to others,” according to the press release.
Explaination: Treatment released by Cali clinic for COVID-19 does not yet have conclusive scientific evidence.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Multiple posts shared hundreds of times on Facebook and Twitter in March 2020 claim a new vaccine and a new drug have been developed to prevent and treat the novel coronavirus. The posts claim the developments were made by scientists in Japan and the Philippines respectively.
Explaination: The claims are misleading; the Japanese government announced in late March 2020 that Japanese scientists were testing a new drug, not a vaccine, to treat COVID-19; the Philippine Food and Drug Administration warned the other drug cited in the misleading posts was "unregistered" and not safe.
Label: Misleading

Claim: WHO announces Algeria outside of danger regarding COVID19.
Explaination: WHO department in Algeria denied this allegations. till 12 april 2020 Algeria is still following lockdown rules like other countries.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Amid COVID-19 pandemic, MP government ordered houses locked from April 1, 2020.
Explaination: MP government has not issued any such order.
Label: False

Claim: Official statement of the Serbian Government claiming that experts recommended to ban pet walks.
Explaination: Experts involved in Crisis Headquarter Fighting against COVID-19 denied Government's claim.
Label: False

Claim: Viral post along with a pictures claims civilian thrashing a policeman during lockdown.
Explaination: The viral photos are three years old and have nothing to do with the coronavirus lockdown.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: CDC recommends that people shave their facial hair to prevent coronavirus.
Explaination: No such recommendations have been made by CDC so far.
Label: False

Claim: A front page article by the Southern Times cautioning against travel to Kenya because of the growing number of cases in Kenya.
Explaination: The Southern Times published a post denouncing the front page, and the image appears to be a doctored version of a previous edition of the paper.
Label: False

Claim: Russia released lions in the streets forcing people to quarantine.
Explaination: The photo is originally from a lion that was used to record a movie in South Africa in 2016, while the fake headline was created in a meme generator.
Label: False

Claim: The number of COVID-19 cases we hear about is fake.
Explaination: Many of the statements in the video are false or exaggerated.
Label: False

Claim: A Facebook user attributed a post to ex-President Mahama, saying he will not donate his money to support COVID-19 fight.
Explaination: Former President John Dramani Mahama has NOT said he will not donate towards the fight against coronavirus. On the contrary, he has already made donations to the Greater Accra Regional Hospital (GARH) to help fight COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Sao Paulo governor’s decree artificially raises the number of COVID-19 deaths.
Explaination: After the president questioned the number of deaths in São Paulo related to the pandemic of the new coronavirus, groups spread falsely that a change on death certificate procedures would cause it.
Label: False

Claim: A video says that a Japanese doctor has proven that coronavirus is airborne. Therefore, it’s critical to wear face masks.
Explaination: The video was originally from the special program of Japanese national broadcasting service, NHK, on March 22. The program presented the experiment suggesting the transmission through aerosols, but it didn't say that coronavirus is airborne. Through the expert brought up the possibility of aerosols causing cluster infection in the program, he also emphasized that keeping proper ventilation can reduce the transmission.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: Whether CDC had scheduled announcement that all should wear masks for everyday life.
Explaination: At the time, the CDC confirmed they had nothing scheduled.
Label: False

Claim: If Florida banned alcohol sales due to coronavirus.
Explaination: Story came from a prank news generator.
Label: False

Claim: French State approved a medical protocol with Plaquenil, lopinavir/ritonavir to cure COVID-19, which is more expensive than Pr. Raoult’s protocol with chloroquine.
Explaination: The authorities didn't approved this protocol, even if those medicines are currently tested, and the prizes comparisons between the two protocols are misleading.
Label: False

Claim: As per the video, Bollywood actor Aamir Khan donated 250 crore to fight aganist COVID-19.
Explaination: The video is six years old.
Label: False

Claim: Global temperature, CO2 in atmosphere and ozone hole has decreased in two months of quarantine.
Explaination: Ozone layer has improved steadily since 1987 when Montreal Protocol was signed but in 2020 scientists discovered a increase in the North Pole hole. At the other hand, nor Co2 nor temperature has decreased but air pollution, but the image doesn't picture that.
Label: False

Claim: A comparison of the evolution of the coronavirus in Argentina and Chile.
Explaination: Specialists indicated that the data in the post is not enough to compare objectively the evolution of the pandemic in each country.
Label: Misleading

Claim: COVID-19 affects mainly people with type A blood (group II).
Explaination: The articles refer to the Medrxiv website, which can not serve as a reliable source of scientific knowledge, and the figures in the study itself are very controversial and it is impossible to draw a final conclusion from them.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The WHO amended its guideline: Coronavirus can travel in aerosols and is infectious in the air for eight hours. Everyone must wear a face mask no matter where they are.
Explaination: WHO recommended medical personnel to wear N95 respirators to prevent the transmission through aerosols on March 29, but WHO didn't say that coronavirus is infectious in air for 8 hours, and didn't suggest everyone to wear a face mask.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Italian PM said that the country has surrendered to the COVID-19 pandemic
Explaination: The quote attributed to Italian PM is made up.
Label: False

Claim: Surin Province governor in Thailand revealed that 100,000 people are infected.
Explaination: The shared clip was trimmed from an original (about speculation and situation) to made people believe that actual patient is 100000.
Label: False

Claim: If you don’t wear a mask while driving, police will fine you 200 baht.
Explaination: Police insisted that no such policy to fine people not wearing a mask.
Label: False

Claim: Video clip shows people keep leaving Phuket.
Explaination: It's not in Phuket. It's actually a news from Thailand-Myanmar border in the north. And they are Myanmar labour who wanted to go to their home country.
Label: False

Claim: The medical authorities ask people to leave their groceries outside and disinfect everything with bleach.
Explaination: The medical authorities named in the post say it's fake.
Label: False

Claim: A Facebook user made a post saying that “Ghana has recorded 1,500 cases of coronavirus.”
Explaination: Ghana has not recorded 1,500 coronavirus cases. A total of 137 cases had been confirmed as at the time the claim was made – March 27, 2020. The country currently has 152 confirmed cases of coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Images shows how Indian police have beaten up migrant workers amid India’s lockdown for commuting
Explaination: All the images are old and unrelated to the ongoing COVID-19 Lockdown.
Label: False

Claim: Whether coronavirus began with man having sex with a bat.
Explaination: This came from a clear satire website as fake.
Label: False

Claim: Whether countries with high rates of childhood vaccines were hit hardest by coronavirus.
Explaination: Some of the countries with the lowest spread of the virus are those that have higher vaccination rates than the United States.
Label: False

Claim: If Queen Elizabeth II tested positive for coronavirus.
Explaination: Buckingham Palace gave statement confirming she was in good health.
Label: False

Claim: NY banned cigarette sales because of the coronavirus.
Explaination: Gov. Andrew Cuomo's team told Lead Stories that he is not about to announce a six-week ban on cigarette sales to help curb the death rate from COVID-19, which has devastated the state.
Label: False

Claim: As per the news of Aajtak, Home Minister Amit Shah tested postive for COVID-19.
Explaination: Aajtak didn't telecast such news.
Label: False

Claim: Fire triggered by gas tanker leak near Delhi’s Shahdara Mor.
Explaination: Video is not from Delhi but Lahore's Shahdara Mor in Pakistan.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Images of migrant labourers beaten by the police on highways during the current national lockdown.
Explaination: The images are not related to any recent incident. The image on the left is found to exist on the internet at least since July 2019 and the other image is of an incident in Bangladesh in 2017.
Label: False

Claim: A claim that 500 body bags were delivered to an ice skating rink outside the Australian city of Adelaide has been shared widely on Facebook during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; South Australian health authorities said the claim is a “myth” and a spokesperson for the local ice rink said “the rumour is completely false”.
Label: False

Claim: Israel has the best situation in the world in the face of the coronavirus pandemic without isolation measures.
Explaination: The country keeps some isolation measures active and does not have the 'best situation in the world' in the face of the pandemic.
Label: False

Claim: In Spain, the police came to encourage doctors to work after they gave up and wanted to quit.
Explaination: The video is taken in front of the Puerta del Mar Hospital in Spain and the police did come to encourage medical staff to continue their great work. There is no news about surrendering from doctors of this hospital or any other hospital in Spain.
Label: Partly false

Claim: Video post claiming that inhaling traditional appetizer salt with limestone can cure a COVID-19 infection.
Explaination: Currently there is no medicine/Vaccine to cure or prevent COVID-19 as per WHO, also Dr. Myo Thant-deputy director general of Yangon region’ public confirms the mentioned claims on COVID-19 cure to be false.
Label: False

Claim: Image of a mother unable to feed her suckling as she battles COVID-19.
Explaination: The image is of a 35 year old woman comforting her daughter at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center in Seattle, Washington.
Label: False

Claim: Image of COVID-19 infected Indonesian doctor Hadio Ali watching his daughters from a distance as he bids them final goodbye; the image is said to be posted by his wife.
Explaination: The Image posted is of a Malaysian doctor posted by one of his relatives, and the doctor is alive and healthy.
Label: False

Claim: Italian president said that Italy has surrendered to the coronavirus.
Explaination: Neither the Italian Prime Minister or President have stated that Italy has surrendered to the virus. We even cross checked with Italian fact checkers.
Label: False

Claim: An image poster states Indian religious leader Mata Amritanandamayi has hidden foreigners in her hermitage and has not allowed them to be tested.
Explaination: FactCrescendo contacted the relevant officials who have dismissed the allegations calling it a motivated campaign against the Hermitage.
Label: False

Claim: Images of the medical facility shared with the claim that the Indian Army set up a 1,000-bed hospital in Rajasthan during the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: Upon investigation, we found out that all the images were old and two of them were not even from India. One is from the US and another is from Germany. Even the Indian Army clarified on Twitter that such claims are baseless.
Label: False

Claim: In Sri Lanka, Sathosa Supermarket trucks bearing the image of former PM Mahinda Rajapaksa are being used to distribute food during current COVID-19 curfew. Text condemns the act by mentioning how ethical is it to carry out such acts during this difficult time and gain political advantage.
Explaination: 2014 Images of Sathosa Lorries with PM Mahinda Rajapaksha portrayed as recent vehicles used to distribute food during curfew. Newspaper which carried original image published a disclaimer.
Label: False

Claim: An audio clip is circulating on Whatsapp claiming that Nagpur (Second Capital of Indian state Maharashtra) has tested 59 positive coronavirus cases including three doctors.
Explaination: We found that there are only 4 positive coronavirus cases in Nagpur. The district administration and Nagpur Municipal Corporation have denied such rumors. Divisional Commissioner of Nagpur said the administration would take stern action against such rumor mongers. We also spoke with Deputy Commissioner who informed the same.
Label: False

Claim: A post with a photo claiming that an Italian mother, suffering from COVID-19, hugs her baby
Explaination: The viral image is an old image, The mother is suffering from cancer and was clicked post her radiotherapy when she could not hug her child.
Label: False

Claim: Photo posts claim a person is committing suicide by jumping from a building in Italy, a doctor couple in an Italian hospital a few hours before their death and chaos in an Italian hospital amid COVID-19.
Explaination: The first image is from Spain where a woman committed suicide in December 2019, The second image is of a couple at the Barcelona airport and the third image is from recent earthquake in Croatia.
Label: False

Claim: A letter supposedly written by Bill Gates where he says that the coronavirus is the corrector of humanity.
Explaination: The letter supposedly written by Bill Gates in which he says that the coronavirus has a "spiritual purpose", that it is "the great corrector" and that "it is here to teach us some lessons that it seems we have forgotten". There is no evidence that Bill Gates is the author of this letter: he has not said anything similar in the latest public statements and the people who claim this provide no evidence of it.
Label: False

Claim: Vladimir Putin dropped lions in the streets to force the Russians to stay at home.
Explaination: A picture of a lion in the street went viral, but the animal has nothing to do with coronavirus or Russia.
Label: False

Claim: An image has been shared hundreds of times in multiple posts on Facebook alongside a claim that shows a poster issued by activist group Extinction Rebellion stating “Corona is the cure, humans are the disease.”
Explaination: The claim is false; Extinction Rebellion said that the image was published by an unaffiliated Twitter account and that the poster’s message in “no way” represents the global environmental movement’s “principles and values”.
Label: False

Claim: Numerous conspiracy theories shared on and off social media claim that 5G mobile networks are the cause of the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: This is false; experts told AFP that 5G is based on radio frequency and that this does not create viruses.
Label: False

Claim: A vaccine for coronavirus has been found.
Explaination: Is not a vaccine, is a test of antibodies.
Label: False

Claim: There is no space in the hospitals in Italy because people are crowding outside.
Explaination: The claim with the pictures is false. While these photos are both real and recent, they are actually from Croatia’s capital Zagreb, which was rocked by a powerful earthquake on 22 March.
Label: False

Claim: An Indian politician claimed that the strain of coronavirus in India is a less virulent mutation.
Explaination: Experts and doctors have denied this claim and said that there is no such study which corroborates the information provided by the politician in his tweet.
Label: Misleading

Claim: An audio that says that MMS or sodium chlorite cures the coronavirus in 24 hours.
Explaination: An audio by Isidro Fuentes García, alleged biologist, and a video by Josep Pamiès, fined by the Generalitat of Cataluña for promoting pseudo therapies to cure diseases, is going viral. In it he advises the MMS or sodium chlorite as a solution in 24 hours against the coronavirus. There is no evidence that works against COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Viral WhatsApp audio message claims President Buhari and his chief of staff flew out of the country for coronavirus treatment.
Explaination: Credible sources from the presidency clarify that Abba Kyari who tested positive for COVID-19 is in Lagos for treatment. As regarding the President, no credible reports suggest he is infected with the novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Demon creature flying above a church in Italy.
Explaination: This is an old video created digitally using VFX created by an Animation studios.
Label: False

Claim: Decathlon’s snorkeling masks are used in hospitals to help patients’ breathing.
Explaination: The idea came from Italy where a doctor contacted a 3D printer and the sports brand to adapt masks to the respirators. The company shared the 3D plans of her masks, but remains very cautious about the outcome of such an innovation.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Photos of patients and medical beds on the street showing the situation in Italian hospitals.
Explaination: These viral photos of medical beds and patients on the streets do not show Italy suffering from coronavirus, but Croatia, after the earthquake on March 22.
Label: False

Claim: Why you should not take seriously this card on the efficacy of chloroquine.
Explaination: Datas of the card are not accurate. Some are obsolete for days and some for years.
Label: False

Claim: A message from the CHU in Mans (hospital in France) presenting alarmist arguments to encourage French people to stay home.
Explaination: CHU Le Mans denied having written such a message. Arguments in the message are false or unfounded.
Label: False

Claim: Pictures of people stranded on hospital beds claimed to be Italians not coping with the pressures of COVID-19 cases; India should learn from Italy’s mistakes and not step out of the house in the 21-day lockdown
Explaination: The images were from the earthquake that hit Croatia on March 22, 2020 and were falsely shared as Italy.
Label: False

Claim: A picture claims that an Italian man committed suicide after his whole family succumbed to COVID-19
Explaination: The image is of a woman committing suicide in Spain in December 2019. BOOM could not establish what drove the woman to take such a step.
Label: False

Claim: Reliance Jio, one of the biggest telecom networks in India, is providing Internet for free during the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: A spokesperson from the company denied any such schemes and the link in the messages were linked to scamming websites.
Label: False

Claim: Videos showing police detaining COVID-19 patients in India.
Explaination: These were mock drills that were conducted by the UP Police to determine the preparedness of the public with regards to COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: An image with human body figurines in a bowl that claims China is serving human baby soup in its restaurants.
Explaination: The image is of an art installation to raise awareness about the rampant killing of sharks.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A herd of deer flocking out in Tamil Nadu, India, due to the coronavirus lockdown.
Explaination: The image is originally from Japan and was taken in 2014. It shows the Nara deers that are considered to be auspicious flanking the streets of Nara.
Label: False

Claim: A 48-year-old man, unemployed because of the COVID-19 crisis, attempted suicide in São Paulo.
Explaination: São Paulo state officers reported that no such case occurred. Photo was from 2017.
Label: False

Claim: Augusto Heleno, Brazilian general, was cured from the COVID-19 infection using chloroquine.
Explaination: Augusto Heleno denied he had taken chloroquine for his COVID-19. He tested positive last week, but returned to work only seven days later.
Label: False

Claim: Hospitals don’t allow parents to visit children with COVID-19 in the hospital.
Explaination: Hospital policies have become generally more restrictive, but pediatric patients are still allowed visits by at least one parent.
Label: False

Claim: This chart shows the current cases in Turkey.
Explaination: The chart shows the quarantined people coming from abroad.
Label: False

Claim: The outbreak was discussed in the German Bundestag back in 2012.
Explaination: The report discussed in the Bundestag was about a possible outbreak and how Germany can be prepared. The possible coronavirus outbreak was also foreseen by scientists.
Label: False

Claim: Putin sent lions into the streets to discourage people from going out.
Explaination: The photo dates back to 2016 and taken in Johannesburg during a movie shooting.
Label: False

Claim: The Portuguese government has spent much more than the acceptable price for ventilators.
Explaination: It's false that the Portuguese government has spent much more than would be acceptable buying the ventilators. The prices are aligned with market prices.
Label: False

Claim: Supposed quote from the Argentinian president alerting that government aid was going to be removed from those who violated the quarantine.
Explaination: The quote is fake and the disinformation was created by a joke generator website.
Label: False

Claim: Putin enters a meeting with his ministries wearing the full yellow suit used by quarantine doctors to protect themselves against catching COVID-19.
Explaination: The original photo is from Putin's visit to a quarantined hospital where COVID-19 patient are treated not from a meeting with his ministries.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus did not reach the Chinese cities of Beijing and Shanghai, as well as Russia and North Korea.
Explaination: The virus spread to Beijing and Shanghai in January, Russia had its first cases in February, while North Korea's claim of being coronavirus-free is largely contested.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Dead bodies of coronavirus patients are being discarded in mass graves in Italy, according to a 23-second video clip that has gone viral on social media.
Explaination: The video clip was from the US miniseries Pandemic released in 2007.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows bodies on the streets saying that this is the current situation in Italy.
Explaination: The scenes in the video is from the 2007 movie Pandemic, which talks about the spread of bird flu in Los Angeles.
Label: False

Claim: The viral video claims mass graves are in Italy.
Explaination: The viral video is part of a TV series called Pandemic. The viral scene is not from Italy.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: There are 59 positive coronavirus cases in Nagpur along with three doctors, one of whom is on ventilator.
Explaination: There are 5 coronavirus cases in Nagpur as of March 26. None of them is a doctor.
Label: False

Claim: Prince Charles is infected with coronavirus after meeting Indian singer Kanika Kapoor.
Explaination: Viral pictures of Kanika Kapoor meeting Prince Charles are old.
Label: False

Claim: North Korean president has ordered to shoot the first coronavirus patient in his country.
Explaination: There is no credible media report which claims that North korea has ordered to shoot its first coronavirus patient.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: The Ministry for Economic Development has summoned Italians to avoid sharing videos on Whatsapp, due to overcharging issues given by working from home during the COVID-19 emergency.
Explaination: There is no evidence of such a statement from the Italian authorities.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A beautiful Italian nurse has died because of coronavirus.
Explaination: The fake-makers have used the picture of an actress (also, musician and writer) Sasha Grey. They claim her to be a nurse who died of exhaustion after three days of continuous work, which is false.
Label: False

Claim: An image of Indian Home Minister Amit Shah visiting COVID-19 patients.
Explaination: A 2015 picture of the then BJP president visiting hospitals in Madhya Pradesh shared with a false narrative.
Label: False

Claim: An image with human body figurines in a bowl that claims China is serving human baby soup in its restaurants.
Explaination: The image is of an art installation to raise awareness about the rampant killing of sharks.
Label: False

Claim: An image of a purported CNN broadcast shared thousands of times in multiple social media posts claims Nigeria’s President Muhammadu Buhari and his chief of staff Abba Kyari tested positive for the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: While Kyari has indeed tested positive for the virus, there is no evidence to support the claim that Buhari was infected with COVID-19. The picture of the alleged broadcast was fabricated using another screenshot of a CNN show.
Label: False

Claim: Illuminati controlled U.S. government; coronavirus caused by 5G.
Explaination: No evidence for either claim. COVID-19 is in places without 5G.
Label: False

Claim: President Trump did sign a 5G bill but exposure effects are misleading.
Explaination: No clear evidence that exposure of 5G at the current recommended levels are harmful long term.
Label: False

Claim: Malaysia dismissed residents outside the home with drones that shoot fireworks.
Explaination: The events in the video are part of the action carried out by a Brazilian influencer, Lucas Albert. The video was uploaded on Instagram on July 14, 2019, before the Corona COVID-19 virus was first reported in Wuhan, China, in December 2019. Even in the original video, there was no Malay-speaking male voice asking people to disperse.
Label: False

Claim: Photo of Italian PM Giuseppe Conte who cried for regretting the late lockdown.
Explaination: The photo is a photo of Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro who gave a speech during an evangelical service at the Planalto Palace on December 17, 2019.
Label: False

Claim: The UN is providing food aid to South American countries due to the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The UN office at Colombia has warned that a WhatsApp hoax claiming the UN would be providing food aid is false. A version of the same hoax was debunked by the UN office at Paraguay.
Label: False

Claim: China got prepared to contain the virus and let the whole population get infected.
Explaination: An audio claimed that China’s strategy was to infect the whole population with COVID-19. However, one of China’s main measures was to keep quarantined almost half of its population, according to New York Times estimates, in order to control and stop the spread of infections. The WHO praised the measure.
Label: False

Claim: Paraguay’s Ministry of Health is not following up people who are related to confirmed cases of coronavirus.
Explaination: An audio claimed that the Ministry of Health does not follow up people who have been related to confirmed cases of coronavirus. The Ministry does have a public plan that lays out that they have to keep a eye on those people. The plan states that their records should be kept and that they should be monitored. If a person show symptoms, they must be tested. If not, he has to remain quarantined.
Label: False

Claim: Ireland is in the first phase of a lockdown sequence.
Explaination: Ireland has introduced measures to restrict the spread of COVID-19 but it is not a lockdown and there is no evidence to suggest that the government is considering a lockdown. The Irish PM has said that Ireland is following the South Korea model of social distancing, social isolation and contact tracing, and this does not include the locking down of the country.
Label: False

Claim: On March 25, French scientist successfully tested a vaccine against COVID-19.
Explaination: Although the title said vaccines, the story was about a French research (published on March 17) on hydroxychloroquine, which is not a vaccine.
Label: False

Claim: Health authorities recommend shaving your beard during the COVID-19 crisis.
Explaination: Only people who need to use respirators should shave. That's because the beard can alter the positioning of the mask, which allows air to reach the mouth and the nose directly (thus, making the respirator itself useless)
Label: False

Claim: A publication by Pearls news says 15 Nigerian senators have tested positive for COVID-19.
Explaination: No Nigerian senator has tested positive for coronavirus, not according to the NCDC or any credible news platform. The Nigerian Centre for Disease Control remains the number one source on all updates to confirmed COVID-19 cases in the country.
Label: False

Claim: A blog site claimed Kogi State Governor in Nigeria, Yahaya Bello, tested positive with COVID-19.
Explaination: There are no reports by the Nigerian Centre for Disease Control to corroborate the claim. Not to mention, Yahaya Bello, himself released a video debunking the claim. Moreover, the report format lacks credibility with no discernable details or source present.
Label: False

Claim: Image of TV reporter in hazmat suit is proof media is “fabricating” panic.
Explaination: Reporter was using hazmat suit to illustrate a report about local production of suits.
Label: Partially false

Claim: 232 children died from COVID-19 in Italy in just one day.
Explaination: Italian Ministry of Health didn't report any cases of deaths of people under 30 years old.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 can be read on a tank car image taken in 2019.
Explaination: Field Guide for Tank Cars does not let the arbitrary titling. The owner of the cars also denied.
Label: False

Claim: CDC announces thennew coronavirus can survive on surfaces for up to 17 days.
Explaination: The report on CDC's website was not about the survival period of SARS-CoV-2. Researchers wrote they found RNA traces of the virus, not infectious viral load.
Label: False

Claim: Turkey map on Wikipedia shows the provinces in which COVID-19 cases are diagnosed.
Explaination: Metadata of the map shows that the data collected from unverified local media news. Turkey does not announce the cases by provinces so far.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows Italians drinking chrism together against the outbreak.
Explaination: The video is recorded in Romania not in Italy. It can be detected the flag and the statue in the video.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows Turkish citizens leaving food packets on the road for the poor during the outbreak.
Explaination: The video recorded on 25th of Jan, 2020 and the aid for the earthquake victims in Elazığ. There was no cases in Turkey in that time.
Label: False

Claim: Spanish doctor says they give the ventilators to younger people.
Explaination: The man in the video is not a doctor. Triage in Spain is not just based on age but the probability of survival.
Label: False

Claim: Viral WhatsApp message claims Netflix is ​giving free passes to their platform during this period of isolation.
Explaination: It is customary for a streaming service such as Netflix to give a free trial of 30 days, after which the subscriber is billed. The streaming giant, however, is not hosting any such bonanza. More so, the service is planning to actually reduce video quality owing to the internet spike in a bid to prevent downtime. It hence would be counterproductive to open the service to a host of more users. Also, the site in question was flagged by a security module as a “deceptive site”.
Label: False

Claim: Image of police punishing people in Indian state of Assam for violating the curfew.
Explaination: While there are reports which suggest that the police is taking action against people in India for violating the orders, this picture is from Pakistan and not Assam.
Label: PARTLY TRUE

Claim: Pakistan’s leading scholar Mufti Naeem suffers from coronavirus. A few days ago, he refused to close madrasas and mosques.
Explaination: According to Pakistani media outlets Mufti Naeem was admitted to the hospital due to heart disease.
Label: False

Claim: Indian Singer Kanika Kapoor met Prince Charles, after which he tested positive for coronavirus.
Explaination: Contrary to the claim, the viral image is not recent but from 2015, when the singer attended the Elephant Family charity ‘Travels to my Elephants’, hosted by Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall.
Label: False

Claim: Italian doctor couple diagnosed with coronavirus.
Explaination: The couple was spotted and clicked by an Associated Press (AP) photographer Emilio Morenatti nearly two weeks ago.
Label: False

Claim: An open letter from Bill Gates: The Microsoft founder believes there is a spiritual purpose behind the disease.
Explaination: Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has denied publishing that letter. The sun, the media which ran a story about the story of Gates'' letter, had removed the story and apologized for the incident.
Label: False

Claim: A U.S. railway car has carried the word “COVID-19”
Explaination: The image was manipulated.
Label: False

Claim: The University of Barcelona will approve its students if classes are suspended for more than a month.
Explaination: The image shared was a screenshot of the university official webpage that was manipulated.
Label: False

Claim: “Food contribution” campaign using the UN logo.
Explaination: The UN has denied this information through its headquarters in Colombia.
Label: False

Claim: Chlorine dioxide cures the coronavirus.
Explaination: Its consumption is dangerous and it is an illegal medicine in Spain.
Label: False

Claim: Prime Minister of Mexico with tears in his eyes says to all the people: We have lost the battle against the coronavirus.
Explaination: Although the situation in Italy itself is serious, the government has not made such a statement. In addition, the person who appears in the photograph is Bolsonaro.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Uber suspends night services in Kenya.
Explaination: Uber has responded to the post online saying that its services were still available to users after 7pm in Kenya, and had not been suspended as claimed.
Label: False

Claim: Compounds in tea can help cure COVID-19.
Explaination: Methylxanthine, theobromine and theophylline, which are found in tea, are good for health and airway management, but cannot cure COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: A treatment for COVID-19 will be manufactured in Uganda.
Explaination: The treatment is actually conventional sanitizer, and will be produced by a company already producing hand and surface sanitizer.
Label: False

Claim: A picture showing dead Italian doctors in an operating theater after succumbing to COVID-19.
Explaination: The picture showing doctors on the floor of an operating room is actually from an episode of Grey's Anatomy.
Label: False

Claim: Nairobi Governor Mike Sonko has donated 58 million shillings for COVID-19 response.
Explaination: The governor has not made any such donation, and the County Government has also stated that the claim is false.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus remains on the asphalt for nine days.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence to show that the coronavirus remains on the floor for 9 days.
Label: False

Claim: Cigarette smoke spreads the coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence that proves the cigarette smoke can spread coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: A new outbreak pandemic of hantavirus is coming from China.
Explaination: Hantavirus is not a new virus, and is not transmitted from person to person. In Europe it usually causes a disease that has less than 0.5% case fatality.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: Purchases of health products and health councils are taking advantage of the “hook” of the COVID-19 disease to sell online cures that are not endorsed by any official organization.
Explaination: A compilation of "miracle" products that are being announced in social media to cure COVID-19 and are not aprobbed by any medical or gubernamental institutions. Most of them are scams.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: An audio states that the worst coronavirus crisis in Spain will start on 3/29/20.
Explaination: We consulted experts to find out if the audio was real, although there were versions with different dates. Doctors say it is impossible to know when there will be a peak and they are confident in current containment measures.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: A publication on Facebook assures that it is confirmed that “the [Spanish] president and the three vice presidents are ill with COVID-19 and assures that the king must close the Parliament, dissolve the Cortes and take political and military control of the country.”
Explaination: The only Spanish vice president who has tested positive for COVID-19 is Nadia Calviño and the Constitution does not grant the King the power to dissolve the Spanish government in the face of this catastrophe.
Label: False

Claim: Countries that use nivaquine (chloroquine) against malaria are not affected by coronavirus.
Explaination: Nivaquine is prescribed in other countries, including France where there is coronavirus, and COVID-19 affects many more states than those indicated on the maps.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: In France, the state pays 46 billions a year for its army, but only 1 billion for its inhabitants’ health.
Explaination: It's the opposite : the state spends much more on health than on its army.
Label: False

Claim: You can get coronavirus from makeup and creams.
Explaination: No proofs about it in the new WHO Q&A.
Label: False

Claim: Did an American die because he self-administered chloroquine ?
Explaination: In Arizona a man died after ingesting chloroquine phosphate on self-medication. He had the idea after listening to a speech by Donald Trump about chloroquine efficiency against COVID-19.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The internet can crash because of a lockdown.
Explaination: Experts and internet companies assure that the network can handle an increasing traffic. However, extending the lockdown as well as closing the borders could make it more difficult to maintain and to repair the network.
Label: False

Claim: Mosquitoes can spread the coronavirus.
Explaination: The World Health Organization (WHO) and the French Ministry of Health have been very clear : no, the mosquito does not transmit the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: After dealing with 134 patients, an Italian doctor couple took off their masks and stared at each other from the bottom of their hearts. Both died later.
Explaination: The photo is a couple kissing at Barcelona airport on March 12.
Label: False

Claim: A video circulating on WhatsApp about a COVID-19 patient escaping from an hospital in Costa Rica.
Explaination: The patient didn't have COVID-19 and didn't escape.
