Label: False

Claim: A publication claiming the city of San José in Costa Rica has created mass graves for COVID-19 victims.
Explaination: Authorities denied such a construction work.
Label: False

Claim: Indian Government snooping messages over social media and all social media platforms will be monitored for COVID-19 messages
Explaination: The message mentions a fake ministry of internal regulation that does not exist in the country.
Label: False

Claim: Pakistani doctor Osama Riaz’s last message for you (while taking his last breath).
Explaination: The video is not of the Pakistani doctor who died but of another doctor from the UK who tested positive and is going to be discharged soon.
Label: False

Claim: Last photo of Indonesian doctor Hadio Ali standing away from his family before he passed away from COVID-19
Explaination: The picture is of a Malaysian doctor not infected by COVID-19 but who is treating COVID-19 patients in Malaysia and this was him before he left for duty.
Label: False

Claim: Leave objects in the sun to avoid contracting the coronavirus.
Explaination: There’s no evidence that sunlight can kill the coronavirus. Experts say ultraviolet light in the sun isn't strong enough.
Label: False

Claim: Streaming apps Netflix and Amazon Prime give free subscriptions during COVID-19 outbreak in India.
Explaination: The websites were phishing and spamming websites while the streaming apps have not declared any such free plans. A parody account portraying to be Indian news wire agency, ANI shared the sites stating free plans till April 31 while April has only 30 days.
Label: False

Claim: Indian Army has built a 1,000-bed quarantine facility for COVID-19.
Explaination: The Indian army called out this claim to be false and BOOM also found that all the three images were unrelated to each other.
Label: False

Claim: An image of a couple claimed to be doctors who have lost their lives to the coronavirus.
Explaination: The picture is an AFP picture of a couple at the Barcelona airport after US President Donald Trump informed that US was banning travel from the EU.
Label: False

Claim: The WHO is offering monetary help to buy medicines and food during the emergency.
Explaination: It's not true that WHO is offering monetary help. It's a technical institution, said representatives contacted for this verification.
Label: False

Claim: The application of menthol ointment in the nostrils helps to prevent the virus.
Explaination: There's no evidence that menthol ointment could prevent the contagion with coronavirus, according the physicians consulted and information spread by WHO and FDA on the prevention of COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: In a WhatsApp chain from workers of Argentina’s most important lab that is testing for coronavirus, they advised not to leave the house because the next two weeks will be the infection peak.
Explaination: The lab workers denied the message came from them. Many of the claims included in the chain were denied by specialists.
Label: False

Claim: A message sent by WhatsApp states that the Ministry of Defense of China has announced that it has “successfully” developed a vaccine against the new coronavirus, which causes COVID-19 disease. Portugal would receive the first doses in a few days.
Explaination: It is a fraudulent message that is being sent on behalf of the National Health Service, full of false information, especially regarding vaccines that are due to arrive in Portugal
Label: False

Claim: The Italians accept Islam en masse.
Explaination: In fact, the video used in the fake was taken during a protest in Germany, in the center of Hamburg, held on January 11, 2020. The action was aimed at the oppression of the Muslim Uighur minority in China.
Label: False

Claim: The Brazilian singer Preta Gil was infected with COVID-19 and performed to more than 320,000 people.
Explaination: When the singer performed to 320 thousand people, on March 1, she was not infected with the new coronavirus. She started feeling ill on March 11 and tested positive on March 13. Since then, she has been in quarantine.
Label: False

Claim: Several photographs published on Facebook claim to portray coffins with victims of the new coronavirus in Italy.
Explaination: The pictures were taken in april 2009, after an earthquake in L'Aquila, that killed 308 people.
Label: False

Claim: A message in an image claims that drinking coffee can help prevent the new coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence to support this theory. Health authorities have never made this connection an it.
Label: False

Claim: Over 200 doctors in Italy die every day due to coronavirus.
Explaination: The total number of doctors in Italy who died due to the coronavirus is 66 as of Thursday, April 2.
Label: False

Claim: Italian people in the streets surrendering and bidding farewell to the world after COVID-19.
Explaination: The original video is from an Italian protest against the far-right on Nov 18 2019.
Label: False

Claim: A photo of a fleet of blue lorries bearing the image of Sri Lankan Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa has been shared repeatedly on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that the lorries were distributing food during the novel coronavirus curfew.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; the photo in fact shows lorries that were used in a political initiative in 2014, more than five years before the coronavirus pandemic. Rajapaksa’s office also denied the claim, saying that authorities are pursuing legal action against those spreading the “false information”.
Label: False

Claim: Images of patients treated in the open are from Italy as it has run out of hospital beds.
Explaination: The images are from Croatia after it was hit by an earthquake on March 22.
Label: False

Claim: While coronavirus tests in other countries are conducted for free or at nominal charges, in India, it costs Rs 4,500
Explaination:
In India, coronavirus tests are free in government labs. Private labs charge more in India, as well as in other countries
.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Thanks to the halt imposed by the government to travel boats for COVID-19, a crocodile has shown up in Venice’s canals.
Explaination: The picture has been manipulated. There has never been a crocodile swimming in Venice.
Label: False

Claim: The government has mandated by decree a salary cut for high public officials.
Explaination: The government has never approved such a measure.
Label: False

Claim: This news bulletin from 2015 proves that COVID-19 was created in a laboratory of Wuhan.
Explaination: The news bulletin from 2015 was reporting on an experiment regarding a coronavirus created in a laboratory. However, this virus has nothing to do with COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Facebook user asserted that U.S. President Donald Trump has announced a vaccine for COVID-19.
Explaination: The President of America, Donald Trump, has not announced the launch of a COVID-19 vaccine. The photo attached to the text is not a vaccine, but a COVID-19 test kit manufactured by Sugentech in South Korea. There is no known vaccine yet for the COVID-19 virus.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus has a pH level of 5.5 to 8.5 and can be prevented and cured by eating alkaline foods.
Explaination: There is no evidence that the new coronavirus which causes COVID-19 has a unique pH level. And the study referred to in the claim had nothing to do with this particular virus - it was published in 1991, long before the emergence of the new virus.
Label: False

Claim: A purported notice issued by the Pakistan Red Crescent and Pakistan’s Health Department on COVID-19 isolation rules has been shared thousands of times on Facebook. The advisory claims that families of those killed while in isolation will not be able to hold funerals or burials for them
Explaination: The claim is false; the Pakistan Red Crescent denied issuing such a statement, and Pakistan’s health authority does allow funerals for those killed by the novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: An “open letter” purportedly written by US billionaire and philanthropist Bill Gates about the novel coronavirus pandemic has been shared in English and Chinese on Facebook, Twitter and various websites. The Chinese-language posts state the letter was translated from its original publication in British newspaper The Sun.
Explaination: But the letter is fake; Gates’ philanthropic organisation, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, clarified on Weibo that the letter presents “false information” and urged netizens to stop sharing it. The Sun has reportedly removed the letter from its website.
Label: False

Claim: Children will be separated from parents for coronavirus treatment.
Explaination: Neither the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention nor the World Health Organization has recommended children be separated from a guardian while being treated.
Label: False

Claim: Congress included include a raise for themselves in the coronavirus stimulus package.
Explaination: The $25 million claimed to be a raise actually went to other things, like policing, telecom and remote work.
Label: False

Claim: Tanks are coming into U.S. towns in advance for martial law
Explaination: Tanks were only on the move in one town in California because they were being repaired.
Label: False

Claim: Bitter gourd juice can cure novel coronavirus, as per Bihar Health Department in India.
Explaination: The post claiming bitter gourd can cure novel coronavirus in 2 hours is fake. Bihar Health Department has not issued any such statement.
Label: False

Claim: A photo of a couple locked in an intimate embrace with their face masks lowered has been shared in Facebook posts that claim they were nurses who were treating COVID-19 patients in an Italian hospital.
Explaination: This is false, the photo was taken by an Associated Press photographer at Barcelona’s airport.
Label: False

Claim: An Image is being shared on social media claiming; this italian doctor couple in the picture worked day and night and saved the lives of 134 patients, but on the eighth day, they caught coronavirus and died after an hour.
Explaination: The couple in the picture is not Italian but a couple from Spain. The photograph was taken at Barcelona Airport on March 12, 2020.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Peeled onions can suck coronavirus.
Explaination: The chain message is a modification of an old myth that developed in society that is not supported by scientific research.
Label: False

Claim: Videos of passenger plane from Italy to Ethiopia in which are positive for the coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is a video of a terrorist hostage-taking at the Blaise Diagne International Airport, Senegal, on November 28, 2019.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Paraguayans should not go out “even to buy bread” because the incubation period is up and positive cases of coronavirus will increase.
Explaination: A WhatsApp message says that doctors warned people to not got out at all because the incubation period of coronavirus in Paraguay was at bay. The message was also shared in Spain and had no grounds to be true.
Label: False

Claim: Holding your breath for 10 seconds is a way to test for coronavirus.
Explaination: In a video, a woman showed how to supposedly test if one has coronavirus by holding her breath for ten seconds. WHO expert denied it.
Label: False

Claim: Netflix is providing free access to the platform due to quarantine.
Explaination: A WhatsApp message with a link stated that the platform would provide free access due to the coronavirus quarantine. As Maldita.es pointed out, it's a hoax.
Label: False

Claim: Photo of Copacabana beach on 3/22/20 full of sunbathers, even though Rio is in quarantine due to COVID-19.
Explaination: The picture was not from 2020, but from 2009.
Label: False

Claim: Viral WhatsApp message advises against purchasing used clothing as they expose buyers to COVID-19.
Explaination: While health experts have not ascertained the exact length of time COVID-19 stays active on fabrics, the WHO suggests a low probability of infection via package delivery. This rationale holds as studies show environmental changes and time affect the activeness of COVID-19; all of which are present in shipping clothing from another country. Furthermore, the assertion is not feasible as most countries with index cases have placed forms of travel and trade restriction.
Label: False

Claim: Controversies surrounding chloroquine suggest health authorities approved it as a cure for COVID-19.
Explaination: Foremost health authorities, WHO, FDA and CDC and the likes have not approved Chloroquine as a treatment for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo “rejected buying the recommended 16,000 ventilators in 2015 for a pandemic, and established death panels and lotteries instead. So he had a chance to buy, in 2015, 16,000 ventilators at a very low price, and he turned it down.”
Explaination: A 2015 New York state report said that in the case of a “severe” pandemic, the state would be short about 16,000 ventilators during the peak week. But the report did not recommend buying 16,000 ventilators, and did not indicate whether the state was at a fiscal position to purchase them. The state did not plan to increase its ventilator stockpile because it anticipated that in the event of a severe crisis, there would be shortage of trained staff to operate them and demand would outweigh any emergency stockpile. The report said the state had to balance the likely ventilator shortage with the need for adequate funding for current and ongoing health care expenses.
Label: False

Claim: Wisconsin Governor Tony Evers is “pushing firearm confiscation orders.”
Explaination: A Facebook post finding new life amid the coronavirus outbreak says Evers is pushing gun confiscation, but the linked article is from April 2019. At that time, Evers had not proposed any such thing, and the article only details a call for red flag laws from the attorney general. So what was wrong in 2019 is now both wrong and ridiculous.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Indian Army has set-up a 1,000 bed quarantine facility in Rajasthan’s Barmer.
Explaination: The Indian Army clarified that no such facility has been set-up in Rajasthan's Barmer. Also, we found out that the pictures were old and unrelated.
Label: False

Claim: Justin Trudeau’s wife has released a video from her hospital bed.
Explaination: The woman in the video is not Sophie Trudeau but Tara Jane Langston, a 39-year-old who was diagnosed with pneumonia at the Hillingdon Hospital in west London. She recorded this video for her work colleagues and the public, to make them aware about the seriousness of COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: President of Italy crying because of the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: Firstly, the man in the picture, Jair Bolsonaro, is not the President of Italy but that of Brazil. Further, the image is not recent and was taken at the thanksgiving speech at the Palacio do Planalto in December 2019.
Label: False

Claim: The man in the video is a science board member and says ginger and milk are the remedies for COVID-19.
Explaination: The man in the video is not a member; not even an MD. The advices he gives are not evidence-based.
Label: False

Claim: A hair dryer can kill the coronavirus in your nose, Iranian artist Golshifteh Farahani says.
Explaination: Golshifteh Farahani denied the allegation. There is no evidence that hair dryer can kill the viruses. It can harm the mucus layer in nose.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows looting in Mexico.
Explaination: The video dates back to 2017. There is no reported looting in Mexico currently.
Label: False

Claim: China granted the test kits to Turkey in return to Mustafa Kemal’s cholera vaccine aid to China in 1940.
Explaination: Turkey's help to China in 1938 can be seen in official documents; but the test kits were paid.
Label: False

Claim: CDC said that the coronavirus survived 17 days on the surface of a cruise ship.
Explaination: CDC found RNA 17 days after but this doesn't mean that the virus survived.
Label: False

Claim: There is no coronavirus. The Chinese were secretly working on a biological agent that was supposed to make protesters docile and obedient.
Explaination: The claim that the coronavirus which causes COVID-19 does not exist is based on a work of horror fiction posted on Reddit. COVID-19 has infected individuals in more than 150 countries, most of which have laboratories that have independently confirmed the existence and non-man-made nature of the virus.
Label: False

Claim: The new hantavirus is a deadly problem emerging in China. There is no cure for it.
Explaination: Hantavirus is not new. The is no special cure, the disease is treated as any other respiratory disease.
Label: Misleading

Claim: According to a report by the WHO, coronavirus lives the longest in the cabbage layer. Elsewhere the virus lives for 9-12 hours, whereas in cabbage, this virus lives for more than 30 hours. People of all cities are requested not to eat cabbage.
Explaination: WHO has not mentioned anything about cabbage being dangerous as coronavirus can stay longer on it than any other surface.
Label: False

Claim: The bodies of people infected with coronavirus are lying on the road of Italy. No one is carrying them due to the risk of infection.
Explaination: The Image is from Germany, where people lay down in a pedestrian zone as part of an art project in remembrance of 528 victims of the Katzbach Nazi concentration camp in Frankfurt.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus fear in Germany results in large crowds outside a supermarket. People are pushing each other to get into the store first for necessary supplies.
Explaination: This video was uploaded on 30 January 2011 on youtube. When people in huge number came for shopping at ALDI mall.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Tea can cure coronavirus.
Explaination: Doctors and experts say that there is no scientific evidence to prove that tea can be used to cure coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: New vaccine can help cure coronavirus in three hours.
Explaination: No vaccine has been found yet that can cure coronavirus. Moreover the image which is doing the rounds is that of a diagnosis kit and not vaccine.
Label: False

Claim: Gargling with hot water can prevent coronavirus infection.
Explaination: Experts and doctors say that there is no evidence to support this claim. Dr Suranjit Chatterjee, Senior Consultant, Indraprastha Apollo Hospitals said that drinking hot water can be beneficial for a sore throat but it generally helps with fighting certain symptoms and is not a medical treatment.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A video has been shared thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook which claim it shows a woman who was detained by police in Australia after she tested positive for the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, and was filmed spitting at a supermarket in a Sydney suburb.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; the video has been created from two clips of separate incidents involving different women; police in Australia said the first clip shows a woman who was questioned and released after a disturbance at a store in a Sydney suburb; the Australian supermarket chain cited in the misleading posts said the second clip was not filmed in its stores.
Label: False

Claim: A screenshot of a purported news broadcast showing a lion in the street and reporting that Russia has deployed hundreds of lions to maintain order during the novel coronavirus lockdown has been shared tens of thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter.
Explaination: The claim is false; the photo used in the image was taken in Johannesburg, South Africa in 2016; Russia has also not announced any major coronavirus lockdown.
Label: False

Claim: Tens of thousands of people who are victims of the coronavirus have died in China, and this is proven by maps of Wuhan released online that show a massive burning of corpses.
Explaination: The maps are based on unreal data and do not prove that China is massively burning bodies in Wuhan.
Label: False

Claim: Hospitals in Madrid are removing artificial respirators from those admitted with coronaviruses older than 65 years for use by younger patients.
Explaination: It is not true. And until Tuesday, March 24, Madrid Health department had the capacity to increase ICU income due to coronaviruses with respirators for all.
Label: False

Claim: A purported news report claims that Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte approved the release of P20,000 (USD $400) to all recipients of the Philippines’ Social Security System (SSS) to help them through the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the SSS said the report was “fake news"; the website that published the claim is also not a reputable news source.
Label: False

Claim: A video allegedly showing Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s wife in a hospital bed urging people to stay home to avoid ending up seriously ill with the novel coronavirus has been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter.
Explaination: The woman in the video is not Sophie Trudeau, but a British waitress who has been infected with COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: A tank circulates through the streets of Tudela, Navarre, Spain, to combat COVID-19.
Explaination: It was an old image taken in another village.
Label: False

Claim: A new law prohibits “leaving the home” after 3 p.m. in Spain.
Explaination: It was not an official document.
Label: False

Claim: On 3/22/20, the coronavirus contagion rate decreased “for two consecutive days.”
Explaination: The numbers of cases of contagion in Spain went from an increase of 16.52% on Friday to an increase of 24.75% on Saturday and 14.6% on Sunday.
Label: False

Claim: Andalusia proposes that students must repeat their classes (not on March 26).
Explaination: The image of the headline shared was manipulated from an actual media.
Label: False

Claim: Iceland tested its whole population.
Explaination: According to health authorities in Iceland, 3.5% of the population has been tested, and not 100% as claimed by the publications on Twitter.
Label: False

Claim: France found a vaccine for the coronavirus.
Explaination: Screenshots show people applauding for medical workers, like every night in Spain and in France, not applauding for a vaccine. The picture of the "vaccine" is in fact a picture of a South Korean test kit. On March 24th, when we wrote this fact check, France had not found any vaccine.
Label: False

Claim: ONU to provide food voucher for coronavirus quarantine.
Explaination: ONUas already clarified that everything is a fraud.
Label: False

Claim: 23 new COVID-19 cases confirmed in Mombasa.
Explaination: The cases were not confirmed by Kenya's Ministry of Health.
Label: False

Claim: A photo showing the bodies of Italian COVID-19 victims on a street.
Explaination: The 2014 photo shows participants in an art project to remember victims of the Nazi Katzbac concentration camp in Frankfurt, Germany.
Label: False

Claim: Pakistani Dr. Usman Riaz speaks about coronavirus before his death.
Explaination: The man in the video is not Pakistani Dr Riaz but a UK resident named Mubashir Ahmed, who was admitted to a hospital after testing positive for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Purported advisories urging residents to stay indoors while national air force helicopters spray disinfectant over homes to kill off the novel coronavirus have been circulated online in Sri Lanka and the Philippines.
Explaination: But the claim is false; both the Sri Lankan and Philippine governments said their air forces were not involved in any such operations.
Label: False

Claim: Globe Telecom is giving every subscriber free mobile load worth P500 as help or donation amid the coronavirus crisis.
Explaination: In a message sent to Rappler, Globe said the free P500 load to each user is not a legitimate offer from them.
Label: False

Claim: Five person were healed in Morocco with chloroquine.
Explaination: The website mixed two distinct pieces of information to create this false claim.
Label: False

Claim: Mosques and synagogues are the only holy places to be opened during French confinement.
Explaination: According to a French legal decree published on March 23rd, mosques, churches and synagogues can be opened but meetings of more than 20 people are forbidden. Besides, authorities from the Jewish communities and from the Muslim communities decided to close some synagogues and mosques.
Label: False

Claim: This photo shows nurses insulting French President Emmanuel Macron.
Explaination: The picture has been modified. The original photo was a message to French citizens who didn't respect the lockdown rules.
Label: False

Claim: You won’t be charged a 135 euro fine if you’re driving with several other persons in your car during the lockdown.
Explaination: Several people are authorized in the same vehicle. It is not prohibited to use your car with passengers to go to the doctor or to the supermarket, for example.
Label: False

Claim: An alarming text message signed “Claire Magne, a friend, nurse”.
Explaination: Hospitals of Montpellier and Toulouse denied this alarmist message.
Label: False

Claim: In Costa Rica, dead bodies are not returned to their families.
Explaination: There are procedures in place, but the bodies are returned.
Label: False

Claim: In Costa Rica, the Red Cross and Walmart are giving out emergency funds for COVID-19.
Explaination: It's a scam to steal personal data.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows Malaysian police sanction people who violated lockdown stipulation by hitting them on the foot sole.
Explaination: The video was filmed in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan, not a recent shoot in Malaysia. The Malaysian government has released a series measure towards the COVIS-19 on March 18. But hitting violator on the foot sole is not part of it.
Label: False

Claim: Gargling with hot water cures coronavirus, says a doctor from Mumbai’s COVID-19 hospital.
Explaination: Gargling with water does not cure or prevent coronavirus, and this is not the doctor from the Mumbai hospital but a Tik Tok video with a pre-recorded video clip.
Label: False

Claim: A police commissioner from Mumbai has asked essential services to be available at certain hours.
Explaination: The Mumbai Police did not put out any such notification and all essential services are available in the city.
Label: False

Claim: False that the OMS grants food and medicine vouchers.
Explaination: Neither the World Health Organization (OMS), the United Nations (UN) and the "Government" are giving out vouchers for food or medicine in support of the family economy due to the COVID-19 pandemic, as messages that share on social networks.
Label: False

Claim: Says that under order from Gov. Tony Evers, he and his eight children can’t legally have dinner together anymore.
Explaination: The key here is what Stroebel’s tweet didn't say – that five of the children he referenced were adults living on their own. Evers’ order does indeed ban gatherings of immediate family members in different households.
Label: Partly true

Claim: Says Nancy Pelosi’s coronavirus bill includes “tax credits for solar and wind energy … retirement plans for community newspaper employees … $300 million for PBS … climate change studies” and more.
Explaination: The House version of a coronavirus relief bill does include several requirements for airline companies that take federal assistance from the bill. The House bill also includes provisions related to community newspaper pension plans and a $300 million funding boost for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
Label: MOSTLY TRUE

Claim: Gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates the coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no evidence to suggest that gargling salt water or vinegar, or partaking in many other home remedies, fight SARS-CoV-2 infection. Upon entering the body, the virus attaches to and enters cells in the airway where it takes over the cells’ machinery, producing more viral particles that spread to other cells. Because the virus hides out in the body’s own cells, it can not be targeted without also killing healthy, uninfected cells. Therefore, fighting viral infections relies on the body’s immune response.
Label: False

Claim: [SARS-CoV-2] is spreading quickly from gas pumps. Shopping carts as well.
Explaination: People may become infected by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which causes COVID-19, when they touch contaminated surfaces and transfer the virus to their eyes, nose, or mouth. However, it is not known how often this is likely to occur and there is no evidence that it is spreading quickly in this manner. Therefore, proper handwashing and cleaning surfaces with soap or other common disinfectants are effective ways to reduce the risk of contracting the virus from surfaces.
Label: Partially correct

Claim: Trump web ad usings misleading edits to create a false picture.
Explaination: These are actual quotes but in the video they are so truncated and mixed together that overall it leaves a misleading impression.
Label: Two Pinocchios

Claim: A post says that, on 3/22/20, 793 people died in Italy and included 232 kids.
Explaination: In that day, 651 people died in Italy due to the new coronavirus and there were no mention to children. None of the deaths were related to child infections.
Label: False

Claim: A post says that a vaccine for the new coronavirus will be available in a few days.
Explaination: The image that is shown on the post is a South Korean COVID-19 test from the laboratory Sugentech. There is not a vaccine available on the market yet.
Label: False

Claim: Facebook posts featuring a photo of ventilators in the U.S. state of New York claim the devices are “stuck in a warehouse.”
Explaination: This is misleading; New York is stockpiling supplies because of the novel coronavirus pandemic, but emergency response staff say those in the photo were sent to hospitals within 24 hours of their receipt.
Label: False

Claim: President of the National Assembly of Serbia Maja Gojkovic claimed that according to the Constitution, Parliament cannot be in session during the state of emergency.
Explaination: According to the Serbian Constitution, during the state of emergency, the National Assembly shall convene without any special call for assembly and it may not be dismissed.
Label: False

Claim: Photo of people in medical scrubs lying on the floor of an operating theatre shows some of the 200 Italian doctors who died of COVID-19 in one day on 3/23/20.
Explaination: Photo is a still from an episode of US TV drama, Grey's Anatomy. And there is no evidence to show that 200 Italian doctors died on 23 March 2020.
Label: False

Claim: The vaccine against COVID-19 is finally ready.
Explaination: There is no vaccine against COVID-19 at this point in time.
Label: False

Claim: Former French health minister prevented the use of chloroquine to heal dying people of COVID-19 to harm infectologist Didier Raoult.
Explaination: The author of the video doesn't have any reliable sources : all of his claims about a "political scandal" are based on conspiracy theories, exaggerated or misleading affirmations.
Label: False

Claim: An image shared on social media claims this Italian doctor couple worked day and night and saved the lives of 134 patients, but on the eighth day, they contracted the coronavirus and died after an hour.
Explaination: The couple in the picture is not Italian but a couple from Spain. The photograph was taken at Barcelona Airport on March 12, 2020.
Label: False

Claim: An image shared on social media claims this Italian doctor couple worked day and night and saved the lives of 134 patients, but on the eighth day, they contracted the coronavirus and died after an hour.
Explaination: The couple in the picture is not Italian but a couple from Spain. The photograph was taken at Barcelona Airport on March 12, 2020.
Label: False

Claim: Image of the people who died of coronavirus in Italy.
Explaination: The photo is not related to recent coronavirus deaths in Italy. It was taken in Frankfurt (Germany) in 2014 as part of an ‘art project’ in remembrance of 528 Katzbach victims of the Nazi concentration camp.
Label: False

Claim: Italy’s prime minister cries and declares that his country “lost the battle” against the coronavirus.
Explaination: The Italian government has not made such a statement. In addition, the person who appears in the photograph is a representative from another country.
Label: False

Claim: Homemade masks prevent the spread of coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; the photos actually show the aftermath of a strong earthquake that hit the Croatian capital of Zagreb in March 2020.
Label: False

Claim: Posts shared thousands of times on Facebook claim to provide an emergency food stamp hotline.
Explaination: This is false; the phone number is not for the US Department of Agriculture, which is responsible for food stamps, and instead is a disconnected number formerly belonging to rapper Mike Jones.
Label: False

Claim: There was a riot in a grocery store due to COVID-19.
Explaination: The riot took place in Mexico in 2017.
Label: False

Claim: A video of a woman reciting Sanskrit verses has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that she was delivering sacred verses on a Spanish radio station during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video was recorded by a London-based Sanskrit teacher who published the footage on her official social media accounts in November 2019, weeks before the novel coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Multiple posts shared repeatedly on Facebook and Twitter claim that a Hong Kong medical lab has warned the novel coronavirus can remain viable on fruits and vegetables for 12 hours, therefore people should “avoid salads” over fears of contracting COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is false; the Centre for Food Safety in Hong Kong said there is no evidence to suggest that the virus is transmitted through food produce; the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) have also separately said there is "no evidence" that COVID-19 has been transmitted through food.
Label: False

Claim: Claim that coronavirus is a false pandemic.
Explaination: This is a debunked conspiracy theory.
Label: False

Claim: Deaths blamed on coronavirus are actually due to the flu.
Explaination: Fatality rates and characteristics of flu and coronavirus are different.
Label: False

Claim: The names of coronavirus victims have been published online in media.
Explaination: News organizations have repeatedly mention names of victims and have even done life tributes to them.
Label: False

Claim: Video claims that Angela Merkel is saying Germany is negotiating with a Tunisian doctor for his new treatment for COVID-19.
Explaination: The video translation is incorrect. the original video was from Merkel celebrating her party winning in the parliament election in 2013. There is no announcement about any Tunisian drug for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: A new vaccine to cure coronavirus has been developed by U.S. scientists.
Explaination: No, the image in the viral post isn’t a coronavirus vaccine. It is a COVID-19 test kit.
Label: False

Claim: A photo has been shared hundreds of times on Facebook alongside a claim it shows coffins of coronavirus victims in Italy.
Explaination: The claim is false; the photo has circulated in media reports since 2009 about the coffins of earthquake victims in the Italian city of L'Aquila.
Label: False

Claim: False offer of free Internet during 60 days due to the quarantine.
Explaination: Please read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Russia has unleashed over 500 lions to ensure that people stay inside their homes amid the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The image of a bulletin viral on social media has nothing to do with Russia or Russian President. The image is from South Africa’s Johannesburg, and the lion seen in the viral image was brought for film shooting by a production crew.
Label: False

Claim: Russia has allegedly unleashed over 500 lions in order to ensure that people stay inside their houses.
Explaination: The bulletin has been created using a template caled 'Break your own news'. Secondly, the image of the lion dates back to 2016 and was taken in South Africa’s Johannesburg
Label: False

Claim: A WhatsApp forward has gone viral which claimed that a vaccine for coronavirus has been discovered. The viral forward also claims that the treatment for coronavirus is mentioned in India’s Intermediate Zoology book. The viral forward reads, “It is not a new disease as it is already mentioned in the Intermediate zoology book along with its treatment. It happens sometimes that many great scientists and doctors do not focus on lesser-known books as they are mostly busy with famous books. Book name: Zoology, Writer: Dr. Ramesh Gupta, Page No. 1072.) Friends, this is not fake news so I request you to kindly share it maximum so all coronavirus patients are treated in time.”
Explaination: The virus being talked about in the viral claim is not the novel coronavirus(Covid-19) but SARS. WHO has clearly negated the discovery of any vaccine that can cure Covid-19. In an answer to the question, “Are there any medicines or therapies that can prevent or cure COVID-19?”, the WHO replies, “While some western, traditional or home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease.
Label: Misleading/False

Claim: Inhaling water into the nose can prevent coronavirus transmission.
Explaination: Numerous studies show that water alone is not enough to kill the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Vladimir Putin released 800 tigers andlions to force residents to stay at home.
Explaination: Photos of the lion have been circulating on the internet since April 2016, long before the Corona COVID-19 virus first appeared in Wuhan, China, in December 2019. The lion in the photo is named Columbus, released on the streets of Johannesburg, South Africa, for the purpose of filmmaking.
Label: Misleading

Claim: WHO says Ibuprofen drugs can make the coronavirus live longer.
Explaination: WHO does not mention that the ibuprofen drug can make the Corona COVID-19 virus live longer. In fact, WHO does not recommend against using ibuprofen based on information available so far. The reason, WHO did not find reports about the negative effects of ibuprofen on COVID-19 patients, beyond the known side effects that limit their use in certain populations. The WHO also did not find any clinical or population-based data published on the claim.
Label: False

Claim: Picture of “baile funk” (a type of Brazilian popular party) in São Paulo during the coronavirus, despite restrictions of mass gatherings due to the COVID-19.
Explaination: The picture was taken in September 2019, thus before the COVID-19 was first detected
Label: False

Claim: A recipe for homemade alcohol: Mix 3 parts of ethanol with 1 part of water.
Explaination: The ethanol sold in gas stations as fuel has toxic substances which should not to be used as disinfectant at home
Label: False

Claim: A vaccine that cures COVID-19 in three hours will be released next Sunday, according to President Donald Trump. Roche has already produced millions of those vaccines.
Explaination: Vaccines do not cure diseases, they prevent diseases. Roche is starting clinical trials on a proprietary drug that might be efficient for treating COVID-19, but the tests will only start in April and no promise of "3 hour cure" has ever been made. Donald Trump did not say anything like it.
Label: False

Claim: There are a thousand open vacancies for nurses, doctors and other health professionals to work on a temporary hospital in São Paulo, which will be use to treat COVID-19 cases.
Explaination: There are 509 temporary jobs available at the Pacaembu temporary hospital.
Label: PARTLY FALSE

Claim: An audio message lists five ways people can prevent the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no evidence that sipping water every 20 minutes or exposing your clothing to the sun can help prevent the coronavirus. Officials advise people to wash their hands, but not every 20 minutes, as the message claims. There’s also no evidence that consuming cold things makes you more susceptible to the virus. There’s no proof that the coronavirus can live for up to nine days on metallic surfaces. A preliminary study suggests it can remain viable on stainless steel for up to three days.
Label: False

Claim: Autohemotherapy cures COVID-19.
Explaination: WHO says there is still no cure for COVID-19; Brazilian Ministry of Health does not approve auto-hemotherapy.
Label: False

Claim: The WHO confirms COVID-19 is airborne and remains in the air for 8 hours.
Explaination: WHO explained that COVID-19 may be aerosol-borne and not airborne, that is it may linger in the air when healthcare workers are performing aerosol-generating procedures. Further, Infectious Disease Epidemiologist at the WHO, Dr Maria Van Kerkhove clarified that disease is spread through “liquid droplets through people’s noses or mouths when they sneeze or cough”.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Favipiravir cures COVID-19.
Explaination: Favipiravir is still on trial both in Japan and Korea. The treatment benefits are not certain yet.
Label: No evidence

Claim: Europe is rationing food due to the outbreak.
Explaination: There is no ration stamp practice in Europe in general. Some markets put purchase restrictions; but that does not mean ration stamp.
Label: False

Claim: A whole onion located indoors can absorb the viruses in the air.
Explaination: Bacteria can breed in onions in room temperature. Viruses only survive in certain kind of cells.
Label: False

Claim: A WhatsApp forward has gone viral which claimed that a vaccine for coronavirus has been discovered. The viral forward also claims that the treatment for coronavirus is mentioned in India’s Intermediate Zoology book.
Explaination: The viral forward reads, “It is not a new disease as it is already mentioned in the Intermediate zoology book along with its treatment. It happens sometimes that many great scientists and doctors do not focus on lesser-known books as they are mostly busy with famous books. Book name: Zoology, Writer: Dr. Ramesh Gupta, Page No. 1072.) Friends, this is not fake news so I request you to kindly share it maximum so all coronavirus patients are treated in time.” The virus being talked about in the viral claim is not the novel coronavirus(Covid-19) but SARS. WHO has clearly negated the discovery of any vaccine that can cure Covid-19. In an answer to the question, “Are there any medicines or therapies that can prevent or cure COVID-19?”, the WHO replies, “While some western, traditional or home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease.
Label: Misleading/False

Claim: A WhatsApp forward claims that the COVID-19 vaccine is ready, was announced by U.S. President Donald Trump, and will be launched next Sunday. It also claims that the vaccine discovered by the U.S. scientists can cure a COVID-19 infected patient within 3 hours. With the WhatsApp forward, the alleged image of the vaccine is also being shared.
Explaination: The image being forwarded is an image of a COVID-19 test kit and not of any vaccine that can cure the virus. As per the viral forward, US President Donald Trump has announced that the vaccine will be launched next Sunday, we checked President Trump’s Twitter handle, Facebook Page and Instagram profile but we didn't find any such announcement by the US president.
Label: False

Claim: Italy’s Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte broke down publicly due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The image viral on social media is of Brazilian President Bolsonaro and not of Italy's PM Giuseppe Conte. The claim shared by several Social media users and media outlets is hence false.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus will be cured within 2 hours by drinking bitter gourd juice.
Explaination: Neither WHO nor the Indian Ministry of Health has mentioned any such remedy for coronavirus. The Press Information Bureau of India has also marked it fake.
Label: False

Claim: A Facebook post asserts the U.S. developed a COVID-19 vaccine to release this Sunday.
Explaination: Currently, there are still no definitive and institutionalised vaccines for COVID-19; nonetheless, research persists and holds potential solutions.
Label: False

Claim: Offers to buy special device, which will “clean” water before drinking.
Explaination: The claim is false; there is no evidence that this device is effective; in the US it's even considered dangerous.
Label: False

Claim: The Spanish Government will declare imminently the state of emergency and no one will be able to leave the house and supermarkets will close.
Explaination: It is not true. There is no evidence that the Government is planning to enact a state of emergency, only the extension of the alarm state with the current restrictions.
Label: False

Claim: A lengthy post purportedly contains advice on how to prevent infection from the novel coronavirus. The post claims the advice was issued by a UK hospital to its medical staff.
Explaination: The claim is false; the hospital named in the misleading Facebook posts denied issuing the guidelines; the posts also contained several false claims previously debunked by AFP Fact Check.
Label: False

Claim: Vox is going to donate the money it receives for representation in institutions to public health.
Explaination: The political party denied it.
Label: False

Claim: Netflix gives away free accounts during coronavirus quarantine.
Explaination: It was phishing and the company recommended not to click on the link that was spreading.
Label: False

Claim: Pablo Iglesias announces that social benefits are suspended for three months.
Explaination: The image of the headline shared was manipulated from an actual media.
Label: False

Claim: Governmental economic measures will allow “unemployed people to earn 100% of their wage, workers 70% and craftsmen 0%”
Explaination: In France, unemployed people can receive money from the state, and in general the amount of money represents 72% of the last wage (very few cases can receive 100% or more, there are exceptions). "Workers" is a very vague term. If it means people still working in spite of confinement, it's false: wages will be the same. If it means workers forced to be half unemployed, the government will give them up to 84% of their wage. "Craftsmen" don't have wage, but earn money for themselves. The government said it will help them too, case by case, thanks to a new national grant.
Label: False

Claim: Video links the Family Bonus Payment established by the Government of Bolivia due to the COVID-19 crisis and electoral campaign proposal of Juntos.
Explaination: The video announcing the Family Bonus Payment links the political party “Juntos”. Nevertheless, the official page Juntos in facebook denies the creation of this video explaining that they suffered an “cyberattack”.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Video showing a group of the Bolivian army making people respect the quarantine and stay at home by using violence is not from Punata but from Chimbobo.
Explaination: The team of Bolivia Verifica, confirms that the images were recorded in Chimboco zone, (municipality of Sacaba – Cochabamba), 55 km away from Punata.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Holding your breath can let you test whether you may have COVID-19.
Explaination: Holding your breath for 10 seconds is not a valid way to test if you may have COVID-19, and the World Health Organization recommends testing by qualified health professionals.
Label: False

Claim: Roche has developed a COVID-19 vaccine.
Explaination: A video claiming that the pharmaceutical company has developed a vaccine for COVID-19 contains false information.
Label: False

Claim: A photo showing Uganda’s first case of COVID-19.
Explaination: The photo of a man wearing a mask does not show Uganda's first COVID-19 case, but was actually taken at the John F Kennedy International Airport in February 2020.
Label: False

Claim: Russian President Vladimir Putin releases 800 tigers and 500 lions amid the coronavirus outbreak to keep people at home.
Explaination: The photos used were taken in 2016 and 2019 respectively, both in South Africa.
Label: False

Claim: Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte was quoted in various posts and graphics on Facebook as saying they have “lost control” of the coronavirus pandemic that is greatly affecting Italy.
Explaination: No official statements or reports from credible news organizations carry this supposed quote by Conte. The graphics and screenshots also did not point to the source of the quote.
Label: False

Claim: A new vaccine that can cure COVID-19 patients in 3 hours is now ready.
Explaination: As of March 27, there is still no vaccine or drug approved by the World Health Organization (WHO) or any Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the world to cure or prevent COVID-19. Moreover, the image used in the post is not a photo of vaccines from Roche Medical Company, but is a photo of rapid test kits from South Korean company Sugentech.
Label: False

Claim: Image attributed to Italian Prime Minister suggesting Italy has lost control.
Explaination: Image of Brazilian Prime Minister Bolsonaro crying at an event falsely shared as Italian President.
Label: False

Claim: The CDC now says that the coronavirus can survive on surfaces for up to 17 days.
Explaination: A CNBC story touted a misleading headline that said the CDC reported that the coronavirus survived on cruise ship cabins for up to 17 days. A recent CDC report found that traces of the virus were found on the ship for that long, not a live sample.
Label: False

Claim: “Donald Trump would receive $17 million for three hotels closed for four days under Republican bill! How in the hell is this right?!”
Explaination: The Senate-approved bill prohibits Trump family hotels from getting coronavirus aid from a $500 billion fund that would be set up to help businesses that incurred losses from the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Vladimir Putin let lions loose in the streets of Russia to keep them indoors amid COVID-19.
Explaination: The image is from Johannesburg, South Africa, where a lion was released for a video shooting.
Label: False

Claim: “People´s scientist” found that coronavirus is a bioweapon mixing SARS and HIV.
Explaination: This "scientist" has no publications, academic records or any institutional support.
Label: False

Claim: Italy registered 4,200 new recovering cases from coronavirus in 24 hours.
Explaination: According to the Italian Health ministry's daily reports, Italy recorded 408 new recovering cases on the period mentioned by the publication. Moreover, its most highest number of new recovering cases since the beginning of the outbreak is 1084 cases (not 4200).
Label: False

Claim: Tests results, theft, ban: Three false reports about chloroquine
Explaination: Facebook messages claim that the former French Health Minister Agnès Buzyn chose to forbid chloroquine and that the efficiency of this treatment against COVID-19 was proved. It's incorrect.
Label: False

Claim: Will lockdown cause a shortage of banknotes in ATMs?
Explaination: Cash withdrawals had increased slightly before the start of lockdown but have declined sharply since. The Bank of France as well as bank union representatives say that ATM are full and that no shortage is to be feared.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus has gripped Italy and nobody is willing to carry corpses off Italy’s streets.
Explaination: The photo was taken on March 24, 2014 in Frankfurt, Germany. People lay down on a pedestrian area to remember victims who lost their lives in a Nazi concentration camp.
Label: False

Claim: Italian police are being brutal on people not following lockdowns; India should follow.
Explaination: The police apprehended a man who was brandishing a gun in Sao Paulo, Brazil.
Label: False

Claim: “Special military helicopters will spray pesticide against the coronavirus in the skies all over the country.”
Explaination: There is no evidence the United States military is using helicopters to spray pesticide in an effort to kill the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: “Putin has stated: Russian citizens (have) 2 options: Stay home for 15 days or in jail for 5 years.”
Explaination: Russian President Vladimir Putin has implemented some policies to cancel large gatherings and keep people at home during the coronavirus pandemic. But we could not find any evidence that he has threatened jail time for people who don't comply.
Label: False

Claim: “Slices of lemon in a cup of hot water can save your life. The hot lemon can kill the proliferation of” the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence that lemon can treat or prevent the coronavirus. Health officials have debunked the claim. The video comes from a man who promotes alternative health information on YouTube.
Label: False

Claim: Study suggests malaria drug can treat coronavirus.
Explaination: Despite Trump stating that chloroquine had been approved for use to treat COVID-19, the FDA released a statement saying it had not approved the drug for use against COVID-19 and is still studying its effectiveness against the disease.
Label: No evidence

Claim: Footage purportedly showing a looting spree in Mexico prompted by panic over the novel coronavirus was aired on multiple Facebook live streams and viewed by tens of thousands of people during the week of 3/23/20. Posts sharing the streams claimed that the chaotic scene was happening in real-time.
Explaination: The claim is false; the streams showed old footage from a 2017 looting incident in Mexico that was being played on a loop.
Label: False

Claim: Photographs shared hundreds of times online purport to show the coffins of Italian victims of the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the pictures date back to October 2013 when hundreds drowned in a boat tragedy in the Mediterranean.
Label: False

Claim: A video of former Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram alongside a claim it shows him stating the U.S threatened to spread the novel coronavirus in Iraq during a meeting in the 1990s.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video's audio has been doctored; the original Associated Press archive footage does not include any reference to COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Photo showing crowd during an illegal — due to quarantine — Way of the Cross prayers in Wejherowo.
Explaination: This image is from 2018.
Label: False

Claim: The French state gives more benefit to people who were unemployed before the COVID-19 than it does for people who are partially unemployed due to the coronavirus.
Explaination: The French state helps more people who are partially unemployed due to the COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Washington admits it is the responsible for COVID-19.
Explaination: Washington didn't admit its responsibility for COVID-19. according to research COVID-19 virus is highly unlikely to be humanly made. The video used in the claim is from the ministry of justice announcement that it was charging a Harvard professor who took funds from China.
Label: False

Claim: A vaccine against coronavirus was developed.
Explaination: In fact, the photo shows a test to detect antibodies to the virus in the body. This test is used along with others to diagnose coronavirus, not to treat it. The vaccine for COVID-19 has not yet been developed and Donald trump has not announced anything like this.
Label: False

Claim: George Soros is one of the people responsible for the new coronavirus, born in a laboratory.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence that the new coronavirus was made in a laboratory. A study published in “Nature” says that the virus came from an animal that infected a human being.
Label: False

Claim: Italian mimicks Muslim prayers because of fear from COVID-19.
Explaination: The original video is from a muslim protest in front of airports and public squares against Trump decisions to ban 7 muslim countries from entering america in 2017.
Label: False

Claim: Photo shows dozens of wooden coffins of people dead from the coronavirus in Italy.
Explaination: Photo is of the coffins of African migrants who drowned off Italian island in 2013.
Label: False

Claim: South African mayor claimed that Interferon alpha-2b is a vaccine for the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Interferon alpha-2b has been used to treat some earlier strains of coronavirus, but it’s not a vaccine that would prevent people from getting COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: You shouldn’t take Ibuprofen because it appears this drug would enhance and accelerate the effects of COVID-19.
Explaination: According to EMA (the European Medicine Agency), there is no scientific evidence on this.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Russia has released 500 lions to enforce the quarantine for COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no evidence that Russia has employed lions to enforce quarantine measures. Also, the picture comes from a South African movie.
Label: False

Claim: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim it shows Italian nationals expressing their gratitude to China for providing aid during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video shows a Belarusian band singing a Chinese song several months before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.
Label: False

Claim: Russia has unleashed over 500 lions to ensure that people stay inside their homes amid the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The image of a bulletin viral on social media has nothing to do with Russia or Russian President. The image is from South Africa’s Johannesburg, and the lion seen in the viral image was brought for film shooting by a production crew.
Label: False

Claim: A WhatsApp forward claimed that a vaccine for coronavirus has been discovered. It also claims that the treatment for coronavirus is mentioned in India’s Intermediate Zoology book. The viral forward reads, “It is not a new disease as it is already mentioned in the Intermediate Zoology book along with its treatment. It happens sometimes that many great scientists and doctors do not focus on lesser-known books as they are mostly busy with famous books. (Book name: Zoology, Writer: Dr. Ramesh Gupta, Page No. 1072.) Friends, this is not fake news so I request you to kindly share it maximum so all coronavirus patients are treated in time.”
Explaination: The virus being talked about in the viral claim is not the novel coronavirus(COVID-19) but SARS. WHO has clearly negated the discovery of any vaccine that can cure COVID-19. In an answer to the question, “Are there any medicines or therapies that can prevent or cure COVID-19?”, the WHO replies, “While some western, traditional or home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Russia has unleashed over 500 lions to ensure that people stay inside their homes amid the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: the image of a bulletin viral on social media has nothing to do with Russia or Russian President. The image is from South Africa’s Johannesburg, and the lion seen in the viral image was brought for film shooting by the production crew.
Label: False

Claim: The mayor of Guayaquil in Ecuador lied about her health condition
Explaination: The official data don't reveal the name of people that has COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: The Health Minister in Ecuador quit her job because she was forced to lie about the statistics of COVID-19 related cases.
Explaination: Her reasons to resign the Health Minister are unknown.
Label: False

Claim: The president of Ecuador doesn’t ask for help to China because of the IMF
Explaination: The government of China is already sending help to Ecuador because of COVID-19 spread.
Label: False

Claim: Whatsapp audio ensures there will be a 24-hour curfew for 5 days in Ecuador.
Explaination: The audio is fake the curfew in Ecuador nationwide is from 14:00 to 05:00.
Label: False

Claim: Fake Twitter account of the Ecuadorean Health Ministry.
Explaination: The only official account of the Health Ministry is @DrJuanCZevallos.
Label: False

Claim: People are still shopping in malls in spite of the curfew and mobility restrictions in Ecuador.
Explaination: The date doesn't match the images. It was taken before march 22nd.
Label: False

Claim: The vaccine that China is testing for COVID-19 is bad for humans.
Explaination: The information was published in a fake account.
Label: False

Claim: An image encourages people to stay home and not go out to terraces or balconies .
Explaination: It's not official information.
Label: False

Claim: Because of the global quarantine, the WHO and the Ecuadorian government have given a weekly bonus to each family for food and medicine.
Explaination: The government is studying the possibility to apply a welfare amount for poor people during quarantine.
Label: False

Claim: Ecuadorian government gives money to people from Venezuela.
Explaination: The government doesn't give money to Venezuelans.
Label: False

Claim: Multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter claim the WHO has warned against eating cabbage during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the WHO said it did not issue any such advisory against consuming cabbage; the US-based Centre of Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says there is "no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with food".
Label: False

Claim: A video of food packets deposited on a street has been viewed millions of times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim it shows food donations for people in Turkey during a novel coronavirus lockdown.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video shows donations for victims of a deadly earthquake that struck eastern Turkey in January 2020, almost two months before Turkey recorded its first case of the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Kaletra protocol for HIV (lopinavirus – ritonavir) is effective to treat COVID-19.
Explaination: Clinical trial showed "no relevant benefits" from using this protocol in 99 patients in Wuhan through 14 days.
Label: False

Claim: The second COVID-19 infection is worse than the first one and can be fatal.
Explaination: The man in the video is not an expert and his scientific statements are false or exaggerated.
Label: False

Claim: An image has been shared multiple times on Facebook in Liberia in support of a claim that pastors were beaten for defying government restrictions on religious gatherings amid the novel coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: Although a police crackdown on churches took place, the use of the picture in this context is false as it was shot years ago at an unrelated event.
Label: False

Claim: Whether 60 Democrats voted against coronavirus stimulus bill.
Explaination: There are not 60 Democrats in the U.S. Senate. Also, the Democrats voted on March 22, 2020, against a key procedural vote that would have advanced the bill because they said they were unhappy with worker protections.
Label: False

Claim: Russian President Putin released 500 lions onto the streets to keep people indoors.
Explaination: The screen grab in the post was taken from a movie, not a real news report.
Label: False

Claim: Getting a flu shot increases the risk of coronavirus by 36%.
Explaination: Medical experts told LeadStories there is not a cross-effet between flu shot and COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: An Arabic poem from 1170 predicted COVID-19.
Explaination: The book in which the poem is alleged to be doesn't exist as well as the author to whom the poem is attributed.
Label: False

Claim: President Trump refers to the coronavirus as a hoax in an audio clip.
Explaination: Audio and video clips were purposely edited.
Label: False

Claim: Does vaping reduce your chances of getting the coronavirus?
Explaination: There aren't a ton of studies on the link between vaping and COVID-19 specifically, but there is enough evidence that smoking certainly wouldn't help. Vaping could increase your risk of coronavirus infection since experts say that smoking suppresses immune function.
Label: False

Claim: US military brought the virus to Wuhan on October 2019.
Explaination: The US CDC director says that the flu has started in October in the US, and that some apparently flu-related deaths were in fact due to the COVID-19. He does not say that the COVID-19 has started in october in the US.
Label: False

Claim: Polish telecommunications provider PLAY has installed 5G antennas during quarantine.
Explaination: The were installed before quarantine was introduced.
Label: False

Claim: Russian president using lions to ensure people stayed indoors in Russia.
Explaination: Lion roaming in Johannesburg street as part of a film production in 2016.
Label: False

Claim: Channel 4’s Jon Snow is infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: Jon Snow was on a self-isolation after an Iran assignment in late February and has reported to work after 14 day period, and continues to be part of the Channel4 News and to-date has not contracted COVID-19, verified from his Twitter account and verified News sources.
Label: False

Claim: Initial lack of evidence for human-to-human COVID-19 transmission unusual.
Explaination: We lined up the tweets from WHO and showed there was a progression from not know to the transmission being human-to-human
Label: Misleading

Claim: Tom Hanks died, confessed admiration for Trump.
Explaination: Story published by clear death-hoax website.
Label: False

Claim: Helicopters Are Spraying Disinfectants To Try To Eradicate Coronavirus.
Explaination: False information being spread on Facebook. Completely made up, but post is spreading across countries.
Label: False

Claim: A tent will be set up next to the Viamed de Calahorra hospital (La Rioja) to carry out rapid tests for coronavirus.
Explaination: No, a tent will not be enabled next to the Calahorra hospital for rapid coronavirus tests.
Label: False

Claim: The government of Spain is going to declare a state of emergency.
Explaination: There is no proof that Spain would enter a state of emergency starting March 23, when the viral audio was spread.
Label: False

Claim: A WhatsApp forward has gone viral which claimed that a vaccine for coronavirus has been discovered. The viral forward also claims that the treatment for coronavirus is mentioned in India’s Intermediate Zoology book.
Explaination: The viral forward reads, “It is not a new disease as it is already mentioned in the Intermediate zoology book along with its treatment. It happens sometimes that many great scientists and doctors do not focus on lesser-known books as they are mostly busy with famous books. Book name: Zoology, Writer: Dr. Ramesh Gupta, Page No. 1072.) Friends, this is not fake news so I request you to kindly share it maximum so all coronavirus patients are treated in time.” The virus being talked about in the viral claim is not the novel coronavirus(COVID-19) but SARS. WHO has clearly negated the discovery of any vaccine that can cure COVID-19. In an answer to the question, “Are there any medicines or therapies that can prevent or cure COVID-19?”, the WHO replies, “While some western, traditional or home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.
Explaination: The video is not related to coronavirus but with London riots that happened in 2011. The 2011 England riots, more widely known as the London Riots, were a series of riots between 6 and 11 August 2011, when thousands of people rioted in cities and towns across England, saw looting, arson, and mass deployment of police, and resulted in the deaths of five people.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Aspirating boiling water vapor for five minutes deactivates the coronavirus.
Explaination: Doctors say it does not deactivate the virus. The WHO also says there is no vaccine yet.
Label: False

Claim: Lemon and bicarbonate kill the virus.
Explaination: Official sanitary authorities debunk that claim
Label: False

Claim: Photographs of the Army in Dublin city centre show that the country is about to go into lockdown.
Explaination: The photographs show the Army setting up mobile testing centres in Dublin city centre, not preparing for the country to go into lockdown
Label: False

Claim: Poison spray for coronavirus from Malaysia and Singapore by air.
Explaination: Indonesian Minister of Communication and Information Johnny G. Plate, Malaysian Army, and Head of Batam City Health Office Didi Kusmaryadi have denied the rumors.
Label: False

Claim: The Peruvian Social Security is offering monetary help to some people included in a list to endure the quarantine.
Explaination: The government is offering an excepcional monetary help for people in extreme poverty, but that message is a fraud, according the Social Security authorities.
Label: False

Claim: There are 1,000 open vacancies for nurses, doctors and other health professionals to work on a temporary hospital in São Paulo, which will be used to treat COVID-19 cases.
Explaination: There are 509 temporary jobs available at the Pacaembu temporary hospital.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Social media posts suggest Zimbabwean police flogged churches who gathered in defiance to warnings encouraging social distancing.
Explaination: The video is neither related to the coronavirus nor church activities. It is a November 2019 video of Zimbabwean police dispersing supporters of the main opposition political party.
Label: False

Claim: “Boil some orange peels with cayenne pepper, stand over the pot, breathe in the steam so all mucus can be released from your nasal passages … Mucus is the problem, it’s where the virus lives!”
Explaination: Orange peels and cayenne are not proven to treat COVID-19, and neither is boiling them.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: The photo shows the funeral of Turkish deceased general Aytac Yalman due to COVID-19.
Explaination: The photo was taken in 2006 in someone's funeral who died of hemorrhagic fever.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows coronavirus patients at an airport in China and gauges how serious the situation is.
Explaination: The video is not of the coronavirus infected patients of China or Italy, but of the mock drill conducted at Blas Dian Airport in Decar, Senegal last year.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A drug made from cow urine or pigeon membrane can cure coronavirus.
Explaination: No evidence found which can prove that the pigeon membrane can cure the coronavirus. WHO has not mention this too.
Label: False

Claim: Five helicopters will disinfect the Netherlands to extinguish the coronavirus. Citizens have to stay inside.
Explaination: Different versions of this message have been circulating all over the world since March 10th. The Dutch police force has confirmed no such measures have been or will be taken.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus is infectious in the air for 8 hours and everyone must wear a face mask.
Explaination: Coronavirus may remain in the air 1-3 hours, and face masks are not required for everyone, just healthcare workers.
Label: False

Claim: An image has been shared thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook alongside a claim that it shows a medicine created by U.S. scientists that can cure the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; the photo in fact shows a COVID-19 test kit developed by a South Korean company; as of March 2020, international health experts have said there is no "cure" or vaccine for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: A photo has been shared hundreds of times in multiple Facebook, Twitter and Instagram posts alongside a claim that it shows Italy’s president crying over the novel coronavirus epidemic that has claimed thousands of lives in his country.
Explaination: The claim is false; the photo shows Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro getting emotional during a Thanksgiving speech in December 2019.
Label: False

Claim: A video shared thousands of times on Facebook claims to show police in Zimbabwe beating churchgoers because their place of worship refused to close to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
Explaination: The claims are false; the video was filmed before the virus outbreak. It shows opposition supporters being dispersed after gathering to hear their leader.
Label: False

Claim: A purported emergency notice from Australian authorities has been shared hundreds of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter. It states people can receive free home visits from doctors during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; Australian health authorities denied issuing the notice, adding the hoax had prompted “unnecessary phone calls” that had overwhelmed public health units.
Label: False

Claim: A viral WhatsApp voice note in Nigeria claims that the coronavirus could kill up to 45 million Nigerians.
Explaination: This is misleading, as data from the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) shows. The message makes several other false claims, which we debunk here.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Russian President Vladimir Putin released 800 lions and tigers across Russia to stop people from leaving home.
Explaination: The original photo was taken on April 11., 2016, in Johannesburg, South Africa, in a movie shooting locale.
Label: False

Claim: Science Minister Pedro Duque was hospitalized due to coronavirus in Denia.
Explaination: Pedro Duque itself denied it in El Objetivo while de chaintext was viralizing
Label: False

Claim: DRC president, Felix Tshisekedi, has suspended the payment of rents and water and electricity bills because of coronavirus.
Explaination: AFP dug into governmental speeches and announcements since the outbreak of coronavirus, and there is no mention of suspension of bills. Plus, the team of the DRC's president denied to AFP having announced such economic measures.
Label: False

Claim: A photo showing nurses raising their middle fingers against the French government, with a caption against the French President.
Explaination: The woman who took the picture explained to AFP having posted such photo to raise her finger to the coronavirus, not to the French government. Analysis of the medatada allowed AFP to confirm she was the one who took the picture.
Label: False

Claim: Vladimir Putin “released 500 lions to monitor the quarantine.”
Explaination: This is false. It is a meme that has already gotten out of control.
Label: False

Claim: One photograph of the meeting of the Bolivian health minister, Anibal Cruz with delegates, hints that they are hiding current figures of the infections with COVID-19 to the population
Explaination: The photo hints that in Bolivia are one thousand people infected with COVID-19. But in Bolivia are registered 61 one cases today (3/27/2020).
Label: False

Claim: President Giammattei said that the country has 10,000 COVID-19 tests.
Explaination: Guatemala had received 1.000 test from WHO-PAHO and now has 622.
Label: False

Claim: Photo of the “crying president of Italy” with a caption stating Italy was not prepared to deal with the coronavirus outbreak despite having adequate health facilities.
Explaination: The world leader in the photo on these posts is not the president of Italy. He is Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro.
Label: False

Claim: Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced a 14-hour curfew as the virus lives for 12 hours on surfaces.
Explaination: Research studies show that The study found the new coronavirus can live in the air for several hours and on some surfaces for as long as 2 -3 days. These studies are not peer reviewed.
Label: False

Claim: Celebrities spreading misinformation about coronavirus and the Janata curfew in India.
Explaination: The celebrities shared posts that were already debunked about the 12 hour curfew on March 22 in India.
Label: False

Claim: Yves Levy, husband of the former french health minister Agnès Buzyn, inaugurated the P4 laboratory of Wuhan in China, where thethe coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 was created.
Explaination: The virus wasn't created in Wuhan's P4 laboratory.
Label: PARTLY FALSE

Claim: “Go to 2020census.gov and fill out this census form so you can get your stimulus check.”
Explaination: Your response to the U.S. Census won't affect whether you get a federal stimulus check.
Label: False

Claim: A screenshot of a Nigerian television station showing a breakdown of “472 confirmed cases” has been shared on Facebook, Twitter, and WhatsApp alongside claims it shows novel coronavirus cases across the country.
Explaination: But the image is being shared out of context: It shows figures for Lassa fever, not coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A video has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim that it shows a drone launching fireworks at people who breached a curfew in Malaysia during a nationwide coronavirus lockdown.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video's audio has been manipulated to include a man speaking in Malaysian; the original clip actually shows a prank that was staged by a Brazilian influencer in Brazil in July 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Belgium Health Minister has banned group sex due to coronavirus outbreak associated with orgy.
Explaination: This information is based on a satire article.
Label: False

Claim: A Twitter user claimed that Russia released 500 tigers to keep people inside during lockdown.
Explaination: While this particular image shared by the claim-source was generated from a meme maker website, the original image of the lion was taken in Johannesburg, South Africa in 2016, not recently as we have been led to believe by the publisher.
Label: False

Claim: In a video made by Dr. Mario Pesaresi, he recommends water steam to deactivate the coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no evidence of the impact of water steam in coronavirus. The WHO and CDC indicate there is no conclusive evidence to determine whether heat is impacting the virus.
Label: False

Claim: An image shows a Spanish scientist asking Cristiano Ronaldo and Messi to find the cure for COVID-19.
Explaination: The woman in the picture is not a scientist, but an ex-member of previouses Spanish governments and it was taken in April 2008. It was never related to the new coronavirus or to the football players.
Label: False

Claim: WHO confirmed COVID-19 as airborne.
Explaination: WHO insisted that COVID-19 is not spread as airborne in everyday life.
Label: False

Claim: Second-hand clothes and blankets sold cheaply in African markets are infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: The photo is at least ten years old. China imports mostly new clothes to Africa, but WHO, Harvard Medical School and other experts advise it is safe to receive goods from COVID-19 affected areas.
Label: False

Claim: A statue of the Virgin Mary from Loreto will be carried by a plane over Italy to ask for the pandemic of COVID-19 to stop.
