Explaination: The picture was taken in January and is related to a specific event that has nothing to do with COVID-19. The Loreto cathedral has denied that such an event will take place.
Label: False

Claim: Army to be deployed to respond to COVID-19 pandemic.
Explaination: Army explained the vehicles were returning from a canceled military exercise.
Label: False

Claim: One Polish telecommunications company used the quarantine as a cover up to put 100 5G antennas in Gdynia.
Explaination: They were installed long before coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: A WhatsApp forward claimed that a vaccine for coronavirus has been discovered and that the treatment for coronavirus is mentioned in an Intermediate Zoology book.
Explaination: The viral forward reads, “It is not a new disease as it is already mentioned in the Intermediate zoology book along with its treatment. It happens sometimes that many great scientists and doctors do not focus on lesser-known books as they are mostly busy with famous books. Book name: Zoology, Writer: Dr. Ramesh Gupta, Page No. 1072.) Friends, this is not fake news so I request you to kindly share it maximum so all coronavirus patients are treated in time.”The treatments mentioned in the viral page of the book are first of all not a treatment for coronavirus but a treatment for common cold caused by a coronavirus which is negated partially by various research reports so the viral claim that there is pre-existing medication for coronavirus, is ‘Misleading’.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.
Explaination: This video is of riots that happened in Peckham, London. With the help of Google search, we found several global media reports on the London riots. It was clear from these reports that the video viral on social media is the London riots that happened in 2011.
Label: False

Claim: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.
Explaination: The video is not related to coronavirus but with London riots that happened in 2011. The 2011 England riots, more widely known as the London Riots, were a series of riots between 6 and 11 August 2011, when thousands of people rioted in cities and towns across England, saw looting, arson, and mass deployment of police, and resulted in the deaths of five people.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Drauzio Varella, one of Brazil’s most famous doctors, stated in a video on 3/22/20: There’s no coronavirus crisis; this is just a strong cold. There’s no reason for changing your routine unless you are infected.
Explaination: The video was actually published on January 30, when Brazil had no confirmed cases of COVID-19. Varella himself said, in a video published a month later, that the situation had changed and the previous video did not represent his current opinion on the matter.
Label: False

Claim: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.
Explaination: The video is not related to coronavirus but with London riots that happened in 2011. The 2011 England riots, more widely known as the London Riots, were a series of riots between 6 and 11 August 2011, when thousands of people rioted in cities and towns across England, saw looting, arson, and mass deployment of police, and resulted in the deaths of five people.
Label: False

Claim: Yves Levy, husband of the former french health minister Agnès Buzyn, inaugurated the P4 laboratory of Wuhan in China, where the coronavirus was created.
Explaination: The virus wasn't created in Wuhan's P4 laboratory.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Multiple Facebook and Twitter posts shared thousands of times by Australian social media users claim people with pre-existing respiratory conditions will be given a “rescue pack” of medication from their general practitioners during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; Australia’s Department of Health dismissed the rumour as “misinformation”, adding that patients will not receive “rescue packs” from their doctors unless previously prescribed.
Label: False

Claim: A photo of a man and woman embracing has been shared on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it shows two Italian doctors who died from COVID-19 after contracting the disease from the patients they treated.
Explaination: The claim is false; this is an Associated Press photo of a couple kissing at an airport in Barcelona, Spain.
Label: False

Claim: Robbers pretend to test for COVID-19 and use it as pretext to rob houses.
Explaination: The Montreal police confirmed that this type of crime is not happening.
Label: False

Claim: The COVID-19 cases have reached a peak and people must not go outside even for groceries.
Explaination: In Canada, people are still allowed to go out to buy groceries.
Label: False

Claim: Famous Brazilian doctor posted for people “not to panic” about COVID-19 and keep up with their lives.
Explaination: The video was recorded in January, more recently he said he was safe at home because he was part of the risk group.
Label: False

Claim: Helicopters are spraying disinfectants to stop the spread of coronavirus.
Explaination: This is a false rumor spreading around the world on social media, as well as through popular messaging services. NYC Emergency Management declared it a hoax.
Label: False

Claim: IPhoto shows people falling dead on Italian streets from COVID-19.
Explaination: This was a stolen photo originally dating back to 2014 for a Holocaust remembrance project.
Label: False

Claim: Black people are immune to the coronavirus.
Explaination: COVID-19 does not affect races differently as far as symptoms and infectiousness. Reports from around the world show the virus affected all people.
Label: False

Claim: Boiled orange peels with cayenne pepper are a cure for coronavirus.
Explaination: There is still currently no cure, and this has not been medically verified as a viable treatment.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 stands for “Chinese Originated Viral Infectious Disease.”
Explaination: The CDC explains the origin of the virus's name, which has nothing to do with China.
Label: False

Claim: NY Governor Andrew Cuomo did not reject buying 16,000 ventilators in 2015.
Explaination: The report referred to did not actually make any recommendations for buying ventilators.
Label: False

Claim: A photo showing hundreds of people in the Montparnasse train station in Paris, despite confinement measures due to the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The photo was taken on May 26, 2019.
Label: False

Claim: A letter from the French ministry of Education saying summer holidays will be postponed because of the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: Clues in the letter shows it is a fake (for instance, the signature) and Jean-Michel Blanquer, minister of Education, denied on Twitter having published such a letter. He also denied any change in the holidays' schedule.
Label: False

Claim: Sophie Trudeau is sharing her COVID-19 experience.
Explaination: Video is of a woman from London and not Sophie Trudeau.
Label: False

Claim: A positive COVID-19 patient recently met Narendra Modi.
Explaination: A 2018 picture is being shared with a false narrative.
Label: False

Claim: A line of coffins suggesting they are from Italy currently.
Explaination: Old image of 2013 of migrants dying in a shipwreck shared as recent.
Label: False

Claim: Cow urine is helpful to fight coronavirus.
Explaination: No scientific evidence backs the use of cow urine to tackle viruses.
Label: False

Claim: The Colombian government just made it official that all citizens will receive 350,000 pesos a week for staying home to prevent the proliferation” of COVID-19.
Explaination: It is false that the Colombian government is giving 350,000 pesos to stay at home.
Label: False

Claim: Banglore Municipal body (BBMP) will be spraying medicine in the air to kill coronavirus.
Explaination: The BBMP Commissioner, the Mayor and PIB Fact Check India have clarified that the viral message is just a rumor and the BBMP has no such plans to spray any medicine for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Sick COVID-19 patients at the airport runway in Senegal.
Explaination: Video is old and not from Italy. It actually shows mock drill carried out on 28 November 2019 at Blaise Diagne Airport in Dakar, the capital of Senegal. It has nothing to do with coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Image claims that dead bodies from Italy are kept in a room.
Explaination: The image is from a Cairo Mosque which was turned into a makeshift morgue in 2013.
Label: False

Claim: Consuming alcoholic beverages may help reduce the risk of infection by the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Drinking alcohol does not protect you from coronavirus infection, according to WHO.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus will be cured after a 14-hour curfew.
Explaination: Novel coronavirus have different life spans on different objects however it can live upto 2 to 3 days.
Label: False

Claim: “Only India can resist coronavirus” — Saudi Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman.
Explaination: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman has not made any such statement.
Label: False

Claim: Bill Gates and the Vatican have a plan to depopulate the world with a coronavirus vaccine.
Explaination: Video clip taken out of context from 2010 Gates TedTalk.
Label: False

Claim: US Homeland Security mobilizing National Guard to combat coronavirus.
Explaination: National Guard refuted claims.
Label: False

Claim: Joe Biden tested positive for coronavirus.
Explaination: Another news publication refuted the false claim.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus cases linked to 5G rollout.
Explaination: Overlaps in the map between 5G and cases can be explained by population density.
Label: False

Claim: Photo shows coffins from coronavirus outbreak in Italy.
Explaination: Old photo from African migrants who died from shipwreck in 2013.
Label: False

Claim: Elderly COVID-19 patients won’t have access to respirators
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: Partially false

Claim: Seeing the rise of novel coronavirus in India, the WHO has recommended the government of India lockdown the country from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20.
Explaination: We reached out to one of the representatives in India, who rubbished the claim and clarified that WHO has not made any such recommendation.
Label: False

Claim: A WhatsApp video claims that the lady shown is the wife of Canada’s PM Justin Trudeau. In the viral video, a lady can be seen describing her improved condition because of medication and also warns to not take chances.
Explaination: The lady in the viral video is not Canadian PM Justin Trudeau’s wife Sophie Grégoire Trudeau but a British national namely Tara Jane Langston.
Label: False

Claim: The King of Spain has plagiarized his COVID-19 speech from a book.
Explaination: A picture shows a fragment of the King's speech and the image of a book as if the king had plagiarized his words from a writer.
Label: False

Claim: The schools in Bizkaia in Spain do not close until September.
Explaination: The Education ministry of The Basque Country denies it to Newtral.es.
Label: False

Claim: A video posted on Twitter shows a group of Chinese people converting to Islam under the argument that Muslims are immune to COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is false. Islamic people are not immune to COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Doctors are giving out “rescue packs” for people with pre-existing respiratory conditions.
Explaination: There is no evidence that doctors in Ireland are giving out packs containing steroids and antibiotics to people with pre-existing respiratory conditions, such as asthma or COPD. On the contrary, doctors have advised that such a move would not be safe, given the different needs that each patient would have.
Label: False

Claim: “If you are in Las Vegas and you get a knock on your door from NV Power, 2020 Census or CVD-19 testers, do not open your door. They are robbing people at gunpoint.”
Explaination: Las Vegas police said they have received no such reports. Similar rumors are being spread around the country.
Label: False

Claim: If people violate the quarantine measures in Ukraine, they will be imprisoned.
Explaination: According to the law on coronavirus in Ukraine, there is no such measure.
Label: False

Claim: Pets can transmit the new coronavirus.
Explaination: The is no proof that pets can transmit the new coronavirus, although the droplets with the virus can stay on pets and, then, get into the human organism.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Fill out a 2020 U.S. Census form to receive an economic stimulus payment.
Explaination: U.S. government relief payments for coronavirus relief will be determined by tax returns, not census information.
Label: False

Claim: Rinsing throat and nose with warm and salt water will prevent the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Rinsing the throat and washing the nose with salty water may slightly alleviate the cold. However, it does not help with respiratory diseases, including COVID-19. The effectiveness of such treatment or prevention of the new coronavirus is not proven.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A photo circulating on Facebook in Nigeria appears to show President Muhammadu Buhari shaking hands with the nation’s Code of Conduct Bureau Chairman Mohammed Isa while both men are wearing face masks — seemingly against precautions during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The image was doctored using an old photo, taken long before the pandemic.
Label: False

Claim: The death of Kobe Bryant overshadowed the news that an American drugmaker was hustling to make a vaccine for coronavirus, and 200 people died of COVID-19 in August 2019 in the USA.
Explaination: There was an article about American drugmakers working on a new vaccine to counter the rapidly spreading respiratory virus publishing on the American daily newspaper, USA Today, on January 24. But the feature didn't mention a death toll of 200 in August 2019.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Worshipers were beaten by policemen because they gathered in a church.
Explaination: We found the same video published on Twitter on November 2019, so before the outbreak of coronavirus. The caption was : "Zimbabwe riot police attacked opposition party MDC Alliance supporters today who had gathered to hear leader, Nelson Chamisa, give his Hope of the Nation Address." Other pictures on Twitter and within AFP archives allow us to match the video with this anti riot police operation.
Label: False

Claim: A Chinese woman in Mombasa was attacked and killed after showing flu-like symptoms and refusing to go to hospital.
Explaination: The article uses an image from the 2013 Westgate terror attack in Kenya, and police in the area also had not received any information about the attack.
Label: False

Claim: 22 travelers in Uganda for the EU-Uganda Business Summit scheduled for early March had refused to go into quarantine.
Explaination: The 22 travellers had refused to go into quarantine and opted to travel back to their home countries, but they were not in Uganda for the conference as claimed.
Label: Partially false

Claim: It is recommended to disinfect everything you buy with bleach to prevent infection from the coronavirus.
Explaination: It is not really recommended. Experts say it is better to focus on washing your hands and to follow the official recommandations.
Label: False

Claim: Chloroquine could cure coronavirus.
Explaination: There are not enough conclusive evidence to point out chloroquine as a cure treatment
Label: No evidence

Claim: Stocks of “medical masks” made in Woippy, in Moselle, by a company are being blocked for lack of “agreement of the government,” in spite of a shortage of masks in France.
Explaination: Facebook users did not answer to AFP. Their publications mention a place that does not exist. Woippy mayor told AFP he does not know about a company that is making masks in his city.
Label: False

Claim: Quotes Joe Biden as saying “people who have never died before are now dying from coronavirus.”
Explaination: The quote was first misattributed to President Donald Trump. Joe Biden didn't say it either.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: “19 Tigers fans got infected with COVID-19 in NY.”
Explaination: Although it is true that members of the group “Libres y Lokos”, a bar of a Monterrey soccer team, made a trip to New York, in the United States, to witness the game of Tigres vs New York City FC, it is false that even the March 20, 2020, it has been confirmed that 19 people from the blue-blue bar have contracted the new coronavirus as indicated by an audio circulating on WhatsApp.
Label: False

Claim: People with type O blood are more resistant to COVID-19.
Explaination: "It circulates on social networks and in various media portals, a note that ensures that a study establishes that certain blood groups are more resistant (or even immune) to the COVID-19 virus. This information is DECEPTIVE. Although this clinical trial was carried out, this is a preliminary study published on the medRxiv portal, a free online archive and distribution server for complete (unpublished) manuscripts from the medical, clinical and health-related sciences."
Label: False

Claim: Russia unleashed more than 500 lions on its streets to ensure that people are staying indoors during this pandemic outbreak.
Explaination: Russian President Vladimir Putin hasn’t resorted to releasing lions in order to keep people inside during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: A purported warning from Australian hospitals has been shared thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook that using petrol pumps can enable the spread of the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; Australia’s Department of Health said it did not issue the purported advisory; scientists say the virus is unlikely to survive on petrol pumps outside as sunlight and lack of moisture generally kill it; motorists are advised to regularly wash their hands to avoid infection.
Label: False

Claim: Biden campaign claims a top CDC official was “silenced.”
Explaination: Messonnier’s remarks on Feb. 25 may have caught the attention of Wall Street and caused angst in the White House. But we cannot find evidence of her being immediately silenced, as Klain claims in the video.
Label: Four Pinocchios

Claim: Denmark passed from 200 new cases of COVID-19 in one day to only 26 cases.
Explaination: These numbers are not in line with the national authorities, it was never reported 200 or 26 news cases in one day in Denmark. On March 19, there were 75 new cases in the country.
Label: False

Claim: Korean drama predicted the occurrence of COVID-19 in 2018.
Explaination: The korean series didn't talk about COVID-19 but used SARS as a reference in creating a highly lethal coronavirus that have very different death rates, symptoms and incubation period .
Label: False

Claim: There are more than 6 000 coronavirus infections in Ukraine. The government hides the real numbers.
Explaination: The real numbers in any country are unknown. The aim of such publications is to spread panic.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Pets can transmit the new coronavirus.
Explaination: The is no proof that pets can transmit the new coronavirus, although the droplets with the virus can stay on pets and, then, get into the human organism.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The quarantine in Italy showed more clean waters in Venice with fish and a dolphin.
Explaination: It is not true, the image of a dolphin was taken in another Italian city, Cagliari, in the Sardinia island, and not in Venice. It was not due to the quarantine.
Label: False

Claim: Muammar Gaddafi predicted the current coronavirus pandemic, and warned it would be created by the same people who would then sell  the “antidotes.”
Explaination: In a speech to the UN General Assembly in 2009, the late Libyan leader did speculate about the creation of viruses and express his concern about the sale of vaccines. But he did not say the quote attributed to him, and he did not "predict" coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: A post shared thousands of times on Facebook lists companies whose chief executive officers have allegedly stepped down during the novel coronavirus crisis.
Explaination: some of the 19 CEOs remain in their positions, while the announcements that others were leaving came before the virus emerged in late 2019.
Label: False

Claim: A video from a British broadcaster shows Italian coronavirus victims got taken down.
Explaination: The report is still available on Sky News and was not removed.
Label: False

Claim: Italy’s president was caught on camera crying over and regretting country’s coronavirus response.
Explaination: The man in the video is not even Italy's president. It was an older video of Brazil's president at a Thanksgiving service.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus life span in a single place is 8 hours, and the Janata Curfew in India is for 14 hours. Thanks to 12 hours of Janata Curfew, the virus will be killed.
Explaination: Social Distancing Is Important; But Viral Post Claiming 14-Hr Break Will Kill COVID-19 Is Misleading.
Label: Misleading

Claim: This is a self-check test for coronavirus.
Explaination: No, holding your breath for 10 seconds isn't a coronavirus ‘Self-check test. Keeping your throat moist and drinking water every 15 minutes cannot kill coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Egypt discovered a treatment for COVID-19.
Explaination: Egypt MOH refuted the claim to Fatabyyano and later on it official Facebook page.
Label: False

Claim: Claim that the outbreak of COVID-19 is not real.
Explaination: WHO, CDC, ECDC, Ministry of Health as well as multiple other agencies claim the outbreak is real.
Label: False

Claim: Claim that the outbreak of the virus was caused by 5G.
Explaination: No proof to link 5G network with the outbreak of the virus.
Label: False

Claim: Elderly people who are caught wandering outside in Brazil will have their pensions canceled by the government.
Explaination: INSS (government body responsible for paying the pensions to retirees) says no such measure has been considered.
Label: False

Claim: Photos show Maju Coutinho (a well known Brazilian journalist) walking around in Leblon beach with her boyfriend, even though she is urging people to stay inside during the pandemic.
Explaination: Pictures are from 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Burglars are disguised as health agents to invade and rob apartment buildings in Belo Horizonte and Goiânia.
Explaination: Police forces from Goiás and Minas Gerais deny these occurrences.
Label: False

Claim: Atacadão, a supermarket chain in Brazil, is distributing goods for free. You might get them if you leave a comment on the post.
Explaination: This is a scam used for acquiring Facebook logins and passwords.
Label: False

Claim: “The chloroquine stock in Paris hospitals was robbed”.
Explaination: The chloroquine stocks had lowered drastically, but there have been no robbery.
Label: False

Claim: This graph compares coronavirus deaths with other diseases.
Explaination: Specialists emphasize that the comparison is misleading because it is a new virus that is still spreading and has not reached its "maximum circulation" like the other diseases mentioned.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Romania is introducing a new law that will penalize breaking the quarantine with 15 years of imprisonment.
Explaination: 15 years of imprisonment is maximum length of punishment for those who knowingly spread the contagious disease and their action resulted in death of others. Breaking the quarantine will be punishable up to 3 years of imprisonment or fine.
Label: Partially false

Claim: COVID-19 was created in a lab to be used as a biological weapon.
Explaination: Nature Medicine magazine published on 17th March that scientists have found Sars-CoV-2 is very different from other coronaviruses and hasn´t evidence of being manipulated or created in lab but it is product of "natural selection". A the the other hands, sources are all-Moscow related and alt-right, conspiracy theories and antisemitism approaches
Label: False

Claim: India will go under lockdown from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20.
Explaination: Government Of India has clarified that this audio is fake and has no authenticity.
Label: False

Claim: Viral post claims that a COVID-19 infected patient was found in Hsipaw township hospital in Myanmar.
Explaination: Both ministry of health and sports and Hsipaw township medical superintendent have issued patient had not contracted the COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: “Gale of the wind” and “Neem Tree” leaves are good medicine to protect from the coronavirus.
Explaination: As stated by WHO still there is no official remedy or cure for COVID-19, while some of the traditional methods have symptomatic improvements.
Label: False

Claim: Pope Francis ran away at a public meeting due to coronavirus fear.
Explaination: This video dates back to 2019 and is not related to COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Bitter gourd juice can cure coronavirus.
Explaination: Bitter gourd juice cannot cure coronavirus, there is no cure to coronavirus as of this date.
Label: False

Claim: After COVID-19 outbreak in europe Muslims and non-Muslims have come out in the streets shouting praises for Allah and reading Kalma.
Explaination: Fact Crescendo found the viral video to be unrelated. The video dates back before the outbreak of COVID-19 in Europe. This is a demonstration march by the citizens in Hamburg, Germany in solidarity with Uyghur Muslims.
Label: False

Claim: Saddam Hussein predicted the coronavirus outbreak 40 years ago.
Explaination: The video is edited and was shot before the Iraq war. In the video Saddam Hussein can be seen discussing prospects of war with his military advisors and son Qusay. There's no mention of CoronaVirus in the actual video.
Label: False

Claim: Eight COVID-19 patients in Ghana have recovered.
Explaination: Please read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Persons with blood type A are more prone to coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence to show that people with blood type A are more likely to get ‘COVID-19’.
Label: Unproven

Claim: People with type A blood are more prone to get the new coronavirus.
Explaination: The study is preliminary and there is no scientific evidence that supports the relation between type blood and Covid-19.
Label: FALSE

Claim: There’s definitive proof that chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine, are effective against COVID-19.
Explaination: Studies have shown some early promise, but it's not entirely solid to say the treatments work against coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Fox News won Pulitzer for coronavirus coverage.
Explaination: Claim made on website that is clearly labeled as satire.
Label: False

Claim: WhatsApp chain sent by a doctor at Vall d’Hebron Hospital (Barcelona) about coronavirus
Explaination: That doctor didn't write chain. The chain also makes some inaccurate claims.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Video recorded by a Muslim resident in Spain who accumulates supplies for coronavirus
Explaination: The product brands shown in the video are Dutch.
Label: False

Claim: El País publishes that Renfe is proposing an ERTE for its employees due to the coronavirus.
Explaination: El Pais' has not published the article and Renfe denies that they are considering apply an ERTE.
Label: False

Claim: These remarks were made by Spanish Health official Fernando Simón “9 days ago”
Explaination: These remarks were made on January 31, not 9 days ago.
Label: False

Claim: MIlitary planes are going to fumigate the region of Comunidad Valenciana to disinfect it from coronavirus
Explaination: Ministry of Defense said there is not going to be such action.
Label: False

Claim: Speech from Spanish King Felipe VI about coronavirus was plagiarized from the book “Palmeras en la Nieve” or “Las Palmeras.”
Explaination: It is not king's speech about coronavirus, but from years ago about Catalonia. This speech was afterwards included in the book "Las Palmeras". There is no plagiarism.
Label: False

Claim: A WhatsApp forward claims Prime Minister Narendra Modi called for a 14-hour long “Janta Curfew” on 3/22/20 from 7 a.m. to 9 p.m. because the lifespan of the coronavirus in one place is only 12 hours and if we all follow the Janta Curfew religiously, then the chain will be broken
Explaination: There is no clear information on the lifespan of the novel coronavirus. However, various study reports have suggested a similar lifespan as that of other coronaviruses. PM Modi’s motive behind calling for a ‘Janta Curfew’ was just to curb the spreading of novel coronavirus and the Government has not claimed that the Janta Curfew is called to kill the virus hence the claim turned out to ‘Misleading’ in our fact-check.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister YS Jagan Reddy has claimed that Paracetamol is the only medication for coronavirus.
Explaination: It is evident from our findings and Dr. Pandey’s testimony that Paracetamol can help with the coronavirus symptoms but it cannot entirely cure coronavirus. We also found that Paracetamol is not the only medication that can help with coronavirus symptoms as there are many medications.
Label: False

Claim: The United States of America threatened Iraq with coronavirus in 1990.
Explaination: According to the AP Archive description, Saddam Hussein said, “If God wills it and we have to run after the enemy, then we will do it.” Also, in AP’s description, we found that Saddam Hussein did not refer to the word ‘Coronavirus’ in the original video.
Label: False

Claim: Education Ministry will approve the exams of every student in Spain.
Explaination: The ministry of educations debunks this claim.
Label: False

Claim: Vladimir Putin accused the “rest of the leaders” of having a plan to “reduce the world population.”
Explaination: The subtitles are manipulated.
Label: False

Claim: People are committing suicide due to the quarantine in Spain.
Explaination: National Police of Valencia confirms that the images that are shared these days are from last year.
Label: False

Claim: A Facebook post suggests that China has created the new coronavirus in order to kill 1% of its population.
Explaination: There is no evidence that supports this claim.
Label: False

Claim: Don’t take NSAIDs. This medicine worsens the symptom.
Explaination: The French health minister has made a similar statement while the health authorities of EU, UK, Taiwan said there is no enough evidence to support that claim.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: If you see a person wearing a white wristband, leave him alone. He is under quarantine.
Explaination: The measure of the electronic wristband is implemented in Hong Kong, not Taiwan. The picture is miscaptioned.
Label: Partially false

Claim: The symptoms of the first nine days when one contracts COVID-19.
Explaination: COVID-19 patients don't have the exact same symptoms. The most common symptoms are fever, tiredness, and dry cough. Some patients may have aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat or diarrhea.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Many foreigners wiped their saliva onto the handle of Taipei’s metro to spread COVID-19.
Explaination: The videos were filmed in Hong Kong and Brussels, not in Taiwan.
Label: Partially false

Claim: The spokesman for Chinese Foreign Ministry Zhao Lijian: American CDC admitted that COVID-19 patients were misdiagnosed as flu. U.S. Army is responsible for the outbreak in Wuhan.
Explaination: China's Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian tweeted and commanded.
Label: False

Claim: University of Vienna declares Ibuprofen makes the COVID-19 disease worse.
Explaination: University of Vienna denied the research. The relation between ibuprofen intake and COVID-19 is still under investigation.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Dr. Yavuz Dizdar’s multiple allegations around the COVID-19.
Explaination: Dr. Dizdar is an oncologist, not an expert in the field. The allegations are based on the interpretation, not scientific evidence.
Label: False

Claim: An audio clip suggests that the WHO has advised a lockdown.
Explaination: A source in WHO confirmed that the organisation has not put out any such information as heard in the viral audio clip.
Label: False

Claim: In an Ethiopian Airlines flight from Italy to Addis Ababa airport this evening, most of the passengers are infected with the virus, and there is no strength except in God.
Explaination: The visuals actually pertain to a mock rescue drill that took place at Blaise Diagne Airport near the town of Diass, Senegal. The incident dates back to 28 November 2019 and was a simple simulation aimed at evaluating the capacity to respond to various crises that may arise during airport operations.
Label: False

Claim: Saddam Hussein talked about coronavirus to his cabinet and army in the nineties. He said that America has threatened him to spread this virus if he doesn’t follow their command.
Explaination: The viral video is a doctored version of the original video shared by Associated Press in 2015. The audios of both the videos are different not only in terms of their content but voice as well. In the original AP video, Saddam Hussein does not mention the word ‘virus’ or ‘coronavirus.’
Label: False

Claim: Janta curfew in India will help break the chain of transmission.
Explaination: The World Health Organisation has maintained that it is not certain how long the virus that causes COVID-19 survives on surfaces, but it seems to behave like other coronaviruses.
Label: False

Claim: Hospitals are advising people to wear gloves at petrol pumps.
Explaination: The hospital named in the message confirmed that it did not issue this advice, and health authorities, including the Chief Medical Officer, said that the public is not being advised to do this.
Label: False

Claim: Gargling with warm salt water can cure from the coronavirus.
Explaination: Post claiming gargling with warm salt water can save from coronavirus is fake as per health organizations and experts.
Label: False

Claim: The original form of the Corona COVID-19 virus after being enlarged 2,600 times
Explaination: Both ministry of health and sports and Sipaw township medical superintendent have issued patient had not contracted the COVID-19.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Video of the American Army distributing the coronavirus in China.
Explaination: The man in the first video is a train passenger in Belgium who is drunk. While the man in the second video is a company manager in Hong Kong who intentionally made a parody video. The narrative that contains the conspiracy theory "the American army is the spreader of the Corona COVID-19 virus to China" comes from one Chinese official who has not been able to prove the truth.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar can kill coronavirus.
Explaination: An image was shared on WhatsApp claiming that gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar can kill COVID-19. There is no evidence that asserts the claims. The WHO reminds that there is still no medicine or household remedy to treat coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: President Donald Trump tried to buy a vaccine developed in Germany.
Explaination: In an audio a woman said that Trump tried to buy a vaccine that was developed in Germany. However, the german CureVac laboratory denied the allegations on March 16.
Label: False

Claim: A WhatsApp message resembling an Nigerian CDC circular says Nigeria has not placed a travel ban or provided quarantine measures for travellers from countries with coronavirus cases.
Explaination: As at when the message was received, Nigeria was yet to establish travel restrictions; it has since so imposed said restrictions on 13 high-risk countries. Also, contrary to the claim, there are and have always been quarantine measures for migrants into the country.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: University of Vienna declares Ibuprofen makes the COVID-19 disease worse.
Explaination: University of Vienna denied the research. The relation between ibuprofen intake and COVID-19 is still under investigaion.
Label: PARTLY FALSE

Claim: Spain is the European country where the coronavirus is more lethal.
Explaination: Spain is not the European country where the coronavirus is most lethal, it is Italy.
Label: False

Claim: Spaniards need to carry a work certificate or purchase receipts to justify to the Security Forces why they have taken to the streets under the state of alarm.
Explaination: It is not mandatory, but it helps to facilitate police controls.
Label: False

Claim: Chloroquine cures COVID-19.
Explaination: Studies with chloroquine are ongoing and are not conclusive.
Label: Partially false

Claim: A post has been shared tens of thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter which claims that a factory in the Australian city of Melbourne has been hoarding essential supplies including baby formula, toilet paper and hand sanitiser for export to China during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; police said the accusation was "false". The company cited in the misleading posts also refuted the claim.
Label: False

Claim: Chloroquine was forbidden by a French government decree in January.
Explaination: The legal decree did not forbid chloroquine, but sets up a new requirement to be allowed to be given this medicine: people need to have a prescription. This change followed a recommendation of the national agence of medicine (ANSM), made on December 13, 2019, so before the outbreak of coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: A post giving a nurse’s advice not to be infected by coronavirus. The nurse is called Claire Magne and works at hospitals in Toulouse, or in Marseille, depending on publications.
Explaination: Quoted hospitals in the publications both denied to AFP having a Claire Magne working for them.
Label: False

Claim: An audio circulating on WhatsApp says the way to end the COVID-19 pandemic is by “creating herd immunity groups.” Supposedly, it is a group of people who, thanks to their “positive thoughts and diet,,” manage to “alkalize their body” and prevent the virus from spreading.
Explaination: Immunity is not achieved through food or the mind.
Label: False

Claim: Deputy of the Movement to Socialism (MAS) in Bolivia, Juana Quispe Ari: USA created the anthrax disease.
Explaination: Actual medicine Information of the disease explain why this is not true.
Label: False

Claim: Bolivian Government Minister, Arturo Murillo, said that COVID-19 “is a type of cold”.
Explaination: The bolivian former minister of Health, Guillermo Cuentas Yañez tells about: “In no way it is a cold”.
Label: False

Claim: The Whatsapp audio that states absolute quarantine in Bolivia is from Andrés Rojas, the CEO of Bolivia TV.
Explaination: Bolivia Verifica contacted the deputy of Movement of Socialism (MAS), Franklin Flores, who denied that the audio is from Bolivia. He also explained that when it (The state of Bolivia) comes to emergency, no law projects are carried out.
Label: False

Claim: Ugandan landlords have been asked by the government to stop collecting rent as citizens stay home to fight COVID-19.
Explaination: A letter allegedly from State House Uganda directing landlords in the country to stop collecting rent as Ugandans stay home to fight COVID-19 is not authentic.
Label: False

Claim: An article claims that a Kenyan died from COVID-19 on 3/20/20.
Explaination: An article claiming that a Kenyan had died from COVID-19 on 20 March is false.
Label: False

Claim: An image of coffins showing the victims of COVID-19 in Italy.
Explaination: A Facebook post with an image claiming to show the victims of COVID-19 in Italy uses a photo of the coffins of African immigrants who drowned off the coast near Lampedusa in 2013.
Label: False

Claim: Persons with blood type A are more prone to coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence to show that people with blood type A are more likely to get ‘Covid-19’.
Label: Unproven

Claim: An image of coffins in Italy.
Explaination: The image was taken in 2013.
Label: FALSE

Claim: President Rodrigo Duterte said COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus, is only transmitted through contact with other people.
Explaination: The novel coronavirus is known to spread mainly from person to person, but it can also spread through infected surfaces or objects.
Label: False

Claim: U.S. President Donald Trump said in a White House briefing on 3/20/20 that chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, which are often used to treat malaria, have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for treatment of COVID-19.
Explaination: Chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine is FDA-approved for treating malaria, lupus, and rheumatoid arthritis, but not COVID-19. There is no official cure for the disease as of March 25.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Says truck drivers are being turned away from fast-food restaurants during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explaination: Truck drivers are having issues getting meals at some fast-food chains with shuttered dining rooms. Their rigs can't fit in drive-thru lanes and they aren't allowed to walk up and order at the window.
Label: Mostly True

Claim: This picture show dozens of coffins in Italy because of the coronavirus.
Explaination: This pictures has been taken in 2013, it has no links with the current pandemia.
Label: False

Claim: It is forbidden to be more than one in a car in France during the lockdown.
Explaination: You have to follow some rules, but it is not always forbidden.
Label: False

Claim: 1720, 1919, 2020… Every hundred years, a pandemia “cleans” the Earth.
Explaination: Multiples pandemia occurred outside of this timeframe.
Label: False

Claim: The French Education Minister has postponed the summer holidays because of the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The minister said the measure was not considered for the moment.
Label: False

Claim: “Wisconsin is the only state where all Republicans voted against protecting its citizens.”
Explaination: Wisconsin is indeed the only one of the 50 states where all Republicans voted no. But it’s a bit of an exaggeration to describe that vote as “against protecting its citizens.”
Label: MOSTLY TRUE

Claim: “Fish tank additive may treat coronavirus.”
Explaination: Fish-tank cleaners containing chloroquine cannot be substituted for prescription drugs used to treat malaria. The FDA says you should not take chloroquine unless it has been prescribed by a doctor and obtained from a legitimate source.
Label: False

Claim: Romania is introducing new law that will penalize breaking the quarantine with 15 years of imprisonment.
Explaination: 15 years of imprisonment is maximum length of punishment for those who knowingly spread the contagious disease and their action resulted in death of others. Breaking the quarantine will be punishable up to 3 years of imprisonment or fine.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Italian doctor saying no one has died from coronavirus.
Explaination: The interviewed mentioned as a source is from late February when the coronavirus outbreak in Italy wasn't that significant. At the moment, this doctor has changed his position on coronavirus and casualties.
Label: False

Claim: A post claims that there are no cases of the new coronavirus in Russia.
Explaination: In the day that the post was published there were already 147 people infected with COVID-19, according to the national authorities.
Label: False

Claim: Using hot air from a hair dryer on sinuses can prevent and treat COVID-19
Explaination: No evidence supports this theory. Directing hot air to sinuses will make it dry which cause tiny tears that may increase the risk of getting COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: A runny nose is not a COVID-19 symptom.
Explaination: Even the fever and dry cough are the most symptom for COVID-19, runny nose also one of its. In Thailand, 25% of patients has runny nose.
Label: False

Claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube in March 2020 alongside a claim that it shows police in Spain detaining people during a lockdown due to the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video has circulated in reports about an anti-government protest in Azerbaijan in October 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Romania has changed the law so that those who break the quarantine will face 15 years in prison.
Explaination: 15 years is maximum potential punishment (from 7 up to 15 years of imprisonment) but not for those who break the quarantine but for those infected who willingly spread contagious disease and it will be proven to result in death of other people.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Recording of a conversation where one claims to be a friend of the WHO India Director’s brother, Saurabh, who gave him information that India will go into a complete lockdown mode from 4/15/20April to 6/15/20.
Explaination: WHO’s official in SEARO confirmed to us that the viral audio on social media is “Fake”.
Label: False

Claim: Bitter gourd juice can cure coronavirus in just two hours.
Explaination: PIB India clarified that this viral message is Fake. According to WHO there is no cure medicine discovered or recommended to cure coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Ibuprofen is not good as a possible COVID-19 treatment.
Explaination: University of Vienna denied the research. The relation between Ibuprofen and COVID-19 is not clear yet.
Label: Partially false

Claim: A photo of coffins of dead people as a result of the new coronavirus.
Explaination: The images were taken in October 2013.
Label: False

Claim: People with type A blood are more prone to get the new coronavirus.
Explaination: The study is preliminary and there is no scientific evidence that supports the relation between type blood and COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Persons with type A blood are more prone to the coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence to show that people with blood type A are more likely to get ‘COVID-19’.
Label: No evidence

Claim: Coronavirus is spreading rapidly on gas pumps.
Explaination: Experts confirm it can spread on gas pumps but not more than on any other location.
Label: False

Claim: Retirement cut for elderly people who take to the streets during quarantine.
Explaination: Message circulating on WhatsApp simulates Social Security statement and cites provisional measure, which is unrelated to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Label: False

Claim: Ambev company will distribute hand sanitizer to the population.
Explaination: The company will distribute alcohol gel to health establishments, not to the entire population.
Label: False

Claim: Using sauna or aiming a hairdryer at one’s nose will kill the coronavirus.
Explaination: Expert in infectious diseases said it won't make any impact against coronavirus, and the heat could be damaging if excessive.
Label: False

Claim: Belgium’s health minister banned sex inside or with 3 or more people.
Explaination: This is a satirical article.
Label: False

Claim: Bill Gates has access to your DNA and ownership in WHO.
Explaination: Gates is not behind testing because each country does that themselves.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus is an illusion and the cause of COVID-19 is the 5G signal.
Explaination: The virus was found in the secretions of the patients all over the world which is detected by PCR, COVID-19 is present in countries that doesn't support 5G till now.
Label: False

Claim: Giant hornets migrated to Europe due to the outbreak of coronavirus.
Explaination: The authors of the article stole older material on hornets and climate change and wrote headline about coronavirus
Label: False

Claim: Photo shows row of coffins in Italy. Claims that this is how Bergamo in Italy deals with the dead from the virus.
Explaination: The photo was taken in 2013, amidst the migration crisis.
Label: False

Claim: Video showing police beating people in China, linked with the outbreak.
Explaination: The video shows police beating people in Hong Kong. The video was shot on the last day of August 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Breathing air from a hair dryer or a sauna can prevent or cure COVID-19
Explaination: This is false; an expert in coronaviruses said these methods would not be effective, while a cell biologist said there is no evidence the virus can be treated via heat.
Label: False

Claim: A purported advisory has been shared repeatedly in multiple Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp posts that claims a disinfectant will be sprayed into the air overnight in India in an effort to kill the novel coronavirus, COVID-19. The posts urge residents to remain indoors during the spraying.
Explaination: The claim is false; Indian authorities said the advisory was "fake" and that no such measure had been announced.
Label: FALSE

Claim: In France, Mulhouse’s ice rink has been converted into a morgue.
Explaination: Mulhouse city hall and a hockey club, which is used to practising on this rink, had denied the claim.
Label: False

Claim: People who replied to a French government text with texts saying they won’t respect confinement measures are now facing justice.
Explaination: The Nanterre Court denied having received any instruction to prosecute senders of these messages, and the messages present many inconsistencies.
Label: False

Claim: The RDC government canceled every future exams for pupils, because of coronavirus.
Explaination: The minister of Education, Willy Bakonga, denied this claim to AFP.
Label: False

Claim: Netflix is offering free access to anyone in Brazil during the coronavirus crisis.
Explaination: Netflix is not offering free services during the pandemic. The URL used is not a Netflix domain.
Label: False

Claim: Petrobras (Brazil’s largest oil company) is closing its refineries from March 24th onwards.
Explaination: The alleged press release did not come from Petrobras. Refineries are not going to be shut down for now.
Label: False

Claim: A man claims his dog was vaccinated for coronavirus, thus the SARS-Cov-2 is not really a new virus.
Explaination: Canine coronavirus (CCov) and the novel coronavirus are not the same virus.
Label: False

Claim: Uber will suspend operations for 10 days in Brazil due to the pandemic.
Explaination: The alleged announcement did not come from Uber, and the company will not stop working during the crisis.
Label: False

Claim: Popular Cardiologist Devi Shetty talking about symptoms of COVID-19.
Explaination: The person in question is a different doctor and not the famous cardiologist.
Label: False

Claim: India asked for restriction of movement.
Explaination: The notification is from Malaysia and not India.
Label: False

Claim: India spraying pesticides at night to prevent COVID-19.
Explaination: Officials stated that no pesticides were being sprayed.
Label: False

Claim: Image claims to show dozens of coffins of Italians who have died from COVID-19.
Explaination: The photo actually shows the caskets of African migrants who died in a 2013 shipwreck off the coast of Italy.
Label: False

Claim: In this video Putin said: “Powerful of the world, I am aware of his diabolical plans to reduce the population”.
Explaination:
The captions were changed to make people believe that the Russian president said things he did not say at the time.
The video was recorded at an event commemorating World War II.
Label: False

Claim: Spaniards are violating quarantine rules.
Explaination: The video was recorded in October 2019 days before the exhumation of the remains of the dictator Francisco Franco.
Label: False

Claim: The recommendations against coronavirus in the viral WhatsApp audio were made by the owner of Swiss Medical (private health insurance company).
Explaination:
A report by the Conicet Sensory Research Laboratory indicates that, although it is limited, there is evidence that the audio does not belong to the businessman.
The company denied that the audio was recorded by the president of the company.
Label: False

Claim: The WHO recommended that all countries go into quarantine to combat COVID-19.
Explaination: In networks and the media, it has been stated that the World Health Organization, WHO, "recommended that all countries declare themselves in quarantine to combat COVID-19". However, the WHO itself denied it.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows the Russian leader Vladimir Putin, giving a speech with captions that make him seem like he is rebuking world leaders.
Explaination: A video is being moved on Facebook and Twitter in which Vladimir Putin, the President of Russia, is seen giving a speech in front of a crowd. The video is accompanied by Spanish subtitles that make it appear that you are criticizing the leaders of other countries for their recent actions. Some social network users even shared the video as if this were Putin's response to the handling that other countries have given to the coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus was created in a biological laboratory in Wuhan.
Explaination: There is no evidence that 'the coronavirus comes from a biological laboratory in Wuhan,' as claimed by Mexican youtuber Alexander Backman.
Label: False

Claim: Polish charity organisation WOSP has withdrawn its donation to coronavirus fight in Poland.
Explaination: There was no decision of backing down whatsoever. WOSP couldn't possibly donate the money it collected during public gathering as there was clearly stated goal for that gathering that can't be changed afterwards. WOSP is involved in many activities supporting coronavirus fight.
Label: False

Claim: You no longer need to have contact with someone to get the coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Donald Trump said about coronavirus, “People are dying who have never died before.”
Explaination: Ernest Hemingway said it.
Label: (Org. doesn't apply rating)

Claim: IDH Hospital, the main center in Sri Lanka for treating COVID-19 patients, is in shortage of number of essentials.
Explaination: We contacted both doctors and health officials and confirmed that there is no shortage of goods at the hospital as of yet and the messages were fabricated.
Label: False

Claim: You should leave your shoes outside, as they carry the virus.
Explaination: Official sources say this is not true.
Label: False

Claim: These images show coffins of COVID-19 victims in Italy.
Explaination: Images in question were actually taken in 2013.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese claim that the virus was created in 2015 in US.
Explaination: There's no evidence that supports this claim.
Label: False

Claim: Ibuprofen aggravates patients with the new coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence that conclusively proves ibuprofen aggravates coronavirus patients.
Label: False

Claim: 5G technology caused the coronavirus.
Explaination: Historical events were conflated, and did not back up claims with real evidence.
Label: False

Claim: WHO director overstated COVID-19 fatality rate as higher than flu.
Explaination: CDC data and doctors said that coronavirus has much higher mortality rate than flu.
Label: False

Claim: Walmart is closing hundreds of its stores.
Explaination: This story is several years old, and there has been no recent announcement.
Label: False

Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo bought private island to escape coronavirus.
Explaination: Ronaldo's management company confirmed it was false.
Label: False

Claim: Trump said “people are dying who have never died before”.
Explaination: Searches in databases of the phrase never show up. Other fact checks confirm fabrication.
Label: False

Claim: Obama family flown to private island to escape coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: Website has visible disclaimers saying it is purely satire.
Label: False

Claim: Link takes viewers to application for FEMA assistance in the US.
Explaination: Link just takes you to a meme picture.
Label: False

Claim: Cuba has a vaccine against the coronavirus called Interferón.
Explaination: The interferon is a drug used in certain countries to mitigate the spread of COVID-19, but it is not a vaccine.
Label: False

Claim: Cuba’s health ministry, Dr. Hala, has given the vaccine against the coronavirus to China.
Explaination: For the moment, there is no vaccine against COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: The parks of Adra, in Spain, are being fumigated with poison.
Explaination: Local and national police explain to Newtral.es that it is not true.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking water every 15 minutes helps to avoid the contagion of cononavirus.
Explaination: It is false that drinking water every 15 minutes helps to avoid COVID-19 by "cleaning" your throat.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Katy Perry, Madonna and Black Sabbath shared videos of Italy’s flash mob with fake audio.
Explaination: All the videos have real images but fake audios. In the first case – Katy Perry – Italians are singing the song Roar instead of the national anthem (real video). In the second case – Madonna and Black Sabbath – Italians are singing I rise or War pigs instead of Macarena (real video).
Label: Misleading

Claim: Coronavirus stays in throat for four days before arriving lungs. Gargling with salt water or vinegar kills the coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no evidence that rinsing the mouth with salty water or vinegar can prevent COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: A magic remedy to prevent COVID-19: mix brown sugar, ginger, garlic, and Chinese leek, boil them and drink it.
Explaination: There is no evidence that the recipe can prevent or cure COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Remedy recipe: (1) boil tea with bitter melon. (2) Lemon juice with salt or Chinese mesona
Explaination: There is no evidence that the recipe can prevent or cure COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows how American soldiers spread coronavirus during 7th CISM Military World Game in Wuhan.
Explaination: The video happened in Brussels on march. It is not happened in Wuhan or Taipei.
Label: False

Claim: Italians played the Chinese national anthem to thank China. People yelled “Grazie Cina”.
Explaination: It's a video of Italian expressing gratitude to medical staff. The soundtrack of "Grazie Cina" and the Chinese national anthem was edited into the original video
Label: False

Claim: A dog in Hong Kong died of COVID-19.
Explaination: Vets shared the test results with Teyit. Dog's tests were negative for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows a balcony party in the Turkish capital Ankara due to quarantine.
Explaination: The video is originally from Spain and manipulated with a Turkish song on top of it.
Label: False

Claim: Korean series My Secret Terrius predicted the outbreak in advance.
Explaination: The series was about an international conspiracy, not a outbreak. The fictional virus was quite different from the current one.
Label: False

Claim: Sitting in the sunlight will help cure coronavirus.
Explaination: The answer to this statement, according to doctors, is more than just true or false. Professor Ramanan Laxminarayan, Director of Centre for Disease Dynamics, Economics and Policy (CDDEP) said that, “We do not know how heat will affect this coronavirus as of yet. Usually, respiratory pathogens disappear in the summer and in the heat, but we have seen many cases in tropical countries too.”
Label: Misleading

Claim: China recognizes Palestinian doctor as discoverer of Corona COVID-19 virus vaccine
Explaination: Not a single report was discovered about the discovery of the Corona vaccine by Palestinian doctors. Even the doctor who claimed to be the inventor of the vaccine, Manar Saadi Al-Sheenawi, was not found in the Google search engine. In addition, until now, the WHO has not announced the discovery of any vaccine that can treat COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking water every 15 minutes helps to avoid the contagion of cononavirus.
Explaination: It is false that drinking water every 15 minutes helps to avoid Covid-19 by "cleaning" your throat.
Label: FALSE

Claim: An audio message shared by Whatsapp users affirms that COVID-19 dies at 27° Celsius.
Explaination: It is still unknown whether weather and temperature will affect the spread of COVID-19. According to the United States Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), it is currently unknown whether the spread of COVID-19 is reduced in hot seasons.
Label: FALSE

Claim: An audio broadcast on Whatsapp indicates that garlic helps to overcome diseases such as the coronavirus.
Explaination: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), garlic is a healthy food that may have some antimicrobial properties. However, no evidence has been obtained that eating it protects against COVID-19.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Beverages like ‘akpeteshie’, a local Ghanaian brewed spirit made from sugarcane or palm wine, can be used as a substitute for hand sanitizers.
Explaination: Herbal and local gin bitters often do not meet the required alcohol content for an effective hand rub. Thus, they may not be good substitutes for hand sanitizers against the COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Allegations that garlic and a cold shower helps to avoid COVID-19.
Explaination: Doctors say garlic, coal and cold shower don't prevent COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Martial law is imminent in United States.
Explaination: U.S. governments are not planning to implement martial law; National Guard is providing aid and support for communities.
Label: False

Claim: A video of US President Donald Trump and a top US pharmaceutical executive speaking at a press conference has been viewed thousands of times in multiple Facebook, Twitter and YouTube posts alongside a claim that it shows them announcing a vaccine for the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, was “ready” to be administered.
Explaination: The claim is false; neither Trump nor the pharmaceutical executive make any reference to a vaccine being "ready" for distribution; as of March 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) states there is not yet a vaccine for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: A screenshot of a purported internal email disclosing that a bank in the Pakistani city of Rawalpindi was closed after an employee tested positive for the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, has been shared on Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp.
Explaination: The claim is false; the bank said in a statement that “no employee at any” branch had tested positive for COVID-19, and that all branches remained “open and fully operative.”
Label: False

Claim: Homemade recipes for alcohol gel.
Explaination: Making alcohol gel at home is not recommended by medical authorities; it can be ineffective and dangerous.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Netflix is offering free access for those in quarantine.
Explaination: Netflix has not announced free access; message on WhatsApp is a phishing scam.
Label: False

Claim: Posts circulating on social media claim that Ugandan and Kenyan authorities have instructed landlords to stop collecting rent due to the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; the countries have issued public guidance amid the pandemic, but there has been no official communication on rent payments and government officials dismissed the reports.
Label: False

Claim: Crocodiles were spotted swimming in the canals of Venice without the bustle of tourists.
Explaination: The photo is a composite image making up of two photographs.
Label: False

Claim: The canals in Venice have become cleaner after the shutdown, attracting schools of fish and dolphins.
Explaination: The video was filmed in Cagliari, Italy, a harbor city 743 kilometers away from Venice.
Label: False

Claim: Four men were tested positive to COVID-19 in Cameroon and ran away from the hospital.
Explaination: These four men published many videos on Facebook to debunk this claim. They also told AFP they lived in Italy. Cameroon's Health ministry also told AFP those four men don't belong to the group of people who are in quarantine in Cameroon.
Label: False

Claim: A private lab was denied authorization to perform COVID-19 test.
Explaination: The government only authorizes the National Lab to perform COVID-19 tests.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: Gargling salt water can protect against against COVID-19 by washing down the virus into the gut.
Explaination: Gargling salt water is not a recommended protective measure against COVID-19, and has been debunked by the World Health Organization.
Label: False

Claim: Tanzanian club spokesman Haji S. Manara was infected with COVID-19 during his tour of The Netherlands.
Explaination: Tanzania's Simba Sports Club spokesman Haji S. Manara does not have COVID-19 as claimed, and he was tested after leaving Spain and when he entered the Netherlands.
Label: False

Claim: The World Health Organization is offering free internet for the public to access information about COVID-19.
Explaination: A link circulating on WhatsApp claiming that the World Health Organization is offering free internet to help people access information on COVID-19 is a hoax.
Label: False

Claim: Fake quote of Senator of the Philippines Francis “Kiko” Pangilinan saying he wants children to be exempted from the lockdown.
Explaination: Pangilinan did not say the quote attributed to him. News5 also said the graphic did not come from any of their official social media accounts.
Label: False

Claim: Agnès Buzyn, former french minister of Health, took chloroquine out of a list of drugs that could be sold over the counter when the coronavirus started to spread.
Explaination: The decision was taken before the COVID-19 crisis began.
Label: False

Claim: Claim that “there is no” COVID-19 virus.
Explaination: The coronavirus is real and infecting thousands of people around the world. As of March 19, COVID-19 had infected more than 191,000 people around the world and resulted in 7,807 deaths.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: The federal government is “preparing to mobilize the national guard,” “dispatch them across the US with military” and “announce a nationwide 1 week quarantine for all citizens.”
Explaination: There is no evidence that the federal government is set to announce a lockdown. White House officials have repeatedly said it’s not something they’re considering at this time.
Label: False

Claim: For coronavirus cases “in the U.S. 38% of those hospitalized are under 35.”
Explaination: The CDC reported that between mid-February and mid-March, 20% of the hospitalizations for coronavirus were for patients age 20-44 and 18% were age 45-54.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: “Huge! Results From Breaking Chloroquine Study Show 100% Cure Rate For Patients Infected With The coronavirus.”
Explaination: A French study of 20 COVID-19 patients indicates the drug might help treat the coronavirus. But it is no “100% cure.”
Label: False

Claim: According to Art. 116 of the Constitution, a “state of emergency” will be implemented in Mexico that will limit the free movement of people to combat the #COVID-19 epidemic.
Explaination: This is FALSE, the mentioned article is in the Spanish Constitution, not in the Mexican. Article 116 of the Spanish Constitution speaks of the state of alarm. And to avoid leaving you in doubt, constitutional 116 (the one in Mexico) talks about the division of powers, not "states of emergency."
Label: False

Claim: Biden claims that Trump eliminated the White House pandemic office.
Explaination: One can see the dueling narratives here, neither entirely incorrect. The office — as set up by Obama — was folded into another office. Thus, one could claim the office was eliminated. But the staff slots did not disappear and at least initially the key mission of team remained a priority. So one can also claim nothing changed and thus Biden’s criticism is overstated.
Label: IN DISPUTE

Claim: WHO offers free data for coronavirus info.
Explaination: Links in post lead to external website, potentially with harmful malware. Post is false, clickbait.
Label: False

Claim: Italian Prime Minister Conte has foregone 20% of his salary due to COVID-19.
Explaination: Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte decided to cut his salary on October 2018, months before the outbreak of COVID-19 in Italy.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The Italian National Guard has declared that it will apply a stricter set of rules, called BLS-4, if COVID-19 has not been contained by April the 15th.
Explaination: The authorities have officially denied this fact.
Label: False

Claim: Utility companies Manila Electric Company (Meralco) and Maynilad Water Services Inc are waiving their billings for March 2020 due to the coronavirus crisis.
Explaination: The graphic did not come from the official channels of Meralco and Maynilad. The two utility services are only offering an extension for payments, not cancellation of fees.
Label: False

Claim: Study proves wrong conspiracy theory that China created coronavirus for economic purposes.
Explaination: Scientists have shown that SARS-CoV-2 characteristics indicate a natural origin.
Label: False

Claim: A purported advisory has been shared repeatedly in multiple Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp posts that claims a disinfectant will be sprayed into the air overnight in India in an effort to kill the novel coronavirus, COVID-19. The posts urge residents to remain indoors during the spraying.
Explaination: The claim is false; Indian authorities said the advisory was "fake" and that no such measure had been announced.
Label: False

Claim: Drink water every 15 minutes to avoid coronavirus.
Explaination: It is false that drinking water every 15 minutes helps to avoid COVID-19 by "cleaning" your throat.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking water every 15 minutes helps to avoid the contagion of coronavirus.
Explaination: It is false that drinking water every 15 minutes helps to avoid COVID-19 by "cleaning" your throat.
Label: False

Claim: An audio shared on WhatsApp indicates that the coronavirus “is a psychosocial” and “a political war”.
Explaination: Coronavirus is not a "psychosocial" caused by a "political war". To date, the COVID-19 virus has caused nearly 21,000 deaths in 187 countries where nearly 462,000 cases have been confirmed, according to the latest report released on Wednesday, March 26 by the World Health Organization (WHO). This was one of the audios that circulated on WhatsApp the day that Peruvian President Martín Vizcarra declared the national emergency and ordered the closure of the borders.
Label: False

Claim: An audio broadcast on Whatsapp indicates that garlic helps to overcome diseases such as the coronavirus.
Explaination: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), garlic is a healthy food that may have some antimicrobial properties. However, no evidence has been obtained that eating it protects against COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: An audio message shared by Whatsapp users affirms that COVID-19 dies at 27° Celsius.
Explaination: It is still unknown whether weather and temperature will affect the spread of COVID-19. According to the United States Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), it is currently unknown whether the spread of COVID-19 is reduced in hot seasons.
Label: False

Claim: A purported advisory has been shared repeatedly in multiple Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp posts that claims a disinfectant will be sprayed into the air overnight in India in an effort to kill the novel coronavirus, COVID-19. The posts urge residents to remain indoors during the spraying.
Explaination: The claim is false; Indian authorities said the advisory was "fake" and that no such measure had been announced.
Label: False

Claim: The quarantine will last until the end of May in Ukraine.
Explaination: The official sources on the day when the news appeared have not published such information. The authors of the article confused the end date of the tax holidays and the end day of the quarantine.
Label: False

Claim: Indian City Bangalore Municipal Corp. requested people to stay at home and lock down houses as they will be spraying medicine to kill coronavirus.
Explaination: Municipal commissioner of the city has no such plans of spraying medicines to kill COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Shoes are an important vector for the transmission of coronavirus.
Explaination: A virologist confirmed that shoes are not a significant vector of transmission.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking water every 15 minutes prevents the coronavirus.
Explaination: There is anything about drinking water in the list to precaution measures recommended by the World Health Organization.
Label: False

Claim: Using a non-dominant hand to open doors is a way to prevent coronavirus.
Explaination: Doctors recommend washing hands or using hand sanitizer.
Label: False

Claim: Italian prime minister cries because there is nothing they can do to treat COVID-19 and the situation is out of control.
Explaination: There is no such statement of despair was made by italy prime minister, at the contrary the statements made by the prime minister say the opposite
Label: False

Claim: The UNHCR said ‘migrants and illegals’ in Malaysia were resisting COVID-19 testing.
Explaination: The claim is false; UNHCR officials in Malaysia said the alleged statement is fake and condemned the erroneous claim for stoking “unnecessary fear and distrust”.
Label: False

Claim: Javier Ortega Smith, from VOX, has said that he prefers to be infected by the new coronavirus than to “have homosexualism”.
Explaination: This is false; provincial health officials and the mall administrator told AFP that no cases are connected to the mall to date.
Label: False

Claim: This video shows a brawl this week which took place in a supermarket in Aubervilliers, in France, because of coronavirus.
Explaination: This scene actually took place in May 2019, according to a police source.
Label: False

Claim: This photo shows French nurses holding a sign to denounce police violence.
Explaination: It's a photomontage.
Label: False

Claim: Facebook post claiming that French animal shelters “are overwhelmed by the abandonment of dogs and cats due to the coronavirus”.
Explaination: SPA president told AFP the claim was false. However, he fears a saturation of shelters, closed to the public because of containment measures.
Label: False

Claim: Claim that the coronavirus was created and patented in a French institute (Institut Pasteur).
Explaination: The video author refers to a patent filed in 2004 but this patent concerns another type of coronavirus. Moreover, filing a patent for a virus does not mean that it was created.
Label: False

Claim: Rodrigo Maia, president of the lower house of the Congress in Brazil, voted a law that forbids the president to close borders.
Explaination: The law doesn't turn difficult to close borders, because it is about migrants rights. And Maia didn't vote "yes" for it.
Label: False

Claim: “Coronavirus victims are buried in the morning this Wednesday in Italy. Rest in peace.”
Explaination: The image was taken in 2013 by Tullio M. Puglia, for Getty Images. The coffins were used for the bodies of african refugees that died on a shipwreck near Lampedusa, south Italy.
Label: False

Claim: Goats in Ajmer, Rajasthan were found to be COVID-19 positive.
Explaination: The video is old and unrelated to COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Indian cricketer Sachin Tendulkar asked for meat shops to be banned in lieu of COVID-19.
Explaination: Claim was falsely attributed to the cricketer.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 passengers being disembarked at Senegal airport.
Explaination: Video was of a mock drill for dealing with hostage like situations.
Label: False

Claim: The COVID-19 has been invented by a big French public medical institute (Institut Pasteur).
Explaination: Big confusion between the 2003 coronavirus and the COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Helicopters of the Argentine Air Force will spray disinfectant against the coronavirus.
Explaination:
The alleged measure was denied by the Argentine Ministry of Defense.
The same message circulates, and was denied, in different countries.
Label: False

Claim: Christine Lagarde said: “The elderly live too long and that is a risk to the global economy.”
Explaination:
There are no written or audiovisual records of the former IMF director saying the statements attributed to her.
In addition, the European Central Bank -inquired by Maldita- assured that Lagarde had not said that phrase.
Part of the phrase attributed to the president of the European Central Bank (ECB) comes from a 2012 report by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in whose presentation Lagarde was not present.
Label: False

Claim: Cali in Colombia is going to be quarantined; for 14 days all commerce, supermarkets, shopping malls will be closed, no one can enter or leave by land or by plane.
Explaination: At the time of this publication, there had been no quarantine or trade closure in the Valle del Cauca capital, as a viral audio claimed.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows coffins of people who died because of coronavirus in Italy, and that the virus is dangerous and you should stay inside.
Explaination: The photo is old and shows coffins of migrants who drowned at a boat accident at Lampedusa in 2013. But the appeal to stay inside to avoid infection with coronavirus is correct.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Jobcenters (for unemployed people) close from today on in Germany.
Explaination: The jobcenters are not completely closed, they offer personal contact in emergency cases.
Label: Mostly true

Claim: Retaining your breath for 10 seconds will help you detect the coronavirus.
Explaination: It won't help you in detecting coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: In Ecuador, Maritza Frías, former director of the Teófilo Dávila Hospital in Machala, and Mauro Calle, former manager of this health center, concealed official figures of those infected.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Coronavirus phase 4 involves war code.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: People with A-blood type are more prone to get coronavirus.
Explaination: Study is not peer-reviewed and should not be published as established information
Label: No evidence

Claim: Egyptian doctor has invented a fluid to treat coronavirus.
Explaination: WHO has not informed about any cure or treatment specific to COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Maracaibo in Venezuela is the safest city to avoid coronavirus because it’s too hot, said Unicef.
Explaination: Unicef communicates it hasn´t publish that kind of information.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 is no worse than other outbreaks that have occurred in “every election year,” suggesting that the new coronavirus is being “hyped” to hurt President Donald Trump.
Explaination: Most of the dates cited to defend those conclusions about previous outbreaks are misleading or incorrect.
Label: False

Claim: Australian researchers have found that bananas can help prevent infection of COVID-19.
Explaination: We found the post to be False. There is no proof that banana can boost one’s immune system and prevent the disease caused by coronavirus. At present there are no medicines to cure COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Kitchen foods plus morning sunshine can prevent and cure coronavirus.
Explaination: At present there is no evidence to prove that eating kitchen foods like onion, garlic and lemon does prevent or cure COVID-19 and the same is not recommended by WHO.
Label: False

Claim: Man contracts COVID-19 by eating mutton.
