Explaination: It's a fake news card and the news channel has denied publishing any such news.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows Chinese police crackdown on suspected COVID-19 patients.
Explaination: We found the video to be False because this is an old video A from Hong Kong showing riot police storm a metro station to crack down on political protesters in the city.
Label: False

Claim: Image of coffins from Italy showing carnage due to recent COVID-19 outbreak.
Explaination: The image is 7 years old and is of the dead bodies of African immigrants who died while entering Italy.
Label: False

Claim: Clean your throat with salt water or vinegar to cure coronavirus.
Explaination: Experts confirmed this is a false claim.
Label: False

Claim: Spanish minister of agriculture called out football players for earning too much and showing lack of solidarity.
Explaination: The minister never made the statement attributed to her.
Label: False

Claim: A train carrying vaccines with the inscription “COVID-19.”
Explaination: Content seems to be digitally edited, and there is no inscription on that location on such trains.
Label: False

Claim: Evidence Shows The WHO Director-General Overstated COVID-19 Fatality Rate
Explaination: All evidence says the WHO director-general was on point. This is a ultra-conservative false spin on what the director-general said, getting many facts and medical numbers wrong.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Trump Is Promising To Send Americans Checks – Only After Checking People’s Social Media History.
Explaination: This is a false tweet, though there have been real suggestions to have a stimulus package.
Label: FALSE

Claim: 5G Technology Believed To Have Caused coronavirus
Explaination: The claim is false, not backed by scientific research, and many dates given to back up the theory are wrong or misleading.
Label: FALSE

Claim: “Ministry of Health ITALY released a small video, HOW the virus spreads!!!… BEST VIDEO. Please see ..how innocently it spread. SOAP is the remedy CLEAN/ WASH ur Hands always”
Explaination: The viral video is not released by the health ministry of Italy in the wake of coronavirus but it is long-existing on YouTube, we reached the conclusion that the viral claim is ‘Misleading’.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The viral video claims to show the visuals of China police personnel trying to control the patients allegedly suffering from the pandemic.
Explaination: The viral video has nothing to do with the coronavirus outbreak and is related to police storming the metro in the wake of Hong Kong protests.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Coronavirus can be cured by sniffing clove and camphor and by drinking water, the virus will go to the stomach and the acid in the stomach will kill the virus.
Explaination: Dr. Mohammad Imran, an Ayurveda doctor, said, “It is merely a rumor which has gone viral on social media .There is no scientific evidence which backs the claim that sniffing clove and camphor can cure coronavirus. However, natural camphor and clove does have certain health benefits as it can cure fungus and bacteria”.
Label: False

Claim: As coronavirus outbreak surges, PM Narendra Modi has decided to facilitate fellow countrymen with free masks under the ‘Swacch Bharat’ scheme.
Explaination: The government has not announced any such scheme under which it is aimed to provide free masks. The viral webpage may be a part of the decade-old phishing technique or it may be an attempt to collect the data. However, the intent behind creating this webpage is not yet clear but it is crystal clear that the webpage does not belong to Indian govt and might be a venture of some fraudulent organization.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese intelligence officer says the novel coronavirus as a biological weapon invented by China.
Explaination: The viral post also claims that the damage caused by the pandemic is being normalized by the Chinese officials. The website which has published the alleged testimony of the said Chinese intelligence officer has published the report with the headline, “CORONA UNMASKED: Chinese Intelligence Officer Reveals True Magnitude of China’s Fake “Coronavirus” Crisis – 包含中文字符版本”. The story published by the Reddit community No Sleep is just a horror story and does not have anything to do with reality. the community itself terms it as a storytelling platform and not a true story publisher.
Label: False

Claim: Helicopters are going to spread ‘medicines’ against the coronavirus in Spain.
Explaination: Defense ministry denied it.
Label: False

Claim: France has suspended payment of rent and taxes for citizens due to coronavirus crisis.
Explaination: The measures announced by President Emmanuel Macron are for SMEs in difficulty and include both payment deferrals and cancellations.
Label: False

Claim: La Paz, Gregorio Marañon or 12 de octubre hospitals are closing because the are over capacity.
Explaination: Madrid government denied it.
Label: FALSE

Claim: The exams to access university in Valencia region will be delayed to August 10, 11 and 12.
Explaination: The Valencian Government debunks the hoax on its official social media accounts.
Label: False

Claim: The army is requisitioning coronavirus protection material in Catalonia.
Explaination: The Defense ministry denies the claim.
Label: False

Claim: France will pay rent, light and gas during quarantine for its citizens.
Explaination: France is only paying for small company's that are not earning enough.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Helicopters are going to spread ‘medicines’ againts the coronavirus.
Explaination: Defense ministry denied it.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Peru has just nationalized hospitals and clinics.
Explaination: Peruvian government gave a temporary order for centralizing all the medical resources under the Ministry of Health authority during the emergency, but it's does not include the property of clinics and private services.
Label: False

Claim: There is a Russian medicine that could be use against Sars-Cov-2.
Explaination: It is not the case.
Label: False

Claim: This picture showing lots of coffins was taken in Bergamo in 2020.
Explaination: The picture has been taken in Lampedusa in 2013.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Novel coronavirus is being spread via Coca-Cola.
Explaination: No evidence shows the virus transmission via food. Coca-Cola products are inspected.
Label: False

Claim: Novel coronavirus can survive 9 days on the road; you should keep your shoes out, a doctor from Milan says.
Explaination: No Milanese doctor says that. No evidence shows the exact survival time of the virus on the road.
Label: False

Claim: Countries that are the most affected by the coronavirus are along the same latitude.
Explaination:
1. The fact that large countries cannot be represented by a single latitude is conveniently ignored.
2. Further, all of the aforementioned cities and countries are not situated along Latitude 40 degrees.
Label: False

Claim: Clorox Already Knew About Coronavirus And Coronavirus Isn’t A New Virus.
Explaination: The post claiming that the new coronavirus was known beforehand as Clorox label shows that it kills human coronavirus’ is misleading.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Indonesian President Joko Widodo locked down 10 cities
Explaination: the Indonesian President Joko Widodo has not yet chosen the option to quarantine or lockdown as a way to deal with the Corona COVID-19 virus pandemic.
Label: False

Claim: People in this video are falling because of the coronavirus
Explaination: The people in the three videos fainted due to other causes, such as epilepsy and fatigue. Two of the four videos also did not occur in Jakarta, but in Bali and Singapore.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Novel “The Eye of Darkness” predicts the coronavirus as a biological weapon from China
Explaination: There is only one similarity about the virus in this novel with the Corona COVID-19 virus, namely the name Wuhan, where the Corona COVID-19 virus was first reported in Wuhan, China. The rest, regarding the incubation period, death rates, and so on, is very different from the pandemic that is happening now.
Label: False

Claim: If we want to protect ourselves from the coronavirus, we must back away from all the climate change efforts we’ve been making.
Explaination: Some preliminary scientific publications report that SARS-CoV-2 may be less prevalent or less contagious in warm and humid climates. However global warming does not occur at a pace or magnitude that would prevent further SARS-CoV-2 propagation. In addition, scientists emphasize that virus propagation primarily depends on other factors such as existing immunity and there is currently no way to reliably predict the spread of COVID-19 on a warmer Earth.
Label: False

Claim: China has successfully tested an anti-coronavirus serum made in Egypt and presented in Beijing by the Egyptian Minister of Health.
Explaination: It's false. Neither Egypt has delivered a COVID-19 serum to China, nor has any treatment been released against those infected with the virus in either country.
Label: False

Claim: The spread of COVID-19 can be prevented with a “home-made vaccine” based on fruits and other ingredients.
Explaination: This is a hoax for citizens to open a potentially dangerous attachment.
Label: False

Claim: A hospital in Murcia in Spain has made a citizen appeal to make surgical masks.
Explaination: That has not happened.
Label: False

Claim: A video of a fire erupting inside a vehicle has been viewed hundreds of times on Facebook, Twitter and on messaging app Line in March 2020 alongside a claim it shows an explosion that was sparked by an alcohol-based disinfectant used during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video has circulated in media reports about a car explosion in Saudi Arabia since at least 2015, almost five years before the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan in December 2019.
Label: False

Claim: All fruit and vegetable markets in the Indian city of Chennai and across the state of Tamil Nadu have been ordered to close in an effort to curb the spread of the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; Chennai’s municipal authority called the social media posts “fake”, and Tamil Nadu’s chief minister said that stores selling “essential items” such as groceries are allowed to operate as normal despite a nationwide lockdown.
Label: False

Claim: Claim that an American soldier was intentionally spreading the novel coronavirus in Wuhan during the seventh CISM Military World Games in October 2019 with a video clip of a man purportedly smearing saliva on the handrail on a train.
Explaination: The video is authentic but it was taken in Brussels, Belgium, on March 10, 2020. The man is not an American. According to media reports, the man was arrested by the police on the same day.
Label: Misleading

Claim: List of first COVID-19 patients in Guatemala with their personal information.
Explaination: The list was authentic (as confirmed later on by the Ministry of Health) but we explained that to share private information is not only risky for those in the list but illegal.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: As the US government moved to approve a $2 trillion stimulus package to address the impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak, a short block of text outlining Canada’s alleged response to the outbreak flourished on social media.
Explaination: The claims about school closings and economic support are misleading; no province has officially closed schools through the end of the year, only individuals directly impacted by COVID-19 are eligible for financial aid, and mortgage relief is granted by banks on a case by case basis.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The Social Security System (SSS) in the Philippines “approved financial aid worth P20,000 for every member,” to assist those affected by the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The SSS has not announced such financial aid for every member. On its official Facebook page, the SSS denied the claim, saying it was "fake news."
Label: False

Claim: “China is to blame because the culture where people eat bats and snakes and dogs and things like that, these viruses are transmitted from the animal to the people and that’s why China has been the source of a lot of these viruses like SARS, like MERS, the Swine Flu and now the coronavirus.”
Explaination: Experts said Cornyn's assertion that Chinese culture is at fault is inaccurate, as the threat of viral transmission from animal to human is not unique to China, and the risk of this kind of spillover is growing globally as humans come into closer contact with animals.
Label: False

Claim: Five Helicopters will spray disinfectants into the air to eradicate the coronaviruses.
Explaination: Similar rumors have circulated in multiple languages in many countries, including South Africa, India, USA. The version circulating in Taiwan connected to America. New York City Emergency Management Department has tweeted that the rumor is false.
Label: False

Claim: President Donald Trump tweeted, “I ordered the Treasury secretary to send checks to Americans! First however, we will go through your social media history from the last 4 years and search for any post with #NotMyPresident in it. I wouldn’t think of offending you with a check if I’m not your president! #MAGA”
Explaination: Americans could receive a $1,000 check as part of an economic stimulus package that isn't yet finalized. Donald Trump didn't tweet that he would vet who gets the checks based on whether they support him.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: President Donald Trump said, “People are dying who have never died before.”
Explaination: We searched a number of databases and found no evidence that Trump, on March 18, said, “People are dying who have never died before.”
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: The coronavirus “snuck up on us,” adding that it is “a very unforeseen thing.”
Explaination: Members of the Trump administration have been sounding the alarm for months. Public health experts have been warning for years about the threat of a pandemic.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: 2019 coronavirus can live for “up to 3 hours in the air, up to 4 hours on copper, up to 24 hours on cardboard up to 3 days on plastic and stainless steel.”
Explaination: Preliminary research indicates that COVID-19 can live for up to three hours in the air, four hours on copper, 24 hours on cardboard and three days on plastic and stainless steel.
Label: MOSTLY TRUE

Claim: Chennai municipal corporation has asked all vegetable and fruit markets to shut down.
Explaination: No such order was issued. All vegetable and fruit markets are open in Chennai.
Label: False

Claim: This poem describes people applying social distancing during a plague outbreak from the 19th century.
Explaination: The poem has been written by an American woman on her blog on the 16th of March.
Label: False

Claim: This text critically observes the behavior of the religious communities in Macedonia toward the Government’s recommendations to reduce the risk of spreading the coronavirus by limiting contacts and movement.
Explaination: The religious communities do not respect Government's recommendations. Last Friday, both the Islamic Religious Community and the Macedonian Orthodox Church did not take any steps to close the doors of religious buildings for the mass gathering of their believers.
Label: False

Claim: A sensationalist headline, misleading readers: “Disturbing video: A proof that only today there are 349 dead in Italy, stay at home.”
Explaination: This text operates with outdated data.The figures published in the text are from 14 March. The article was published on 16 March at 11.12 pm, which means that at the time of publication on the Internet, the data from 15 March were available, i.e. 1,809 dead and 24,747 infected in total.
Label: false and misleading

Claim: Author Chen Ming-Fang, the daughter-in-law of renowned doctor and medical professor Dong Da-Cheng, shared her own experience recovering from COVID-19.
Explaination: The content was originally from a Facebook post by a Seattle coronavirus survivor, Elizabeth Schneider. Chen Ming-Fang said in an interview with TFC that she didn't write that post.
Label: False

Claim: Audio allegedly from a CEO of a major hospital in São Paulo, Brazil, gives a higher number of deaths from coronavirus than officially announced.
Explaination: The CEO denied the audio was his.
Label: False

Claim: China planned coronavirus.
Explaination: This fake news boasts the conspiracy theory that China made coronavirus in order to have economic benefits.
Label: False

Claim: São Paulo city hall schedules coronavirus tests by phone.
Explaination: City hall says fake news came from misinterpretation of a town law addressing coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Wash your throat with salted water and apple vinegar to cure COVID-19.
Explaination: WHO and other medical institutions say this is not a cure.
Label: False

Claim: Spanish scientist (and former minister for agriculture) says that people should go to Ronaldo or Messi for the cure, as they are better paid.
Explaination: The former Spanish minister for agriculture never said this.
Label: False

Claim: Evidence shows the WHO director-general overstated COVID-19 fatality rate
Explaination: All evidence says the WHO director-general was on point. This is a ultra-conservative false spin on what the director-general said, getting many facts and medical numbers wrong.
Label: Misleading

Claim: 5G Technology believed to have caused the coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false, not backed by scientific research, and many dates given to back up the theory are wrong or misleading.
Label: False

Claim: In Ecuador, Maritza Frías, former director of the Teófilo Dávila Hospital in Machala, and Mauro Calle, former manager of this health center, concealed official figures of those infected.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus phase 4 involves war code.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: France will pay rent, light and gas during quarantine for its citizens.
Explaination: France is only paying for small companies that are not earning enough.
Label: False

Claim: Helicopters and military aircraft spraying and disinfecting the streets at 11 p.m. in Spain
Explaination: Air Force and Ministry of Defense sources deny it.
Label: False

Claim: Some of Madrid hospitals close because they are “too full” because of the coronavirus.
Explaination: Madrid's health ministry says it is not true. Hospitals still working and accepting people.
Label: False

Claim: In Spain, La Paz, Gregorio Marañon or 12 de Octubre hospitals are closing because the are over capacity.
Explaination: Madrid government denied it.
Label: False

Claim: There is a Russian medicine that could be use against Sars-Cov-2.
Explaination: It is not the case.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking alcohol helps against the new coronavirus
Explaination: The fact that drinking alcohol can protect from new coronavirus has no clinical support.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking hot water every 15 min helps fighting COVID-19.
Explaination: Regular drinking of water, sauna and hot towels doesn't help to fight COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: American fast-food chain Hardee’s is advising truckers to walk up to drive-thrus during coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: A spokesperson from CKE Restaurants said the company advises against walking up to drive-thrus for safety reasons.
Label: False

Claim: An investigation team from France discovered what is hidden about COVID-19, the virus was made by the Pasteur Institute in Wuhan.
Explaination: The document in the claim is talking about a Patent Registration for a vaccine that is intended for SARS by the Pasteur Institute in 2004, SARS was present in China in 2003.
Label: False

Claim: The atheist Italian doctor Julian Urban and his colleagues have converted to Christianity in the wake of the COVID-19 crisis.
Explaination: There is no (Italian) doctor called Julian Urban (or any variation on that name, like Iulian Urban). COVID-19-doctors converting Christianity over the last few weeks isn't unthinkable, but there is a great lack of verifiable information.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus stays in the throat for a long time and dry out the mouth; you should use a gargle made of vinger and high salt solution to get rid of the virus.
Explaination: Coronavirus doesn't stay in the throat for long times, the gargling is not effective as a cure for COVID-19, until now there is no specific treatment for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: There is nothing called coronavirus and COVDI19 is caused by sarin gas.
Explaination: Doctors all over the world managed to extract the virus from the patients. the symptoms and the spread of COVID19 is correlated with the virus and its effects and has nothing to do with the sarin gas or any effect of gas.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A man is touching a push-cart with his tongue to spread the virus outside Lidl in Lithuania.
Explaination: The video is most likely shot in Lebanon and definitely not in Lithuania.
Label: False

Claim: A train marked “COVID-19” was spotted in the U.S.
Explaination: The photo was doctored.
Label: False

Claim: Philippine Vice President Leni Robredo says bats are the “enemy” in the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the graphic has been doctored from an earlier Inquirer.net post in which Robredo was quoted about confusion surrounding the government’s response to the coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: The Indian government is distributing free face masks.
Explaination: However, the claim is false; the Indian government said there is no such scheme in place and the linked website is not an official government site.
Label: False

Claim: The Australian prime minister is about to announce a national lockdown.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; the Australian Prime Minister’s Office refuted the details of the post; Australia's government told its citizens on March 18 not to travel abroad and warned those already overseas to come home but did not order a "lockdown"; AFP found the wording of the misleading posts was identical to Malaysia’s announcement of a nationwide lockdown.
Label: Misleading

Claim: This photo shows a Sri Lankan airline pilot who tested positive for the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; the local health authority told AFP the pilot is not pictured in the photo; the man wrongly identified in the posts denied the claim.
Label: False

Claim: Russian supermarkets are imposing pre-filled trolleys with basic food in the midst of the coronavirus crisis.
Explaination: Auchan Russia told AFP photos had been taken during a special event earlier in the week and that there is no pre-filled trolleys for customers because of coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: 35 people infected by coronavirus are being treated in Ivory Coast within a military station.
Explaination: French embassy in Ivory Coast and the Ivory Coast government denied this claim to AFP. Mediapart told AFP it has "no information" about this.
Label: False

Claim: Photo showing the poor condition for people who recently arrived in the country and were quarantined because of the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The photo was first published in February 2017 on TripAdvisor to denounce the bad accommodations of an hostel in South Africa.
Label: False

Claim: Water boiled with garlic cures coronavirus.
Explaination: There's no scientific evidence of that.
Label: False

Claim: Israel has already developed a vaccine against COVID-19
Explaination: Migal Galilee Research Institute, in Israel, is currently one of many labs trying to develop a vaccine against COVID-19. They claim their vaccine might be ready for tests in 8-10 weeks.
Label: False

Claim: Avoid drinking cold water during the pandemic; be exposed to sunlight.
Explaination: Neither is proven to have any effect on the disease.
Label: False

Claim: Universal Church of the Kingdom of God is selling 500 Brazilian “blessed” hand-sanitizer bottles.
Explaination: The image was digitally altered to include fake information and the Universal church logo.
Label: False

Claim: Brazilian singer Preta Gil was singing in a carnival “bloco” while infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: She very likely caught the coronavirus seven days after her last public concert, while singing at a wedding that has become a major hub of COVID-19 dissemination. On March 1st, date of her last public concert, there were still only two cases confirmed in the country.
Label: False

Claim: A mixture of vinegar and fabric softener is a better disinfectant than alcohol.
Explaination: Even when vinegar and quaternary ammonium included in some fabric softeners do have some antibacterial properties, it's mixture is not more effective than alcohol in inactivating viruses and killing bacteria. This mixture is not included in the official recommendations to fight COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Staff of two Mumbai hotels have COVID-positive cases.
Explaination: Both the hotels denied having any such cases.
Label: False

Claim: President Donald Trump announced a vaccine by Roche Diagnostics.
Explaination: Roche Diagnostics received FDA approval for testing kits, not a vaccine.
Label: False

Claim: Narendra Modi is giving free masks in India.
Explaination: A fake phishing website was set up in the name of Narendra Modi.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus patients were being arrested in Punjab, India.
Explaination: The video is of a mock drill which is being passed off as real.
Label: False

Claim: The military is coming to Paris because of the coronavirus.
Explaination: Normal military movements ; nothing to do with the covid.
Label: False

Claim: Another rumor claims the military is coming to Paris because of the coronavirus.
Explaination: Normal military movements ; nothing to do with the covid.
Label: False

Claim: Ibuprofen enhances the coronavirus.
Explaination:
The World Health Organization assured that there is no proven evidence that the use of ibuprofen can aggravate the health of patients with this virus.
Initially, he recommended the use of acetaminophen (paracetamol) to treat symptoms, but later clarified that he was "not aware of reports of any negative effects" of ibuprofen.
Label: No evidence

Claim: An image of people lying on the street is related to coronavirus.
Explaination: The image was taken in Germany during an event commemorating the victims of the Nazi concentration camp in Katzbach.
Label: False

Claim: Gargling with warm water and salt removes the coronavirus.
Explaination: The World Health Organization says there is no evidence that rinsing your mouth with saline "provides protection against this disease."
Label: False

Claim: Cuba discovered a serum that cures COVID-19.
Explaination: This supposed discovery was denied by an Egyptian official, whose last name is the same as that attributed to the Cuban Minister of Health in the disinformation, who is actually called Portal Miranda.
Label: False

Claim: A study establishes the relationship between Ibuprofen and the severity of the virus infection. Apparently Ibuprofen facilitates the reproduction of the virus.
Explaination: There is no solid scientific evidence to indicate that Ibuprofen worsens the coronavirus.
Label: Partially false

Claim: “17 at 6:00 am, the state of emergency begins throughout the national territory” in accordance with “article 116 of the Constitution”, in Colombia.
Explaination: WhatsApp chain that alerts state of emergency by COVID-19 is from Spain.
Label: False

Claim: Although Germany closes its borders refugees and migrants may still come in and they will not be medically checked for coronavirus.
Explaination: Asylum seekers may under certain circumstances still come to Germany, but they are not the only persons allowed to cross the border. And there will be medical checks if they are infected.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Medical University in Vienna has published a study about Ibuprofen and coronavirus.
Explaination: There was no such study, Medical University of Vienna denied it and rated is as fake news. Relation between ibuprofen treatment and worsening conditions of patients with COVID-19 is still researched but unproven at the moment.
Label: False

Claim: An image shows a “Spanish biologist” who claimed that footballers who earn millions of euros should research the cure for coronavirus.
Explaination: This is not the Spanish Biologist. Her name is Isabel García Tejerina and she is former Spanish Minister of Agriculture.
Label: False

Claim: Three thousand Ecuadorians are infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Coronavirus will not be covered by private health insurance in Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Helicopters are going to spread chemicals against the coronavirus.
Explaination: False information circulating in many Spanish-speaking countries, from Spain to Honduras.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus patients develop lung fibrosis but you can diagnose by holding your breath.
Explaination: Fibrosis has many other symptoms and it is harder to diagnose than holding your breath for 10 seconds.
Label: False

Claim: The WHO approves anti-malarial drug Chloroquine for COVID-19.
Explaination: Fact Crescendo found the details mentioned in the news published by Economic Times to be False. WHO has not declared, approved or recommended anti-malarial drug Chloroquine as a treatment medicine for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Thailand CDC announces green chiretta can cure coronavirus.
Explaination: No such evidence for curing COVID-19 with green chiretta is recommended by WHO or Thailand CDC.
Label: False

Claim: Traditional cures and self-checks for the coronavirus.
Explaination: Our fact check reveals that there is no scientific evidence to prove that drinking water washes down COVID-19 and gargling with warm water & salt or vinegar eliminates the coronavirus. Similarly the self-check breath test for coronavirus is absolutely baseless.
Label: False

Claim: Video of police in China taking into custody suspected COVID-19 patients in the country.
Explaination: The video shows Police in Hong Kong taking into control demonstrators who were protesting against the introduction of a controversial bill that would have allowed extraditions to mainland China.
Label: False

Claim: After husband tested positive for coronavirus, wife fled from Bangalore to Agra in India.
Explaination: The woman went to her parents place in Agra on 9 March, while her husband was confirmed positive for coronavirus on 12 March. Also, she didn't enter Bangalore city. Karnataka government has also clarified that the woman didn't flee to her parents’ place.
Label: False

Claim: 5,000 million Rupees fund allocated by Telangana CM KCR for coronavirus prevention is entirely funded by Central Government.
Explaination: No, the entire fund is not given by the Central Government.
Label: False

Claim: Video of President Donald Trump announcing that Roche Medical Company will launch the vaccine for COVID-19 next Sunday.
Explaination: In the video, American President Donald Trump hasn't said that Roche Medical Company will launch the vaccine for COVID-19. He announced FDA’s approval of a coronavirus ‘test’ developed by a company ‘Roche’ to increase and accelerate the country’s capacity to test for the virus.
Label: False

Claim: 2,000 people died of COVID-19 on 3/15/20 in France.
Explaination: As per WHO, 36 people died of COVID-19 in France on March 15, not 2000 people.
Label: False

Claim: Oman is releasing a special chemical into the sky to eradicate coronavirus with military helicopters.
Explaination: The Oman health minister said that they had never conducted such operations with military helicopters. When the same message went viral in India, the Press Information Bureau has said that it is a fake message.
Label: False

Claim: With self-checkup you can find out if you are infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: Neither the World Health Organization (WHO) nor the government of India has stated anywhere that the coronavirus infection can be evaluated by the breath test as mentioned in the post. Some doctors have also mentioned that breath test cannot help in finding out if the person is infected with coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Gargling with lukewarm water mixed with salt/vinegar will remove coronavirus.
Explaination: Press Information Bureau (India) has clarified that coronavirus cannot be treated by gargling with warm water mixed with salt and vinegar.
Label: False

Claim: Tips for the new coronavirus: Holding breath and drinking water.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence to indicate that holding breath and drinking water every 15 minutes kills coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: China finds a vaccine for the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Chine didn't find a vaccine for coronavirus..
Label: False

Claim: A dog vaccine can be used against coronavirus in people.
Explaination: There is still no approved vaccine for coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: 15 minutes in a sauna will kill the coronavirus.
Explaination: Infectious disease epidemiologist debunked this
Label: False

Claim: Eating bananas prevents coronavirus.
Explaination: The video splices together clips to make incorrect and misleading information.
Label: False

Claim: Italy has mandated no treatment of all elderly patients for coronavirus.
Explaination: The guidelines to ration care to those with higher survivability are only suggestions at this point.
Label: False

Claim: All U.S. citizens are entitled to $700 per week to stay at home to avoid spread of coronavirus.
Explaination: U.S. citizens may get some economic relief from Congress at some point, but that could still be a few weeks away.
Label: False

Claim: List comparing diseases with coronavirus.
Explaination: The comparison of the outbreaks is extremely misleading as it doesn't take into account the rate of infections, timeframes of the outbreaks and the rapid rise in the number of COVID-19 cases.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 is a scripted narrative to justify closed borders or force residents to remain home.
Explaination: Debunked as a conspiracy theory.
Label: False

Claim: Football player Cristiano Ronaldo turned all his hotels into hospitals to help coronavirus patients and is paying doctors and the staff.
Explaination: A spokesperson for the hotel denied the claim stating "We are a hotel. We are not going to be a hospital. It is a day like everyone else, we are and will remain a hotel." The news was also denied by HRT, Gol, Haber, Pogled, Flash and Hayat, while the Sport and Magazine plus portals deleted their articles.
Label: False

Claim: Madrid enables 915,038,030 to request prescription drugs.
Explaination: The government denied it.
Label: False

Claim: Niño Jesús hospital has been left without COVID-19 to care for children and young people in Madrid.
Explaination: The hospital denied it to newtral.es.
Label: False

Claim: Here are the measures that Mercadona will implement due to the coronavirus crisis.
Explaination: Mercadona Communication department explains that nearly all the points of the message are false.
Label: False

Claim: Police have “free entry into houses and buildings” in Malaga to identify possible coronavirus infected people.
Explaination: Police denied it on its Twitter account.
Label: False

Claim: Spanish politician Ortega Smith said “I prefer to get the COVID-19 than being gay”.
Explaination: It was posted by a satirical website, but it viralized as real.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Spanish politician Ortega Smith said “I prefer to get the covid-19 than being gay”.
Explaination: It was posted by a satirical website, but it viralized as real.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Madrid enables 915038030 to request prescription drugs.
Explaination: The government denied it.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A whole floor of the main Peruvian hospital is infected with COVID-19 and they decided to close the place.
Explaination: It is false that Peruvian government decided to close a floor at the main national hospital due a general contagion of COVID-19
Label: False

Claim: Italy official Giulio Gallera: China lies to us. The date China provided is false. Italy has become Wuhan and the medical system has a breakdown.
Explaination: The Health and Welfare Regional Minister in Lombardy, Giulio Gallera, didn't give such statements in the interview.
Label: Partially false

Claim: The photo shows the aid crew from Cuba to Italy.
Explaination: Cuba has sent aid to Italy but the photo is not new. Taken in 2015.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo donated his hotel to be turned into an hospital.
Explaination: Ronaldo did not announce this and his partners denied.
Label: False

Claim: Coronil drops can help cure coronavirus.
Explaination: Leading homeopaths say that very little is known about the composition of this medicine and it will be careless to recommend this medicine for coronavirus
Label: Misleading

Claim: Police asked shops selling alcohol to restrict opening hours on St. Patrick’s Day to lower the risk of house parties where coronavirus could be spread.
Explaination: Police make an annual request of shops not to sell alcohol before 4pm on St Patrick's Day - but it has nothing to do with coronavirus
Label: Misleading

Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo turns hotel into hospital for coronavirus.
Explaination: The manager of the hotel owned by Ronaldo has denied the rumors and stated that the hotel was and will remain a hotel.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows Chinese police crackdown on coronavirus patients.
Explaination: The video actually dates back to August 2019 when anti-government protests were happening in Hong Kong. The visuals pertain to an incident of police crackdown at Prince Edward station in Kowloon where the police personnel and riot police arrived after reports of a tussle between pro-government and anti-government protesters.
Label: False

Claim: It is advisable to leave outside the shoes used on the street to prevent coronavirus.
Explaination: It is an unnecessary preventive measure because it is excessive.
Label: False

Claim: Sanitary technicians are going to inspect houses and seize cash.
Explaination: It is false that technicians and police agents have "free entry" in the homes
Label: False

Claim: A graphic has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook alongside a claim it contains a quote from Philippine Vice President Leni Robredo that bats are the “enemy” in the novel coronavirus pandemic. The graphic is attributed to Inquirer.net, a Philippine media outlet.
Explaination: The claim is false; the graphic has been doctored from an earlier Inquirer.net post in which Robredo was quoted about confusion surrounding the government’s response to the coronavirus outbreak.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A flyer offers official advice about the novel coronavirus from a Veterans Affairs (VA) healthcare system in the U.S. state of Oregon.
Explaination: The flyer is fake, it was not issued by the Roseburg VA and health experts told AFP the advice it contains is misleading.
Label: False

Claim: A photo of a room lined with coffins shows Italian nationals killed during the novel coronavirus pandemic in 2020.
Explaination: The claim is false; the photo actually shows coffins for a group of dead migrants at an Italian airport in October 2013 after their boat sank off the coast of Italy.
Label: False

Claim: A “Spanish biological researcher” says “You give the footballer 1 million euros a month and a biological researcher 1,800 euros per month, and you are now looking for a coronavirus treatment. Go to Cristiano Ronaldo or Messi and they will get you a cure.” A quote published with a photo of this so-called “Spanish biological researcher.”
Explaination: The woman on the photograph is not a Spanish biologist researcher, but Isabel Garcia Tejerina, an ex Spanish minister. The photo was taken during an interview, in 2018, long before the outbreak of coronavirus. There is no clue of this Spanish biologist researcher, whose name is never given in the publications.
Label: False

Claim: Jeanine Áñez, actual president of Bolivia, has COVID-19.
Explaination: The team of Bolivia Verifica, checked the image and verified that was not real. Also, in a communication with the Coordination Director of the Ministry of the Presidency, Marco Julio, he ensured that the president’s health condition is good.
Label: False

Claim: 14 University of Nairobi students have tested positive for COVID-19.
Explaination: An article by Times Live claiming that 14 students from the University of Nairobi are infected with coronavirus cites a non-existent news story by KTN News.
Label: False

Claim: Senator of the Philippines Risa Hontiveros says she is “ready to get coughed on,” and that “the police and military are more frightening than dying from the virus.”
Explaination: The senator did not say what was attributed to her in the graphic. She dismissed the graphic as "fake news" on her social media accounts.
Label: False

Claim: Philippines Vice President Leni Robredo says “bats, not the virus, are our enemy.”
Explaination: The Vice President did not say what was attributed to her. Robredo’s camp said it is a fake quote, and the Facebook accounts that posted the fake quote the earliest on Facebook failed to give Rappler their source.
Label: False

Claim: A photo showing coffins and describing them as coffins of people who died because of the coronavirus.
Explaination: We found this picture within our AFP archives. Those coffins are those of dead migrants in the Mediterranean sea in 2013.
Label: False

Claim: The WHO coronavirus test “was a bad test.”
Explaination: A review found the World Health Organization’s test did not give false positives when similar viruses were present. The White House provided no evidence that the WHO test fell short.
Label: False

Claim: Sweden has stopped fighting against the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Manipulative headline that Sweden has stopped fighting against the new coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: “All U.S. citizens are entitled to $700 USD per week to stay at home to avoid the spread of COVID-19 novel coronavirus, starting 3/17/20.”
Explaination: Americans could receive a check for $1,000 or more as part of an economic stimulus package amid the coronavirus. A Facebook post about weekly $700 checks is a hoax.
Label: False

Claim: “I’ve always known this is a real, this is a pandemic. I’ve felt it was a pandemic long before it was called a pandemic.”
Explaination: In January, Trump said there were no worries about a pandemic. In late February, he said the virus was “very much under control.” Trump did activate federal measures to contain the spread in late January.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: “People are going door to door in Colorado Springs stating they are COVID-19 testing so they can rob people!”
Explaination: Colorado Springs police said they’ve received no reports of robbers pretending to offer coronavirus testing.
Label: False

Claim: “U.S. deaths since 1/22/20: COVID-19, 27; flu, 4,700; abortion, 118,000.”
Explaination: The post’s numbers are inaccurate, but abortions do far outnumber deaths from COVID-19 and flu. The COVID-19 number is likely too low, and the flu number is too high. The number of abortions is roughly accurate.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Says it was “unquestionably” not within his “legal authority” to postpone Illinois’ primary election by changing the date or shifting to vote-by-mail.
Explaination: It’s difficult to know for sure that Pritzker could not have done anything to delay the March 17 election. But experts told us the governor spoke correctly in describing the limits of his powers under existing law.
Label: MOSTLY TRUE

Claim: Novel coronavirus can be eliminated by drinking lots of water and gargling with warm water mixed with salt or vinegar.
Explaination: At present, there is no study or evidence to support the claim.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: President Trump’s use of data for deaths from swine flu and seasonal flu.
Explaination: Trump is comparing apples and oranges. The figures he cites for the swine flu and seasonal influenza are after-the-fact estimates that try to account for all excess deaths that could be, in some way, attributed to a flu infection. Studies indicate that the official lab counts may be missing as many as 9 in 10 deaths.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Having a beard increases your chances of getting coronavirus.
Explaination: The CDC never told anyone to shave their beards, a 2017 graphic circulating the web from the CDC was put out to show the effectiveness of masks with facial hair. The work-place graphic is unrelated to the current coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Sweden refused to fight the coronavirus.
Explaination: Sweden has not abandoned the fight against coronavirus, although it has taken less stringent measures than other countries. Some of the statements in the checked article are completely made up.
Label: False

Claim: Taking a hot bath, breathing in hot steam or using a hand dryer to blow hot air up the nose are effective ways to prevent COVID-19, according to a lecturer in health sciences faculty at Ghanaian university.
Explaination: No evidence for claims, which go counter to WHO recommendations.
Label: False

Claim: An image shows a train transporting the COVID-19 virus.
Explaination: The dark wagons on the image are the ones used to transport oil and they have to obey the 4 letters and 6 digits rules. That’s not what happens with the word “COVID-19” that appears in the image. Also, the name of the virus is Sars-Cov-2 and not COVID-19 (that’s the name of the disease). If the train was transporting the virus it would mention “Sars-Cov-2” and not “COVID-19”.
Label: False

Claim: A hospital in Debar (North Macedonia) was left without an epidemiologist.
Explaination: The information was denied by the Ministry of Health. They pointed out that there is an epidemiologist in the Debar hospital and there is no shortage of staff.
Label: False

Claim: Some portals published a photo that they claim was taken on the buses of the Public Transport Company in Skopje. The photo shows a person in protective equipment in a public transport. And that was enough for someone to claim that this is how the buses in Skopje are disinfected against the coronavirus in the presence of passengers.
Explaination: A simple Google photo search shows that this photo was not taken in Skopje, but in Poland.
Label: False

Claim: Fiocruz (Brazilian health organization) did not share text informing that coronavirus is bigger than other virus; that the virus dies on temperatures such as 26ºC or 27ºC; warm water with salt kills the coronavirus in your amygdala; hot plates are the best to kill the virus
Explaination: Fiocruz denied sharing such informations.
Label: False

Claim: Brazilian government releases R$ 470 for people in Bolsa Família (poverty addressing program) to buy masks and hygiene products.
Explaination: Ministry of Economy promised a increase of R$ 3 billions on the social program, but there was no help to buy masks and cleaning products.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus was created the Institut Pasteur in France and patented in 2004.
Explaination: The patent was for 2003 SARS vaccine.
Label: False

Claim: Philippine Vice President Leni Robredo says bats are the “enemy” in the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the graphic has been doctored from an earlier Inquirer.net post in which Robredo was quoted about confusion surrounding the government’s response to the coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Oman is releasing pesticides in the air through helicopters to eliminate coronavirus.
Explaination: Oman's Health Minsitry has clarified that they are not conducting any such operation with helicopters.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking water every 15 minutes will protect people from coronavirus.
Explaination: WHO has clarified that drinking water is important for overall health but it does not prevent coronavirus infection.
Label: False

Claim: 3,000 Ecuadorians are infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus will not be covered by private health insurance in Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Madrid has enabled the phone number 915038030 to request prescriptions.
Explaination: The region of Madrid says it is a hoax.
Label: False

Claim: Niño Jesús Hospital is now “clean” of coronavirus to take care of children and young people in Madrid.
Explaination: The Hospital and the health ministry explain it is false.
Label: False

Claim: Police has “free entry in houses and buildings” in Malaga to identify possible coronavirus infections.
Explaination: Malaga and Police authorities debunk the hoax on their official twitter accounts.
Label: False

Claim: Javier Ortega Smith, from VOX, has said he prefers to be infected by the new coronavirus than to “have homosexualism”.
Explaination: The claim is from a satire website.
Label: False

Claim: Spanish politician Ortega Smith said “I prefer to get COVID-19 to being gay.”
Explaination: It was posted by a satirical website, but it viralized as real.
Label: False

Claim: “While all COVID-19 news has been going on, the U.S. government has been sneakily trying to remove end-to-end encryption” which means “the government will be able to see all of your messages and listen to all of your calls.”
Explaination: A bill currently being considered by Congress, called the EARN IT Act, would make it easier for law enforcement to demand information from technology companies about certain users of their services. The bill wouldn't grant unlimited access. Any request would have to be premised on a link to suspected child exploitation.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Did Donald Trump attempt to steal a COVID-19 vaccine from a German company and refuse testing kits from WHO?
Explaination: Reports that Trump tried to pay a German company for the rights to a vaccine are not confirmed, and the U.S. government did not refuse tests from the World Health Organization.
Label: False

Claim: Genefir Haller, the woman who voluntereed to try one of the COVID19 vaccines, is dead.
Explaination: Genifer appeared on CNN after taking the vaccine ensuring that she is doing OK and the vaccine didn't harm her or anyone surronding her.
Label: FALSE

Claim: The word “coronavirus” used on various sanitary products suggest that the outbreak of COVID-19 is a planned operation.
Explaination: Term coronavirus describes a group of viruses known to man for decades.
Label: False

Claim: Gargling warm water with salt and/or vinegar kills SARS-CoV-2.
Explaination: No proof that salt and/or vinegar can kill the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Clinics in the Philippines are turning away people with COVID-19 symptoms, because of a advisory from the department of health.
Explaination: The claim is false; the Philippine Department of Health denied issuing the advisory.
Label: False

Claim: Red soap and white handkerchiefs are good against the coronavirus.
Explaination: But the recommended practices are misleading; health experts told AFP there is no scientific basis for many of the claims, which include using red-coloured soap and white handkerchiefs, as well as obtaining specific light bulbs.
Label: False

Claim: Israel allegedly developed a COVID-19 vaccine.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; the image used to illustrate a vial of the new drug is originally a stock picture while the MIGAL Research Institute in Israel, despite having a head start, continues to work on a vaccine for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: A video on Facebook and YouTube purports to show billionaire businessman Jack Ma praising China’s response to the outbreak of the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: But the video has been doctored; the original video shows Jack Ma at a meeting of former Alibaba employees in 2018, at least one year before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan; the voiceover in the clip has been taken from another clip which shows a different man speaking.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows two military vehicles transported by a truck on the highway, near Paris, to be used for the French population’s confinement.
Explaination: The vehicle transporter and the army told AFP that it was a routine trip, unrelated to the COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: On 3/16/20, Macron announced a quarantine for all cities in France and will announce later during the day the passage to “stage 4” of the epidemic.
Explaination: Stage 4 means back to normal and Emmanuel Macron has not made announces yet about quarantine. The website appears to be a clickbait website.
Label: False

Claim: A legal decree in France, published on 3/15/20, sets the ground for the use of the army in the fight against the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: If using the army in the fight against the novel coronavirus is possible, it has nothing to do with the legal decree published on March 15th, according to the Ministry of the Armed Forces. This legal decree only simplifies the management of soldiers deployed to work for other organizations, according to the Ministry.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus stays in the throat 4 days before reaching the lungs and gargling lukewarm water with vinegar and salt can kill it.
Explaination: Neither water temperature, salt, nor vinegar has any impact on the coronavirus, according to experts interviewed by the AFP and recommendations from WHO and health authorities in several countries.
Label: False

Claim: You can self-diagnose COVID-19 by holding your breath for 10 seconds, and avoid COVID-19 by drinking water constantly. COVID-19 causes fibrosis in the lungs.
Explaination: None of this is true. COVID-19 does not cause lung fibrosis, which renders the "hold your breath" argument senseless. Also, drinking water constantly does not help you to avoid it.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking water and gargling with salt or vinegar eliminates the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: According to the brazilian Ministry of Health and experts consulted by Aos Fatos, this information is untrue and may even worsen the patient's condition. Publications circulating on social media with misleading content also omit that there is still no drug or treatment to cure COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Israel has found a cure and a vaccine for coronavirus.
Explaination: The video report shared with these posts actually shows the process of developing a vaccine that, according to the scientists in charge, may be available in May. At no time does the video claim that the drug already exists or that a cure for the infection with the new coronavirus has been found.
Label: False

Claim: Indian industrialist tweets that a specific mask can kill viruses.
Explaination: The mask is an anti-pollution mask and its effect on COVID-19 is not scientifically explained.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo’s hotels to be turned into quarantine centres in Portugal.
Explaination: Footballer's hotel chains denied any such claims.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese police crack down on suspected coronavirus patients.
Explaination: Video is originally from the Hong Kong protests.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows Italians or French people singing Madonna, Katy Perry, Britney Spears or Aya Nakamura songs on their balcony because of the lockdown measure in France and Italy.
Explaination: The video was shot in Torino (Italy) and people are singing and dancing La Macarena.
Label: False

Claim: The ice skating rink in Mulhouse will be used as a morgue.
Explaination: The rink is not used to stock dead bodies.
Label: False

Claim: An official decree taken by the government says the military will have to help in the hospitals.
Explaination: The text is just a transposition of an old law into a decree - and has nothing to do with the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Nostradamus predicted COVID-19.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Italian doctors recommend taking off shoes when you get home.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Christine Lagarde says the elderly are living too long.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Ecuadorean President Lenin Moreno and family quarantined in luxury Galapagos home.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Ibuprofen worsens coronavirus infection.
Explaination: Ibuprofen could worsen some conditions but there are not proof it could include COVID-19. Spanish health authorities has communicated that ibuprofen is not contraindicated to treat first or mild cases.
Label: False

Claim: President Donald Trump in the next 48 to 72 hours will impose a nationwide “mandatory quarantine.”
Explaination: The White House’s National Security Council addressed the claim in a statement on Twitter, saying: “Text message rumors of a national #quarantine are FAKE. There is no national lockdown.”
Label: False

Claim: Gargling water with salt or vinegar “eliminates” the coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no known treatment for the new coronavirus,according to WHO.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus pneumonia is similar to a dry cough and hot weather, garlic and hot water are remedies for COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no scientific proof that hot and humid weather conditions or drinking warm water and consumption of garlic, onions and other spices can prevent the spread of novel coronavirus infection.
Label: False

Claim: Claims of cures for COVID-19 from multiple countries.
Explaination: While some drugs have provided symptomatic improvement, there is no confirmation that any of the medication currently being tested across different parts of the world is a definitive cure for COVID-19. WHO officially confirms there has not been any definitive vaccine or antiviral drug developed to prevent or treat COVID-19 to date, hence all above claims are misleading.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Photo of meat (mutton) affected by coronavirus.
Explaination: It is a photoshopped image. No proof so far that coronavirus is present in mutton.
Label: False

Claim: Office Memorandum of the Indian Ministry of Health and Family Welfare declaring holidays to the states of Maharashtra, Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh and Sikkim in the wake of COVID-19.
Explaination: No, the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare has not declared holidays to the states of Maharashtra, Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh and Sikkim. The Office Memorandum with such information is ‘fake’.
Label: False

Claim: 35 Italians tourists don’t want to leave Ethiopia and go back in Italy because of the coronavirus.
Explaination: Testimonies seems to be invented and the characters quoted does not exist. The website is well known for clickbait content and false stories.
Label: Misleading

Claim: 30 cases of new coronavirus in the city of Barranquilla, in Colombia.
Explaination: At the time of this publication, the Health ministry had not confirmed any cases of coronavirus in Barranquilla.
Label: False

Claim: Saline water kills the new coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no solid scientific evidence to indicate that mouthwash and saline water kills coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: All baby formula providers are shipping formula for free during the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: Enfamil and Gerber issued statements clarifying this is a hoax.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Coronavirus Outbreak Prompted Gun And Ammunition Policy Changes At Walmart.
Explaination: Walmart had already changed its ammo sales policy on September 3, 2019, a month after a gunman killed 22 people at one of its stores in El Paso, Texas.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Dallas student celebrating spring break collapses from coronavirus.
Explaination: Came from fake news generator website.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus is the least deadly virus.
Explaination: The chart, published by Business Insider, issued a correction on the chart exaggerating its figures. But the false info still spreads.
Label: False

Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo is turning his hotels into hospitals to fight coronavirus.
Explaination: Ronaldo's management company denied the claim.
Label: False

Claim: WalMart reducing hours of operation.
Explaination: WalMart website confirms
Label: FALSE

Claim: Tanker train marked with “COVID-19” on its side.
Explaination: Photo was digitally manipulated
Label: False

Claim: CDC warns people that morel mushroom increases coronavirus risk by 200%.
Explaination: User who published made clear this was a hoax.
Label: False

Claim: Police have not issued any “domiciliation order” in Madrid to stay at home under a fine of 1000€.
Explaination: The National Police has denied on its Twitter account this document that forces the citizens of Madrid to remain at home from 9pm to 9am
Label: False

Claim: EFE news agency published a tweet announcing that the Government will impose fines of 300,000 euros on people who travel to other regions.
Explaination: EFE news agency denies it published that tuit. Also, Newtral could not find any proof that the agency published the tweet.
Label: False

Claim: “A looting” in a supermarket due to the coronavirus.
Explaination: The images were recorded three years ago in an establishment of the supermarket chain HiperDino.
Label: False

Claim: Irene Montero is coughing on someone during the 8M women protest.
Explaination: The subtitles are manipulated. irene Montero and the concerned person deny the false claim.
Label: False

Claim: Egypt Health Minister has given China the vaccine against the coronavirus.
Explaination: World Health Organization (WHO) states that to date, there is no vaccine or drug to prevent or treat COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Insurance companies stop covering traffic accidents because the coronavirus.
Explaination: The UNESPA Business Insurance Association deneid it.
Label: FALSE

Claim: The Portuguese soccer player Cristiano Ronaldo decided to turn his hotels into free hospitals
Explaination: Cristiano Ronaldo has never decide to turn his hotels in to free hospitals.
Label: False

Claim: Italy from the space during a flash mob in March 2020.
Explaination: The picture has been taken 2014.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Turkish Ministry of Health issued a document that shows radical measures against COVID-19.
Explaination: The document is fake and the signature in the document belongs to famous boxer Vitali Klitschko.
Label: False

Claim: Women’s inhouse gatherings are banned due to the outbreak.
Explaination: The ministry of family did not issue an order bans women's gatherings.
Label: False

Claim: New virus stays at the throat level for four days.
Explaination: The virus attaches human cells and does not wait to replicate itself. It is not possible to push the virus into stomach by drinking water.
Label: False

Claim: Turmeric And Lemon Help Fight Against Coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no evidence to prove that turmeric and lemon help fight against coronavirus. The viral post is fake.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus patient arrested in Punjab
Explaination: Mock drill video of Mansa, Punjab viral with false claim
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus detection is possible by holding your breath for 10 seconds
Explaination: Whether someone is positive or not is infected with the coronavirus can only be known through laboratory tests. In addition, no health organization, such as the US CDC and WHO, and also the Ministry of Health have included fibrosis as a symptom of COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking alcohol can kill the coronavirus
Explaination: According to WHO, when the virus has entered a person's body, spraying alcohol or even drinking it will not be able to kill the virus.
Label: False

Claim: Uber services in Ghana were suspended because of the pandemic.
Explaination: Uber Services are still available in Accra and other parts of the country.
Label: False

Claim: A military Humvee labeled “COVID-19 quarantine team” was on Interstate 696 in Michigan.
Explaination: The same image has been shared and described as a vehicle spotted in Ohio and London in the United Kingdom.
Label: False

Claim: EFE has published that those who move from one Spanish region to another under the state of alarm will be fined up to 300,000 euros.
Explaination: It is false both the application of that measure and that EFE has published it.
Label: False

Claim: Insurance companies will stop covering auto accident policies under the alarm state.
Explaination: Auto insurance coverage to third parties and to all risks will continue to be assumed by insurers as before the declaration of the state of alarm.
Label: False

Claim: Helicopters will spray Spanish cities to disinfect them from coronaviruses.
Explaination: It's a hoax. The Spanish Government has no plans of spraying cities.
Label: False

Claim: President Giammattei said the economic activity would be limited but didn’t mention call centers and maquilas.
Explaination: Maquilas and call centers continue operating and there are many complains of COVID-19 risks from their workers.
Label: Partially false

Claim: President Donald Trump is “announcing tomorrow that the U.S. is going into quarantine for the next 14 days.”
Explaination: There was no evidence by March 16 that the federal government was set to announce a nationwide lockdown. President Trump said he was not considering it. Trump said the government is thinking about additional measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in some hotspots around the country.
Label: False

Claim: President Donald Trump “will evoke (sic) what is called the Stafford act” and “order a two week mandatory quarantine for the nation.”
Explaination: There is no evidence that the federal government is set to announce a nationwide lockdown. President Trump said March 16 that he was not considering it. The Stafford Act authorizes aid to state and local governments and is commonly used during hurricanes. It does not mandate a nationwide lockdown.
Label: False

Claim: “Now, as it stands, our health care system has adequate ventilators, ICU beds, medical professionals.”
Explaination: Experts said all evidence points to the U.S. being short on hospital beds, ICUs and ventilators, assuming COVID-19 continues to spread. The U.S. could take any number of actions to increase the number of hospital beds, supplies and medical staff available.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Claim that Dr. Anthony Fauci’s statement that the coronavirus death rate is 10 times that of the seasonal flu is “a claim without any scientific basis.”
Explaination: It’s not yet known what the death rate from the current coronavirus, COVID-19, will be. But early data indicate it is more than 10 times higher than the death rate for the flu.
Label: False

Claim: “Sunlight actually can kill the [novel coronavirus].”
Explaination: This is a common theory because sunlight contains ultraviolet rays, which can kill bacteria. However, experts say the sun's UV light isn't intense enough to rely on as a disinfectant.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows problems faced by Chinese police while catching coronavirus-infected people.
Explaination: The video has nothing to do with the coronavirus pandemic. It was shot last year in September during Hong Kong's ongoing pro-democracy protest.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Flu vaccine increases coronavirus risk 36%, says military study.
Explaination: More research is needed to provide a conclusive answer to the question of whether the flu shot increases the risk of non-influenza viral respiratory infections. It is important to keep in mind that while the flu vaccine cannot prevent COVID-19, it still provides several indirect benefits. For example, it reduces cases of flu and flu complications that require hospitalization, in turn reducing the burden on the healthcare system, which has become strained during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Label: No evidence

Claim: A headline about the closure of the airport in Skopje: “The Airport Also Closed: 26 passengers from Skopje Airport returned, foreign nationals”.
Explaination: Because the measure of complete closure applies to Ohrid Airport, it is quite possible that the reader will be misinformed and think that this has happened to Skopje Airport as well. The ban on entering the territory of the country according to the government decision that is in force at the time of publishing the reviewed text refers to the countries exclusively at high risk for COVID-19. Therefore, it is not true that the airport is closed to everyone, as the title suggests, but only to these passengers.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A large group of citizens in the Republic of North Macedonia — every member of the party Social Democratic Union of Macedonia (SDSM) — is quarantined, allegedly because they were in contact with the director of the Skin Clinic in Skopje, infected with COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no official information that a decision has been made by any competent state body to guarantee that the entire party membership of the SDSM were quarantined.
Label: False

Claim: A headline reads: “Chaos in Debar: Roadblocks, fires, apocalyptic scenes in Macedonia”.
Explaination: Of course, the entrance and exit from the city are strictly controlled and only citizens with proper documentation can leave the city - in case they need urgent medical care that they cannot get from the local health care. But there are no barricades, which can be seen in the photos, nor any apocalyptic scenes.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro declared a national holiday due to coronavirus.
Explaination: The "national holiday" was a prank shared by users on WhatsApp..
Label: False

Claim: Nostradamus predicted the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: There is no reference to such prophecy in Nostradamus' works.
Label: False

Claim: Brazilian beverage company Ambev stops beer production.
Explaination: Ambev denied any stop in its production.
Label: False

Claim: A video on Facebook and YouTube purports to show billionaire businessman Jack Ma praising China’s response to the outbreak of the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: But the video has been doctored; the original video shows Jack Ma at a meeting of former Alibaba employees in 2018, at least one year before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan; the voiceover in the clip has been taken from another clip which shows a different man speaking.
Label: False

Claim: Nostradamus predicted COVID-19.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Italian doctors recommend taking off shoes when you get home.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Christine Lagarde says the elderly are living too long.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Ecuadorian President Lenin Moreno and family quarantined in luxury Galapagos home.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Insurance companies in Spain cease to cover traffic accidents due to coronavirus.
Explaination: The Insurance Business Association UNESPA, which includes 200 companies in the sector, has debunked the hoax.
Label: False

Claim: Insurance companies stop covering traffic accidents because the coronavirus.
Explaination: The UNESPA Business Insurance Association denied it.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 is caused by 5G.
Explaination: The doctor in the video makes scientifically false statements on the virus.
Label: False

Claim: No evidence that 5G is being forcibly installed in schools.
Explaination: Schools have been closed, but no evidence it's to install 5G. It's to protect against the pandemic.
Label: False

Claim: The government is closing businesses to stop the spread of coronavirus even though “the numbers are nothing compared to H1N1 or Ebola. Everyone needs to realize our government is up to something …”
Explaination: Any suggestion that the coronavirus isn't real or that it’s part of a government conspiracy is a ridiculous claim.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Photos show animals returning to clear Venice canals.
Explaination: Yes, these photos of clear water in Venice are real. However, the Dolphins were not in Venice like one twitter user suggests.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A charitable hospital in Pakistan charged patients for novel coronavirus tests.
Explaination: But the claim is misleading; the hospital, which was founded by Prime Minister Imran Khan, denied charging a fee, saying in a statement that eligible patients have been receiving free tests; the health minister of Punjab also denied the claim.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Train with the name of COVID19 in september 2019 in America that carry the gas responsible for COVID19.
Explaination: The image is photoshoped. The type of train on the picture follows a naming pattern and there is no train registered with this name or any similar names.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Claim that football star Cristiano Ronaldo has converted his hotel chain into coronavirus hospitals.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: The novel coronavirus is not new.
Explaination: This is false; coronaviruses affecting cattle or canines differ from the new virus strain affecting humans, for which no vaccine exists.
Label: False

Claim: Ugandan president announces the postponement of elections.
Explaination: The claim is false; an electoral commission official issued a flat denial, labelling the claim “nonsensical”.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows how the coronavirus is transmitted between people
Explaination: The claim is false; the video was produced by a regional hospital trust within the UK’s public healthcare system, the National Health Service (NHS), in May 2010 about how infections spread in hospitals.
Label: False

Claim: In France, a picture shows policemen spraying tear gas on nurses and a text criticizes Macron’s treatment toward health employees.
Explaination: The picture is said to have been taken "yesterday", ie during the massive demonstrations in favor of the public health services, that took place in France, from March 2019. The picture was taken in 2010, before Macron was even president.
Label: False

Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo will convert his hotels into coronavirus hospitals.
Explaination: A spokesperson for the hotels said the claim was “inaccurate”; Ronaldo has also not mentioned any such plan on his social media platforms.
Label: False

Claim: In Spain dozens of people faced beatings and shoves with the police because they prevented them from going to a mass to pray against COVID-19.
Explaination: The video has nothing to do with the coronavirus, nor with the state of alert decreed in Spain. In fact, when the video was originally released on October 14 last year, there were still no reports of COVID-19 existing in the world.
Label: False

Claim: European and South American flights cause chaos at Mexico Airport, due to coronavirus.
Explaination: The video was recorded in December and is not related to COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: China benefited financially from new coronavirus
Explaination: Contrary to what the piece of misinformation suggests, the country's stock exchanges have suffered from the pandemic: two of its most important indices - the CSI 300, which brings together the largest companies in the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges, and the compound Shanghai - have fallen 8% and 0.94% since the beginning of the year. In addition, the coronavirus outbreak caused a reduction in economic activity in China, with a sharp drop in industrial production and retail sales and an increase in the unemployment rate in the first two months of 2020.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese intelligence officer reveals coronavirus is a bioweapon.
Explaination: The story originated from a reddit thread which discusses horror stories inspired by true events.
Label: False

Claim: Indian Daily Reports That Wife Of A Positive Patient Ran Away, did not comply with the authorities and tested positive.
Explaination: The Indian daily misreported as the woman had not yet tested positive and she did not flee so as to not be tested.
Label: False

Claim: Audio claiming India would be put under a complete lockdown.
Explaination: The government rubbished claims of there being such a lockdown.
Label: False

Claim: Nostradamus predicted the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The text used as proof is not found on Nostradamus' writings.
Label: False

Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo transformed his hotels into hospitals for COVID-19 patients.
Explaination: Cristiano Ronaldo did not say this and is not planning to do this.
Label: False

Claim: A ship from China is anchored in Santa Marta, in Colombia.
Explaination: The Yuan Shun Hai ship is not anchored in Santa Marta is anchored and does not come from China.
Label: False

Claim: Holding your breath for 10 seconds will tell you if you have COVID-19.
Explaination: This is not an approved method for testing.
Label: False

Claim: There are 30 cases of COVID-19 in Barranquilla, but the government is hiding them.
Explaination: At the time of publishing there were no confirmed cases.
Label: False

Claim: State of emergency begins on Tuesday, the 17th, according to article 116 of the Constitution
Explaination: The text is from Spain.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Gargling with hot water and salt can prevent COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no scientific basis for this claim.
Label: False

Claim: China has successfully developed a vaccine ready to combat the coronavirus.
Explaination: China announced the vaccine began clinical trial, not that it was developed successfully.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows an Italian doctor who says that nobody died from coronavirus in Italy, that it’s not more dangerous than a flu.
Explaination: The video is from February when there were only 11 deaths by coronavirus in Italy. It is not possible to say whether people with prior diseases die only because of the virus. But studies show that also healthy people died so far.
Label: False

Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo will turn his hotels into hospitals.
Explaination: Information was published without verification and was denied afterwards.
Label: False

Claim: Lombardia, Italy, asks Cuba, China and Venezuela to send doctors.
Explaination: Gallera really said that but the next day he explained venezuelan doctors weren't related to Maduro but to Piccola Venezia, a local Italian-venezuela NGO. China send doctors with no relations with him and was Cuba, and not him, which offers to help a week before his speech.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 arrived in the U.S. by train.
Explaination: The photo has been manipulated.
Label: False

Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo turned his hotels into hospitals.
Explaination: The claim is false.
Label: False

Claim: A meme posted offers mixed advice — some true, some false — about coronavirus protection.
Explaination: The claims in this meme are muddled.
Label: Mixed

Claim: Left-wing Spanish politicians Irene Montero and Pablo Iglesias have private sanitarian services waiting in front of their homes.
Explaination: Madrid's Health Department, the emergency medical service and PODEMOS say it is false.
Label: False

Claim: A message chain claims that Stanford hospital gives advice to drink water every 15 minutes in order to prevent COVID-19.
