Explaination: A statement from the Stanford hospital distanced themselves from the fake message.
Label: False

Claim: The Portuguese soccer player Cristiano Ronaldo decided to turn his hotels into free hospitals
Explaination: Cristiano Ronaldo has never decide to turn his hotels in to free hospitals.
Label: False

Claim: Four young people have been hospitalized with coronavirus, exacerbated by the use of Ibuprofen.
Explaination: The message, which was widely shared, had no basis in fact. It did not match the description of any patients in the hospital in question, and it misrepresented the dangers of ibuprofen
Label: False

Claim: “Bill Gates told us about the coronavirus in 2015.”
Explaination: In the 2015 TED talk featured in the video, he never actually uses the word coronavirus, nor does he mention COVID-19. But his comments do sound prescient. He talks about an epidemic and we're now in the midst of a pandemic. People could be infected with COVID-19 and not show symptoms for days, if at all. And it’s mainly spread between people in close contact through respiratory droplets when someone coughs or sneezes.
Label: Mostly True

Claim: COVID-19 is large in size, where the cell diameter is 400-500 micrometers. For this reason, any mask can prevent its entry.
Explaination: The cell diameter is around 120 nanometers. The surgical mask can protect the wearer from sprays and large-particle droplets, but not against infection with coronavirus. People are recommended to wear a mask if taking care of a person with suspected COVID-19 infection.
Label: False

Claim: A video showing a man infected with coronavirus and touching pieces of bread in a supermarket in Europe.
Explaination: It's a set up video, published by a humoristic American Facebook page, called "The Philly offensive". The author of this page explained having filmed this scene, explaining he hates when people touch bread in supermarkets, but without mentioning coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Helicopter of the armed forces disinfects the streets at night.
Explaination: There is not such measure of disinfectants.
Label: False

Claim: Graphics with information about COVID-19 containing UNICEF branding and inaccurate information.
Explaination: A series of infographics with Unicef branding making claims about COVID-19 are not from the UN agency.
Label: False

Claim: A situation update allegedly from Kenya’s Citizen TV stating the number of COVID-19 cases.
Explaination: A post is with an update about COVID-19 in Kenya containing a screenshot of a Facebook post by Citizen TV is fake.
Label: False

Claim: A meme shows an image of fully stocked shelves of toilet paper, purportedly during the 2009 H1N1 outbreak, above barren shelves during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.
Explaination: The post is misleading; the image of the stocked shelves is a screenshot from US news footage shot this year, not in 2009.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A video viewed more than 2.4 million times on Facebook urges people to inhale steam to “kill” the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: But experts say that doing so will not treat or cure the viral infection, and could in fact be harmful.
Label: False

Claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube which claim it shows Chinese police arresting people infected with the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video shows police arresting pro-democracy protesters at a subway station in Hong Kong in August 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Research made by scientists from the University of Queensland in Australia has proven that bananas improve your immune system and help prevent COVID-19.
Explaination: The University of Queensland dismissed the claim as false. In an email to Rappler, the university’s communication team said: “The video is fake and we would strongly discourage people from sharing this information. We would suggest you share your concerns with the social media platforms.”
Label: False

Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo transformed some of his hotels into hospitals to fight COVID-19.
Explaination: Cristiano Ronaldo refuted those claims.
Label: False

Claim: A large crowd in Paris protested against the lockdown.
Explaination: It was an anti-Government demonstration conducted by yellow-vest activities. As the protest took place on March 14, the French government had not implemented the national lockdown.
Label: False

Claim: The spread of the new coronavirus was planned by the Rockefellers years ago.
Explaination: Scenarios are widely used as analytical methods in simulations. Scenario, which elaborates on the pandemic threat, has nothing to do with the global conspiracy. It is about futurology and possible crisis response management.
Label: False

Claim: The WHO offered the testing kits that they have available and to give it to us now. We refused them. We did not want to buy them.”
Explaination: The WHO never offered to sell test kits to the United States. The CDC opted to develop its own coronavirus test and did not use the WHO’s protocol for the test.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: President Donald Trump “cut funding to the CDC,” “fired the Pandemic Response Team,” “refused WHO tests” and “wasted two weeks calling this outbreak a ‘Democrat hoax.’”
Explaination: Trump did attempt to cut the CDC’s funding, but Congress prevented it from happening. While officials in charge of the U.S. response to pandemics did leave in 2018, it’s unclear if they were “fired.” The U.S. was not on a list of countries receiving COVID-19 tests from the WHO. But the U.S. does not usually rely on the agency for diagnostic tests, and the testing delay was due mainly to an error with the CDC’s protocol. While Trump has called the Democratic response to the coronavirus a “hoax,” he has not used the term to describe the virus itself.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: The claim that there is a cure from the new coronavirus. The name of the drug is decametoxine.
Explaination: There is no proof that the drug in question can be used in the treatment of coronavirus-infected.
Label: False

Claim: Pandemics happen every 100 years.
Explaination: Global pandemics do not occur every 100 years as God's or nature's scourge. The authors of this fake have selected only those pandemics, which fit into their explanation.
Label: False

Claim: The quarantine will last until the end of May in Ukraine.
Explaination: The official sources on the day when the news appeared have not published such information. The authors of the article confused the end date of the tax holidays and the end day of the quarantine.
Label: FALSE

Claim: “COVID-19 started because we eat animals.”
Explaination: Scientists think COVID-19 originated in bats and then jumped to another animal host, possibly pangolins, before spreading to humans. As of now, there is no evidence that eating meat is the source of the coronavirus outbreak.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: “George Soros owns the WuXi PHARMA LAB located in Wuhan, China, where COVID-19 was developed and conveniently broke out.”
Explaination: George Soros has invested in WuXi in the past, but he does not own it. Research shows the genetic makeup of COVID-19 precludes it from being man-made.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus is just “the damn flu.”
Explaination: Coronavirus and the flu do have similarities in spread and symptoms, but there are huge differences in the death rate and ability to treat coronavirus.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: “So Oscar Health, the company tapped by Trump to profit from covid tests, is a Kushner company. Imagine that, profits over national safety.”
Explaination: Oscar Health does have ties to the Kushner family through Jared Kushner and more directly through Jared’s brother, Joshua Kushner. Oscar Health created a website for finding coronavirus testing locations. The project was launched on the same day that Trump announced a similar partnership with Google.
Label: HALF TRUE

Claim: Says businesses will give you free baby formula during the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: Several formula producers have released statements saying the rumor is a hoax.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Study from Queensland Australia says that eating a banana a day prevents COVID-19 because of Vitamin B6.
Explaination: The university mentioned in the claim refuted this claim. there is no scientific research till now says that banana or vitamin B6 prevent COVID-19 infection.
Label: False

Claim: President Vucic claimed that according to the EU decisions, Serbia cannot import medical equipment from the EU countries.
Explaination: Exports of medical equipment outside of the EU are subject to an export authorisation by Member States. Serbia can import such equipment but it requires an authorization.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Drugs used against malaria (Hydroxychloroquine, Azithromycin) can cure COVID-19.
Explaination: The medicines used by medical doctor to cure the disease, but people shouldn't find for curing themselves because it could be a life-threat by its side-effect.
Label: HALF TRUTH

Claim: You can test a quality of reusable mask blowing a lighter as you wear it.
Explaination: Blowing lighter is not a way to test mask quality. Blowing power are vary. Beware burning your mask.
Label: False

Claim: Footballer Ronaldo is turning his hotels into COVID-19 hospitals.
Explaination: No evidence Ronaldo's luxury hotels in Portugal are being turned into hospitals.
Label: False

Claim: No coronavirus in Nigeria yet, according to pastor.
Explaination: The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control reported the country’s first case of coronavirus on 27 February – more than two weeks before pastor's video was posted on YouTube. A second case was confirmed on 9 March.
Label: False

Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo is going to transform his hotels into hospitals.
Explaination: It’s not true that the Portuguese football player is doing this. Observador spoke with sources close to the Hotels and the player and found out that it was false.
Label: False

Claim: Having a patent on a virus means we have created the virus.
Explaination: Other fact-checkers before us showed that this and that patent were not related to this coronavirus, but we realized that much of the claims are coming from a misunderstanding of what the word "patent" means in 2020, and especially in life sciences.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows Italian people greeting and clapping for China during the COVID-19 emergency.
Explaination: The video has been edited by adding the Chinese National anthem and a voice saying "Thank you China". However, the video is not related at all to China. On the contrary, people clapping in the video are supporting Italian healthcare personnel during an organized flash mob.
Label: False

Claim: Nostradamus predicted the current COVID-19 pandemic.
Explaination: The text attributed to Nostradamus does not exist in his book.
Label: False

Claim: State of emergency begins on  3/17/20, according to article 116 of the Constitution.
Explaination: The text is from Spain.
Label: False

Claim: Quarantine may last for several years.
Explaination: The information has no support from the official's side. It is posted to spread panic.
Label: Misleading

Claim: “Amoxi” Capsule, made in US, is the only medicine that can completely cure COVID-19.
Explaination: Amoxicillin has nothing to do with COVID-19. It's an antibiotic drug for killing bacteria, not a virus.
Label: False

Claim: Did genetic mutations cause the coronavirus to become more dangerous.
Explaination: Infectious disease specialist said no proof that mutation specifically caused virus to be more dangerous.
Label: Partially true

Claim: A photo claims that military vehicles are combating COVID-19 in Palermo, Italy.
Explaination: Sicilian media wrote that military was indeed driving through Palermo, but vehicles were coming back from a military exercise and had nothing to do with the virus as at the time there were a handful of confirmed COVID-19 cases in Sicily.
Label: Partially false

Claim: A graphic claims that gargling warm water with salt or vinegar can eliminate the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; international health authorities and experts do not list gargling as an effective remedy or prevention method for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo will convert his hotels into coronavirus hospitals.
Explaination: A spokesperson for the hotels said the claim was “inaccurate”; Ronaldo has also not mentioned any such plan on his social media platforms.
Label: False

Claim: 37.000 US soldiers are entering the EU while everybody is busy with the coronavirus; the soldiers are immune.
Explaination: The Nato exercise Defender Europe 20 is no secret exercise, there are only 29.000 US soldiers and media reported about it for months. Further, it was stopped because of the coronavirus outbreak - soldiers are not immune.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: The University hospital in Vienna found out that Ibuprofen speeds up the spreading of the coronavirus.
Explaination: The voice message tells an untrue story and it is not clear whether Ibuprofen can have a negative effect. There is no proof so far that if affects COVID-19 patients
Label: No evidence

Claim: Drinking lots of water and gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates the coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim has not been corroborated by any health institution. The WHO says there is currently no specific treatment, drug or vaccine for the COVID-19, although some home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms.
Label: False

Claim: Quotes by Finnish national health authorities between January 20 and March 3 are taken out of context.
Explaination: Currently, an image with the title "THL and coronavirus in the news" is being circulated in social media, gathering comments from the National Institute for Health and Welfare on coronavirus from January to March. The statements quoted by THL experts are quoted but appear to be largely inaccurate when removed from context. The list as a whole is deliberately misleading. Its purpose is to undermine the credibility of the responsible authority, THL, without providing it with verified information.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Corporations invented the coronavirus.
Explaination: there is no evidence to support this claim.
Label: False

Claim: Curfew issued for Bossier city due to coronavirus.
Explaination: The article itself says it's a joke and a prank.
Label: False

Claim: CEO Resignations Are Linked To Global Conspiracy.
Explaination: Some CEOs have stepped down since coronavirus outbreak, but there's not evidence to suggest it's all linked to a global power issue.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus is found in crab legs.
Explaination: Image did not actually come out of real broadcast with typos, and came from an app that let people make their own stories.
Label: False

Claim: Military on streets of Philadelphia preparing to invoke martial law and bring citizens to FEMA camps.
Explaination: Lt. Col. Keith Hickox, the state public affairs officer said the information was false.
Label: False

Claim: Article overstates threat of coronavirus.
Explaination: The claims in the article are backed by science.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking lots of water and gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates the novel coronavirus. Spread the information as you can save someone.
Explaination: According to GMA news report, saline gargles or gargling with water and salt will provide no protection against or cure for the 2019 novel coronavirus acute respiratory disease (2019-nCoV ARD). The report also carried a statement by the Dr. Eric Domingo “I think this is a home remedy that has been followed for many, many generations and I don't think there’s going to be any harm in doing it. Saline gargle has always been advocated to improve mostly symptoms of sore throat...I don't think there is any evidence that it will kill a virus,” Domingo said.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Eating salt on the onion will eliminate the coronavirus.
Explaination: According to the World Health Organization , eating onions increases the immune system . But it has nothing to do with the treatment of coronavirus. In the investigation we found that no cure for this virus has yet been discovered.
Label: False

Claim: Viral image with differences between a cold, the flu and COVID-19.
Explaination: The symptoms are not accurate.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Catalonia universities give all course credits to its students after classes being suspended.
Explaination: Education ministry in Catalonia denied it.
Label: False

Claim: Spanish home office has not issued a statement announcing the complete closure of Madrid, the Basque Country and La Rioja.
Explaination: Home office denied the authenticity of the document.
Label: False

Claim: Felipe Gonzalez, ex-prime minister of Spain, says the Spanish coalition government cannot face the COVID-19 crisis.
Explaination: The Twitter account is a parody.
Label: False

Claim: The current coronavirus has been “manufactured” in Wuhan.
Explaination: There is no scientific reason to believe that.The international scientific community condemns conspiracy theories and recalls that the current coronavirus originated in wildlife.
Label: False

Claim: There are one hundred children infected with COVID-19 in the main hospital in Lima.
Explaination: Authorities denied the information of one hundred children infectec with the virus in that hospital, the main public facility for the treatment of children in Lima.
Label: FALSE

Claim: An American soldier has been paid to spread COVID-19 in Europe.
Explaination: The man is the sheriff's deputy Rick Grimes, the main character of The Walking Dead and the picture is a thumbnail of the 1st episode of The Walking Dead.
Label: False

Claim: Turkish President Erdoğan will declare a curfew due to COVID-19.
Explaination: The clipping of the Hurriyet newspaper is manipulated. President Erdoğan's speech did not cover such a measure.
Label: False

Claim: Two COVID-19 patients were executed in North Korea.
Explaination: Content belongs to a parody account. There is no declared COVID-19 case in North Korea.
Label: False

Claim: Italian air force’s air show to motivate the public under quarantine.
Explaination: The video is shared in 2019, september, before the outbreak. The plains do not belong to Italian army.
Label: False

Claim: Ireland is going into a full lockdown.
Explaination: Despite two messages which were widely shared on WhatsApp, the country did not go into a full military lockdown with the army patrolling the streets. Shops have not been restricted in their opening hours and public transport has not been cancelled.
Label: False

Claim: A post shows a rail freight tanker with “COVID-19” stamped on one side.
Explaination: The image has circulated globally but it is false, the tanker operating company said. And Railinc, a corporation that manages an industry-wide database, said there is no such mark as “COVID.”
Label: False

Claim: A graphic has been shared thousands of times on Facebook which claims that gargling warm water with salt or vinegar can eliminate the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is false; international health authorities and experts do not list gargling as an effective remedy or prevention method for COVID-19.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Gargling salt with water “eliminates” the 2019 novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Local and international health authorities have said there is not enough study that proves gargling water with salt eliminates the novel coronavirus. To date, there is still no known cure for it.
Label: False

Claim: Former senator Antonio Trillanes IV allegedly posted a tweet saying that President Rodrigo Duterte is to blame for calamities the country has been facing, including the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The tweet came from an account posing as Trillanes. Using his official Twitter account, the former senator explained how the username of the account is different from the one he’s using.
Label: False

Claim: Astrologers had predicted the appearance of a coronavirus in 2020.
Explaination: Horoscopes and astro forecasts have no scientific basis.
Label: Misleading

Claim: “Italy has decided not to treat their elderly for this virus.”
Explaination: Italy, second only to China in the number of COVID-19 cases, hasn't decided to stop treating elderly COVID-19 patients. But the elderly are a lower priority because they are less likely to survive, and hospitals are overwhelmed with coronavirus cases.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Says that “over a 45-minute period that we had the press conference” on the coronavirus on March 13, 2020, the stock market set “an all-time record.”
Explaination: The Dow had a record-high point increase on the day Trump declared a national emergency in response to coronavirus, with the surge accelerating during his late-afternoon news conference. But that followed a record point decrease the previous day. And it was followed by a sharp drop by the opening of the next trading day, which saw continued declines before closing.
Label: HALF TRUE

Claim: Drink water a lot and gargle with warm water and salt or vinegar to eliminate the virus.
Explaination: Whenever the virus get into your body, it infects to a cell, not just fall on a throat. Water can't clean the virus from an infected cell, and normally can't get to a respiratory system where the virus stay.
Label: False

Claim: A Cuban vaccine cured 1.500 people infected with the new coronavirus.
Explaination: There is still no vaccine available in the market, according to Health Authorities. Experts estimate that it will take about 18 months to develop and test a vaccine that can be used with safety in human beings.
Label: False

Claim: Warm water with salt prevents the new coronavirus infection, killing it in the throat.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence to support this theory. Several experts had already explained that there’s no connection between the act of drinking water and the virus.
Label: False

Claim: The Simpsons had already predicted the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: It’s not true, because the images that are shown to illustrate this were manipulated and are not in accordance with the original images of the series.
Label: False

Claim: Gargling warm salt water or vinegar prevents coronavirus infection.
Explaination: The claim is false; international health authorities and experts do not list gargling as an effective remedy or prevention method for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: There are 100 children infected with COVID-19 in the main hospital in Lima.
Explaination: Authorities denied the information of one hundred children infected with the virus in that hospital, the main public facility for the treatment of children in Lima.
Label: False

Claim: There are 100 children infected with COVID-19 in the main hospital in Lima.
Explaination: Authorities denied the information of one hundred children infected with the virus in that hospital, the main public facility for the treatment of children in Lima.
Label: False

Claim: If you drink water with lemon, it prevents the new coronavirus.
Explaination: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory. Health authorities have never made any recommendations regarding water and lemon. It’s not proved.
Label: False

Claim: LGBTQ people in the US are demanding to be treated first for coronavirus.
Explaination: Pulpit and Pen quotes a Reuters article about an open letter signed by more than 100 LGBTQ rights groups, calling on organisations handling the global coronavirus pandemic to remember “that LGBTQ+ communities are among those who are particularly vulnerable to the negative health effects of this virus”. But it doesn't ask for anyone to be given priority treatment.
Label: False

Claim: Stop taking NSAIDs as it increases the effect of the virus on the body and causes the spread of COVID19.
Explaination: There is no studies shows that NSAIDs increase the spread of COVID19. WHO said that until now it doesn't recommend against the use of NSAIDS.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A photo claimed that a Lithuanian town of Mazeikiai is being cut off from the rest of the country due to outbreak of COVID-19.
Explaination: An original photo shows a sign that informs of a road maintenance project. Whereas the fake one claimed that a city is being cut off.
Label: False

Claim: A Facebook post claimed that a message from Stanford hospital gives advice to drink water every 15 minutes in order to prevent COVID-19
Explaination: A statement from the Stanford hospital distanced themselves from the fake message.
Label: False

Claim: An image claims that hundreds of infected people are hidden in Lithuanian hospitals, and were taken to crematoriums.
Explaination: The original message was published by a prank generating Facebook account and repackaged to look as if it was real.
Label: False

Claim: Claim from an “uncle” who “graduated with a master’s degree” and worked at Shenzhen Hospital offers advice on COVID-19 symptoms and treatment.
Explaination: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the post to contain a mixture of true and false claims. A runny nose, sputum, dry cough and pneumonia can be symptoms of COVID-19 however not everyone infected with the disease will have them. Disease expert Prof Collignon says temperatures around 26 to 27 degrees C won't kill the virus however UV light from the sun can be effective in drying out the virus. Understanding of how long COVID-19 survives on surfaces is limited, with the WHO referring to previous studies of other viruses to estimate a range of a few hours to a few days. Drinking warm water, avoiding iced drinks and gargling warm salt water are not treatments or preventions, according to Prof Cunningham, however staying hydrated is important and gargling may relieve sore throats. The timeline for progression of COVID-19 symptoms is partly accurate but not everyone will experience all of these symptoms or in that order. Prof Cunningham also said it was not accurate to say infection will happen first in the throat, as the delicate tissues behind the nose are more likely starting points.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Ancient herbal drink is an effective remedy for the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Experts advise against using herbal remedies to treat coronavirus
Label: False

Claim: False COVID-19 hotline number shared in Canada.
Explaination: 811 is not an official public health hotline in Ontario, and the provincial ministry of health is not organizing home visits, a spokeswoman told AFP.
Label: False

Claim: Israel has no cases of the coronavirus because it developed a cure.
Explaination: Official World Health Organization (WHO) data and Israeli media reports state at least 298 people have been confirmed to have contracted the disease as of March 16; Israel has implemented travel restrictions and closed businesses in response to the spread of COVID-19. Various countries have been working develop a vaccine for COVID-19 and WHO guidance currently states there is no "cure" for the virus to date.
Label: False

Claim: Claim that COVID-19 has been around for a long time, with a photo of an animal vaccine labeled “coronavirus.”
Explaination: The coronavirus affecting these animals is different from the virus that appeared a few months ago in China, for which there is no vaccine.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows full vegan supermarket shelves, next to empty ones, with a caption saying “even at a time of coronavirus, no one wants to eat vegan”.
Explaination: The photo had been circulating on the Internet for two years and a half.
Label: False

Claim: After the closure of schools in France, President Emmanuel Macron announced classes next summer to catch up.
Explaination: Emmanuel Macron has not made such announces. It was published from a fake account.
Label: False

Claim: Cuba developed a coronavirus vaccine.
Explaination: Cuban medication has been used for treating COVID-19 in China, but it is not a vaccine and the substance has been discovered elsewhere.
Label: False

Claim: Holding your breath without coughing will determine if you have COVID-19
Explaination: False, having difficulty breathing is a feature of any respiratory illness and not a sign of coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Books predicted the coronavirus before it happened.
Explaination: One book does have a close enough accurate representation, the second is a work of fiction.
Label: Misleading

Claim: India announced holidays for four states.
Explaination: No such letter was issued by the government.
Label: False

Claim: Israel and USA have come up with a vaccine.
Explaination: Israel has found a vaccine with properties similar to COVID-19, San Diego had developed an algorithm.
Label: False

Claim: Viral video suggests the two cases of coronavirus in Ghana tested negative.
Explaination: The video is not new. It was part of a news item published by Citi TV on February 6, 2020, when two suspected cases tested negative.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Dettol sanitizer can kill the coronavirus.
Explaination: Dettol has been tested on, and found to kill coronaviruses such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS). However, the manufacturer of Dettol, Reckitt Benckiser Group plc(RB), says it has not yet tested its products on the novel coronavirus and could not confirm whether Dettol is effective against the new coronavirus strain.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A misleading chart being spread on Facebook, erroneously dubbing the new coronavirus the “least deadly virus.”
Explaination: The chart cites old data about coronavirus cases and deaths, and it contains an error that makes COVID-19 look less fatal than the 2009 H1N1 “swine flu” outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Indian Ministry of Health and Family Welfare issued an office memorandum declaring compulsory holiday in four Indian states.
Explaination: Ministry of Health India has denied any such notification.
Label: False

Claim: A scientific paper published in Nature in 2015 shows that the new virus was developed in labs.
Explaination: On the contrary, the authors state that viruses similar to SARS have been detected in populations of bats.
Label: False

Claim: Image showing Italian doctors exhausted and sleeping.
Explaination: Images that were used belong to a campaign in Mexico for health workers rights.
Label: False

Claim: Propolis cures COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no evidence to support this claim.
Label: False

Claim: A secret invasion of 40,000 American troops immune to COVID-19 is ongoing in Europe.
Explaination: A secret invasion of 40 thousand American troops on Europe is not happening.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 is human-made, and an American biological weapon
Explaination: Scientific research shows that the virus is not human made.
Label: False

Claim: Croatian president tells people to buy in bulk for at least 2 weeks.
Explaination: The president did not say you should buy food to sustain you for two weeks.
Label: False

Claim: People are panicked about a COVID-19 case at the Dakar Airport.
Explaination: this footage has nothing to do with the coronavirus pandemic and was taken out of context from a Senegalese TV footage showing an exercise.
Label: False

Claim: Saddam Hussein explaining what is coronavirus about.
Explaination: Sound has been edited. It's a video from 2003 where Saddam Hussein is talking about the USA/Irak war.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Healthy ministry sent an email about the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Colombian Ministry of Health explained that the email was false.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus scare began after impeachment.
Explaination: the outbreak began in China in late 2019, and it led to the World Health Organization to declare a global health emergency on January 30, 2020, before the final impeachment vote.
Label: False

Claim: Supermarkets are recalling coronavirus-infected toilet paper.
Explaination: The CDC said that coronavirus is spread through respiratory droplets. No reports yet of toilet paper recalls.
Label: False

Claim: Man did pass along coronavirus infection at a WalMart in Louisiana.
Explaination: The man in the photo who posted it admitted it was a joke.
Label: False

Claim: NYC did implement a citywide quarantine.
Explaination: NY Mayor Bill de Blasio tweeted it was a false alarm.
Label: False

Claim: Spanish Ministry of Interior is closing off Madrid.
Explaination: The ministry of Interior has denied releasing that statement.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking hot beverages prevents coronavirus infection.
Explaination: Fluid intake has nothing to do with the infection process.
Label: False

Claim: Audio from WhatsApp that says there are a doctor and two nurses hospitalized on the ICU in Terrassa (Barcelona)
Explaination: The hospitals in Terrassa deny this situation.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Film “Coronavirus” predicted the current pandemic
Explaination: That's not the cover of the movie. The original name of the film in Korean is "Gamgi" (Cold), "Flu" in English, and it is translated into Spanish as "Virus".
Label: False

Claim: A viral message listing false and unrelated statements about coronavirus has falsely been attributed to the United Nations International Children’s Emergency Fund (UNICEF).
Explaination: No such advisory has been released by UNICEF. Nor much is known about novel coronavirus as it is a newly found coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Israel has manufactured the coronavirus vaccine
Explaination: According to Israel, work at The Biological Institute is going on and it may take time. 50 of the most senior researchers and scientists are working hard to prepare a vaccine. The Image which is being circulated along with the claim is a reference image, available on shutterstock.
Label: False

Claim: They are not looking for volunteers to be infected with COVID-19 in British laboratories for 4,000 euros.
Explaination: Headlines shared on networks do not specify that they will inject other coronavirus strains, 0C43 and 229E.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Zhong Nanshan: Shower may cause coronavirus infection, according to cases in Hong Kong and the Diamond Princess.
Explaination: Zhong said "sewer", but it was translated as shower in Chinese in one wechat account. Then Taiwanese media misunderstood as "shower" and interviewed Taiwanese officials and experts to command it.
Label: Partially false

Claim: The Minister of Defense of Japan posted a tweet to thank Taiwan for donating 500,000 face masks.
Explaination: It is a fake tweet.
Label: False

Claim: Asterix comics in 1981 mentioned coronavirus; French people knew the outbreak in advance.
Explaination: Coronaviruses had been known for a while and are not only referring to COVID-19. 1981 Asterix comic books did not mention coronavirus. The issue from 2017 did refer to coronavirus, but it has nothing to do with the current outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: A Turkish citizen in Yozgat ate yogurt and soap together to get rid of the virus.
Explaination: The news first published in an parody site. There is no such a guy in Yozgat nor the doctors mentioned.
Label: False

Claim: Central government has announced blanket holiday for schools/colleges in 4 states in India.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: The health service in Ireland is asking people to stockpile food.
Explaination: The claim was untrue. The health service is not urging people to stockpile food - in fact, the opposite is true - and the supply chains in Ireland remain robust
Label: False

Claim: Ireland is going into a ‘Status Red’ lockdown with the military patrolling the streets.
Explaination: The claim was untrue. Ireland has not gone into lockdown
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 Breeds Rapidly In Toilet Paper.
Explaination: Post claiming COVID-19 breeds rapidly in toilet paper is fake. The post is taken from an inauthentic website.
Label: False

Claim: Singapore checks the saliva of Indonesian arrivals at Changi Airport.
Explaination: The COVID-19 swab test is only intended for tourists who have symptoms such as fever or other respiratory ailments.
Label: False

Claim: A Twitter post claimed Cristiano Ronaldo is transforming his string of hotels to hospitals to aid in the fight against COVID-19.
Explaination: A spokesperson from the hotel denied the claim. Moreover, there is no such statement present on any of the footballer’s media accounts.
Label: False

Claim: Advice about coronavirus prevention and remedies, allegedly from Stanford Hospital.
Explaination: Almost every advice listed in the original and widely spread Facebook messages was false. Facebook did not label these messages as misinformation (neither in English nor in Dutch).
Label: False

Claim: Staff of Gold Coast Hospital in Australia has gifted a volleyball to Tom Hanks in quarantine.
Explaination: The image has been morphed to claim that Tom Hanks was gifted a volleyball.
Label: False

Claim: An infographic has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts which claim it shows a nine-day timeline of the symptoms of the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: This infographic is misleading; it was not distributed by an official health authority and health experts say COVID-19 symptoms vary in duration and severity.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Evo Morales (ex-mandatary of Bolivia) has COVID-19.
Explaination: Morales continue his normal activities. Moreover, on march twelve he posted in his Twitter account. Also, other followers of the political party Movement to Socialism (MAS) did not refer about the health condition of the ex mandatary.
Label: False

Claim: A post shared more than 165,000 times on Facebook includes a video of a woman turning a baby wipe into a face mask to “protect against coronavirus.”
Explaination: The company that sells the wipes says they should not be used in this way, and health experts also recommend caution.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Eleven coronavirus patients visited malls and hotels in Metro Manila that are part of a “confidential list.”
Explaination: The DOH has dismissed the message as fake. The malls and hotels in question have also not posted any advisories regarding possible infection.
Label: False

Claim: A vaccine for the 2019 novel coronavirus has been found and there will be no more deaths due to the coronavirus.
Explaination: As of Friday morning, March 20, there is no vaccine or cure for the disease caused by the 2019 novel coronavirus and there have been 217,510 cases and 9,020 deaths, across 157 countries.
Label: False

Claim: “It’s actually the safest time to fly.”
Explaination: Older Americans and those with chronic conditions are advised to reconsider all travel plans to avoid COVID-19. The State Department is advising all citizens to reconsider travel abroad.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking “water a lot and gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates” the coronavirus.
Explaination: Neither drinking a lot of water, nor gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar, has been identified as working against the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: In South Florida “all children and adults must remain in their homes” due to coronavirus.
Explaination: We looked at announcements from several major local governments in south Florida and found no complete lockdown announcements. Gov. Ron DeSantis closed bars and nightclubs statewide.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: “President Trump, COVID-19 coronavirus: U.S. cases 1,329; U.S. deaths, 38; panic level: mass hysteria. President Obama, H1N1 virus: U.S. cases, 60.8 million; U.S. deaths, 12,469; panic level: totally chill. Do you all see how the media can manipulate your life.”
Explaination: Numbers that suggest H1N1 was worse than COVID-19 are misleading. It’s too early to calculate how deadly the coronavirus will be, but there are signs it’s much worse.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Says The New York Times exposed the “real reason behind coronavirus hype: Crash the market to harm Trump’s re-election chances.”
Explaination: There's no evidence the coronavirus was manufactured. The New York Times story referenced was an analysis of how current events may influence the election.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: An article about “An Italian doctor working in China gives advice on avoiding infection.”
Explaination: The article is filled with outdated, false and misleading advice on how to cure the virus. None of these have been officially confirmed by WHO or any other relevant institution.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking cold water, hot drinks or alcohol protects against coronavirus.
Explaination: None of these claims hold any medical value.
Label: False

Claim: Picture shows the Mecca totally empty.
Explaination: The picture is from a miniature designed by an artist.
Label: False

Claim: Saddam Hussein explains what coronavirus is about.
Explaination: Sound has been edited. It's a video from 2003 where Saddam Hussein is talking about the US/Iraq war.
Label: False

Claim: Audio from WhatsApp that says there are a doctor and two nurses hospitalized on the ICU in Terrassa (Barcelona)
Explaination: The hospitals in Terrassa deny this situation.
Label: False

Claim: A post says that if you hold your breath you can tell if you are infected with Covid-19 or not.
Explaination: A pulmonologist and member of the National Public Health Commission assured that this exercise doesn’t have any clinical applicability and it’s not safe. You can do the exercise, pass it and be infected with Covid-19.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Elderly people are left to die in an Italian hospital near Milan.
Explaination: Information was based on an audio message circulating via WhatsApp. The message was posted by "Il Giornale", which later retracted the message. Niguarda hospital released a statement claiming that the information was false.
Label: False

Claim: Airports and train stations in Lithuania are being closed down.
Explaination: The article used a statement by the government which claimed that schools are being closed. Authors of the misleading article added information about airports and train stations in a headlines but used the government's statement as main text.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 is cured with hot water and baking soda.
Explaination: Mortality statistics indicate that seasonal flu is at least 60 times less deadly than COVID-19 (based on current data). Hot water and soda have no proven effects to help combat the novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Claim that disease outbreaks and pandemics correspond with election years.
Explaination: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found no correlation between election years and virus outbreaks. The outbreaks of SARS, Bird Flu and COVID-19 do not line up with the dates claimed in the post. In the case of Zika virus, the disease has had multiple outbreaks since 2014 in parts of Oceania and in Brazil. Bird Flu, MERS and Ebola have not been reported in Australia and have not been a significant feature of local political discussion or debate. Considering overseas elections, such as US presidential elections, there is also no consistent pattern of outbreaks occurring in election years.
Label: False

Claim: Photo purportedly showing Tom Hanks holding a volleyball, claiming the hospital staff in Australia gave it to him as a tribute and to cheer him up while in quarantine.
Explaination: The image has been doctored using a 2015 photograph of Hanks and a stock photo of a hospital ward; the doctored photo emerged on a satirical website.
Label: False

Claim: Infographic claiming that the coronavirus pandemic fits a pattern of viral outbreaks that occur every 100 years.
Explaination: The infographic contains inaccurate information about historical viral outbreaks and ignores other epidemics that do not fit the assumed pattern; health experts told AFP that while certain viruses are seasonal in nature, there is no basis for the claim that viral outbreaks occur once every century.
Label: False

Claim: Photos show empty shelves at supermarkets.
Explaination: The photos have circulated online since 2015.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A video purports to show body bags for virus victims in Italy.
Explaination: It has previously circulated in media reports about people who died after contracting COVID-19 in Iran; a man recording the video can be heard stating that he is inside a mortuary in the Iranian city of Qom.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Warm drinks kill the coronavirus, the virus dies when the ambient temperature is higher than 26ºC, gargling warm water helps treating the disease and the virus stays on your hands for 10 minutes.
Explaination: None of this claims have any scientific support.
Label: False

Claim: Mexicans can call the Mexican government to get a COVID-19 test at home.
Explaination: The UIES line was enabled only for suspicious cases and not for the general population.
Label: False

Claim: 3,500 Italians potentially infected with the novel coronavirus arrived in Brazil in a cruise ship
Explaination: The photo that has been shared with the misinformation piece is from the Costa Fascinosa cruise, and the company responsible for the vessel reported that all of its passengers in Brazil are from South America. The ship left Italy on November 17, 2019, has passed through France and Spain and has been on the Brazilian coast since December 2, two months before Italy confirmed its first coronavirus case.
Label: False

Claim: The Brazilian government released additional money for beneficiaries of Bolsa Família, a national conditional cash transfer programme.
Explaination: The Ministry of Citizenship, responsible for the program, denied on its social networks that there will be such a release and stated that it only announced the inclusion of 1.2 million families in Bolsa Família. In addition, messages circulating on WhatsApp with this misinformation (see here) bring links to fake websites.
Label: False

Claim: News channels suggest drinking tulsi and noni juice will help prevent the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: A morphed screenshot of the news channel was used.
Label: False

Claim: Argentine President Alberto Fernández said that coronavirus dies at 26 degrees Celsius.
Explaination:
The WHO maintains that the virus can be transmitted in all climatic areas and that "the virus is too new for us to know how a warmer climate could affect transmissibility".
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), it is not yet known whether climate and temperature affect the spread of COVID-19. There is still no scientific consensus on the impact of room temperature on this particular virus.
Label: No evidence

Claim: Argentine President Alberto Fernández said “the WHO recommends hot drinks because heat kills the virus”
Explaination:
The organization did not issue any recommendation on the consumption of beverages for the prevention of coronavirus.
Experts deny this advice and even say that it could be harmful. This version circulates on social media and WhatsApp in Argentina and in other countries.
Label: False

Claim: In Colombia, “First Child registered as Yair coronavirus Mosquera.”
Explaination: "First Child registered as Yair coronavirus Mosquera". The screenshot of the alleged note from Caracol has been broadcast on social networks.
Label: False

Claim: Hot lemon juice prevents coronavirus.
Explaination: It is false that hot lemon juice prevents coronavirus. The publication allegedly written by "Laila Ahmadi of China, Faculty of Medical Sciences, Zanjan University" is false and that university is not located in China.
Label: False

Claim: Iranians have published a report saying that coronavirus is a biological warfare.
Explaination: There was no such report and claims about coronavirus being biological warfare have been already debunked.
Label: False

Claim: KFC San Marino Shopping (Guayaquil, Ecuador) employee with COVID-19.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Jair Bolsonaro tested positive for COVID-19.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Policemen in China chase COVID-19 in a subway station.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: UNICEF’s advice on preventing COVID-19
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Most countries affected by COVID-19 are along the same 40-degree north latitude.
Explaination: 40-degree North latitude passes through some of the countries most affected by COVID-19 but does not pass through half of the locations given in the post. Also, it does not touch Wuhan (Hubei Province – where around 60% of all the positive cases are reported), which is at around 30-degree North latitude.
Label: False

Claim: Indian President Ramnath Kovind pouring gaumutra (cow urine) on globe to prevent coronavirus.
Explaination: 2017 image falsely shared as President Ramnath Kovind pouring gaumutra on a globe to prevent coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: A worker at the Prince hotel in Mehdipatnam (Hyderbad, India) has tested positive for coronavirus.
Explaination: The message is fake. In Telangana state, till date, only one confirmed case of coronavirus is reported and the person who tested positive for the virus is a software engineer.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking water in which garlic was boiled will cure you from COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no evidence to support this claim.
Label: False

Claim: OMS staff member is spreading coronavirus on purpose.
Explaination: The man is an astrophysicist, and he is touching this lady because she is his girlfriend, and she is sick.
Label: False

Claim: Jair Bolsonaro has the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Health authorities had not confirmed the case and they were the only ones to be able to do so because they are the ones who can test. It was a clickbait.
Label: False

Claim: Garlic heals the new coronavirus.
Explaination: WHO said that there is no evidence that proves that garlic heals coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: The U.S. presidential election is canceled due to coronavirus.
Explaination: The federal government has made no such announcement about canceling the U.S. presidential election.
Label: False

Claim: Australian hospital staff rolled in a Wilson volleyball to keep Tom Hanks company in quarantine.
Explaination: This came from a satire website, and the photo in the story is old and unrelated to Tom Hanks illness.
Label: False

Claim: A former and controversial CIA officer said coronavirus was made in a lab.
Explaination: The quote was pulled out of context and was mere speculation, not fact.
Label: False

Claim: Viral audio from WhatsApp in which a doctor from the hospital Fundación Jiménez Díaz in Madrid claims that there are two young patients in very bad condition because of coronavirus and there are no more respirators in intensive care units.
Explaination: In an internal document, the head of intensive care unit explains that the young patients have not pathologies related to coronavirus. He also says that there are respiratories for all patients.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: Zamora has canceled Holy week due to the coronavirus.
Explaination: It's a false article created on 12minutos, a site that lets you create "satirical" articles.
Label: False

Claim: Catalonia, Valencia and Aragon cancel classes in schools, colleges and universities because of coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The article was not published by El País.
Label: False

Claim: Tuit reports that Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro has tested positive for the coronavirus.
Explaination: Fake Twitter account pretending to be Folha de Sao Paulo.
Label: False

Claim: China has announced the success of Egyptian serum form Dr. Hala, Health Minister of Egypt, against coronavirus
Explaination: Egyptian Health Ministry denied it.
Label: False

Claim: Podemos spokesman Pablo Echenique is not in intensive care after getting infected with COVID-19.
Explaination: The tweet imitated El Mundo's official account.
Label: False

Claim: Education Ministry announces all students are passing the actual course without making exams because of coronavirus.
Explaination: The education ministry issued another document that was manipulated.
Label: False

Claim: The smell of tea tree oil can kill coronavirus in nostrils, according to a study of an Austrian university.
Explaination: It works in a lab, but there is no evidence to prove that smelling oil for 15 mins can kill coronavirus.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Councilor Pen White-Chung said coronavirus is from the USA based on a Chinese academic study.
Explaination: It is another piece of false information based on the unfounded claim that the coronavirus came from the United States. This one is more subtle and shared by China officials.
Label: False

Claim: President Donald Trump admitted the flu cases in the USA are actually infected with the coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is a clip of Trump's speech, but the subtitle and caption are false.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese people prayed with Muslims due to fear of COVID-19.
Explaination: The video is shared in 2019, June, before the outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Turmeric and lemon can cure the coronavirus.
Explaination: Medical practitioners and even WHO has rubbished this claim and has said that there is no evidence to prove that turmeric and lemon can be used to cure coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Drinking water every 15 minutes will protect you from getting coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no medical evidence to support the idea that drinking water every 15 minutes will help protect you from coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: You can check for coronavirus by holding your breath for 10 seconds.
Explaination: There is no evidence to support the claim that holding your breath for several seconds is an effective way to test for coronavirus
Label: False

Claim: A video of Chinese people fighting for Muslim scriptures to not get infected by coronavirus.
Explaination: The video has been circulating since 2014, before the Corona COVID-19 virus was first reported in late December 2019. The video of Christians in China opening their Bibles for the first time
Label: Misleading

Claim: Private health insurance for public workers does not cover expenses related to coronavirus.
Explaination: The statement published by Independent Union of the Tax Agency of Spain in March 12 is real but a more updated version of March 23, and the public institution (MUFACE), affirm that all its insured (public workers) have 100% coverage in expenses related to COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Vitamin C protects against the spread of the coronavirus. Lemon in hot water fights cancer. COVID-19 arises from the fusion of genetic material of a snake and a bat.
Explaination: Any of these protect against the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Says Tom Hanks has a volleyball to keep him company while he’s quarantined.
Explaination: The image of Tom Hanks apparently holding a Wilson volleyball during his COVID-19 quarantine comes from a satirical Australian website.
Label: False

Claim: Of the Trump administration’s European travel restrictions that exempt the U.K.: “Well, you can just get into the Chunnel, and you’ll be in the U.K.”
Explaination: It isn't that easy to get around the restrictions by taking a train linking England and France.
Label: HALF TRUE

Claim: A video has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim it shows a shaman curing a novel coronavirus patient in Malaysia.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video has circulated online in posts about a hospital in Indonesia since at least October 2018, more than one year before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.
Label: False

Claim: A fake quote of Vice President Leni Robredo suggesting to “inhale cough back” to prevent the spread of the 2019 novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The Vice President did not say what was attributed to her in the graphic. News5 said the graphic was edited using their template.
Label: False

Claim: If you donate blood, “they HAVE to test you” for coronavirus.
Explaination: Blood donors don’t get a coronavirus test if they donate blood.
Label: False

Claim: “During the 2009 swine flu outbreak, Biden made reckless comments unsupported by science & the experts. The Obama Admin had to clean up his mess & apologize for his ineptitude.”
Explaination: During the 2009 swine flu outbreak, Biden said he would advise his family against traveling in confined places and said when one person sneezes “it goes all the way through an aircraft.” Scientists say that’s not how germs spread. Biden’s comments were met with backlash and his spokesperson issued a clarification.
Label: MOSTLY TRUE

Claim: Donald Trump claims Joe Biden “was in charge of the H1N1 Swine Flu epidemic which killed thousands of people. The response was one of the worst on record. Our response is one of the best, with fast action of border closings and a 78% approval rating, the highest on record. His was lowest!”
Explaination: Joe Biden was not in charge of the Obama administration’s H1N1 response. Trump overstated public confidence in his administration’s response to the coronavirus and downplayed confidence in the Obama administration’s response to H1N1.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Says Nancy Pelosi was “caught trying to include abortion funding in bill to combat coronavirus.”
Explaination: The U.S. House passed a measure that provides federal funds to people affected by the coronavirus. The bill covers reimbursement laboratory costs for COVID-19 testing. Some raised concerns that language was needed to specifically ensure abortion services weren't eligible to receive funds. The language was amended by Democrats to limit reimbursements to COVID-19 expenses.
Label: False

Claim: In 2007, “The Simpsons” predicted Tom Hanks would contract coronavirus in 2007.
Explaination: In the closing credits of “The Simpson Movie,” Hanks says: "This is Tom Hanks, saying, if you see me in person, leave me be." The movie is about an environmental crisis. There’s no reference to any kind of outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: “The CDC can detain anyone with a fever indefinitely. Vaccination (is) a way people could get out of detention.”
Explaination: In the United States, people can't be quarantined for just having a fever; they have to be shown to have been exposed to one of a specific set of diseases. Most quarantines are done voluntarily, not by force of the government. And vaccination is not a ticket out of quarantine. Most quarantine decisions are up to states and localities, rather than the CDC.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 came to the United States in 2019.
Explaination: The first confirmed COVID-19 case in the United States was reported on Jan. 20, 2020. The patient was a man who had recently returned to Washington state from Wuhan, China.
Label: False

Claim: The new coronavirus dies when a temperature around is 26-27 degrees Celsius.
Explaination: The virus doesn't die when the temperature is around 27-28 degrees Celsius.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Saint Luke’s Hospital of the USA says consuming alcohol can reduce the risk of COVID-19.
Explaination: Saint Luke's Hospital hasn't released any such advisory.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Prime Minister Ana Brnabic claimed that the number of respirators is a state secret in all countries.
Explaination: Information about number of respirators is available in many countries.
Label: False

Claim: A doctor from North Macedonia states that the new coronavirus outbreak  is a conspiracy against humanity or a conspiracy of the pharmaceutical industry for profit, and that the new coronavirus is not dangerous.
Explaination: By transmitting her words, the text goes against the recognized authorities and institutions, such as the World Health Organization, which has already declared a pandemic of the new coronavirus, and which speaks of high infectivity and serious complications in patients of different ages.
Label: False

Claim: Cuba has developed a vaccine against coronavirus.
Explaination: Cuba is working on a vaccine option, but is not ready for distribution; Facebook posts mention Interferon Alfa 2B, a medicine used against hepatitis.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking tea and hot water kills the virus; lemon slices in warm water may save your life; it’s recommended to keep your money in a sealed plastic bag; a conspiracy theory suggests China is benefiting from the pandemic; vinegar is good for cleaning your hands.
Explaination: Coronavirus has already spread to countries with hot weather; water with lemons does not help prevention; WHO recommends washing your hands after touching your money; Asian markets have been operating in low marks because of the pandemic; WHO recommends using alcohol gel and soap to keep your hands free of germs.
Label: False

Claim: A YouTube video claims to show mass animal killings linked to coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The pig footage dated back to 2018 and the poultry footage did not depict contaminated animals.
Label: False

Claim: KFC San Marino Shopping (Guayaquil, Ecuador) employee with COVID-19.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Jair Bolsonaro tested positive for COVID-19.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Policemen in China chase COVID-19 in a subway station.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: UNICEF’s advice on preventing COVID-19
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Spain ex-King Juan Carlos I has the coronavirus.
Explaination: It was tweeted from a fake account pretending to be Spanish newspaper El País.
Label: False

Claim: The new coronavirus dies at a temperature of about 26-27 degrees Celsius.
Explaination: The virus doesn't die when the temperature is around 27-28 degrees Celsius.
Label: False

Claim: Photo of vegan food products left on otherwise bare supermarket shelf is related to COVID-19 outbreak and panic buying.
Explaination: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be incorrectly linking the supermarket shelf image to the 2019/20 COVID-19 coronavirus outbreak. The image of a supermarket shelf full of vegan foods while the shelves either side remain empty has nothing to do with the COVID-19 coronavirus outbreak. It was originally taken in 2017 in the United States when Hurricane Harvey hit the southern state of Texas.
Label: False

Claim: Chart compares COVID-19 with other longstanding diseases.
Explaination: The graphic is misleading and risks underplaying the danger of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, which is a new disease with a fast-rising mortality rate.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Imported second hand clothes from Europe, Asia or America could spread the novel coronavirus in Africa.
Explaination: Experts told AFP the novel coronavirus does not survive long enough outside the human body, and could not survive so long journeys.
Label: False

Claim: Hold your breath 10 seconds to check if you are infected with the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Only a test made by labs can detect the novel coronavirus, according to WHO and some experts interviewed by AFP.
Label: False

Claim: Vitamin C and lemon water prevent coronavirus.
Explaination:
There is no recommendation from the World Health Organization or scientific evidence to support this.
There is also no vaccine or medicine to prevent the disease yet.
Label: False

Claim: Actor Daniel Radcliffe tested positive for covid-19.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Israel’s MIGAL Research Institute is also in the process of producing a vaccine for COVID-19. According to WHO, as on 11 March 2020, there is no vaccine for COVID-19.

Claim: AIIMS (Indian medical institute) team has said that Toddy has medicinal properties to cure coronavirus.

Claim: Holding your breath for 10 seconds can determine if you have COVID-19; drink water every 15 minutes.

Explaination: Restrictions on the entry of migrants from China have been done earlier by the government, namely on February 5, 2020. In addition to stopping flights to and from China, the government has also temporarily suspended the issuance of Visa and Arrival Visas for Chinese citizens.

He had been on a hunger strike demanding tougher a law against corruption and seeking the return of black money stashed abroad.

Claim: The virus dies with high temperatures, teas fight COVID-19, holding your breath for 10 seconds proves you are not infected, drinking a lot of water stops the coronavirus, any mask can avoid contagion, coronavirus does die when “exposed to the sun.”

Claim: The health insurance industry has “agreed to waive all co-payments for coronavirus treatments.”
Explaination: Health insurance companies said they will waive costs for coronavirus tests, not treatment. A shortage in diagnostic supplies means that testing is limited.

Claim: Video shows a WHO official inappropriately touching a female attendee during a briefing session in China about the novel coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan. Same video was also used with another claim that the man is an Australian politician.

Video was taken out of context. The man in the video is a 2006 Nobel Prize laureate in physics, Professor George Smoot, not someone from WHO or a politician.
The clip shows Smoot attending a business conference in Julu County in Hebei Province in China in June 2018 with his significant other who was having a sore back at the time.

Claim: Drinking hot tea can prevent coronavirus infection.

Claim: Recommendations of Dr. “González Ayala” are circulating on WhatsApp.

Dr. Silvia González Ayala denied that she was the author of the recommendations and said that she will file a criminal complaint.

Claim: An audio is circulating on social media claiming it’s from the Colombian scientist Rodolfo Llinás offering some recommendations to know “if we have the infection” of the COVID-19 coronavirus.

Claim: Tips against coronavirus like holding your breath and drinking water.

Claim: Spanish actress Cristina Pedroche has promised to show a breast if the number of coronavirus infections reaches 1,000 in Spain.

Claim: The bill for a coronavirus test in the US is 3.000$.

Claim: This Lysol disinfectant against coronavirus shows the virus is not new.

Claim: A doctor named Lupita Yamamoto Lupercio found the coronavirus vaccine.

Claim: Israeli scientists at the MIGAL Research Institute have developed a vaccine for COVID-19.

Claim: Secretary of Health in Mexico recommends taking Vitamin C to prevent coronavirus.

Claim: A prostitute contracted COVID-19 and her 86 clients have been quarantined in the brothel in Spain.

Claim: Pier Luigi Bersani: None of the confirmed cases are related to China. Coronavirus might have occured in Italy before China.

Claim: Prince of the United Arab Emirates was infected with the coronavirus in early March 2020

Claim: A COVID-19 case has been diagnosed in Umraniye Hospital, Istanbul.

Claim: Post says “President Trump has come into contact with a potential coronavirus sufferer!”

Claim: Post says “being exposed to the sun for two hours” kills the 2019 coronavirus.

Claim: “(Former U.S. President Barack Obama) set up anti-pandemic programs in 47 vulnerable countries as a way to protect against something like the coronavirus. Do you know that Trump closed 37 of them?”
Explaination: News reports in early 2018 said the CDC was preparing to scale back its anti-pandemic programs in some countries because an early source of funding was running out and the agency didn't expect to receive new money from the Trump administration.The spending bills that lawmakers ultimately passed provided more money for those CDC programs than Trump’s budget requests asked for.

Claim: The Department of Health (DOH) reports fake cigarettes that spread coronavirus have reached the Philippines.

Claim: “An entire family” in Santolan, Pasig, is “confirmed to be infected” with the novel coronavirus, according to what looked like a breaking news graphic from GMA News.
