Label: False

Claim: Chinese eating exotic animals is the cause of the 2019 novel coronavirus, as shown in photos shared on Facebook.
Explaination: Some of the photos in the viral Facebook post were not taken in China. Moreover, as of Friday, March 13, there are still not enough studies available that confirm the source of the 2019 novel coronavirus.
Label: Partially false

Claim: A second version of the coronavirus is spreading and it is far more dangerous.
Explaination: Mutations of the virus exists, but it is uncorrect to claim that a "second version" would be far more dangerous.
Label: Partially false

Claim: This laboratory is giving money to people who would agree to be infected with the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: This experiment is related with another coronavirus so it has no link with COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Says 80% of novel coronavirus cases are “mild.”
Explaination: The website Information is Beautiful published a chart showing that 80.9% of novel coronavirus cases are "mild." But reports from the World Health Organization and the U.S. CDC found that mild cases account for 75-to-80% of all cases.
Label: MOSTLY TRUE

Claim: “Coronavirus — 22. Clintons — 39.”
Explaination: Conspiracies linking the Clintons to various deaths are longstanding and unsubstantiated. We've debunked a number of them. The novel coronavirus has killed thousands globally.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: The Mayor of Skopje, Shilegov, returned from Madrid three days ago, and the government passed a decree requiring all passengers from Spain to be tested for coronavirus and placed in a 14-day quarantine.
Explaination: Apart from the problematic photo, for which it is not possible to conclude when and where it was taken or who is on it,  the article also gives untrue information. Namely, the Government has not adopted a decree ordering all passengers who were in Spain to be tested for coronavirus and to be placed in a 14-day quarantine.
Label: False

Claim: Availability of a kit for coronavirus self-diagnosis in Italy.
Explaination: On March 9th there was no legal kit for doing coronavirus self-diagnosis. Only government authorities are authorized to do it.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A kit for coronavirus self-diagnosis is available.
Explaination: A Facebook advertisement selling surgical masks links to a webpage where they sell also a kit for coronavirus self-diagnosis. On March 9th there was no legal kit for doing coronavirus self-diagnosis. Only government authorities are authorized to do it.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Zinc lozenges are proven to protect against COVID-19.
Explaination: No scientific proof of this observation and hypothesis on its relation.
Label: False

Claim: This photo shows the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The photo is a magnified photo of a weevil.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking warm water with lemon protects against the novel coronavirus.
Country: Australia, India, South Africa, Ivory Coast
Explaination: Health experts say there is no proof that this is effective in preventing the disease.
Label: False

Claim: The Colombian government is closing the border with Venezuela, even though they said they’re not going to do it.
Explaination: At the time of the fact-check the government had not closed the border. But it did so a few days later.
Label: Partially false

Claim: A person fainted in Cali’s bus terminal because of COVID-19.
Explaination: It's a photoshopped image.
Label: False

Claim: The mayor of Buga, Valle del Cauca, said: “I invite the people of Buga to keep calm and to live each day as if it was the last.”
Explaination: He never said this.
Label: False

Claim: Hot air from hair dryers can kill the coronavirus.
Explaination: Blowing hot air from hair dryer is not a cure nor a preventive measure against coronavirus. There is no cure for coronavirus as of now.
Label: False

Claim: States are imposing mandatory leave and statewise school closures due to coronavirus.
Explaination: Though schools have closed since this announcement, at the time of its original posting, it was not true.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A post has been shared on Facebook, Twitter and Whatsapp claims a regional government in India has recommended that the juice of bitter gourd, a vegetable often used in traditional medicine, is an effective treatment for the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; Indian authorities dismissed the claim, calling it “absolutely false”; health experts said there is no evidence the vegetable is an effective remedy for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Hot air application through a hairdryer on the face to heat up nostrils and the sinus kills the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Fact Crescendo found the above-mentioned post to be False. Hot air application through a hairdryer on the face to heat up nostrils will not kill the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Consuming colloidal silver can prevent or treat novel coronavirus.
Explaination: US regulators say consuming silver is not safe for use against any disease.
Label: False

Claim: An image has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it shows China administering the “world’s first new coronavirus vaccine” after the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; the photos in this image have circulated in reports about China testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine.
Label: misleading

Claim: Smoking prevents you from getting infected with the coronavirus.
Explaination: The WHO says smoking does not protect a person from COVID-19 infection and warns it can actually cause health conditions that increase the risk of severe coronavirus illness.
Label: False

Claim: Photos purport to show the collapse of a temporary hospital in Wuhan.
Explaination: The photos show the collapse of a hotel in Quanzhou, south of Shanghai, where people infected with the novel coronavirus were in quarantine.
Label: False

Claim: Telangana Ministry in India distributed homeopathic tablets claiming to prevent COVID-19.
Explaination: BOOM could not find any scientific evidence supporting theory that arsenicum album prevents coronavirus- Follow up to AYUSH story.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Parviz Nouri Sayha claims he has made the medicine for coronavirus.
Explaination: Our investigations show that almost everything this person, who calls himself “professor” claims is fake and unfounded. Even his resume and bibliography is filled with fabricated items
Label: False

Claim: People can’t use the right of withdrawal at work because of the outbreak.
Explaination: French labor law experts think that the risk of being infected with the virus at work can be a reason to refuse going back to work in some cases, but not all.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Did the coronavirus mutate and became more aggressive?
Explaination: Chinese scientists discovered that this coronavirus has taken two different types. They suggest that the second type could be more aggressive. But this is only a theory, never tested in lab and French scientists consider that there no really important mutation of the virus yet.
Label: Misleading

Claim: As of 3/7/20, Tanzania and Zambia had confirmed fist cases of the new coronavirus.
Explaination: At the time, the MP said there were no reported cases in Tanzania. WHO also didn't confirm cases at the time in either country.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus patients are being caught on highways in China.
Explaination: The video is not about the coronavirus patients being caught, but of the training and mock drill given to the Swat team in China.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Quarantine video is allegedly from different cities in Turkey.
Explaination: The video is from Sakarya, not Istanbul and the patient was isolated on inspection, not diagnosis. No case in Turkey so far.
Label: False

Claim: A video purports to show panic-stricken travelers infected with the novel coronavirus at an airport in Senegal.
Explaination: These images are actually taken from a security exercise simulating a hostage-taking at Dakar airport in November 2019.
Label: False

Claim: A Facebook post shared 25,000 times features an image of a letter purportedly from a U.S. hospital recommending people drink alcohol to help reduce the risks of novel coronavirus infection.
Explaination: Saint Luke’s Hospital in Kansas City did not issue the letter, according to its staff.
Label: False

Claim: “More people have died from knowing Hillary (Clinton)” than from coronavirus.
Explaination: It’s obviously nonsense to compare Clinton in any way with a global virus outbreak that has killed thousands.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts which claims to show the Koran being distributed to people in China after it lifted a “ban” on the Islamic holy text following the outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video has circulated online since at least 2013 in reports about people receiving copies of the Bible in China.
Label: False

Claim: Graphics or social media cards supposedly from UNICEF contain tips and information on how to prevent and combat the coronavirus outbreak and COVID-19.
Explaination: The graphics and the tips are not from Unicef.
Label: False

Claim: Research by the Saint Luke’s Hospital of Kansas City found that consuming alcoholic beverages may reduce the risk of infection by coronavirus. Vodka was the most recommended drink.
Explaination: The hospital dismissed the claim as false. Further, the World Health Organization (WHO) does not recommend alcohol consumption to prevent the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: U.S. hospitals are preparing for 96 million coronavirus infections and nearly half a million deaths, leaked documents reveal.
Explaination: An infectious disease expert presenting to the American Hospital Association estimated there could be as many as 96 million cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. in a year. But there is no indication that hospitals are preparing, covertly, for an outbreak of that magnitude, as this headline suggests.
Label: False

Claim: Vietnam was the first country to contain and develop a quick test for SARS and COVID-19.
Explaination: The claims that Vietnam was the first country to contain SARS and developed a quick test kit are mostly legit. We're not sure where the claim that WHO says it takes four years to develop a test kit comes from. But that appears to not be accurate.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A video says COVID-19 is caused by 5G.
Explaination: The link between 5G and COVID-19 is never explained in the video and it does not hold any scientific value.
Label: False

Claim: An image has been shared alongside a claim that shows China administering the “world’s first new coronavirus vaccine” after the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explaination: The photos in this image have circulated in reports about China testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine.
Label: Misleading

Claim: An image has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it shows China administering the “world’s first new coronavirus vaccine” after the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; the photos in this image have circulated in reports about China testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Claim that photos show dogs being killed in China as part of efforts to combat COVID-19.
Explaination: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the post to be partly false. While there are media reports concerning pets being killed in China because of fears over the spread of COVID-19, they remain unverified and have been denied by authorities. The photos accompanying the Facebook post are unrelated to COVID-19. It is true that World Health Organization’s advice is there is no evidence that companion animals/pets can be infected with COVID-19 despite a single case in Hong Kong of a dog testing “weak positive”.
Label: Partially false

Claim: People who died after being infected by the novel coronavirus can’t receive any mortuary care.
Explaination: The HCSP (Haut conseil de la santé publique) told AFP not every mortuary care is forbidden for dead people who got infected by the novel coronavirus : embalming is forbidden but mortuary basic care can still be processed (with additional precautions).
Label: Misleading

Claim: Alcohol-based hand sanitizer can influence results in a breathalyzer test.
Explaination: Spreading alcohol-based hand sanitizer does not affect the breathalyzer test.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Muslims to understand why they are not contracting COVID-19.
Explaination: BOOM found that the viral video is a combination of three clips of Xi Jinping visiting the northwest region of China in 2016.
Label: False

Claim: Two local celebrities in Argentine are infected with coronavirus
Explaination: Fake twitter accounts claimed they had contracted the virus. The celebrities denied the disinformation.
Label: False

Claim: A case of coronavirus was confirmed in Cali in Colombia, and a video shows doctors treating patients in a bus station.
Explaination: Video shows a drill organized by Cali's transportation authority, to prepare in case coronavirus arrives in the city.
Label: False

Claim: A case of coronavirus was confirmed in Sincelejo in Colombia.
Explaination: There is a possible case in Sincelejo which hasn't been confirmed.
Label: False

Claim: Work suspension in Ecuador due to coronavirus since Monday 09/03/2020.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: The test for coronavirus costs US$3,000 in the United States.
Explaination: The only tests approved by FDA and CDC in US were provided freely. What may cost for people looking for testing are secondary costs such as hospitalization or medical consultation.
Label: False

Claim: Aaj Tak channel aired a program that said drinking alcohol or smoking weed can cure COVID-19.
Explaination: Aaj Tak channel did not telecast any program that said drinking alcohol or weed can cure COVID-19. The posted photos are taken from their fact-check episode. In the episode, they debunk the claim and conclude that neither a peg of alcohol nor weed can cure COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: The mayor Of Buffalo told people to evacuate due to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The mayor denied this claim when he responded to a Facebook post spreading the misinformation.
Label: False

Claim: CDC sponsored Facebook post asking for help with “escaped” coronavirus patient.
Explaination: The post was created by a fake CDC account.
Label: False

Claim: Medical Center in El Cachorro (Sevilla) closed due to a possible coronavirus infected person.
Explaination: Medical center in El Cachorro (Sevilla) wasn't closed due to possible coronavirus infected person. Emergencies official channel of Sevilla denies it.
Label: False

Claim: Medical report of Hospital General Universitario Santa Lucía de Cartagena (Murcia) from a person with possible coronavirus.
Explaination: The medical report is not actual, ist from the past, and another kind of coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: It is a designed virus ordered to laboratories by Christine Lagarde when she was in the IMF. She said that “old people live too long and this is a risk for the global economy. We must do something, urgently.”
Explaination: There is no proof that the quote attributed to Lagarde was said by her. It probably comes from a part of an IMF inform.
Label: False

Claim: Increasing border controls will stop coronavirus from spreading.
Explaination: Neither WHO or CDC estimate that closing frontieres will stop the coronavirus
Label: Explanatory

Claim: Emirates has suspended flights to Johannesburg after South Africa announced its first case of novel coronavirus.
Explaination: A statement claiming that Emirates has suspended flights to Johannesburg due to coronavirus is fake.
Label: False

Claim: The consumption of pig causes COVID-19 entry into Indonesia.
Explaination: COVID-19 spreads in Indonesia because there are Indonesian citizens who have contact with foreign citizens who have previously been exposed to the Corona 2019 virus. So far, research results show that pigs only carry one virus that can be transmitted to humans, namely the H1N1 virus that causes swine flu.
Label: False

Claim: Turks are not going to be infected by COVID-19 due to their genes.
Explaination: The distribution of the ACE2 protein, possible COVID-19 receptor among nations is not clear. Referred anthropologist was a Nazi and classified people by measuring the body parts; not by genetic analysis.
Label: False

Claim: A COVID-19 case has been diagnosed in Yedikule Hospital, Istanbul.
Explaination: The lab report is old-dated and shows other mild coronaviruses were found in the case
Label: False

Claim: Girl infected with coronavirus found dead in her apartment in Delhi.
Explaination: Contrary to the claim, the incident in the post does not pertain to a coronavirus case in Delhi but is related to the death of a 22-year-old woman in Tamil Nadu’s Chettipedu.
Label: False

Claim: A television news report about a US biotech company runs alongside a claim that the company successfully created a vaccine for the COVID-19 within “three hours.”
Explaination: The US biotech company said the vaccine still requires human testing and will not be made available until at least the end of 2020.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Bloggers say Nancy Pelosi delayed coronavirus funding so “Dems could campaign on it.”
Explaination: President Donald Trump signed an $8.3 billion emergency spending bill to address the coronavirus on March 6. There is no evidence House Speaker Nancy Pelosi delayed the bill solely to run political ads.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: If the coronavirus gets in your mouth, “drinking water or other liquids will wash them down through your esophagus and into the stomach. Once there, your stomach acid will kill all of the virus.”
Explaination: There is no evidence that drinking water helps to prevent coronavirus infection. Health officials and media outlets have debunked the claim.
Label: False

Claim: “Anybody that wants a test (for the coronavirus) can get a test.”
Explaination: The CDC says health care providers are the ones who decide whether someone gets tested for coronavirus.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Pope Francis contacted coronavirus.
Explaination: The Vatican confirms Pope Francis has not contracted coronavirus.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Coronavirus test costs US$3,000 in the U.S.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: WhatsApp message suggests holding your breath for 10 seconds and drinking water every 15 minutes will fight the coronavirus..
Explaination: No scientific proof.
Label: False

Claim: Monkeys are stealing food from a hospital in South Africa.
Explaination: The video was taken before the COVID-19 crisis in a different part of the country.
Label: False

Claim: A Shaheen Bagh protest in India was claimed to have coronavirus.
Explaination: BOOM contacted hospitals in Delhi and confirmed that no Shaheen Bagh protest had tested positive for COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese government is killing people who refuse to be evacuated.
Explaination: Video is an edit from four videos taken out of context.
Label: False

Claim: A herbal tea can cure symptoms of coronavirus, even if it is a bioterrorism weapon.
Explaination: A so-called "doctor" in nanotechnology and antivaccine Venezuelan activist said coronavirus can be cured by electromagnetism and/or this herbal tea. He also claimed he cured presidente Chávez from cancer but then died because he didn't follow his treatment. This is false.
Label: False

Claim: A brothel in Spain was under quarantine.
Explaination: The news piece was initially posted as a joke from satirical website Cerebrother.
Label: False

Claim: Runny nose and coughing sputum are not symptoms of COVID-19.
Explaination: In the advisories issued by WHO, it can be seen that ‘runny nose’ and ‘sputum production’ are also symptoms of COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Precautionary measures suggested by UNICEF.
Explaination: The viral message was not issued by the UNICEF. Some of the measures suggested in the message contradict the WHO’S view on COVID-19. Also, some have no scientific evidence.
Label: False

Claim: Medical book states that coronavirus is just a common cold.
Explaination: COVID-19 is more dangerous than the common cold.
Label: False

Claim: Does France underestimate the outbreak?
Explaination: On social networks, many users claim that the number of coronavirus cases in France is underestimated, because there are fewer tests in France than elsewhere. But this international comparison is not really relevant.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A confidential governmental document proves that the government has decided to postpone local elections in France because of the outbreak.
Explaination: This document is a fake. The government didn't take this decision.
Label: False

Claim: Donating plasma or blood is free testing for the coronavirus.
Explaination: Currently the test for coronavirus is free.
Label: False

Claim: Novel coronavirus has a 99.7% survival rate.
Explaination: The CDC did not confirm this, and the user did not offer any citations for clarification of this fact.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus test costs $3,200.
Explaination: Patients will not incur costs when tested by the CDC.
Label: False

Claim: A patent that is being shared to claim COVID-19 is old.
Explaination: The patent is related to SARS, not COVID-19
Label: False

Claim: No work in several regions of Spain due to coronavirus.
Explaination: It's a joke. When you click on the link it takes you to a picture of a monkey.
Label: False

Claim: 86 clients of a brothel in quarantine after a prostituted tested positive in coronavirus.
Explaination: It was a satire from a web of humour shared as real news.
Label: False

Claim: Two Chinese nationals in Kenya have been killed after allegedly escaping from quarantine at the Nairobi Airport.
Explaination: Reports that two Chinese nationals in Kenya have been killed over COVID-19 panic are false.
Label: False

Claim: Every election year has a disease; coronavirus has a contagion factor of 2 and a cure rate of 99.7% for those under 50 it infects.
Explaination: Every year in the U.S. is an election year, if taking into account midterm elections as well as presidential elections, and contrary to the claim, not every election year has had a disease outbreak, as implied in the claim. In addition, the transmissibility of the coronavirus, represented by the “basic reproduction number”, is still under study. Currently, the basic reproduction numbers reported for the virus causing COVID-19 range between around 2 to more than 6.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus outbreak is caused by 5G technology.
Explaination: There is no causal link between COVID-19 and 5G technology. The cause of the disease has been definitively identified in scientific studies as a novel coronavirus. 5G technology uses low-energy radio waves, which do not damage DNA or cells unlike ionizing radiation.
Label: False

Claim: Shanghai government officially recommends Vitamin C for COVID-19.
Explaination: Intravenous high-dose vitamin C has been used to treat patients with COVID-19 in certain Chinese hospitals, but it has not been recommended by the Shanghai government as claimed. The OMNS article also cherry-picks the treatment’s potential benefits from two reports, leaving out the potential side effects, including nausea and kidney stones, and failing to mention contraindications for pregnant women and individuals with cancer and other medical conditions.
Label: Misleading

Claim: There is an anti-Chinese protest in Italy due to COVID-19.
Explaination: The demonstration was to an anti-Fascist event to commemorate the victim of racism, Valerio Verbano. It was filmed on Feb. 22 in Rome.
Label: False

Claim: UNICEF recommendations: Coronavirus is large in size where the cell diameter is 400-500 micro and for this reason any mask prevents its entrance. There is no need for pharmacists to sell muzzles. The virus does not settle in the air but is grounded; it is not transmitted by air.
Explaination: The message is misleading and has the potential to cause fear amid the outbreak of coronavirus in India.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The WHO has issued an alert against buying holy colors from China
Explaination: WHO hasn't issued advisory against buying of Holi colors from coronavirus-hit China. The viral post is fake.
Label: False

Claim: President Donald Trump tweeted, “Coronavirus vaccine from Israel! Stock market up! Economy even stronger now! Besides US, Israel best at inventions: Judaism, olives. Wonderful vaccine, will stop Corona DEAD around world. Can’t make vaccines when being bombed, not have been possible without peace I created in Israel!”
Explaination: Donald Trump didn't tweet this.
Label: False

Claim: 80 clients of a brothel were put on quarantine due to coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: A post says that there is a movie that predicted the pandemic and it’s called “Coronavirus”.
Explaination: The image is false, is manipulated and it uses the cover of the movie “The flu” with the wrong title. There’s no movie called “Coronavirus”.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Article says that the Vatican confirmed that the Pope and two assistants have coronavirus.
Explaination: There’s no official statement from the Vatican saying that Pope Francis is infected with Covid-19. Pope has felt ill, but not with the coronavirus.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Photos show a well-stocked vegan shelf while other items are cleared out.
Explaination: Photo has circulated online since September 2017 in reports showing panic buying after hurricane Harvey in US.
Label: Misleading

Claim: UNICEF releases coronavirus prevention guidelines.
Explaination: Unicef has not released the advisory and many of the claims are contrary to health experts' advice.
Label: False

Claim: This video shows panic buying in the United States, during the coronavirus outbreak
Explaination: But the video has been shared in a misleading context; it has circulated online since November 2019, weeks before the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.
Label: False

Claim: This is a photo of the first Moroccan infected with the virus.
Explaination: The photo comes from an advertisement for an opthamologist clinic in Algeria
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 was created in 2014 by an English institute.
Explaination:
A viral video denounces that the Pirbright Institute, of the United Kingdom, created that year the virus that causes COVID-19.
The institute denied the rumors, noting that the virus strain they work with to make a vaccine is different from the new coronavirus: it does not affect humans.
Label: False

Claim: The first dog was infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: A dog in Hong Kong was tested weakly positive for coronavirus but didn't show any symptoms so far.
Label: Correct

Claim: Israel creates a vaccine for the coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Dr. Lupita Yamamoto has found a vaccine that destroys the coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: First policeman infected with coronavirus in Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: 10 coronavirus cases confirmed in Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: The Simpsons predicted the coronavirus pandemic years ago.
Explaination: Other than the "Osaka Flu" infecting many residents of Springfield, the events of the episode Marge in Chains (1993) have no similarities with the COVID-19 pandemic and what is currently happening around the world.
Label: False

Claim: The common cold is the only type of coronavirus.
Explaination: Coronaviruses can cause different illnesses in animals and humans, including the common cold. However, they can also lead to severe diseases such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).
Label: Misleading

Claim: Officials say coronavirus killed 200 in Iran.
Explaination: The number of deaths in official reports on March 3, 2020, were much lower than stated in this article.
Label: False

Claim: New coronavirus was registered in 2018.
Explaination: It was another type of coronavirus that doesn't affect to humans. This one was registered in 2018.
Label: False

Claim: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi: China has no faith, no election and no freedom. China has only GDP but is losing it. Besides, nothing left in this country but violence and lies.
Explaination: According to Narendra Modi's official social media account and Indian media, Modi didn't make such a statement.
Label: False

Claim: Lonely Ka’bah from Tawaf after Saudi Arabia makes policy on coronavirus.
Explaination: Activities around the Ka'bah located in the Grand Mosque, Mecca, proceed as usual at time of publication.
Label: False

Claim: Masks from Wet Wipes effectively prevent coronavirus transmission
Explaination: Wet tissue material makes dust, dirt and bacteria more easily stick.
Label: False

Claim: Videograph shows COVID-19 is more dangerous than former outbreaks.
Explaination: The video is cut at the beginning and the end. The whole video shows COVID-19 is not as dangerous as the former outbreaks, also other causes of death.
Label: False

Claim: Cow dung and cow urine can cure coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: Misleading

Claim: Consuming large doses of Vitamin C can stop the spread of coronavirus.
Explaination: Consuming large doses of Vitamin C cannot stop the spread of coronavirus. there is no evidence that the spread of coronavirus can be stopped by consuming large doses of Vitamin C.
Label: False

Claim: “Man visited Albany, N.Y., days before dying from coronavirus.”
Explaination: The image appears manipulated so that it looks like it is from ABC News. There is no evidence one of those individuals who died from COVID-19 had recently been to Albany, N.Y.
Label: False

Claim: “The State of Florida has announced measures that all workplaces with 10 employees or more are to have paid mandatory leave to avoid the spread of COVID-19 coronavirus starting on March 6, 2020. All schools are to close for 2 weeks also from March 6.”
Explaination: As of March 5, Florida is not shutting down schools and businesses for two weeks.
Label: False

Claim: The media “pulled down an entire shelf of goods so that they can present the news of people buying stuff in a hysteria over the coronavirus.”
Explaination: A popular image claims to show a news reporter staging a shot of empty grocery store shelves. But the photo is a hoax from Romania.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: “The Obama administration made a decision on testing that turned out to be very detrimental to what we’re doing” on the coronavirus.
Explaination: The “decision” Trump is talking about had its roots in a 2004 law, when George W. Bush was president. The FDA’s policy pre-dated the Obama administration.
Label: False

Claim: The Obama administration “didn’t do anything about” swine flu.
Explaination: The Obama administration responded with two emergency declarations, triggering billions in spending and other public health responses.
Label: False

Claim: “With regard to the cost, let me be very clear: HHS has designated the coronavirus test as an essential health benefit. That means, by definition, it’s covered in the private health insurance of every American, as well as covered by Medicare and Medicaid.”
Explaination: Pence’s claim over simplifies what is involved in making this coverage assurance because a large swath of private health insurance falls beyond these categories. His statement fails to acknowledge the need for action at the state level and from the private sector.
Label: HALF TRUE

Claim: Trump’s effort to blame Obama for sluggish coronavirus testing.
Explaination: Trump is looking for scapegoats to excuse his administration’s sluggish efforts to expand testing. But he cannot blame Obama. There was no “Obama rule,” just draft guidance that never took effect and was withdrawn before Trump took office.
Label: Four Pinocchios

Claim: The media group Globo published a photo of the dead of the Lampedusa shipwreck as if they were COVID-19 victims.
Explaination: The image shared along with the pieces of disinformation shows coffins of immigrants killed in the tragedy that occurred on the island of Lampedusa in 2013, but Aos Fatos found no evidence that the Globo group used the record outside its original context. G1, a site that belongs to Globo, even denied a piece of misinformation that circulated in March and attributed the same image of coffins to the pandemic.
Label: False

Claim: The first coronavirus case in North Macedonia was a well-known fashion designer.
Explaination: Due to the mass dissemination of the misinformation, Pandeva (the designer) addressed the public through a video message posted on her Facebook profile and denied that she was ill.
Label: False

Claim: Colombia closes its borders to Ecuadorians.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Israel creates a vaccine for the coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Dr. Lupita Yamamoto has found a vaccine that destroys the coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: First coronavirus case in Ambato, Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: 10 coronavirus cases are confirmed in Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: First policeman infected with coronavirus in Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: People queue outside an Aldi supermarket in Germany to buy food in fear of the new coronavirus.
Explaination: A 2011 video showing an opening of an Aldi.
Label: False

Claim: Ads are selling masks protecting against COVID-19.
Explaination: US authorities don't recommend people to wear masks and the doctor does not speak about CoV.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Multiple allegations on how to protect oneself from CoV.
Explaination: Many of the practices detailed in the post are misleading and inaccurate.
Label: Partially false

Claim: A man is hospitalized after eating a bat.
Explaination: This photo has circulated in an online fundraising page for a man with a lung condition unrelated to the novel coronavirus
Label: Misleading

Claim: Russia said COVID-19 is man-made.
Explaination: the Russian Ministry of Health said it did not make such a statement; the document cited in the misleading posts states COVID-19 is a “recombinant virus” which can form naturally.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The coronavirus has been discovered in poultry.
Explaination: Sri Lankan authorities said the coronavirus has not been discovered in poultry; the photos were taken from various unrelated reports online and show chickens sickened with other diseases.
Label: False

Claim: A Nigerian taxi driver threatens to spread COVID-19.
Explaination: The story originated from a parody account and has been denied by the man pictured in the claim and government officials.
Label: False

Claim: The photos show Indians bathing in cow dung to prevent infection.
Explaination: The photos show participants at an annual cow dung festival held in the southern region of India in October 2019, several weeks before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows Wuhan residents lining up for death certificates.
Explaination: The video has previously circulated in reports about Wuhan residents gathering to collect free vegetables.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese official detainted a CoV case.
Explaination: It was an exercise.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Claims that drinking boiled garlic water cures novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Medical experts told AFP there was no evidence to support the theory about drinking garlic water; international health organisations do not recommend the remedy and have said there is no specific antiviral treatment for the new strain of the novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: The Simpsons predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The frames were taken from different episodes - about the Osaka flu and the housecat flu. One of them was digitally manipulated to include the word "coronavirus".
Label: False

Claim: Vinegar is more effective than alcohol-based hand sanitizers for killing the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Vinegar is not effective as a hand sanitizer. Its effects on breaking up the fat protection around viruses are very limited. Meanwhile, alcohol and soap are very effective on breaking up this protection
Label: False

Claim: Drinking hot water prevents the COVID-19
Explaination: This information is false, health authorities do not recognize hot water as a preventive measure and experts point out that it could be counterproductive.
Label: False

Claim: A health expert surmises that the new coronavirus might not spread in Nigeria because of the hot temperature.
Explaination: Warmer air holds more moisture; thus preventing airborne viruses from travelling as far as they would in dry air. Still, the jury’s out on whether or not SARS-Cov2 will be resistant or vulnerable to hot temperature.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Ecuadorean doctor develops a vaccine for COVID-19.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Two cases of coronavirus have been reported in Loja, in Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Azuay Governor in Ecuador seeks the cure of covid-19 in indigenous medicine.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: A new case of coronavirus has been confirmed in Tulcán, Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: This video was supposedly developed by the Ecuadorian Health Ministry to encourage people to wash their hands constantly.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: An image shows Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer criticizing President Trump’s restrictions on foreign nationals traveling to the U.S. from China.
Explaination: It was a fake tweet.
Label: False

Claim: The government — or specific states such as Michigan or Florida — has mandated that employers and schools close for two weeks.
Explaination: No such announcement has been made. It was apparently a prank.
Label: False

Claim: Pope Francis and his two aides have been infected with the new coronavirus
Explaination: Pope tested negative.
Label: False

Claim: The CDC recommends men shave their beards to be protected against the new coronavirus.
Explaination: A 2017 CDC infographic shows how facial hair could interfere with respirator masks. The graphic is unrelated to coronavirus protection and the CDC has not recommended people should shave their beards to ward off the virus.
Label: False

Claim: A bovine vaccine can be used to inoculate people against coronavirus.
Explaination: There is still currently no approved and public vaccine.
Label: False

Claim: Patents mean deadly diseases and viruses were created or invented in a lab.
Explaination: Instead, the patents are for possible treatments or vaccines, some of which were tested but did not work.
Label: False

Claim: You can’t get infected by kissing the hands of a virgin or saint statue.
Explaination: Kissing the hands of a virgin or saint statue is a tradition of the Holy Week in some parts of Spain, but it is not free for viruses and therefore can be a way of infection.
Label: False

Claim: An audio clip claims Kenya has recorded 63 cases of COVID-19.
Explaination: An audio clip claiming that Kenya has recorded 63 cases of novel coronavirus has been edited and taken out of context. The clip was part of a training exercise by the Ministry of Health to prepare for a likely outbreak ahead of the opening of a quarantine center in Nairobi.
Label: False

Claim: Pope Francis and two of his aides have been infected with COVID-19.
Explaination: The Vatican and the embassy said the pope recently fell ill with a common cold.
Label: False

Claim: Japanese Asahi Shimbun TV: USA caught COVID-19 before Wuhan, according to American CDC
Explaination: The original news clip suggested that there could be some COVID-19 cases being misdiagnosing with flu in the USA. But it didn't mention that the COVID-19 is originated in the USA.
Label: False

Claim: A study published by two Chinese research institutions suggest that human semen can cure COVID-19.
Explaination: The screenshot of the report circulated online was digitally manipulated. The original report suggested another medicine could be the cure, not human semen.
Label: False

Claim: Spices can ward off the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Spices can increase endurance but there is no evidence that they can prevent and cure coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Coronavirus can be transmitted through imported goods
Explaination: The virus cannot be outside the human body for a long time.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus dies in temperatures 26-27C and when exposed to sunlight.
Explaination: None of the studies that mention the coronavirus linked with COVID-19 can die in temperatures 26-27 degrees Celsius and when exposed to sunlight.
Label: False

Claim: Turkish raki prevents COVID-19.
Explaination: Clipping was doctored on online app. There is no evidence shows raki prevents the disease.
Label: False

Claim: Bloggers say the Vatican reports that Pope Francis tested negative for the coronavirus before a second test came back positive.
Explaination: An Italian newspaper reported that Pope Francis tested negative for the coronavirus. The Vatican hasn't confirmed or denied the report.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows President Donald Trump saying COVID-19 is the Democrats’ “new hoax.”
Explaination: The video makes it look like Trump called coronavirus “their new hoax.” In fact, there was nearly a full minute between when the president said “coronavirus” and “hoax” during a Feb. 28 rally in North Charleston, S.C.
Label: False

Claim: Drink (warm) water or gargle every 15 minutes to rinse the new coronavirus down.
Explaination: There is no clinical/scientific support that drinking warm water can protect from the new coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: This video shows dead coronavirus victims amassed in the Bergamo (or Brescia) hospital.
Explaination: The video was recorded in Ecuador at the Los Ceibos General Hospital in Guayaquil.
Label: False

Claim: Ecuadorian doctor develops a vaccine for COVID-19.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Two cases of coronavirus have been reported in Loja, Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Azuay governor in Ecuador seeks the cure of COVID-19 in indigenous medicine.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Video claims that “The health system is collapsing” in North Macedonia.
Explaination:
One of the false claims in the video (published on 3 April) is that Macedonia has by far the lowest number of tested compared to other countries. Data from worldometers.info, including data for 4 April, show that Macedonia is the second country in the region in terms of the number of tests conducted for COVID-19 per million inhabitants.
Another false claim is that the number of cases per capita is the highest in Macedonia from the entire region, but as of 7 April, the number of cases per capita in Macedonia is somewhere in the middle compared to the whole region.
Label: False

Claim: Outbreak of COVID-19 is a worldwide fake. The fatality rate is too low for an epidemic. The WHO admitted causing the SARS outbreak in 2003.
Explaination: Thousands of confirmed cases around the globe, virus confirmed in multiple labs, fatality rate greater than that of some of pandemics in the 20th century.
Label: Misleading

Claim: This photo shows a brothel in Europe where people have been quarantined.
Explaination: Claim originated on a satirical website based in Spain, the photo is of a nightclub in Marbella.
Label: False

Claim: These are seven “evil” things COVID-19 is “afraid” of.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; health experts say such practices are only effective when applied properly and can even be harmful if used incorrectly.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A runny nose and sputum secretion are not symptoms of novel coronavirus.
Explaination: WHO listed those as possible symptoms.
Label: False

Claim: Israeli scientists have developed a COVID-19 vaccine.
Explaination: Israel's migal institute said it was still working to develop a vaccine, the photo is from a stock photo website.
Label: False

Claim: 12 pieces of advice for coronavirus, including symptoms, transmission, how to neutralize the virus.
Explaination: The majority of the advice is either false or unfounded.
Label: False

Claim: Plant-based cure for coronavirus discovered in Iran.
Explaination: The plant-based product has not been either approved or submitted for approval to Iranian authorities, according to the official news agency.
Label: False

Claim: Disinfectant gel causes cancer.
Explaination: There have been no credible studies to prove this, according to health experts.
Label: False

Claim: Twitter users said Adutwumwaa Bitters cure coronavirus.
Explaination: Adutwumwaa Bitters does not cure coronavirus. Producers of the medicine, Adutwumwaa Herbal Industries Limited, have emphatically stated that their product cannot and does not cure the deadly virus. The World Health Organization (WHO) says there’s no cure, vaccine or specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat coronavirus at the moment.
Label: False

Claim: Constant sex kills coronavirus.
Explaination: Sex cannot kill or cure coronavirus, the science does not add up. Rather such close contact with an infected person will expose the partner to the disease.
Label: False

Claim: Viral photo in Nigeria suggests former President Obasanjo said there is no coronavirus in Nigeria and that the minister of health lied.
Explaination: President Obasanjo's spokesperson, Kehinde Akinyemi refuted allegations attributed to Baba; a moniker often used to describe the former head of state. Additionally, Dubawa initiated a google reverse image search, which revealed that the "Fox News writer" (the source) used the image out of context.
Label: False

Claim: Ecuadorean youtuber Raùl Alvarez Guene supposedly infected with COVID-19.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Ministry of Health confirms new case of coronavirus in Santa Elena province, Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: There are cases of coronavirus in the Amazon forest.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Local hospital in Ecuador says first covid patient didn’t have coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: A bovine coronavirus vaccine, for cattle, is proof that the novel coronavirus isn’t “new” and is evidence of “how much the media controls people.”
Explaination: The cattle vaccine has nothing to do with the COVID-19 virus.
Label: False

Claim: Journalist claims a coronavirus patient was murdered.
Explaination: The tweet did go out from a TV reporter, but it was doctored to claim that a murder investigation was underway at the nursing home.
Label: False

Claim: U.S. Vice President Pence urged people with coronavirus to go to the police.
Explaination: This is a fake Tweet by Pence. He never said this.
Label: False

Claim: The Ministry of Health in Spain issues advice about the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: It's not a real alert by the Ministry of Health.
Label: False

Claim: 3.000 people from Elche (Spain) are infected with the coronavirus after coming back from Milan’s international footwear industry fair.
Explaination: There currently aren't any coronavirus cases in Elche and the Ministry of Health has not released any statement claiming so.
Label: False

Claim: The pope has COVID-19.
Explaination: Vatican press office announced that the Pope just has a common cold. He is continuing his schedule. If he had the virus, his age would make it difficult for him to do so.
Label: False

Claim: Whatsapp message contains multiple health advises.
Explaination: The text message is based on the advices lacking scientific evidences. WHO advises does not include any of them.
Label: False

Claim: Man critical with novel coronavirus in Barhalganj, India.
Explaination: There is no confirmed case of the novel coronavirus in Barhalganj, a town in Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh. And the man did not get infected with coronavirus in Barhalganj by consuming chicken. The viral post is fake.
Label: False

Claim: Alcohol kills the coronavirus.
Explaination: Post claiming alcohol kills coronavirus is fake.
Label: False

Claim: Ambulance health care workers are transporting a corona patient in The Hague (The Netherlands), dressed in white protective suits.
Explaination: Medical personnel and news websites had already explicitly stated that this patiënt was not infected with the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Post says “sanitizer will do nothing for the coronavirus.”
Explaination: Although it is not effective against all viruses, hand sanitizers with high alcohol content have proven effective against human coronaviruses.
Label: False

Claim: Post says two patients at Valley Regional Medical Center in Brownsville, Texas, “are being looked at” for possible coronavirus infections.
Explaination: Health officials say there are no coronavirus patients in the Rio Grande Valley as of March 3, 2020.
Label: False

Claim: The United States is “actually screening fewer people (for the coronavirus than other countries) because we don’t have appropriate testing.”
Explaination: The CDC has stopped publicly reporting the number of tests it’s administered. As of March 4, the United States has lagged behind other nations in terms of coronavirus testing.
Label: MOSTLY TRUE

Claim: U.S. Senator Lindsey Graham says President Trump “probably knows more about medicine and specifically viruses than any of the so-called scientists at the NIH and CDC.”
Explaination: Sen. Lindsey Graham didn't say that President Trump probably knows more about medicine and viruses than medical professionals.The quote was fabricated by a Twitter account that has posted fake statements in the past.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: “Coronavirus hoax: Fake virus pandemic fabricated to cover-up global outbreak of 5G Syndrome.”
Explaination: No credible evidence has emerged to show that the current coronavirus spreading around the world was fabricated.
Label: False

Claim: Multiple videos claim garlic and onions can prevent and cure infection from the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: This is false; the World Health Organization says garlic cannot prevent or treat COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: In North Korea, a person was allegedly shot by local authorities when he violated the quarantine rule and went to a public restroom.
Explaination: Due to the complete state control over the information and news in North Korea, the true and complete picture of the coronavirus there will probably never be captured. All claims about covid- 19 in North Korea cannot be verified or confirmed, and external sources can only speculate about the true picture within the country's borders. That alone is enough to conclude that all news coming from North Korea should be taken with reservations, including the unconfirmed info that the country has executed the first person infected with COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Ecuadorian youtuber Raùl Alvarez Guene was supposedly infected with COVID-19.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: There are cases of coronavirus in the Amazon forest.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Local hospital in Ecuador says first COVID-19 patient didn’t have coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Indonesia has provided 1,000 free tickets for nationals to return home from abroad.
Explaination: Foreign Ministry dismissed the reports as a hoax.
Label: False

Claim: This is a video of panicked shoppers storming a supermarket amid the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video was in fact filmed in Germany in 2011, nearly a decade before the coronavirus pandemic broke out.

Claim: Four patients infected with the coronavirus are hospitalized in Sri Lanka.
Explaination: Only two suspect patients were hospitalized and both later tested negative.

Claim: Classes in Ecuador are suspended because of coronavirus.

Claim: There is a new case of coronavirus in Latacunga, Ecuador.

Claim: Pope Francis and two aides tested positive for coronavirus.

Claim: An alkaline diet can prevent coronavirus infection.
Explaination: No food or diet, neither alkaline or otherwise, can prevent the infection
Label: False

Claim: Facemasks prevent coronavirus infection.
Explaination: Health authorities does not recommend using facemask unless direct contact with a positive.

Claim: “Florida hospital reports a coronavirus ‘infestation’ with multiple confirmed patients.”
Explaination: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention presumptively confirmed two cases of the 2019 coronavirus in Florida.

Claim: Photo shows a man wearing a “government issued Saint Laurent hazardous materials suit.”
Explaination: The image was posted by a self-described parody account.
Label: False

Claim: “Shands Hospital of Gainesville, Florida, has confirmed its first case of coronavirus.”
Explaination: As of March 2, 2020, the CDC has confirmed two cases of COVID-19 in Florida. Shands Hospital in Gainesville, Florida, has not confirmed a coronavirus case.

Claim: Post says no one has died from the coronavirus in the United States.
Explaination: As of March 3, nine people have died from the coronavirus in the United States. The first death was on March 1.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus is “simply the common cold.”
Explaination: The 2019 coronavirus is part of a family of viruses that produce illnesses ranging from the common cold to more critical diseases such as SARS or MERS, but is a new virus that had not been previously identified.

Claim: This video was shot in a mall in Germany during the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: It has been filmed years before the pandemia.

Claim: Beware of Yellow Rain (Agent Orange) coming with a storm from China. It brings chemicals and the coronavirus.
Explaination: Yellow rain is not a real rain, it's how to call an chemical weapon in the past. Even a storm is coming, it's unable to bring virus from China to Thailand.

Claim: Photo of Iranian officials visiting the vice president after she contracted COVID-19.
Explaination: The photo has circulated in reports since 2014, after one of Iran's vice-presidents was injured in a traffic accident.

Claim: Vatican says Pope Francis has been infected with the novel coronavirus.

Claim: 14 points of expert advice about coronavirus, including symptoms, prevention and how it spreads.

Claim: Mongolia donates 30,000 sheep to China during the coronavirus epidemic.
Explaination: The videos circulated before Mongolia announced the donation on Feb 27, 2020.

Claim: Volcanic ash can kill the coronavirus.
Explaination: WHO says there is no evidence that volcanic ash can destroy COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Germany gave medical protection equipment like masks to China, now it’s missing in Germany.
Explaination: Germany sent protection equipment to China twice in February.

Claim: The coronavirus is more dangerous for animals than for humans.
Explaination: There is no proof that animals can get or spread the new coronavirus.
Label: No evidence

Claim: A video shows people storming an Aldi supermarket to buy groceries because of coronavirus fear.
Explaination: The video was made in 2011 and shows people who wanted to buy laptops at an Aldi store in Kiel.
Label: False

Claim: This virus must be old because the label on a bottle of disinfectant from 2015 shows “coronavirus“.
Explaination: The coronavirus family is known since decades, that's why the name shows on older disinfectants.
Label: False

Claim: Local news channel in Ecuador confirms more people are infected with coronavirus.

Label: False

Claim: Health Ministry in Ecuador confirms three new cases of coronavirus.

Claim: Pope Francis is infected with coronavirus.

Claim: Drinking warm water or tea can prevent contagions.
Explaination: There are not studies about persistence or stability of COVID-19 about temperature and inanimate objects.

Claim: Doctors recommend carbon filter face masks to prevent coronavirus spread.
Explaination: Videos falsely claims that doctors are recommending carbon filter masks as a way to protect families, although the FDA and CDC both concluded that they are not effective for children and are not recommended for home use. The videos are used to sell the masks to people concerned about the coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Garlic water can treat coronavirus.
Explaination: WHO says there is no evidence.
Label: False

Claim: Pangolin is the original cause of COVID-19.
Explaination: The scientists that first pointed to pangolin as the original cause of the infection have since then rectified.

Claim: Russia announces the closure of airspace and suspends all incoming and outgoing flights to China.
Explaination: Russian government had imposed some temporary and partial ban on the movement of Chinese nationals. All Russian airlines, with the exception of national airline Aeroflot (AFLT.MM), stopped flying to China from Jan. 31. Small airline Ikar will also continue flights between Moscow and China. All planes arriving from China will be sent to a separate terminal in the Moscow Sheremetyevo airport. Aeroflot reduced the frequency of flights to Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou until Feb. 29.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Taiwanese president and former president were infected. The former president died.
Explaination: The imagines of screenshots of news outlets and official documents are either doctored or forged. As to the date, the claim appeared online, President Tsai had a public speech at 228 memorial event.

Claim: Police in China have killed 25,000 COVID-19 patients so far.
Explaination: None of the four clips spliced together shows cops “shooting” COVID-19 patients. In fact, one of the clips is actually of a road crash. Another one features not the sound of gunshots, but the explosion of Lunar New Year Fireworks in the background.

Claim: COVID-19 came from Chinese people eating human babies, in an effort to improve their skin.
Explaination: The netizen’s claim about COVID-19 coming from eating babies is false and baseless. The photos used are also all over a decade old, some of which show a Chinese man "eating babies" as a protest art in 2000.

Claim: A video says the Vatican confirmed Pope Francis and two aides tested positive for coronavirus.

Claim: President Barack Obama “waited six months to call swine flu an emergency after thousands died.”
Explaination: The Obama administration declared swine flu, or H1N1, a public health emergency six weeks before H1N1 was declared a pandemic. No H1N1 deaths had yet been recorded in the United States.

Claim: The Vatican confirmed that Pope Francis and two aides tested positive for coronavirus.
Explaination: The Vatican denied allegations that Pope Francis contracted the novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19).
Label: False

Claim: Pope Francis was diagnosed with coronavirus.

Claim: A video of chaos in a shop claims people are panicking after the first confirmed case of coronavirus in Lithuania.

Claim: Doctors in Japan advise people to drink water every 15 minutes to prevent an infection.

Claim: Vitamin helps against COVID-19.
Explaination: Health experts told AFP there is insufficient science to definitively say vitamin D can protect from the viral epidemic.

Claim: Election years in the United States coincide with major disease outbreaks.
Explaination: Several years of discovery or the associated spread of a disease do not match election years, national and international health organizations said.

Claim: The Cambodian prime minister has COVID-19.

Claim: Beef meat is the best vaccine against COVID-19.

Claim: Shaving facial hair ensures safety from COVID-19, further attributing the message to the CDC.
Explaination: Results from our research show that the message from Today.ng's article is a misappropriation of a 2017 NOISH publication; a notification directed at workers using respirators in carrying out their tasks. It has nothing to do with preventing the spread of coronavirus.

Claim: Video of a roof full of bats claims it is the source of coronavirus.

Claim: Coronavirus patients in China are caught by officials on a highway.

Claim: Chinese police use a fishing net to arrest a man with a high fever.

Claim: Florida man is arrested for robbery using cough as a weapon.

Claim: “Every election year has a disease” — SARS in 2004; avian flu in 2008; swine flu in 2010; MERS in 2012; Ebola in 2014 and 2018; Zika in 2016 and the coronavirus in 2020.

Claim: COVID-19 is just a big flu.

Claim: It is best to shave your beard to avoid being infected by the coronavirus.

Claim: Chinese experts warn about a scar in the lung caused by COVID-19. This is more severe than SARS 17 years ago.

Claim: Airport in Karachi suspends all international arrivals during coronavirus epidemic.

Claim: Video shows a person infected with coronavirus being detained by the police.

Claim: A case of coronavirus in the Argentine province of Santiago del Estero was confirmed.

Claim: A case of coronavirus in the Argentine province of Chaco was confirmed.
Explaination: There are no confirmed cases of coronavirus in Argentina at this date.
Label: False

Claim: An Argentinian doctor discovered a vaccine for coronavirus in Spain
Explaination: Is false that an argentinian doctor discovered a vaccine against coronavirus in Spain. The men shown in a photo attached with the message is an actor. The World Health Organization informed that "there is no vaccine and no specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat".
Label: False

Claim: The WHO says the coronavirus might be spread by food.
Explaination: The WHO has no hints so far that infections with coronavirus via food are possible.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Coronavirus is not reproducing in warm places.
Explaination: Other coronaviruses has started to die over 56°C but there are no studies about Covid-2019.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Bleach and chlorine can be used to prevent the coronavirus.
Explaination: WHO confirms bleach and other disinfects might work to kill the virus.
Label: False

Claim: Iran’s deputy Health Minister: This year we have had 13,200 flu cases which caused the death of 108 people. Our population is a fourth of the U.S. population. Last year, they had 28 million flu cases which resulted in 16,000 deaths. Yet nobody is restricting travel.
Explaination: Flu death rate in the US is less than 0.1% and moreover deputy minister’s comparison of flu and COVID-19 is misleading.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The cover of a book titled “Tintin in Wuhan” shows the character standing in an old Chinese market wearing special suits, while people are wearing masks.
Explaination: This is a doctored image that is made of frames from two different Tintin books.
Label: False

Claim: French far right leader Marine Le Pen says the EU didn’t act against the outbreak
Explaination: The EU has activated the civil protection mechanism, launched aid program, mobilizes funds for research and called for more international cooperation and coordination.
Label: False

Claim: Lysol products can kill the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: While Lysol products are advertised to kill 99.9% of bacteria and viruses, including coronavirus, the company is referring to previous strains of the virus. There is no known cure for the novel (or new) coronavirus strain.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A monkey is been infected with the coronavirus in this photo.
Explaination: The photo is a capture of a video taken at least two months before the first symptoms of COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Lectures have been suspended at the University of Sevilla due to coronavirus.
Explaination: The University has made a statement saying that the document that has been shared is false.
Label: False

Claim: There is a new case of COVID-19 in Sacedón (Spain).
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: El Pais said there is a possible case of coronavirus at the hospital Gregorio Marañón in Spain.
Explaination: El País hasn't published that article and the typography doesn't match.
Label: False

Claim: An article in El Pais says there is a case of coronavirus at the School of Architecture of Madrid.
Explaination: El País hasn't published that article.
Label: False

Claim: First case of coronavirus in Alcalá de Henares (Madrid).
Explaination: One screenshot shows a false article done with an app that lets you create these fake contents and the other one shows an article that HAS NOT been published by El Mundo newspaper.
Label: False

Claim: A brothel with 86 customers was quarantined after a prostitute tested positive for the coronavirus.
Explaination: It was a "satirical" content.
Label: False

Claim: Sevilla’s university has suspended classes because of coronavirus on 2/27/20.
Explaination: The institution denied it on its Twitter account.
Label: False

Claim: Dr. Gerardo Dovakin found a vaccine against coronavirus.
Explaination: He is actually an actor, not a doctor.
Label: False

Claim: Honduras’s first confirmed case traveled to Taiwan earlier, which means there is a severe community transmission in Taiwan.
Explaination: As to Feb. 27., 2020, Honduras had zero confirmed case of COVID-19. A Taiwanese traveler had once suspected infection, but she has tested negative afterward.
Label: False

Claim: Taiwan has severe community transmission. Many people have died.
Explaination: As to Feb. 27, there is no evidence indicating the Taiwan government has hidden real COVID-19 figures or information. The Taiwan Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) has a daily press conference to update the latest confirmed case number and has been considered reasonably transparent.
Label: False

Claim: The outbreak in Taiwan is out of control. President Tsai ordered a corpse burned in front of the presidential office.
Explaination: It's a picture of a self-immolation incident in 2015 in front of the presidential office.
Label: False

Claim: Iranian clerics wear masks after the outbreak.
Explaination: The photo is old-dated and manipulated. It was taken in the funeral of Kasem Sulemani.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking water every 10 minutes can send the virus into sthe omach and kill it.
Explaination: Digestive system can not stop the respiratory system's work and the course of infection.
Label: False

Claim: The WHO has issued an alert against buying holy colors from China
Explaination: WHO hasn't issued advisory against buying of Holi colors from coronavirus-hit China. The viral post is fake.
Label: False

Claim: ”America has been vaccinating cattle for coronavirus for years, yet the news tells you it’s new and going to kill you all, so go buy a mask.”
Explaination: The vaccine for cattle won’t help humans, and won't protect against this new form of coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: “The blood test for coronavirus costs $3,200.”
Explaination: The CDC isn't charging for coronavirus testing but patients could be stuck with associated costs, such as a trip to the emergency room. In Florida, a man who worried he was infected initially faced a $3,270 bill even though he never received a coronavirus test.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Starting in March, if you travel outside of the United States you won’t be allowed back in the country “due to high risk of the coronavirus.”
Explaination: As of March 6, there is currently no mandate that states Americans are barred from returning to the U.S. from anywhere overseas.
Label: False

Claim: “‘Akira’ is a 1988 movie about an apocalyptic event taking place months before Tokyo 2020 Olympics, showing the WHO advising Japan to postpone the Olympics because of a pandemic risk.”
Explaination: The movie does not feature a pandemic of any sort. The WHO is never mentioned in the movie.
Label: False

Claim: A video accompanying a claim shows bodies being removed from a hospital in Iran during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video has circulated in reports since at least August 2019 about a funeral procession for pilgrims who died during the annual Islamic pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia's Grand Mosque.
Label: False

Claim: A “letter” from an uncle in Wuhan claims COVID-19 can be cured with hot water.
Explaination: There is no evidence hot water can cure COVID-19, other facts stated in the said letter are not accurate as well.
Label: False

Claim: CDC issued facial hair recommendation for novel coronavirus prevention.
Explaination: Graphic is more than two years old and is unrelated to current outbreak.
Label: Misleading

Claim: There is a confirmed case of coronavirus in a Bogotá hospital.
Explaination: The case was never treated under the suspicion it was coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: You can maintain the alkaline state of the body to avoid contagion.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Is it useful to close borders to stop the outbreak?
Explaination: French medical experts say closing borders in order to prevent infected people from entering in France is ineffective. Likewise, health tests before entering the country have little effect.
Label: False

Claim: Hair Weaves And Lace Front Wigs Made In China Likely To Contain coronavirus.
Explaination: There is very little chance of coronavirus spreading this way, and there have not been any reported cases of this happening.
Label: Unlikely

Claim: Letters and packages sent from China can cause coronavirus infection.
Explaination: Viruses can live for some time in objects like door knobs. WHO has declares COVID-19 can't live very long in envelopes and boxes.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Face masks are a good protection against the coronavirus.
Explaination: Masks are not a good way of protection unless you're a health professional or your are in contact with somebody infected.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: The new coronavirus was registered in 2004.
Explaination: It was another type of coronavirus that was registered in 2004, not the one that caused the current outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: School has been suspended in Catalonia until 3/2/20.
Explaination: It's not a real statement by the Catalonian education department.
Label: False

Claim: New cases of coronavirus in Madrid are linked to two universities and a club.
Explaination: Images of articles published by El Mundo related to coronavirus were manipulated.
Label: False

Claim: Two cases are confirmed of coronavirus in Huelva, Andalucía (2/26/20)
Explaination: Andalusian health ministry denied cases of coronavirus in the Spanish region.
Label: False

Claim: Italian Red Cross gives the recipe for making amuchina (hand sanitizer) at home.
Explaination: Italian Red Cross has never shared any recipe. The recipe shared isn't the real one and could be useful only to disinfect vegetables.
Label: False

Claim: A post says “hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
Explaination: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: “Coronavirus: Florida man arrested for robbery using cough as a weapon.”
Explaination: This screenshot of “breaking news” is originally from a satirical news site. If you look closely, you'll see a news generator watermark in the top right corner, meaning the image was created.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: The CDC recommends men shave their beards to protect against coronavirus.
Explaination: A 2017 CDC infographic shows how facial hair could interfere with respirator masks. The graphic is unrelated to coronavirus protection and the CDC has not recommended people should shave their beards to ward off the virus.
Label: False

Claim: China took advantage of the coronavirus crisis to buy back stocks from its technology companies belonging to foreign investors.
Explaination:
This is the story in full : Previously, stocks of technology companies, belonged to Europeans and Americans foreign investors.
Due to the situation in Wuhan, Juan began to decline, but the Central Bank did nothing to support Juan.
And when the price fell, below the allowable limit, XI JINPING gave the order, at one point, to buy ALL the shares of Europeans and Americans.
Not only has China made $ 20 billion, but these days it has returned the shares of its companies to China. The story is completely fabricated and there is no evidence for it. In fact, the story was published back in 2014 - but it was not the Chinese but the Russian president at the time, and the emergency was not because of the corona but because of the crime. The media only changed the name of the country, the president, the currency and the reason for the emergency and re-published the story.
Label: False

Claim: The Russian CDC admitted that COVID-19 is human-made.
Explaination:
The original document from the Russian health ministry only mentions that COVID-19 is
a recombinant virus. It doesn't suggest the COVID-19 is a human-made virus.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Photos show many corpses floating in the river in Tainan, a Southern city in Taiwan.
Explaination: They are stage photos from Korean movies "Deranged" and "Train To Busan".
Label: False

Claim: “DDP (Democratic Progressive Party) legislator Kao Chia-yu gave my mom two boxes of face masks since DDP has plenty and said the outbreak is out of control.”
Explaination: Legislator Kao denied making such a comment. There are several factual inaccuracies in the claim.
Label: False

Claim: My son, who works as a public servant in the Central government, got one box of face masks while the public is restricted to two per week.
Explaination: All public officials of the central government whose duty are not related to disease control are not allowed to apply for official face masks.
Label: False

Claim: Singapore government said confirmed case No. 12 is a prostitute. As a result, many of her clients are under quarantine.
Explaination: According to the Singapore health ministry, case no. 12 showed symptoms during the family trip in Singapore. The department hasn't released the occupation of case no. 12.
Label: False

Claim: Multiple allegations around how coronavirus was produced by China.
Explaination: The alleged connection between the spies is fictional. No scientific evidence shows the virus is produced as a bioweapon.
Label: False

Claim: A post say “hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
Explaination: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.
Label: PANTS ON FIRE

Claim: A man is allegedly selling medical masks for 80 denars on a bus owned by the Skopje Public Transportation Enterprise.
Explaination: After a short investigation, it was found out that the photo has already been posted on other sites, such as the Facebook page of the site 3minute.net, where the photo was posted on 25 February. According to the status, the photo was taken in the town of Craiova, Romania, and not in Skopje, North Macedonia.
Label: False

Claim: Holding your breath lets you check if you have coronavirus.
Explaination: Infected people can still be able to hold their breath for 20 seconds.
Label: False

Claim: “Hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
Explaination: The Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Multiple allegations on how to protect oneself from the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Many of the practices detailed in the post are misleading and inaccurate.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Coronavirus infects chickens in Pakistan.
Explaination: Authorities say it's related to another disease.
Label: False

Claim: Infected taxi driver demands money from his government otherwise he’ll infect others.
Explaination: Story originated from a parody account, no driver is threatneing to spread covid-19 across Nigeria.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Photos show Muslims in Italy praying outside because of the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The photos have been published long before the COVID-19 outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Indian Government and the WHO advised people not to purchase colors from China for Holi.
Explaination: No such advisory was shared by the government or the Ministry.
Label: False

Claim: A crowd is waiting to greet Colombians living in Wuhan who are being flown to Bogotá.
Explaination: The images are from 2018, when crowds gathered to meet the Colombian National Football Team after the World Cup in Russia.
Label: False

Claim: In Poland, people who are not insured have to pay for coronavirus testing, so if they can’t afford it, they will spread it.
Explaination: He included a document from hospital which named the price for voluntary coronavirus test, for those who are not suspected of having coronavirus (they haven't been to affected areas nor they have medical signs of disease). Anyone who IS suspected of having coronavirus, will have medical examination free of charge, no matter if he's insured or not.
Label: False

Claim: China needs coronavirus SWAT (special weapons and tactics) police teams to arrest this coronavirus victim.
Explaination: Video shows a mock drill by Tongbai police practicing to take down coronavirus infected patients in case they are uncooperative.
Label: False

Claim: In 1981, the book “The Eyes of Darkness” predicted the spread of the coronavirus.
Explaination: The book is a work of fiction that mentions a biological weapon called Wuhan-400 (Originally Gorki-400) that has no similarities to the COVID-19. The other page, is from a totally different book “End of Days” by American psychic Sylvia Browne.
Label: False

Claim: The word “coronavirus” on disinfecting spray reaffirms that the virus was known before the outbreak and could be planned.
Explaination: Coronaviruses have been known for decades. SARS and MERS were caused by coronaviruses. The companies (Lysol, Clorox,etc) have stated that their products have demonstrated effectiveness against viruses “similar” to COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus is a bioweapon leaked from a Wuhan lab.
Explaination: Already disproved similar claims. Scientists in Wuhan insisted no link between virus and labs.
Label: False

Claim: Bats that hide under Wuhan rooftops caused the COVID-19 outbreak.
