Explaination: The video was recorded in the US in 2011.
Label: False

Claim: Video of a road traffic control in China to detect people infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: The video was filmed in China, but it's a simulation, not a real incident.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Coronavirus patients are being “cremated alive” in China.
Explaination: The Chinese government has ordered the swift cremation of patients who die after contracting the coronavirus. But there is no evidence they are being cremated alive.
Label: False

Claim: Evidence indicates COVID-19 escaped a Chinese lab that was researching it, causing the outbreak.
Explaination: Overall, Mosher’s argument is based on unfounded speculation and scientific inaccuracies. Multiple scientific studies have indicated that the virus has a natural origin, not the result of human engineering.
Label: False

Claim: It is a weird and unusual year; an ice tsunami occurred on Xingkai Lake in Heilongjiang.
Explaination: The video of the ice tsunami was filmed at River Yenisei in Dudinka, Russia, in June 2019. Not in China.
Label: False

Claim: An armored vehicle was so full of corpses that it slipped off a trailer.
Explaination: It is a picture of an armored vehicle accident in Taichung. It has been miscaptioned.
Label: False

Claim: The DPP (Democratic Progressive Party) politician Wang Shijian said Taiwan has more than 500 confirmed cases.
Explaination: The DPP councilor Wang Shijian has denied making such a statement. As to Feb. 25., 2020, Taiwan has 31 confirmed cases, one death toll
Label: False

Claim: A vaccine for COVID-19 has been found.
Explaination: Chinese ambassador to Russia announced that they are making progress. No vaccine for COVID-19 yet.
Label: False

Claim: The mortality rate for the flu is “right around” that of the new coronavirus: “It’s right around 2%.”
Explaination: The mortality rate for the flu is considered by most experts to be about 0.1%. Estimates for the mortality rate for coronavirus are currently around 2%, but this number could change depending on how cases are diagnosed.
Label: False

Claim: The Chinese accept Islam en masse (20 million).
Explaination: Video was published with misleading header. After our fact-check some authors changed descriptions for their videos but this hoax is still circulating on WhatsApp.
Label: False

Claim: These are measures that protect from novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Health experts refute new misleading claims about coronavirus prevention in Sri Lanka.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Infected taxi driver demands money from his government or he’ll infect others.
Explaination: Story originated from a parody account, no driver is threatening to spread COVID-19 across Nigeria.
Label: False

Claim: President Trump claims the virus is under control and testing is available.
Explaination: The president spent nearly two months issuing confusing and contradictory signals — leaving the bureaucratic machine of the U.S. government to chart the course for the coronavirus response.
Label: False

Claim: A book by D.Koontz, “The Eyes of Darkness,” predicted COVID-19 in 1981.
Explaination: The first edition of the book mentioned that the virus was invented by the Russians, rather then the Chinese. Moreover, real and imaginary viruses have almost nothing in common.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese people convert to Islam because of COVID-19.
Explaination: Video is from May 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Radio host Rush Limbaugh compares novel coronavirus to “the common cold.”
Explaination: Novel coronavirus is more deadly from the viruses that can cause a cold, according to experts.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Coronavirus case in Uttar Pradesh district, India.
Explaination: Authorities denied.
Label: False

Claim: Shoppers in China storm supermarket after coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The video has circulated in media reports since at least October 2019, two months before the viral outbreak was first reported.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A Chinese SWAT Team takes down a coronavirus suspect
Explaination: A mock drill video was shared as China committing atrocities on its patients.
Label: False

Claim: A 1981 book predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The book does talk about a virus called Wuhan-400, but it's not the same as COVID-19.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The link between COVID-19 and 5G is being hidden.
Explaination: The link is not being hidden because it doesn't exist.
Label: False

Claim: There are two coronavirus cases in Bovalino (Reggio Calabria, Italy).
Explaination: No Sars-Cov-2 cases at that time.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus in Sant’Egidio (Abruzzo, Italy).
Explaination: No Sars-Cov-2 cases at that time.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus in Parabiago e Nerviano (Lombardia, Italy)
Explaination: No coronavirus Sars-Cov-2 sites there at that time.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus is present at Bosch company in Bari (Puglia) because Chinese people visited the week before.
Explaination: No Sars-Cov-2 cases at that time.
Label: False

Claim: “The coronavirus is the common cold, folks.”
Explaination: The 2019 coronavirus is a new virus that had not been previously identified.
Label: False

Claim: Taiwanese manufacturing is awesome. One machine can produce 2.5 million face masks per day.
Explaination: According to the Taiwanese Economy Ministry, each production line of face mask produces around 100,000 masks per day. The claimed video is miscaptioned as well.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows the suspected infected people in eastern Turkey, Van.
Explaination: Video is not new. There is no proved COVID-19 case in Turkey by now.
Label: False

Claim: Author Dean Koontz foresaw the coronavirus outbreak in his book.
Explaination: There is nothing common between the fictional virus in the book and current COVID-19 rather than Wuhan.
Label: False

Claim: Video says President Donald Trump spawned the “Wuhan super virus outbreak under code name ‘zyphr.’”
Explaination: There’s no evidence that President Trump had anything to do with the creation of the coronavirus.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Nostradamus predicted the coronavirus.
Explaination: The predictions of Nostradamus are not correctly translated, and even if Nostradamus truly predicted a “plague”, the title of the original article says that it is taking place in a seaside town. The coronavirus originated in the city of Wuhan in China, which is not a seaside town, which can be confirmed by a simple Google search.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows an anti-China protest amid the COVID-19 outbreak in Italy.
Explaination: The video show a march in Rome to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the assassination of Valerio Verbano, an Italian left-wing activist murdered in 1980.
Label: False

Claim: A Facebook status from 2012 talked about the spread of coronavirus in 2020.
Explaination: The facebook status was updated on 27 Jan 2020.
Label: False

Claim: Years ago, there was a hand sanitizer active against Sars-Cov-2.
Explaination: The hand sanitizer is active against coronavirus in general. There is no specific sanitizer against Sars-Cov-2. Pagella Politica contacted the manufacturing company.
Label: False

Claim: Ketamine can cure COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no evidence that Ketamine can prevent or treat COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Many corpses from South Taiwan were sent to Taichung to burn. Taiwan has a serious community infection.
Explaination: The number of cremation in Taiwan hasn't increased significantly since the COVID-19 outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Bill Gates wrote a letter saying COVID-19 is teaching humans a lesson.
Explaination: The story was retracted and the letter was fake.
Label: False

Claim: There is a case of coronavirus at the School of Architects of Madrid.
Explaination: It was an exercise.
Label: False

Claim: Pigs are buried alive due to coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is not recent and has nothing to do with coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Post says “people of color may be immune to the coronavirus because of melanin.”
Explaination: Melanin is a natural pigment that gives color to skin and eyes. It does not make you any less susceptible to coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows Chinese officials detaining suspected coronavirus cases.
Explaination: The video shows a police drill in China during the novel coronavirus epidemic.
Label: False

Claim: This is artwork from Wuhan.
Explaination: It's in another city, Shandong.
Label: False

Claim: This map shows high sulphur dioxide in Wuhan now due to the burning of corpses.
Explaination: Those are only forecasts based on past emissions.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese people flee to Vietnam due to COVID-19.
Explaination: The video is from november 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows racist reactions toward Asian people.
Explaination: Those are actors.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The WHO considers canceling the Mecca pilgrimage.
Explaination: WHO did not and could not take such a measure.
Label: False

Claim: These charts show the difference betweem COVID-19, flu and common cold.
Explaination: Charts include inaccurate information about symptoms. They claim people suffering from the novel coronavirus do not develop some symptoms seen in flu or common cold patients, such as a runny or stuffy nose, a sore throat, vomiting, diarrhea and muscle pain, among others -- most of which can actually be seen among COVID-19 patients as well.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A suspicious case of coronavirus in a Military Hospital in Maracay originated with an Army member who claimed have visited China in December.
Explaination: The journalist was misinformed and rushed to publish the information. Every source consulted explained the patient was never suspect or examined for coronavirus because he came from Chine one month and a half ago.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese people are fleeing China to Vietnam because of coronavirus.
Explaination: People are actually going from Vietnam to China for work.
Label: False

Claim: Six coronavirus cases confirmed in Wichita, Kansas.
Explaination: No cases were confirmed there, and claim came from non-credible websites.
Label: False

Claim: Four people have died in Zanzibar after handling a chicken infected with COVID-19.
Explaination: A post claiming that four individuals in Zanzibar died from COVID-19 after handling a diseased chicken is false. The post contains images of a diseased chicken that circulated in other countries claiming to show symptoms of COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus has arrived in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Explaination: Since the allegation that the coronavirus arrived in Sarajevo is presented in the title as fact and that there are no confirmations in the text of the articles, all the articles are rated as misinformation and clickbait.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Cannabis boosts immunity against COVID-19
Explaination: There is no evidence to suggest that cannabis improves immunity against the virus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Rainbow shimmers behind a COVID-19 disinfectant truck in China.
Explaination: It's from March 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Those are corpses on the street in Wuhan.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article.
Label: False

Claim: Social media posts claim Chloroquine, an antimalarial drug, can cure COVID-19.
Explaination: No health authorities have certified chloroquine as a cure for coronavirus. WHO, the foremost authority on the subject, according to the Director-General of the body, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, says while the organisation is currently conducting a number of drug trials, it does not expect a result before three weeks. More so, the “malarial chloroquine used in China was not one of the drugs.”
Label: False

Claim: Chinese converting to Islam after realizing that no Muslim was affected by COVD19 in the country.
Explaination: Viral video is available on the internet since June 2019 and has no relation with the current outbreak of coronavirus in China.
Label: False

Claim: 20 million Chinese convert to Islam, and coronavirus does not affect Muslims.
Explaination: The video doesn't feature Chinese people, but rather Filipino men. Video footage predates major coronavirus reports.
Label: False

Claim: A Chinese man has been lynched because he pretended to have the coronavirus.
Explaination: The man was Philippine and not Chinese. He was lynched because other people thought that he could potentially start spreading coronavirus Sars-Cov-2 in their city.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The Simpsons predicted the new coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: An image from the show was altered to read “coronavirus”.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Mosques across China reopened after the coronavirus plague.
Explaination: a video of worship activities in the Dongguan Mosque, China. However, no news was found that the mosque was ever closed or reopened.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese businessman Guo Wengui multiple allegations on coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination:
- The outbreak was not a disaster in the mid of December. 
- The disease did not spread in US quickly after 18th of Feb. 
- Death rate is being updated day by day; not always same. 
- Wuhan's hospital capacity rise doesn't show the real number of infected. 
- Isolation centers in Wuhan are not concentration camps.
Label: FALSE

Claim: The drug Arbidol can help fight the new coronavirus.
Explaination: The drug "arbidol" (other name - Umifenovir) is not proved to be a cure from coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: People queue in Singapore for Halal food.
Explaination: They are queuing for masks.
Label: Misleading

Claim: In Japan, if the new coronavirus test is negative, the cost is 80,000 yen. If positive, the state will bear the cost.
Explaination: No voluntary testing of the new coronavirus has been performed. The test is "when it is determined that the prefecture is necessary based on travel history and contact history with patients", but in this case, the test cost is public expense regardless of negative or positive, and it is "free".
Label: False

Claim: This video shows corpses on the streets of Wuhan.
Explaination: It is in Shenzhen and shows people coming from Hubei sleeping in the streets because no one wants to rent them a roll.
Label: False

Claim: World labs confirm coronavirus was bioengineered.
Explaination: There is no evidence of this.
Label: False

Claim: African skin and blood is resistant to coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no evidence to suggest “black people’s” immunity to the virus, or conversely “white people’s” vulnerability to it. The World Health Organisation (WHO) already stated that anyone in proximity to an infected person is at risk of contracting it (COVID-19).
Label: False

Claim: In Nigeria, Ibrahim Magu, acting EFCC chairman, said corruption caused the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: Coronavirus recently named COVID-19 by the World Health Organisation is a disease. Further, health authorities surmise it emanated from the wet markets in China; being a zoonotic disease. And while the jury’s out on the full clinical picture for COVID-19’s, no evidence suggests it to be a function of moral misconduct or the activities of corrupt individuals.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese police kill a woman escaping a COVID-19 quarantine in China.
Explaination: The scene actually shows a motorbike accident.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus is a biological warfare weapon.
Explaination: Dr. Francis Boyle did say that coronavirus is a biological warfare weapon, but the story lacks context. There is no supporting evidence to back up that suggestion. It was debunked as a rumor and untrue that coronavirus was made in a lab.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese are converting to Islam after realizing that no Muslim was affected by COVID-19 in the country.
Explaination: The viral video is old and not related to coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: The 2008 book “End of Days” predicted the current coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: Dean Koontz, not Sylvia Browne, wrote about “Wuhan-400”.
Label: False

Claim: This is Dr. Li-wen Liang’s funeral ceremony.
Explaination: Dr. Li died on Feb. 7., 2020. The video was uploaded on Nov. 19. 2018.
Label: False

Claim: The amount of ACE2 East Asian people have is 4-5 times more than non-East-Asians. That is why they get infected easily.
Explaination: The claim quoted a 2005 study regarding SARS, not COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese citizens cram for Friday prayer after coronavirus plague.
Explaination: The video is a video of Chinese citizens carrying out Friday prayers taken in 2016, before the coronavirus was first reported in December 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Massive live-pig burials follow the COVID-19 outbreak.
Explaination: The burial is not new. Chinese government decided to kill pigs after African swine fever in 2018.
Label: False

Claim: China seeks court’s approval to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients.
Explaination: Post claiming China seeks court’s approval to kill 20000 coronavirus patients is fake.
Label: False

Claim: This coronavirus-infected patient reached to Dr. Vinod Kumar but he wasn’t given the treatment. He was later referred to Bhagalpur. It further states that one should avoid meat and fish for 3 months and wear mask to protect yourself from coronavirus.
Explaination: The post claiming that coronavirus infected patient reached Bihar and is not given treatment is fake. Health authorities dismiss the hoax report. Further, WHO has also not recommended to avoid fish and meat. It recommended thoroughly cooking meat and eggs. Wearing mask is, however, advisable.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A video says “the coronavirus was invented and patented in the USA and then planted in China.”
Explaination: There is no evidence the coronavirus was “invented.”
Label: False

Claim: India has developed a treatment for coronavirus.
Explaination: The headline of the viral article is misleading. So far, India has not claimed any such discovery.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Police or military prepare for total containment in Canada.
Explaination: Police and army confirmed it's false.
Label: False

Claim: Studies show the coronavirus was engineered to be a bioweapon.
Explaination: The same studies he cites shows how coronavirus strains have an evolutionary, not engineered, relationship.
Label: False

Claim: An Australian couple ordered wine by drone on a Princess Cruise ship.
Explaination: The couple said it was a prank.
Label: False

Claim: This map shows the global spread of COVID-19.
Explaination: This map shows flight paths worldwide -- it does not show the movement of Wuhan residents.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Drinking alcohol kills the coronavirus.
Explaination: Drinking alcohol does not cure coronavirus, alcohol in sanitizers does have an effect.
Label: False

Claim: Seven children died from coronavirus within one week in Karimganj (Assam, India).
Explaination: Public Health Officials have denied any coronavirus death, these children died in a span of 2 months due to fever and other illness.
Label: False

Claim: Data shows a massive release of sulfur dioxide gas near Wuhan.
Explaination: The images in the Twitter posts are not satellite measurements, and a member of NASA said the images did not show significantly increased SO2 measurements. Some other websites cited the images as evidence -- though false -- of bodies being burned due to coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Popping bubble wrap exposes people to coronavirus.
Explaination: Bubble wrap is not produced by people blowing air into the plastic. Claim originated from a satirical Facebook page that was shut down.
Label: False

Claim: Cocaine kills the coronavirus.
Explaination: Post claiming cocaine kills coronavirus is fake.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 is the name of the vaccine against the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: A blog post claiming that the World Health Organization has announced COVID-19 as a vaccine against the novel coronavirus has a false headline. There is no vaccine yet for the disease.
Label: Misleading

Claim: 20 million Chinese people converted to Islam after it was proven that the coronavirus does not affect Muslims.
Explaination: Video claiming to show Chinese converting to Islam after the current coronavirus outbreak was published before the first reported case in Wuhan in 2019.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: A video shows the late Chinese doctor Li-wen Liang’s wedding party.
Explaination: The video is about the wedding of a Taiwanese couple filmed in Taiwan.
Label: False

Claim: Dr. Chao Chien Kuo from Wuhan Central Hospital said drinking alcohol can prevent COVID-19.
Explaination: Dr. Chao Chien Kuo had had such a comment, but it was a joke in his private chat group, not an official recommendation. There is no evidence that drinking alcohol can prevent or treat COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Having 14 face masks is enough. They can be reused every 14 days since the incubation period is 14 days.
Explaination: 14 days of incubation doesn't mean that the coronavirus can be alive for 14 days. People should not reuse single-use-mask.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese are converting to Islam to avoid the coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is a religious activity carried out by ICDO in the Philippines which circulated on the internet before the coronavirus was first reported in December 2019.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows a crow attack and a jumbo mosquito in China during the coronavirus plague.
Explaination: The video is edited by combining several different videos and images.
Label: False

Claim: Taking a hot bath is an effective remedy against COVID-19.
Explaination: Health experts say there is no scientific evidence that bathing in hot water can prevent people from catching the virus; the World Health Organisation (WHO) warned that bathing or showering in very hot water can be “harmful”.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Exactly every 100 years, a viral epidemic breaks out.
Explaination: These epidemics have not arisen exactly 20 years after the beginning of each century.
Label: False

Claim: This bottle of disinfectant gel proves that the coronavirus existed before 2019.
Explaination: Different kinds of coronavirus existed years before SARS-CoV-2, the one which is responsible of COVID-19. That's why the term coronavirus is written on this bottle.
Label: False

Claim: A video claims to show an Eid prayer in China in December 2019.
Explaination: This is a prayer in China in June 19, not related to Cov.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows quarantined people in a building in Shanghai.
Explaination: This video shows tower blocks in Shanghai, not Wuhan – and the clip has been edited to include the audio
Label: False

Claim: Thailand cures COVID-19 with anti-HIV drugs.
Explaination: Thai doctors say their treatment helped a coronavirus patient recover, but it was not a ‘cure’.
Label: Misleading

Claim: There is a COVID-19 case in east Indian state.
Explaination: Local health authority said that there are no confirmed novel coronavirus patients in the area at the time.
Label: False

Claim: There is a COVID-19 case in Ethiopia.
Explaination: No case at this date.
Label: False

Claim: Cuban medicine cures COVID-19.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Bus driver in China vomits blood after becoming unconscious behind the wheel.
Explaination: This video dates back to 2015 when a driver in Xiamen, China was suffering from gastrointestinal bleeding.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows a massive explosion in Wuhan, China, to control the spread of coronavirus.
Explaination: Viral video on social media dates back to 2015 when there were giant explosions at the Chinese port of Tianjin. This video is old and has no relation with coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Latest research by Chinese scientists said coronavirus will render most male patients infertile.
Explaination: The study has not been peer-reviewed. But the study also does not go as far as to say coronavirus will definitely cause infertility in men.
Label: False

Claim: Consuming magnesium chloride, sodium bicarbonate, ginger and lemon juice prevents coronavirus infection.
Explaination: No health organization has recommended eating any of these products to prevent coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Cloud and rain from Wuhan brought the virus to Taiwan.
Explaination: COVID-19 spreads from person to person through small droplets from the nose or mouth which are spread when a person with COVID-19 coughs or exhales. Plus, coronavirus can't survive in clouds.
Label: False

Claim: This burned building is a place of coronavirus patient isolation.
Explaination: The burning building was an apartment in California Park, Yubei District, Chongqing City on January 1, 2020, not a hotel where COVID-19 patients were isolated.
Label: Misleading

Claim: SO2 map proves the massive human cremation in Wuhan.
Explaination: Calculations about the possible sulfur burning and certain degree of air pollution are not consistent.
Label: False

Claim: An “official” mask to combat the novel coronavirus was released.
Explaination: The mask for sale is the Monata reusable dust pollution mask, which is used for woodworking, house cleaning, gardening, and other outdoor activities.
Label: False

Claim: Black skin is resistant to coronavirus.
Explaination: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory and experts have already denied it.
Label: FALSE

Claim: China has announced the sucess of Egyptian serum form Dr. Hala, Ealth Miniter of Egypt, against coronavirus
Explaination: WHO says there is no known cure of vaccine to the coronavirus for now.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte orders state hospital to accept COVID-19 patients from Wuhan.
Explaination: Duterte’s speeches prior to the publication of City News’ false report have made no mention of PGH being used for Chinese patients with COVID-19. Neither have legitimate news media organizations reported on this.
Label: False

Claim: Upon approval from Supreme People’s Court, China will kill 20,000 patients with novel coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no such case being tried at the Supreme People’s Court of China. The high court’s record of scheduled hearings on its official website does not show that it was set to decide on such a case on Feb. 7, and neither is there a record of it on the resolved cases tab and press releases.
Label: False

Claim: China has announced the success of Egyptian serum form Dr. Hala, Health Minister of Egypt, against coronavirus
Explaination: WHO says there is no known cure of vaccine to the coronavirus for now.
Label: False

Claim: The map is “based on traces of Wuhan citizens,” between the outbreak of the new coronavirus and the blockade of Wuhan.
Explaination: This map is an image showing the routes of passenger aircraft around the world, and it is incorrect to use "maps based on traces of movement"
Label: False

Claim: A large amount of sulfur dioxide was observed in Wuhan because up to 14,000 bodies were incinerated.
Explaination: The source of the information is "Windy.com", but even if the body was burned, "Windy.com" does not show real-time sulfur dioxide.
Label: False

Claim: Two videos say that in Ibagué there are cases of COVID-19 and that the Colombian government is covering it up.
Explaination: In two videos of a YouTube channel it is said that in Ibagué there are cases of coronavirus and that the Colombian government is covering it up. However, this information is false.
Label: False

Claim: New confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Kolkatta reported by Press Trust of India.
Explaination: A clear case of misreporting done by PTI. There are no confirmed coronavirus patients in Kolkata/Confirmed both by the airport authority of Kolkatta and the Traveller
Label: False

Claim: High levels of sulfur dioxide in Wuhan “may be a sign of mass cremations of victims of the coronavirus.”
Explaination: The photo shows sulfur dioxide projections. It is not a real-time satellite image.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Someone from Bosnia and Herzegovina was captured on the Diamond Princess cruiser in quarantine. After testing negative for coronavirus, he returned to BiH.
Explaination: This man was not on the cruiser, was not quarantined and was not tested for the virus. He personally said all this for several media in the region, but later said that he was scammed by his friends.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking much hot water can prevent COVID-19.
Explaination: There has been no information nor evidence to suggest that drinking hot water has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Nan-shan Zhong said there is no vegetarian getting COVID-19.
Explaination: Nan-shan Zhong hasn't had such a comment. There is no evidence to support this claim, either.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows crows are flocking to Wuhan.
Explaination: This video shows crows in the Chinese city of Xining -- 1,000 miles from Wuhan.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A map shows hundreds of thousands of Wuhan residents (or even 5 million of them) traveling out of the city before the lockdown.
Explaination: The map is merely “an illustrative picture of the global air network” that shows international flight connections.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A video shows a Chinese epidemiologist saying there are millions of people infected.
Explaination: The video was longer than the version shared in Twitter. The epidemiologist said that if Chinese Government had not taken action, there would be millions of infected by coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: People in Wuhan are locked inside their houses trying to escape a building fire.
Explaination: The fire was caused due to electrical wiring failure. This video is not related to COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: The WHO declared COVID-19 is the abbreviation for China Outbreak Virus in December 2019.
Explaination: WHO declared the official name of coronavirus as COVID-19, which stands for coronavirus Disease. It has been falsely claimed to be an abbreviation for China Outbreak Virus In December 19.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows police killing COVID-19 affected people in China.
Explaination: The posted video was edited with three unrelated clips to falsely claim that Police with arms are killing people. The Yiwu Police have clarified that the armed Police in the video were on their duty to kill a rabid dog. And, the last clip is related to an accident.
Label: False

Claim: Sulfur dioxide pollution in Wuhan reveals that China is burning bodies of victims.
Explaination: The map behind the rumor is not a real-time air quality report, but a forecast based on past datas, which therefore cannot take account of alleged recent events.
Label: False

Claim: A residential building was set on fire in Wuhan to control spread of coronavirus.
Explaination: A fire broke out in a different city in China, but officials said the fire had no connection to the coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: High-rise buildings have become human incinerators to combat the spread of the coronavirus.
Explaination: There was no concrete evidence to prove that buildings were being burned to stop coronavirus. The Twitter authority cited in the story was not credible.
Label: False

Claim: This photo is a “chinese tapa”¨from a bat.
Explaination: False: The picture is not of a Chinese dish, but of a soup from Guam island (United States)
Label: False

Claim: The windy diagram of sulfur dioxide emission level over Wuhan indicated massive corpses burning there.
Explaination: Fa-lun Gong media published several news about this topic. It also was reported or cited by the other mainstream media.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus was created in a lab in Wuhan.
Explaination: No scientific evidence exists to assert that the coronavirus was created in a lab. According to the WHO, “Both Chinese and external expert groups are working in trying to identify the animal source of this new virus.”
Label: Misleading

Claim: Chicken infected from coronavirus found In Bangalore.
Explaination: Post claiming chicken infected from coronavirus found in Bangalore is fake. The image is old and is not related to 2019 novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Ginger can cure and protect you from COVID-19.
Explaination: Unable to conclude like that, even ginger may good for health, but it's no scientific proof on COVID-19 yet.
Label: False

Claim: COVID-19 was caused by 5G antennas.
Explaination: There is no proof that 5G network has anything to do with the outbreak of a novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Boiled ginger can cure COVID-19
Explaination: Doctors deny this.
Label: False

Claim: A video claims to show a plane carrying medical supplies to China.
Explaination: This video shows a plane in Kenya carrying humanitarian aid bound for China.
Label: Misleading

Claim: COVID-19 means “China Outbreak Virus.”
Explaination: It means coronavirus disease.
Label: False

Claim: Satellite images show increase in SO2 emissions around Wuhan.
Explaination: Images were actually from a weather forecast, based on historical data and meteorological conditions. No use of real-time data.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows a family killed by the coronavirus amid China’s multi-city lockdown.
Explaination: False: The video does not show a family killed by the coronavirus amid China’s multi-city lockdown. The family was reported to have died of carbon monoxide poisoning in Dec 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Weed kills the coronavirus.
Explaination: Weed doesn't kill coronavirus. Fake post getting viral.
Label: False

Claim: There is a Cuban drug used in China against the coronavirus.
Explaination: Despite the article cited by the president and the Cuban embassy in China claiming that this medicine is being used by Health Secretary in China, there are no proof about it and Interferón 2B has another uses.
Label: False

Claim: The Chinese news website Tencent filters that there are more than 24,000 deaths from coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Claims of cannibalism in China: People are cutting a baby in order to eat it.
Explaination: This actually shows an autopsy on a baby.
Label: False

Claim: This is a person with coronavirus in Calella, Barcelona (2/13/20).
Explaination: This is denied by the health authorities.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese government requests the Supreme People’s Court for permission to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients to stop the spread of the disease
Explaination: China has not sought the permission of the country's Supreme People's Court to execute 20,000 coronavirus patients.
Label: False

Claim: Bats responsible for the outbreak of coronavirus originated from the rooftop of a house in Wuhan.
Explaination: The viral video is around nine years old and is from Miami, USA.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Using cocaine kills the coronavirus
Explaination: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory. In fact, there is still no cure for the Covid-19.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Philippines has issued an order mandating a compulsory quarantine for all travelers returning from 23 countries.
Explaination: Philippine authorities did not issue this warning after the novel coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: USPS stops accepting items for China and Hong Kong
Explaination: USPS told AFP on February 12 it would continue to accept items bound for China and Hong Kong but could temporarily not offer time guarantees on those shipments; it clarified that it will temporarily halt its transit service that ships mail from other countries to China and Hong Kong.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Black people are more resistant to COVID-19.
Explaination: Dakar's Institut Pasteur denies.
Label: False

Claim: The Pinol brand of disinfectant is the solution to the coronavirus.
Explaination: COVID-19 was discovered at the end of 2019 and cleaners have not proven its effectiveness against this virus.
Label: Partially false

Claim: In Japan, Okinawa Prefecture Governor Tamaki Denny was seen Kachashi dancing with the mayor of Nanjo City. It was reported that “the governor and the mayor danced while the people were terrified about the new coronavirus infection.”
Explaination: It is true that Governor Tamaki danced Kachashi with Mayor Zukeran in January 25. But this is before a cruise ship anchored in Naha.
Label: False

Claim: In a voice note, a pilot greets from the airport of San José del Guaviare and says that he is in quarantine along with other people, between 18 and 22. They arrived in that city by plane and were diagnosed with the coronavirus.
Explaination: WhatsApp circulates an audio of an alleged pilot infected with the new coronavirus, but what he says is a lie. So far, there is no confirmed case in Colombia.
Label: False

Claim: China orders citizens to abandon/kill their pets as they can transmit coronavirus.
Explaination: Several state outlets have asked citizens not to abandon their pets. We also didn't find any local authorities ordering the killing of pets.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Police publicly kill a coronavirus-infected woman in China.
Explaination: Video on social media is not related to coronavirus. The woman in the viral video was taken into custody for violating traffic restrictions in China’s Heilongjiang province.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus epidemic will disappear in April thanks to the heat, as President Donald Trump said.
Explaination: It's impossible to predict the evolution of this epidemic, because this coronavirus is a new virus. Weather probably plays a role, but it remains to be determined among other factors.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The new coronavirus arrives in Colombia.
Explaination: The piece says the Wuhan coronavirus was found in a patient in the town of Ibagué, Colombia, and shows a written diagnosis to show it. However, the image shows it to be a different sort of coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Coronavirus cases reported in Rome, Georgia.
Explaination: The medical facility issued a statement saying there was not a confirmed case.
Label: False

Claim: Vitamin C and Omega prevent the new coronavirus.
Explaination: There isn't any food that can prevent coronavirus infection.
Label: False

Claim: “THE CHINESE HAVE BEGUN TO USE THEIR HUMAN CORPSE TO PROCESS INTO PRODUCTS SUCH AS CORNED BEEF TO SHIP TO AFRICA. Please share with your contacts. Very important”
Explaination: The video might be of Tibet or China’s Sichuan as residents of both these territories perform such rituals. However, we haven’t found the origin of this claim hence we can not emphasize whether or not visuals in this video belong to Sky Burial. But from our findings it is evident that the video is in no way related to the coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: China is seeking court’s approval to kill 20,000 people positive with coronavirus
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Chinese elderly couple infected with coronavirus says goodbye while they are in a hospital.
Explaination: The elderly couple hospitalized for other conditions such as lung cancer and respiratory failure.
Label: False

Claim: Germans quarantined in La Gomera by the coronavirus leave home isolation without permission.
Explaination: The Ministry of Health of the Canary Islands denies they have returned to Germany.
Label: False

Claim: Hand sanitizer form 2010 is labeled against COVID-19.
Explaination: The hand sanitizer marked in 2010 was against the general coronavirus. It wasn't related with the coronavirus-nCoV.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus pandemic can be dramatically slowed, or stopped, with the immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.
Explaination: Maintaining an adequate intake of vitamin C is important for staying healthy. However, evidence from clinical trials shows that regular vitamin C supplementation does not prevent viral respiratory tract infections such as the common cold, which can be caused by coronaviruses, in the general population. Although some studies have shown a reduced incidence of the common cold in individuals undergoing severe physical stress, such as marathon runners.
Label: No evidence

Claim: Putting an onion in your room can help prevent COVID-19.
Explaination: No evidence that placing onions in the room has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: China scientist Ms. Shih generated coronavirus.
Explaination: A SARS-like cluster of circulating bat coronaviruses shows potential for human emergence.
Label: False

Claim: Hold your breath for 10 seconds; if you are able to do this, you are not infected with COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no evidence to support this claim. People must have a test conducted by hospitals or legitimate labs to determine the infection with COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Miles Kwok: China military admitted that coronavirus is made by China. It is a human-made bio-weapon.
Explaination: Miles Kwok didn't mention nor suggest that COVID-19 is human-made bio-weapon.
Label: False

Claim: The  corona antivirus was discovered by Israeli and Chinese doctors.
Explaination: Remdesivir as novel coronavirus antivirus is being carried out in collaboration with various institutions, not related to specific ethnicity or religion.
Label: Misleading

Claim: COVID-19 is officially found in bats.
Explaination: The content of both The Daily Mail and Verter News did not say bats were “officially” the source of the 2019-nCoV, only that they were “likely” to be its source.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Photos show a Chinese man eating “human baby soup” have circulated on social networking platforms. He is seen sitting at a table with a stillborn baby served in front of him.
Explaination: The photos were from a performance art show by Chinese artist Zhu Yu in 2000.
Label: False

Claim: Silver Solution used on strains of coronavirus “totally eliminates it. Kills it. Deactivates it.”
Explaination: There are no pills or remedies that cure any strain of human coronavirus including COVID-19. In fact, Sellman’s "silver solution," and colloidal silver, can hurt you, and not just your wallet.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: This is how to test your lung for COVID-19 self-check.
Explaination: It's just general lung test, not a specific test for COVID-19. It's not the good way to protect yourself.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus pandemic can be dramatically slowed, or stopped, with the immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.
Explaination: Maintaining an adequate intake of vitamin C is important for staying healthy. However, evidence from clinical trials shows that regular vitamin C supplementation does not prevent viral respiratory tract infections such as the common cold, which can be caused by coronaviruses, in the general population. Although some studies have shown a reduced incidence of the common cold in individuals undergoing severe physical stress, such as marathon runners.
Label: No evidence

Claim: COVID-19 is more deadly than Ebola or HIV.
Explaination: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be false. The post’s claim that coronavirus is the most deadly disease in history is not correct. Global fatalities for HIV and Ebola are far higher, figures from the World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show.
Label: False

Claim: The Chinese supreme court OK’d euthanasia for 20,000 people.
Explaination: The article was published on a site that has regularly produced hoax reports, and China has made no such announcement.
Label: False

Claim: There are two COVID-19 cases in Libreville, Gongo.
Explaination: Authorities denied it.
Label: False

Claim: Videos state that 25,000 Chinese are being killed.
Explaination: Three different videos - 2 unrelated to the coronavirus and one with overlaid music are clubbed together with false claims.
Label: False

Claim: Raúl Rodolfo Abhuz Khan, a biochemical engineer from Karmalah laboratories, created the coronavirus.
Explaination: The Auronplay YouTube image was used in a screenshot that is being used in misinformations to "denounce" the "multi-million dollar pharmaceutical business" behind the coronavirus. First, CNN did not publish this news at any time and the man in the photo is also Raúl Álvarez (Auronplay), a famous Spanish youtuber.
Label: False

Claim: China seeks approval from the court to kill over 20,000 coronavirus patients.
Explaination: Source is not reliable and zero credible news platforms have published. There is no such a hearing in supreme court's schedule.
Label: False

Claim: People in Wuhan are locked inside their houses by the Chinese government.
Explaination: The video is of people in wuhan offering their respects to the whistleblower, doctor Li Wenliang.
Label: False

Claim: People are lying on the ground in China because they contracted the coronavirus.
Explaination: Video comes from South Africa during a initiation rite in a private school.
Label: False

Claim: Cats and dogs can be infected and can contaminate humans with COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no evidence that pets such as dogs or cats can be infected with the new coronavirus, say WHO and French medical experts.
Label: False

Claim: “Breaking: UK prepares for full lockdown after hundreds of new cases — Wuhan super virus updates.”
Explaination: Only about a dozen coronavirus cases have been confirmed in the United Kingdom.
Label: False

Claim: A Chinese pirate movie called “Coronavirus” is sold in Mexico City.
Explaination: The video is actually a 2013 South Korean film called Gamgi.
Label: False

Claim: Overseas Chinese bought flights to ship medical supplies from Melbourne to South China.
Explaination: To ship the medical supplies donated by Chinese entrepreneurs in Kenya, the Chinese airline upgraded passengers to business class and used the economic class to place all donation goods.
Label: False

Claim: In the Chinese city of Shandong, no one gets COVID-19 because it’s full of garlic.
Explaination: There is no evidence that garlic has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus. Plus, there was a confirmed case in Shandong. (Feb. 11, 2020)
Label: False

Claim: Russian doctor taught: washing the nostrils with soap can prevent COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no evidence that rinsing nostril has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus. To date, there is no specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Thailand is successfully curing coronairus patients with marijuana.
Explaination: Antiflu and anti-HIV drugs used by doctors in Thailand to treat patients with the coronavirus do not contain cannabis.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese Government requests court permission to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients.
Explaination: There is no credible source that states this claim.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows coronavirus patients and doctors.
Explaination: The original video is from South Africa, not China.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus-infected chicken has been found in Bengaluru, India.
Explaination: Viral image of sick chicken is old and not related to coronavirus.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Pets can contaminate humans.
Explaination: According to the WHO, there is no evidence that dogs or cats can be infected with the new coronavirus. French medical experts confirm that a virus crossing the species barrier is rare.
Label: Misleading

Claim: COVID-19 was stolen from Canada by Chinese spies and accidentally released in Wuhan.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Hong Kong police are misappropriating face masks for personal use.
Explaination: Photo circulating since 2018.
Label: False

Claim: This photo shows a new coronavirus case in New South Wales.
Explaination: Local authorities denied it.
Label: False

Claim: Green chiratta can prevent COVID-19.
Explaination: No scientific evidence for that.
Label: False

Claim: China officially said the new coronavirus had “confirmed aerosol infection” and that “in short, airborne infections” were spread.
Explaination: Aerosol infections are rare and different from airborne infections.
Label: False

Claim: Satellite images show high levels of sulphur dioxide above China are possible evidence of mass cremations of people who have died from coronavirus.
Explaination: False. The maps are not satellite images, and do not show actual levels of sulphur dioxide. They are simply forecasts based on historical data and weather patterns.
Label: False

Claim: Ecuadorean doctor saves lifes during the Wuhan crisis.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Special prayer is organized by the Muslim community in China to save people from coronavirus.
Explaination: Viral video has got nothing to do with the recent coronavirus outbreak
Label: Partially false

Claim: There is a case of coronavirus in Andorra.
Explaination: There is no case of coronavirus in Andorra (as of 10 of February).
Label: Misleading

Claim: A child from China has coronavirus in Galicia, Spain.
Explaination: There are no children infected with coronavirus in Spain at this date.
Label: False

Claim: Can cannabis cure coronavirus?
Explaination: The image has been created with the help of a website called dopl3r. No government mandate or science research or WHO have commented on cannabis and if it can cure coronavirus or not.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A person with coronavirus is in Andorra on 2/10/20.
Explaination: As of February 10, there is no confirmed case of coronavirus in Andorra.
Label: False

Claim: Bill Gates predicted coronavirus.
Explaination: Bill Gates didn't predict coronavirus 2019-nCoV
Label: False

Claim: In 2012, a Facebook user predicted coronavirus from China.
Explaination: The Facebook status wasn't the original one. It has been modified on the 27th of January 2020.
Label: False

Claim: India scientists found that the HIV gene is embedded in COVID-19, China’s bio-weapon.
Explaination: Uncanny similarity of unique inserts in the 2019-nCoV spike protein to HIV-1 gp120 and Gag》.
Label: False

Claim: In Singapore, Hong Kong people ran into the supermarket in a panic to buy toilet paper.
Explaination: The video was filmed in China and was already uploaded online on October 4th, 2019.
Label: False

Claim: An apartment in Wuhan went on fire after the owner over-sprayed ethanol. He turned on the heat, causing an explosion.
Explaination: The video was filmed in Chongqing, not in Wuhan.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese citizens join Muslim prayers because of a fear of coronavirus.
Explaination: The video was taken during Eid prayer at the Yiwu Mosque, China, in June 2019, before the Wuhan coronavirus outbreak occurred.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The people in this video show coronavirus patients in China.
Explaination: The video of initiation activities at a secondary school in South Africa.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Garlic water can cure novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Garlic is a healthy food that may have some antimicrobial properties. However, there is no evidence from the current outbreak that eating garlic has protected people from the new coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: A woman infected with the coronavirus was killed by Chinese police.
Explaination: The woman in the viral video was taken into custody for violating traffic restrictions in China’s Heilongjiang province.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: An Ecuadorian doctor saves lives during the Wuhan crisis.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: There is a case of coronavirus in Caserta.
Explaination: There is no case of coronavirus in Caserta (at 10 of February)
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus is caused by snakes.
Explaination: There is no conclusive proof that snakes have caused the spread of the Wuhan coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: A coronavirus-infected girl was admitted to Badulla Hospital in Sri Lanka.
Explaination: “The girl was tested negative for coronavirus, and she was administered medicines for her ailment and then discharged”.
Label: False

Claim: Ginger ale is an effective cure for the 2019 novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The World Health Organization (WHO) said drinking traditional herbal teas is “not specifically recommended as 2019-nCoV remedies as they are not effective to protect yourself and can be even harmful.”
Label: False

Claim: The Department of Health (DOH) and the Bureau of Immigration (BI) “issued a lookout bulletin” for the “arrest and detention” of a Chinese man who “escaped the quarantine area” of the Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA).
Explaination: The BI clarified in a statement that the story of the foreigner's "escape" from NAIA's quarantine area is a hoax. Further, the DOH did not issue any advisory or bulletin about a foreigner who escaped the NAIA quarantine area.
Label: False

Claim: Lysol disinfectant label says it’s tested against the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Covs a a family of viruses.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A video shows people screaming in Wuhan because they feared the coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is actually of Wuhan residents whistling and shouting to commemorate Dr. Li Wenliang, the whistleblower of the virus who died on February 7 after getting infected.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Kazakhstanis burned and smashed Chinese restaurants and homes because of the spread of coronavirus in the country.
Explaination: The video is real, but the text was misleading. There is no connections between pogroms and coronavirus. It was an ethnic conflict between Kazakhs and Dungans that arose on domestic grounds
Label: Misleading

Claim: Coronavirus has been found in broiler chicken.
Explaination: Post claiming coronavirus found in broiler chicken is fake.
Label: False

Claim: Autopsy reveals a Wuhan doctor was murdered in his sickbed.
Explaination: The story fabricates a quote and did not offer on-the-record source for its claim. It also came from a website that frequently publishes false information. Other news outlets confirmed Li Wenliang died from the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: The new coronavirus “causes sudden death syndrome.”
Explaination: There is no evidence that the virus causes sudden death syndrome.
Label: False

Claim: Dettol cleaners can kill the coronavirus.
Explaination: coronavirus in question is a type of coronavirus MERS-CoV, SARS-CoV, and Human coronavirus that refers to the common cold
Label: Misleading

Claim: In a photo of Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan and Chinese President Xi Jinping, Imran Khan is wearing a mask.
Explaination: Edited image of Imran Khan and Xi Jinping viral with wrong claim.
Label: False

Claim: Cannibalism in China has caused the outbreak of a new strain of the coronavirus. A Chinese man is preparing a dead baby for consumption.
Explaination: No, this photo shows a piece of performance art created by a Chinese artist in 2000.
Label: False

Claim: Thai department of health published an infographic on how to properly wear face masks.
Explaination: MOH denied.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows the cause of COVID-19.
Explaination: The video has circulated online since at least July 2011 and actually shows repairs being made to the roof of a bat-infested house in the city of Miami in the United States.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows COVID-19 patients in China.
Explaination: It's a school initiation in South Africa.
Label: False

Claim: The Asterix comic books and The Simpsons predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: Coronavirus has been around since the 1960s while the Simpsons picture was edited.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Tencent revealed the real number of deaths.
Explaination: We have no proof the screenshot is true. However, it seems really unlikely.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The coronavirus has already existed, even in domestic animals, and there is a vaccine to fight it.
Explaination: Wuhan coronavirus is not related to canine coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Taking chlorine dioxide helps fight coronavirus.
Explaination: Taking chlorine dioxide does not help against the coronavirus or against other diseases. It is harmful.
Label: False

Claim: China seeks court approval to kill over 20,000 coronavirus patients to stop the spread of the outbreak.
Explaination: This unsubstantiated claim came from a website that published frequently false claims. There is no evidence that China went to courts looking for such approval. Claim was also debunked by several other outlets.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited a mosque amid the coronavirus outbreak and asked the people of the Muslim community to pray about present crisis.
Explaination: Chinese President Xi Jinping’s visit to the mosque is not related to coronavirus as the viral video is almost-four-year-old.
Label: False

Claim: There is a patent for the new coronavirus.
Explaination: A post claiming that the Pirbright Institute in the UK applied for a patent for the novel coronavirus outbreak, but uses documents showing a patent from 2015 that the institute holds for avian influenza virus, which is also a coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Government of the Philippines gave out free masks on the streets.
Explaination: The government of the Philippines did donate face masks to several organizations but hadn't give face mask for free on the street at least by Feb. 7, 2020.
Label: Partially false

Claim: The WHO announced that among many medicines, the best coronavirus killer is nicotine.
Explaination: WHO hasn't published such a study nor recommendation. To date, there is no specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: A doctor said coronavirus can be alive in temperatures of 25-26C. Drinking hot water can help prevent it.
Explaination: Coronavirus can be active in temperature 25-26C. Drinking hot water does not prevent the new coronavirus disease.
Label: False

Claim: If you have a runny nose or cough, you don’t have COVID-19.
Explaination: Runny nose and dry cough are among the symptoms of COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows the Vietnam government giving out free face masks on the streets.
Explaination: The film documented the charity event organized by motorcycle group, not Vietnam government.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese president visits a mosque and says prayers about the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The video was taken in 2016, before the coronavirus was first reported in Wuhan in December 2019.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A photo shows the Biohazard Container Discovery at the American Consulate General in Wuhan.
Explaination: No news was found from the Xinhua news agency or other media related to the findings of the biohazard container.
Label: False

Claim: Weed (cannabis) cures coronavirus.
Explaination: In the absence of any evidence, the claim is found to be misleading.
Label: Misleading

Claim: China is planning to kill coronavirus patients.
Explaination: A hoax website, which has been called out multiple times by various fact-checkers for spreading fake news, has published an article without any source of information to claim that China is planning to kill over 20,000 patients who have been infected by coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Sanitizer manufacturer Dettol knew about the new coronavirus before it was reported.
Explaination: The label of Dettol mentioning that it kills coronavirus is not the recent strain of coronavirus. They have not tested its products for the recent novel coronavirus. Misleading post is getting viral.
Label: Misleading

Claim: China has sought to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients to control the spread of the virus.
Explaination: No media outlet has reported it. Also, the claim originates from a rather suspicious website.
Label: False

Claim: Tencent claims that over 24,000 patients have died in China.
Explaination: We have only proved that the screenshots can be manipulated using HTML but whether the number is actually that much and the government is hiding it is not known.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang had dinner in Wuhan during the epidemic.
Explaination: Photo taken in 2013 in Sichuan.
Label: False

Claim: The Dettol disinfectant label says COVID-19 was tested.
Explaination: COv are a family of viruses
Label: False

Claim: Research shows that parts of the HIV genetic code have been inserted into the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Researchers from India indeed claim to have found HIV genetic sequences on the novel coronavirus, and speculate that it might indicate the new virus was artificially created. Nonetheless, these genetic sequences can be found in many different viruses, including some other strains of coronavirus. The paper, which was not peer reviewed, has been debunked by a wide array of researchers.
Label: False

Claim: Xi Jinping visits a mosque for coronavirus.
Explaination: BOOM found that the video is from July 2016.
Label: False

Claim: China asks for permission to kill 20,000 infected cases.
Explaination: The website is renowned to share misinformation. There is no evidence for China asking for the same.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus has not “hit” Ghana.
Explaination: While there are reports of two suspects exhibiting symptoms of the said virus, both men tested negative. This is according to Dr Asare, the Chief Executive Officer of Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital.
Label: Misleading

Claim: President Xi Jinping visits Masjid to pray for coronavirus victims.
Explaination: 2016 video of Xi Jinping visiting a mosque is being shared in the context of the recent coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows people behaving abnormally in China due to coronavirus.
Explaination: Old video clips are shared in the context of the recent coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows bats found under the tiles of many roofs in Hubei, China, that were the source of coronavirus.
Explaination: The video was not taken in China. It’s an old video uploaded on 05 July 2011 by a Miami based roofing company called ‘Istueta Roofing’. The bats in the video were found under the tiles during the process of replacing a roof for a customer in Miami (US).
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus was created in a laboratory in Wuhan.
Explaination: There is no evidence that coronavirus was created in a laboratory in Wuhan.
Label: False

Claim: Vitamin C stops or slows novel coronavirus.
Explaination: There is, to date, no known cure for coronavirus. Medical professionals and researchers also said there was no conclusive evidence to suggest Vitamin C can treat or prevent coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: China is seeking court’s approval to kill all who tested positive with coronavirus.
Explaination: The official website of the National Health Commission of the People’s Republic of China uploaded the daily brief on coronavirus and there was no mention of any such case there
Label: False

Claim: The label on Dettol disinfectant spray claims it is proven to “kill coronavirus;” the company knew about the new strain since 2019.
Explaination: The recent outbreak of coronavirus in China is a strain named 2019-nCoV. For this particular strain, the source of infection, animal host and reservoir are currently unknown.
Label: False

Claim: Ultimo (Italian singer) has coronavirus.
Explaination: At today's date (Feb 6) in Italy we have only 2 case of coronavirus (2 Chinese citizens).
Label: False

Claim: Woman eats bat soup contaminated with coronavirus in China.
Explaination: The video was recorded on the island of Palau, Micronesia in 2016.
Label: Misleading

Claim: People infected with coronavirus die in the street while doctors travel through the infection zone.
Explaination: Both images belong to different events. The first photo corresponds to a performance in Germany and the second photo portrays two doctors who care for Ebola sufferers in Uganda.
Label: False

Claim: Share this post on Facebook, and get free face masks.
Explaination: Taiwan FactCheck Center has shared that post following the instruction but didn't get any feedback. The posts had been neither deleted or revised afterward.
Label: False

Claim: WHO calls for isolation of China due to the coronavirus.
Explaination: WHO states that they do not recommend restrictions on travel or trade with China.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows an infected baby with a doctor.
Explaination: Video uploaded on 14th of January. There was no reported case on that time. It does not fit the COVID-19 quarantina protocol.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus discovered In broiler chicken.
Explaination: Unrelated images of ailing chicken shared with the claim that coronavirus has been discovered in broilers chicken. The viral post is fake.
Label: False

Claim: A Bulgarian doctor claims that alcohol helps cure or prevent the new coronavirus.
Explaination: The only thing the WHO claims about alcohol and the coronavirus is that an alcohol-based hand sanitizer is recommended. It is a well known fact that there is no cure for the virus. There are medications that help treat the symptoms of the virus while you wait for the immune system to fight the virus, and vaccines are the best prevention.
Label: False

Claim: You can’t transmit the virus to other people if you don’t feel its symptoms.
Explaination: It's more complicated than this, and that's why the French health minister corrected its communication on this matter.
Label: False

Claim: Several posts say that coronavirus deaths are linked to 5G technology.
Explaination: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory. People die because they were infected with the virus SARS-CoV-2.
Label: FALSE

Claim: The new coronavirus can be cured with a bowl of garlic water.
Explaination: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory and there is still no cure to the Covid-19 disease.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Boiled garlic water can protect from COVID-19.
Explaination: Health experts refute false claims that drinking boiled garlic water cures novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Tinospira crispa plants can treat COVID-19.
Explaination: Philippine health experts dismiss misleading online claim that tinospora crispa plants can treat novel coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: There is a case of COVID-19 in Alberta, Canada, on 2/5/20.
Explaination: Authorities denied it.
Label: False

Claim: A case of the novel coronavirus was registered in a hospital in Maranhão, Brazil.
Explaination: It was a different type of coronavirus, HCoV-OC43, which causes regular colds.
Label: False

Claim: This is a market in China where bats and snakes were served as food.
Explaination: The market was in Indonesia.
Label: False

Claim: Doctors confirm the novel coronavirus may arrive in Brazil through AliExpress packages.
Explaination: There's no evidence for this claim. All specialists agree that it's very unlikely that a virus would survive more than a few hours outside a host, on a solid surface.
Label: False

Claim: A study is linked to coronavirus.
Explaination: The study was linked to filoviruses and had the minimal role of Wuhan's virology institute.
Label: Misleading

Claim: “Coronavirus epidemic in Poland.”
Explaination: Article has clearly misleading, false headline that is an obvious clickbait: "Prime minister has no doubts: coronavirus epidemic in Poland". In the article itself there is no claim or statement said by any of Polish officials that could justify such alarming headline.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Coronavirus has infected broiler chicken.
Explaination: We found the above circulated post to be False. There is no such confirmation that broiler chicken has been infected by coronavirus, the source of the disease is yet to found. The images in circulated are old and unrelated.
Label: False

Claim: Dettol sanitizer can kill tthe coronavirus. The company knew about the coronavirus back in 2019.
Explaination: The ‘Coronavirus’ mentioned on Dettol bottle is the previous strains of coronavirus, not the 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV). Also, Dettol manufacturer (‘RB’) has clarified that they do not yet have more details of the new virus and are not yet in a position to confirm levels of effectiveness against the new strain.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The novel coronavirus can be cured by one bowl of freshly boiled garlic.
Explaination: World Health Organization (WHO) has issued a clarification that garlic may have some antimicrobial properties but there is no evidence that it can protect people from the 2019 novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Videos show pigs being buried in China due to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The videos posted are old. They are in no way related to the recent coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Children under 8 are immune to the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Official WHO reports indicate that among infected there have been children as young as 2. Malaysian press have reported that 3 coronavirus cases in Malaysia include a 2-year-old boy. Also Australia's ABC reports: Queensland confirms third coronavirus case as eight-year-old child from Wuhan, China.
Label: False

Claim: Health Canada has advised that keeping the throat moist by drinking water can prevent infection.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence to support this. Health Canada has never suggested this method.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus is caused by bat soup.
Explaination: There is no evidence that eating bat-soup is the cause of coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Farts were recorded by infrared temperature sensors recently installed in airports and train stations to monitor temperatures of passengers amid the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The farts were added digitally.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Rinsing your mouth with salted water will prevent coronavirus infection.
Explaination: The doctor's team has debunked the chain.
Label: False

Claim: First case of coronavirus in San Vicente del Raspeig (Alicante, Spain).
Explaination: The article was not published by El País and there has been no case detected in Alicante.
Label: False

Claim: Spain’s Health Secretary advises against selling products from China.
Explaination: The Health Secretary has denied making such recommendations.
Label: False

Claim: “The Simpsons” predicted the new coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The episode of The Simpsons talked about a flu from Japan, no China. Moreover, one of the photos shared was manipulated.
Label: False

Claim: Confirmed cases of coronavirus have been found in Shaheen Bagh, Delhi.
Explaination: There have been three official cases of coronavirus in India so far. The Twitter handle's claim about the coronavirus case in Shaheen Bagh is fake and misleading.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Cow urine cures coronavirus.
Explaination: In our verification, we found several media reports, research reports, and advisories that talk about prevention and cure of the disease but there was no mention of cow urine and dung in these reports hence the claim made by the Hindu Mahasabha president Swami Chakrapani is ‘Misleading’.
Label: Misleading

Claim:
1. Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang visited a mosque and seek protection to the country from coronavirus. 
2. Chinese president Xi Jinping visited a mosque in China after realizing the fact that only Allah can save China from this epidemic.
Explaination: The first video is of former malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi who visited a mosque in China during his visit in 2015. The second video is also an old one, President Xi Jinping paid a visit to the Xincheng Mosque in Yinchuan city, capital of NW China's Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region on Tuesday, July 19, 2016.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Chinese prime minister visits a mosque following the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The man in the viral video is former Malaysian Prime Minister, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. The video was shot during his visit to China when he visited Beijing’s Nan Xia Po Mosque in July 2015.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows people in China fainting on the street after they were infected with the coronavirus
Explaination: The pictures was actually taken in 2014 in Germany during a concentration to remember holocaust victims.
Label: False

Claim: The novel coronavirus contains “pShuttle-SN” sequence, proving laboratory origin.
Explaination: The pShuttle-SN vector was designed by researchers seeking to develop a potential SARS vaccine. However, the 2019 novel coronavirus does not contain a sequence from the pShuttle-SN vector as claimed. There is no evidence supporting the claim that 2019-nCoV is man-made.
Label: False

Claim: Label on disinfectant says the new coronavirus strain is not new.
Explaination: The disinfectant can only eliminate other types of coronaviruses that are found on hard and non-porous surfaces. But it does not include the new strain 2019-nCoV
Label: False

Claim: When the first group of Japanese evacuated from Wuhan to Tokyo, each evacuee took one ambulance.
Explaination: According to the Japanese media NHK, among 206 Japanese evacuees being withdrawn from Wuhan on January 29th, 199 evacuees took seven buses, and five evacuees took ambulances to the hospital for further examination.
Label: False

Claim: There are 40,000 Chinese foreign workers in Morowali quarantined with coronavirus.
Explaination: There are only 5,390 foreign workers employed at the company.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese kill their pets due to epidemic anxiety.
Explaination: The photo of a dead dog was verified. Others not. There is no evidence that there is a massive pet killing in China.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Weed, slang for the cannabis plant, can “kill coronavirus.”
Explaination: As of Tuesday, February 18, the World Health Organization (WHO) said "there is still no specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat" the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV).
Label: False

Claim: Macedonian citizens are afraid to order from AliExpress because of coronavirus.
Explaination: According to a statement from the Post Office, the institution has received no information on further action on the coronavirus by either the Ministry of Health or the World Postal Union. And this is because the coronavirus is not transmitted by post packages. Citizens are also aware of this fact. Thus, the claim of Faktor is false.
Label: False

Claim: Sri Lanka has eradicated coronavirus.
Explaination: One patient recovered but experts said it's not enough to mention eradication.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A photo shows a Japanese medical professional providing aid in Wuhan.
Explaination: This photo has circulated in reports about a Japanese medical team travelling to China in 2008.
Label: False

Claim: 300.000 people are infected with the new coronavirus in China.
Explaination: Fewer cases according to China.
Label: Misleading

Claim: COVID-19 comes from rhino horns.
Explaination: Origin is unknown and rhino horns could not hold any virus.
Label: False

Claim: Face masks can be steamed for reuse.
Explaination: Experts warn against it.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The Chinese prime minister visited a mosque to gain protection for coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is of the then Malaysian Prime minister in 2015 visiting a mosque in Beijing.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Dettol sanitizer kills coronavirus and the company knew about the existence of the virus before the outbreak in China.
Explaination: Dettol kills older strains of coronavirus but has not tested the new strain yet. coronavirus is a family of strains infecting mammals and humans.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Broiler chickens were found to have coronavirus in Mumbai.
Explaination: Chickens have not been identified as the source for the coronavirus so far and the attached pictures are not linked to coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Pigs mulled in China are blamed for coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is from the African swine flu outbreak in China in 2018-19.
Label: False

Claim: “Kochi Prefectural Assembly, who returned from Wuhan, refused the test while it was infected with coronavirus.”
Explaination: No coronavirus infection has been confirmed in Kochi Prefecture, and no tests have been carried out.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows pigs buried alive.
Explaination: This video if from January 2019.
Label: False

Claim: A Postobon tank in Colombia was infected with coronavirus and all sodas were contaminated.
Explaination: The alleged infection of a Postobón tank is false. Both the company and the Ministry of Health denied it.
Label: False

Claim: A Sri Lankan girl finds a cure for coronavirus.
Explaination: From our investigation it is evident that any definitive cure or antibiotic for 2019-nCoV has not been discovered as yet. Therefore, the claims of the discovery of a drug that can cure Wuhan Virus are totally baseless.
Label: False

Claim: Prime Minister of China visited a mosque and realized the only protection from coronavirus is to bow before Allah.
Explaination: This Video is from an AP archive repository that was uploaded in 2015 showing ex-Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi visiting a mosque in China which is falsely being shared as Prime Minister of China visiting a mosque during coronavirus outbreak in the country. Also as per the AP repository this event took place in the year 2004.
Label: False

Claim: There is a confirmed case of coronavirus in the Macarthur Region of Australia.
Explaination: This story has not been reported by 7NEWS Sydney news, nor any other news outlets,(7News Sydney confirmed with us).
Label: False

Claim: Video shows a family that died from novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The video was found on the internet at least since the last week of December 2019. But the first death from the novel coronavirus was reported only in the second week of January 2020.
Label: False

Claim: Video of Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang visiting a mosque and offering prayers seeking protection to the country from coronavirus.
Explaination: The man in the video is not Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang, he is former Malaysian PM Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. The video was taken in 2015 and it shows Badawi visiting ‘Nan Xia Po’ Mosque in Beijing to offer his Friday prayers.
Label: False

Claim: Video from China shows people fleeing from coronavirus quarantine.
Explaination: The video footage is originally from an anti-government protest that was posted in December 2019, well before the coronavirus quarantine began.
Label: False

Claim: A case of novel coronavirus has occurred in Huelva, Spain.
Explaination: It hasn't been any case of novel coronavirus in Huelva (Spain) at 3rd of February.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A neighbor of Noia (region of Galicia, Spain) has been infected with the coronavirus.
Explaination: The picture has been doctored. La Voz de Galicia hasn't published that article and there has been no new case of coronavirus in Spain.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus is not new; there is a vaccine for dogs.
Explaination: Coronavirus is not new, but the current outbreak was caused by a type that was recently discovered.
Label: False

Claim: Photos show coronavirus is found in broiler chicken.
Explaination: The pictures are outdated and have nothing to do with the coronavirus. Pictures that went viral on social media are about sick chickens.
Label: False

Claim: Video shows bat infestation under a tiled roof, the source of coronavirus in Hubei, China.
Explaination: The viral video is eight-year-old and it is not from China.
Label: False

Claim: We made a Q&A of what we know about the videos of people fainting in the middle of the street.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: There is a person with coronavirus in Galicia on 2/4/20.
