Explaination: According to the Spanish Health Ministry, there is just one case of coronavirus in Spain until now. The image has been manipulated and La Voz de Galicia hasn't published that article.
Label: False

Claim: There is a person with coronavirus in Huelva on 2/4/20.
Explaination: According to the Spanish Health Ministry, there is just one case of coronavirus in Spain until now. The image has been manipulated and RTVE hasn't published that information.
Label: False

Claim: “It is not safe to receive a letter or a package from China.”
Explaination: According to the WHO and other experts, people receiving packages from China are not at risk of contracting.
Label: False

Claim: Dr. Zhong Nanshan said saline solution can kill the virus.
Explaination: Several Chinese media outlets debunk that fake. Moreover, experts say it is not true.
Label: False

Claim: A doctor faints during surgery on a coronavirus patient.
Explaination: The video was published in the Chinese social media WEIBO and it shows a fainting doctor during an open heart surgery. According to the post, the video was recorded in a hospital of Zhotong in Yunnan, China.
Label: False

Claim: A doctor named Leslie Chow discovered the coronavirus and died after contact with coronavirus patients.
Explaination: The portrait in the post corresponds to the American actor Ken Jeong. However, the doctor Lin Wenliang was the first to warn of the risk of coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: According to the Chinese CDC, tea can reduce the risk of contracting coronavirus.
Explaination: Chinese CDC hasn't published such a study nor recommendation. To date, there has been no information nor evidence to suggest that tea has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Study indicates that black tea and Pu’er tea can prevent coronavirus
Explaination: To date, there has been no information nor evidence to suggest that drinking tea has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: A coronavirus victim was secretly cremated.
Explaination: The photo of the pile of boxes at Tianhe International Airport in Wuhan contains protective clothing bought by the Zall Foundation to help control the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus can be transmitted through sweat from Chinese canned food factory workers.
Explaination: Transmission of the Corona Wuhan virus is only possible through close unprotected contact with sufferers, through snot or saliva splashes when sneezing and coughing.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows infected people in China.
Explaination: The photo is taken for the commemoration of holocaust victims in Frankfurt in 2014.
Label: False

Claim: Chickens cause coronavirus.
Explaination: There has been no official confirmation of a link between chicken and nCov - and no source for nCov has been found as yet. However, WHO has said that they are looking into animal sources to find the origin but there is no clarity on what the animal is.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Alibaba Group founder Jack Ma gave US$5 million to a Filipino student who developed a vaccine for novel coronavirus.
Explaination: No vaccine has been developed to stop the recently discovered virus. There are also no news reports saying Jack Ma made a special separate donation to a Filipino student in China Medical University.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows domesticated and exotic animals being sold in a wet market in Wuhan, China.
Explaination: The video currently being spread on social media is a composite of two different clips, one of Langowan Traditional Market and the other of Tomohon Traditional Market, both in Indonesia.
Label: False

Claim: Japan has sent a 1,000-man medical team to Wuhan.
Explaination: The image circulating on social media is over 11 years old, taken on May 20, 2008, of a 22-member medical team at Japan’s Narita International Airport before flying to Chengdu city in China, then been hit by an earthquake.
Label: False

Claim: This image is related to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: This image has nothing to do with coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: The novel coronavirus “will not spread” in the Philippines due to the country’s high temperature and relatively high humidity.
Explaination: In an email response to this claim, the World Health Organization (WHO) told Rappler that 2019-nCoV "has spread to countries with both hot and humid climates, as well as cold and dry."
Label: False

Claim: Israeli spy Dany Shoham claims the new coronavirus is linked to the Chinese secret program for the production of biological weapons at the Institute of Virology in Wuhan, the epicenter of the infection.
Explaination: On 29 January 2020, two credible media outlets, The Foreign Policy and The Washington Post deny the Washington Times' claims in their headlines. Foreign Policy says the Wuhan virus is not a laboratory bio-weapon, stressing that conspiracy theories are spreading faster than the coronavirus itself. The Washington Post has a similar headline, in which experts say that they have debunked the theory linking the emergence of coronavirus in China with the development of biological weapons.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus has killed 112,000 people and infected 2,800,000 in China.
Explaination: Till the time of writing this article, coronavirus had killed more than 400 people and infected over 20,000 in China.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: There is an herbal cure for COVID-19.
Explaination: Health experts in Sri Lanka say there is no evidence asafoetida or other herbal medicine can definitively protect people from infection.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A photo shows people infected with coronavirus  lying on the sidewalk in China.
Explaination: It was an artistic performance in germany in 2014.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows bats, the main source of the coronavirus, on many roofs in Hubei district.
Explaination: The video is an 8 year old video from Miami Florida and is not linked to the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: The common flu kills 60 times more people than the coronavirus every year.
Explaination: It is not right to compare common flu to coronavirus because influenza is seasonal virus, we have vaccines for it and the virus is predictable whereas while this new coronavirus exists only for few months and nobody could say exactly what is mortality rate from this virus. Even compared to current information about coronavirus fatality rate, it comes much higher (around 2-3 percent) than common flu (0.01 percent).
Label: False

Claim: 3 preliminary studies that went viral are incorrect.
Explaination: Those are 3 authentic publications, but they were either too preliminary to conclude what they were concluding, or social networks overstated their conclusions.
Label: Partially false

Claim: A viral image suggests that cocaine kills coronavirus.
Explaination: The World Health Authority has said there is no that there is currently no specific medicine to prevent or treat the new coronavirus. Moreso, relevant authorities stance is in contradiction to the viral headline.
Label: False

Claim: Two Italian scientists, named Concetta y Francesca, were the first to isolate the new coronavirus in Europe
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: There are cases of the news coronavirus in Maturín city.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: A video depicts a street market in the city of Wuhan, where the new coronavirus originated.
Explaination: "The market seen at the video in question is located in Indonesia, not in China."
Label: False

Claim: Vitamin C can “stop” the new coronavirus.
Explaination: While it’s true that vitamin C can have a marginal effect on warding off a cold, there’s no evidence that it can stop or treat the new coronavirus.
Label: (Org. doesn't apply rating)

Claim: Chlorine dioxide kits sold online under various “MMS” names — Miracle Mineral Solution, Miracle Mineral Supplement, Master Mineral Solution — will cure the coronavirus.
Explaination: MMS does not "cure" coronavirus and can be dangerous to your health.
Label: False

Claim: The new coronavirus contains HIV “insertions” and shows signs of being created in a lab.
Explaination: This stems from a poorly done study that was retracted. There is no evidence that the new virus was bioengineered, and every indication it came from an animal.
Label: False

Claim: The new coronavirus can be cured by drinking one bowl of freshly boiled garlic water.
Explaination: There is no known cure for the virus.There are no antiviral treatments that are recommended to prevent or treat the new coronavirus, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows pigs buried in China because of the coronavirus.
Explaination: The video showing the mass burial of pigs in China is unrelated with the recent Wuhan virus outbreak. The video is a year old and shows the mass burial of pigs after the outbreak of the African swine fever virus.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows a bat-infested roof in Hubei, China, claiming to be the source of the new coronavirus.
Explaination: This video dates back to 2011, which is almost 9 years ago. This video is from Miami, Florida, USA and has nothing to do with Novel coronavirus and China.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows a new hospital for coronavirus patients in China.
Explaination: The video is found to exist on the internet at least since 2018. So, the claim that it shows the new hospital set up by China for coronavirus patients is FALSE.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese politician Xi Jinping has said that Chinese scientists found a cure for the coronavirus in cow urine.
Explaination: Xi Jinping did not make the statements regarding gaumutra (Cow urine) mentioned in the post.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows coronavirus victims in China.
Explaination: The image is from Germany and it shows people lying down in a pedestrian zone, as part of an art project in Frankfurt, in remembrance of victims of the Katzbach Nazi concentration camp.
Label: False

Claim: The Korean Government took every facial mask from factories and sent them to China.
Explaination: Some sellers claimed this to consumers. However, it turns out to be false.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Bill Gates helped fund a patent for coronavirus.
Explaination: The Pirbright Institute addressed the conspiracy theories and said the patents involve infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) only, and the Gates Foundation did not fund that work.
Label: False

Claim: Scientists from Australia create the first vaccine for novel coronavirus
Explaination: This website was a scam. There is no known, widely available or public vaccine for the coronavirus. The website that was taking orders was shut down.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows a doctor fainting in the operating room after being infected with the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: Misleading

Claim: A video shows pigs buried in China because of the coronavirus.
Explaination: The claimed video is one year old when pigs were buried in large numbers after the outbreak of african swine flu.
Label: False

Claim: Garlic soup can cure the coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false as according to the WHO no treatment has yet been found for coronavirus. The search is still on.
Label: False

Claim:
More than 35 million people in China are now on a travel lockdown. More than 2700 have been sickened, and 81 have died.
Nothing happens without Allah’s permission and He is aware of all things.
Explaination: The shared image is not from China. This image was taken on 14 March 2014 in Frankfurt, Germany, where people lay down in a pedestrian zone as part of an art project in remembrance of the 528 victims of the Katzbach Nazi concentration camp.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Dettol can kill the new coronavirus.
Explaination: The company said that coronavirus cannot be eliminated by using its liquid soap. Also, the company said that we do not know about this virus and no testing has been done at the moment.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows a doctor fainting in the operating room after being infected with the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Symptoms do not show immediately and according to Chinese media he fainted because he spent 17 hours operating.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus is in Cecina, a city in Tuscany, Italy.
Explaination: At today's date (Feb 3), there are no coronavirus cases in the city of Cecina.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus is in Arezzo, a city in Tuscany, Italy.
Explaination: At today's date (Feb 3), there are no coronavirus cases in the city of Arezzo.
Label: False

Claim: 27 patients with coronavirus are in a Rome hospital.
Explaination: At today's date (Feb 3), there are no coronavirus cases at the Umberto I hospital in Rome.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The image that has been shared is not a photo of the coronavirus 2019 n-CoV. It's a graphic processing.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The new coronavirus is as dangerous as the plague and cholera.
Explaination: At today's date, we are not able to consider coronavirus 2019n-CoV as dangerous as other diseases
Label: Misleading

Claim: Scientists “are shocked to discover that weed kills coronavirus.”
Explaination: The CDC still reports that there is "currently no vaccine to prevent" and "no specific antiviral treatment recommended" for the novel coronavirus, or COVID-19.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: “The coronavirus was engineered by scientists in a lab.”
Explaination: There is no evidence that the coronavirus was created in a lab.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus contains “HIV insertions.”
Explaination: This claim is based on a study which compared extremely short protein sequences between the 2019 novel coronavirus and HIV, a practice likely to give false positives. The study’s authors also overlooked checking for potential similarities between 2019-nCoV and other organisms. As it turned out, these short protein sequences were similar to many other organisms, not just HIV, thereby refuting the claim that 2019-nCoV contains DNA from the HIV virus.
Label: False

Claim: The Wuhan coronavirus was leaked from the Wuhan P4 lab.
Explaination: The argument is based on unfounded speculation and quoted from an outdated study.
Label: Partially false

Claim: A video shows the Wuhan market.
Explaination: The video was filmed in Indonesia, not Wuhan.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows a Japanese professor who saysTaiwan doesn’t need to join the WHO.
Explaination: The man in the photo is a Japanese pornography star, Shigeo Tokuda.
Label: False

Claim: Garlic water can cure the new coronavirus.
Explaination: In the absence of any study or concrete proof, it is hard to claim that garlic water or any such home remedy can help cure coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: In a video, the Chinese prime minister offers namaz (prayer) during the coronavirus scare.
Explaination: The video was uploaded in 2015 by Associated Press and it shows the former Malaysian Prime Minister visiting Beijing’s Nan Xia Po Mosque. He took part in the Friday prayers during his five-day trip to China.
Label: False

Claim: “You’re more likely to die of influenza right now” than the 2019 coronavirus.
Explaination: Based solely on the numbers, you're more likely to die if you get the 2019 coronavirus than if you get the flu. But, as of March 10, the flu is more common in the United States than the coronavirus.
Label: HALF TRUE

Claim: Pigs are being burned alive in China to control the coronavirus.
Explaination: Viral video is around a year old and has nothing to do with coronavirus in China.
Label: False

Claim: The religious beliefs of some Macedonian citizens are being used to create panic and misinformation about the new coronavirus by citing Russian texts portraying it as the beginning of a worldwide catastrophe.
Explaination: Totalitarian and authoritarian regimes around the world, both in the past and today, have often supported the dissemination of prophecy stories that foretell disasters and conspiracy theories as a means of keeping subjects in a state of constant fear. Such stories are often republished by unprofessional media not only for ideological but, above all, commercial reasons, because they attract readers’ attention.
Label: False

Claim: A post says that WHO has adviced against unprotected sex with animals to prevent a coronavirus infection.
Explaination: The image attributed to the World Health Organization was digitally manipulated. The recommendation was never to avoid unprotected contact with wild and farm animals.
Label: FALSE

Claim: The coronavirus outbreak is the start of a depopulation program, based on links established by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: Conspiracy theory

Claim: The white side of a surgical mask should be worn on the outside, with the colored side on the inside.
Explaination: Only the coloured side of the surgical mask is to be worn outside and N95 masks are better than these normal surgical masks.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A photo shows coronavirus victims lying on the ground.
Explaination: Video is from a performance in Frankfurt in 2014
Label: False

Claim: An image shows Leslie Chow, a doctor who died in China fighting the coronavirus.
Explaination: It's actor Ken Jeong, Leslie Chow is one of his characters.
Label: False

Claim: QQ instant messaging announced the real death toll is 25,000.
Explaination: Epidemiologists say that such a high death rate is impossible at this time. Also, with the inspection tool available on most browsers, we were able to create an exact copy of the screenshot.
Label: False

Claim: WHO confirmed 50 new cases in Guayaquil, in Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: Coronavirus has been mentioned on a bottle of Dettol since October of 2019, so the company expected an outbreak.
Explaination: "The term coronavirus is an umbrella term for viruses that have specific characteristics. In the Dettol bottle we encounter the term human coronavirus in the list of microbes that this product can deal with. Human coronaviruses are 7 including the newly added 2019-nCoV, so the product did not mention the new type of human coronavirus 2019-nCoV but other members of that specific group."
Label: False

Claim: A photo caption reads: “The person in this image came with the Chinese lady who tested positive for coronavirus, fled to avoid medical tests and is reportedly hidden in the Delgoda (Sri Lanka) area.”
Explaination: The allegations are totally baseless and the photo had been taken from a profile of a person named Tharin Gunawardhana, an undergraduate student from the University of Moratuwa and a Sri Lankan national
Label: False

Claim: Scientists claim the Wuhan coronavirus is an HIV-1 engineered “super weapon.”
Explaination: The scientific research cited was not peer-reviewed, and the paper was withdrawn by the researchers to revise their results.There was also a note saying it was only a preliminary study.
Label: False

Claim: A photo of people lying in the street is accompanied by a caption implying they are coronavirus victims in China.
Explaination: The picture was taken in Frankfurt when people participated in an art protest to pay tribute to the lives lost in the Nazi concentration camps in 2014.
Label: False

Claim: Italy is the first European Union country to isolate the coronavirus.
Explaination: France was the first country.
Label: False

Claim: “When using a medical mask, you’re supposed to wear the white side out when you’re not sick.”
Explaination: Global health agencies and medical mask producers agree that the colored side of the mask should always be worn on the outside.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus arrived in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Explaination: Coronavirus has not arrived in the Balkan region, the article is about a man from Serbia who is in quarantine in India.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The WHO confirmed 50 new cases in Guayaquil, Ecuador, on 2/2/20.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: A U.S. soldier stationed in Lithuania is the first confirmed case of coronavirus in the country.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Boiled ginger can cure the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Health experts say there is no scientific evidence boiled ginger can definitively relieve people of the viral infection, and the World Health Organisation (WHO) advised those showing symptoms to seek immediate medical help, instead of testing home remedies.
Label: Misleading

Claim: “How to prevent the coronavirus (…) Drink fennel tea twice a day. Fennel tea has the same component as Tamiflu medicine, used to treat H1N1”.
Explaination: Fennel tea doesn't has the same component as Tamiflu and Tamiflu is not recommended by WHO to treat the new coronavirus.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Garlic water prevents the novel coronavirus, according to a Chinese doctor.
Explaination: The WHO has not prescribed any methods, there is no link with the recent coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: The Taiwanese flag is printed on masks to prevent the Chinese from buying them.
Explaination: Production of the mask with the national flag started at the latest in 2019. There is no relationship with this coronavirus. Posts posted as "jokes" on Taiwanese Internet bulletin boards have spread.
Label: False

Claim: “Scientists found similar sequences in the coronavirus as in HIV.”
Explaination: There is some similarity between the new coronavirus and the proteins of HIV, this is only accidental, saying that "similar sequences can be found in many organisms."
Label: False

Claim: Biohazard containers found at US consulate in Wuhan
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Charles Lieber, a Harvard University professor who was arrested, had a connection to the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Lieber, a nanoscientist, was charged for lying about his participation in a Chinese recruitment program and his affiliation with a Chinese university. He is not accused of being a spy and has no connection to the new coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A photo shows dead people on the streets of China.
Explaination: The picture was taken in 2014 in Frankfurt, Germany as a tribute to the victims who lost their lives in a Nazi concentration camp. This image has nothing to do with coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Facts about coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: An FAQ on the recent coronavirus outbreak.
Label: Explanatory

Claim: A video caption said: “Doctor affected by the virus in a hospital in Wuhan, China.”
Explaination: Prior instances of the video had captions, confirmed by media reports, said the video showed a doctor collapsing in Yunnan province because of overwork and hypoglycemia.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows the newly built hospital in Wuhan.
Explaination: The viral image was taken from an online listing and is actually a modular apartment building.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The coronavirus is “a military bio-weapon developed by China’s Army.”
Explaination: There is no evidence that the Chinese military developed the 2019 coronavirus as a bioweapon.
Label: False

Claim: The novel coronavirus is not a new virus.
Explaination: Many coronavirus strains have already been discovered, but new strains regularly emerge due to mutations. The particular coronavirus responsible for the outbreak originating in Wuhan, China, provisionally named 2019-nCoV, is a new strain that was identified by scientists after sequencing its genome.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus can be transmitted through free Fire Game and Xiaomi mobile phones.
Explaination: The 2019-nCoV virus cannot be transmitted through inanimate matter. To survive, the virus needs a host or cell that is also still alive.
Label: Misleading

Claim: There are 5 coronavirus Suspect Patients in Indonesia, one of whom died.
Explaination: Video of a simulation activity of handling the Wuhan coronavirus at RSUP Dr. Kariadi, Semarang on January 30, 2020 ago.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A coronavirus case was confirmed in the Istanbul Medical School Hospital.
Explaination: A patient was isolated in the hospital on inspection but not diagnosis. There is no confirmed case by now in Turkey.
Label: False

Claim: The Gates Foundation was the real agent behind the pandemic.
Explaination: The simulation Gates Foundation funded was based on another coronavirus in the same family.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows a doctor falling down because of the coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is old. The doctor in the video was on the floor because some of the patient relatives punched him on the face.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows a medical team of 1,000 sent by Japan to Wuhan.
Explaination: The photo was taken way back in May 2008. The medical team came from Japan to help China after the devastating Sichuan earthquake that year.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus responsible for COVID-19 is a mix of SARS and HIV.
Explaination: If the symptoms of COVID-19 are partly similar with both diseases, the virus itself doesn't looks like a mix of HIV and SRAS.
Label: False

Claim: Punjab authorities have advised citizens not to eat goat meat for 60 days.
Explaination: China coronavirus: Pakistani officials deny they issued warning over dangers of eating goat meat.
Label: False

Claim: Singapore closed a subway station after a case of COVID-19.
Explaination: Authorities denied.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese spies stole the coronavirus from a Canadian lab.
Explaination: Mix up with an investigation of Chinese scientist in Canada in 2019.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows a new hospital in Wuhan.
Explaination: This is the Tangiers hospital in Algeria.
Label: False

Claim: Fennel tea can cure the coronavirus.
Explaination: Doctors are not saying that.
Label: False

Claim: A photo shows corpses strewn about in China due to the coronavirus.
Explaination: The image is from Frankfurt, Germany from 2014 where people lay down in a pedestrian zone as part of an art project in remembrance of the 528 victims of the "Katzback" Nazi concentration camp.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus is a “virus weapon” as lethal as Ebola. Everyone who is infected dies.
Explaination: The Washington Times article does not provide any evidence. According to the CDC, the source of the new coronavirus is currently likely to be wildlife. The mortality rate is currently 2-3%. Most of the dead are elderly people or those with underlying illnesses such as diabetes.
Label: False

Claim: A video showing where “the coronavirus began” was made in Wuhan.
Explaination: Video taken in Langowan, Indonesia.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus “arrived” in Cúcuta, Colombia.
Explaination: A column meant to be satirical did not explain this aim and many readers believed that there were confirmed cases of coronavirus in Cúcuta, Colombia's largest city in the border with Venezuela.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus is unknown and kills in seconds.
Explaination: The coronavirus is not unknown nor does it kill ‘under a few seconds.’ The WHO says the virus is part of a family of viruses that includes Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS-CoV) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS-CoV). Also, fatality and severity of the disease may be determined by age and other pre-existing health conditions.
Label: False

Claim: A bowl of garlic cures “Wuhan’s coronavirus.”
Explaination: Health authorities have not recommended any particular drug for coronavirus. So, suggesting an alternative medical practice(s) such as eating a bowl of boiled garlic water is questionable.
Label: False

Claim: A dry throat make you more vulnerable to be infected by coronavirus.
Explaination: Already fact-checked by Maldita.es, but they found it said Spain instead of Canada.
Label: Fake

Claim: The coronavirus 2019-nCoV was patented in the past and is human-made, a project in which the Bill and Melinda Gates foundation is involved.
Explaination: "The patent mentioned in the articles in question is about the development of a vaccine for the IBV virus which belongs in a sub-family of the wider category of viruses termed coronaviruses. In short the patent was not for the coronavirus 2019-nCoV."
Label: Misinformation / Conspiracy theory

Claim: Photos show part of Huoshenshan Hospital in Wuhan, built in five days.
Explaination: "The building in the pictures that were circulated in social media is the medical center Dabie Mountain which was restructured in order to respond to the coronavirus patients in a short period of time. It is located in the town Huanggang, 75 kilometers away from Wuham."
Label: False

Claim: The director of a major hospital in São Paulo, Brazil, has recommended drinking fennel tea and eating bull’s liver as ways of prevention against COVID-19.
Explaination: The recommendations made on the text do not follow WHO's pattern and include a false information about the medicine Tamiflu. Furthermore, the hospital said its board of directors didn't do any alert of the kind.
Label: False

Claim: China builds a hospital for coronavirus patients in 48 hours.
Explaination: Our fact check reveals that the newly opened hospital is an extended wing of Huanggang Central Hospital, scheduled to open in May 2020. A dedicated work force made the empty building into a fully operational hospital within two days, which was mistaken as the Huoshenshan Hospital proposed to be constructed in 6 days. Huoshenshan hospital is still under construction and is expected to open to the patients on 3rd day of February.
Label: False

Claim: A video of an Indonesian traditional market is being used to depict Wuhan, China.
Explaination: an old video from Indonesia shot in July 2019 is being falsely shared as a Market in Wuhan, China which was the origin of the coronavirus. This video has nothing to do with the coronavirus or its place of origin.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus is enabled by 5G technology.
Explaination: There is no scientific proof that coronavirus is in any way linked to 5G.
Label: False

Claim: franceinfo hosted a chat with a scientist in order to answer questions about the coronavirus, including fake news
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: Explanatory

Claim: Scientists and experts answer questions and rumors about the coronavirus (bat soup, Wuhan P4 Laboratory, patented virus, people collapsing, etc).
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: A container of soda in Colombia was infected with the coronavirus.
Explaination: There was no contamination. There is no evidence of coronavirus in the country or of its ability to contaminate soda drinks.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus was called a “plague” by the WHO; 2.9 million were infected and 950,680 died.
Explaination: A global emergency was declared by WHO. To date, 213 people had died as a result of the coronavirus and another 9,800 cases had been confirmed in mainland China, according to reports, while cases had been discovered in more than a dozen countries worldwide.
Label: False

Claim: “2019-nCoV is old and there is already a cure to it”
Explaination: Although human coronavirus was first discovered in the 60s, the current 2019-nCoV outbreak was first identified recently.
Label: False

Claim: Over 1,500 people have died from the new coronavirus (Jan. 31)
Explaination: As of January 31, the coronavirus death toll is 213.
Label: False

Claim: A video shows a market in the Chinese city of Wuhan, where the deadly coronavirus strain emerged.
Explaination: The video actually shows a market in Indonesia’s Sulawesi island.
Label: False

Claim: The Canadian Department of Health issues an emergency notification asking people to drink warm water.
Explaination: The notification was not issued by the Department of Health of Canada.
Label: False

Claim: China builds a hospital for coronavirus patients in 48 hours.
Explaination: The building has been in construction since 2018. What China has done is accomodate the building with 1.000 beds for coronavirus patients
Label: False

Claim: An institute funded by Bill Gates will contribute to 65 million deaths in the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The work that Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation does on healthcare has in no way contributed to the spread of coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: There is a link between the COVID-19 and irregular migration.
Explaination: There is no direct connection between the spread of Coronavirus 2019-nCoV and the irregular migration in the Mediterranean sea.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A team of medical trainees from JKUAT (a university in Kenya) have developed and tested a vaccine successfully.
Explaination: The university that the students allegedly attended has denied the claim. Additionally, a doctor contacted by PesaCheck has indicated that a vaccine cannot be developed within a month. An Australian lab is in the initial stages of developing a vaccine by recreating the virus.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus isn’t new because “Lysol has it listed as one of the viruses it kills.”
Explaination: Lysol says some of its surface cleaning products, including its disinfectant spray, have been effective against viruses “similar to” 2019 Novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus was created in a lab in order to destroy the Chinese economy. A vaccine is already available.
Explaination: Claims that the "mutation of the virus corona was caused artificially in the laboratory" and that it was a "biological war" and that the virus was "released to weaken the Chinese economy" are rated as conspiracy theories because there is no evidence or argument for them.
Label: False

Claim: Environmental enzymes can prevent COVID-19. Use them to wash vegetables, wash your mouth, nostrils and hands.
Explaination: Post is a commercial ad with false health information.
Label: False

Claim: Dr. Kuo Yen-Jen of Taiwan suggested smearing sesame oil into the nostril can prevent flu and COVID-19.
Explaination: There is no evidence that smearing sesame oil into the nostril has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus. To date, there is no specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: People who have ACE2, especially those with hypertension, are easily infected with COVID-19.
Explaination: The post is a commercial ad with false health information.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus was discovered by Ali Mohamed Zaki in 2012.
Explaination: The coronavirus discovered by Zaki is the MERS-CoV type, not the 2019-nCoV type. The Corona 2019-nCoV virus was first reported in Wuhan, China, not in Saudi Arabia.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A photo shows coronavirus victims lying in the streets in China.
Explaination: The photo is an art project created in Frankfurt, Germany, on March 24, 2014 to commemorate the victims of one of the Nazi concentration camps, Katzbach.
Label: False

Claim: A video indicates one case of the coronavirus infects another 14 people.
Explaination: It's not clear that the girl in the video indicates R0. But, by now, the R0 value is quite lower than the claim according to WHO
Label: False

Claim: The novel coronavirus was made in a lab and is now spread as a way to force vaccinate people.
Explaination: The claim has been fact checked by several IFCN-members who all have reached the same conclusion. The mentioned patent concerns SARS.
Label: FALSE

Claim: The “proper” way to wear a surgical mask is blue side out if you are sick and white side out if you do not want to be infected by the virus.
Explaination: The World Health Organization, the Philippine Red Cross, the country's Department of Health, San Francisco’s Department of Public Health: Disease Prevention and Control, and the Hong Kong government are all one in saying there is only one way to wear surgical masks: have the blue color on the outside and the white on the inside.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus outbreak attributed to an advisory from India’s Health Ministry.
Explaination: The viral notification post on coronavirus outbreak is falsely attributed to Health Ministry.
Label: False

Claim: Corpses of coronavirus victims are scattered on a street in Wuhan, China.
Explaination: The photo was taken on March 24, 2014, depicting people who lied down on a pedestrian zone for an art project remembering the Katzbach Nazi concentration camp victims.
Label: False

Claim: Doctors recommend Vitamin C and fennel seed tea to warn off the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Authors of a tabletop exercise in Oct 2019 predicted that Wuhan coronavirus might kill 65 million people.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: Misleading

Claim: A Facebook meme claims that COVID-19 is the latest in a once-every-100-years pattern of pandemics.
Explaination: Disposable or homemade fabric face masks do not fully protect against viruses.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Video of Wuhan market where the new coronavirus started to spread.
Explaination: Video is not from China, but from Indonesia.
Label: False

Claim: Photo of several people lying on the ground in the middle of the street, allegedly in China.
Explaination: Photo from Frankfurt, Germany, 2014.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese pet owners are killing their cats and dogs by throwing them out of the window, in fear of their pets spreading the coronavirus. This comes after memos were issued by authorities for pet owners to get rid of their animals.
Explaination: The pet killings happened within the context of the Chinese local authorities issuing REAL memos that ordered citizens to get rid of their pets and the dissemination of the misinformation about the transmission of the coronavirus 2019-nCoV, but we cannot affirm that the motivation of the owners of the animals has been related to the disease outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: The Canadian Department of Health issued an emergency notification recommending that people keep their throats moist to protect from the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The bulletin is false and there is no scientific evidence that shows that drinking water prevents against coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: 4,600 Chinese arrived to Hakata Port, in Japan.
Explaination: According to Hakata-city, this information is misleading.
Label: Misleading

Claim: “Tokyo Olympic Games 2020 will be canceled because of coronavirus.”
Explaination: According to The Tokyo Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, this information is false.
Label: Misleading

Claim: In Japan, “It’s the Democratic party’s fault that health insurance system is abused by foreigners”
Explaination: According to Japan Tourism Agency, this information is false.
Label: False

Claim: It’s not a virus but 5G that is causing disease and deaths
Explaination: The deaths from COVID-19 had nothing to do with 5G.
Label: False

Claim: Gates Foundation has funded the development of the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Article was based on manipulative connection of facts concerning the Gates Foundation and Pirbright Institute which resulted in misleading context and ultimately, disinformative article.
Label: False

Claim: The Canadian Ministry of Health issued a press release indicating the states in which they are taking security measures to combat the coronavirus 2019-nCoV.
Explaination: "The Canadian Health Ministry didn't issues such a statement and the security measures mentioned are incorrect."
Label: False

Claim: We did a Q&A on the facts about the coronavirus.
Explaination: Q&A on the facts about the coronavirus
Label: (Org. doesn't apply rating)

Claim: Manir Hossain, a 23-year-old man from India’s Tripura, died in a hospital in Malaysia due to the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Upon our investigation, we found the above news reports to be False. An Indian citizen from Tripura did not die due to coronavirus in Malaysia. The reason for his death is Status Epilepticus Secondary Meningoencephalitis.
Label: False

Claim: Mélange Of Unrelated Videos From China Shared Misleadingly In Context To Recent Corona Virus Outbreak.
Explaination: A mix of different unrelated videos from China have been merged to create this misleading video shared in context to coronavirus. People infected by coronavirus 2019-nCoV, do not exhibit the symptoms such as howling like dogs and biting as shown in the video.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Two ways of wearing a surgical mask: Colored side out if you are sick and white side out if you do not want to become sick.
Explaination: There is only one way of wearing a three-layered surgical mask. The colored side of the surgical mask should face outwards.
Label: False

Claim: “Some Japanese people infected with the novel coronavirus were refused from a charter flight from Wuhan to Tokyo (on Jan.30) without any Japanese legal basis.”
Explaination: It is true that two Japanese people who may have been infected could not take a charter flight. They were not permitted to go through the Chinese immigration office because they were stuck at the quarantine station by Chinese medical staff. Japan didn't refuse them.
Label: FALSE

Claim: According to a certain document, there are infected cases in some areas of South Korea, but the Korean government is hiding the cases. (Jan. 30)
Explaination: The documents are confirmed as crafted documents. These case are under investigation by Korean police.
Label: Misleading

Claim: According to a certain document, there are infected cases in some areas of South Korea, but the Korean government is hiding the cases.
Explaination: The documents are confirmed as crafted documents. These case are under investigation by Korean police.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The Chinese government announced on official document “Garlic is a preventive food for Novel coronavirus.”
Explaination: The official document is not from China's central government. It's from Shanghai city government. On this original document, there is no mention about garlic or preventive food.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Novel coronavirus is commuicated by package or imported goods shipping from China to Korea.
Explaination: Currently there is no evidence to support transmission of novel coronavirus by imported goods. Also there have not been such cases in Korea.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Romania developed a coronavirus vaccine able to cure white people only.
Explaination: There is no known cure for the coronavirus. This is a hoax.
Label: False

Claim: Video of a woman eating bat soup and its relation with the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: There is yet no confirmation regarding the exact cause of the outbreak. Also, the video was filmed in Palau in 2016, so there is no relation with the current coronavirus in China.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Video shows a plate of bat soup that allegedly started the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: There is yet no confirmation regarding the exact cause of the outbreak, although some scientists agree that bats can be (and have been in other occasions) carriers of coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Five foods that help you avoid the coronavirus
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus has killed over 10,000 people (Jan. 30)
Explaination: The latest report from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control says there are currently 170 people who died.
Label: False

Claim: The biological research laboratory Ruilan Bao Hu San Biotech Limited in Shanghai, the city where #coronarvirus originated, has a logo like that of the Umbrella Corporation of RESIDENT EVIL and corona is an anagram for Racoon. WTF
Explaination: There are no proofs of the relation between the Chinese company RLSW and coronavirus, neither that Shanghai is the place where it all started. Moreover the anagram of the word "corona" is not the same as Raccoon, the name of the city where takes place the video game Resident Evil.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Video shows a parasite being removed for someone’s lips, sharing it in relation with coronavirus.
Explaination: The video was uploaded on YouTube on October 24, 2019 with the title “Amazing Botfly Removal on Lips”.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A video of a girl collapsing in a store because she was affected by coronavirus.
Explaination: Incident is from Malaysia and the girl has been identified as Nur Izzah Izzati. Malaysia’s Health Ministry also confirmed that the claim attached with the video is fake.
Label: False

Claim: Spanish Health Department has released a notification about the new coronavirus.
Explaination: The Spanish health department did not issue that notification.
Label: False

Claim: WHO advises to avoid “unprotected sex” with animals.
Explaination: It is a manipulated imagen, WHO confirmed.
Label: False

Claim: Video of a doctor fainted on the floor after getting infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: The doctor was in the floor because the family of the patient punched him after he was not able to save him after he had a heart attack.
Label: False

Claim: “Cocaine kills coronavirus, scientists are shocked to discover that this drug can fight the virus.”
Explaination: This “breaking news” image is from an online news generator and not based on any real news coverage.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: Coronavirus has arrived in the Balkan region. (Jan. 30)
Explaination: A Serbian citizen has indeed been quarantined because suspicion of being infected with the 2019-nCoV virus, but he is quarantined in India, not in Serbia.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The Simpsons predicted the new coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: Simpsons did not predicted coronavirus, the episod was talkin about "osaka flu". Image was also photoshopped.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus hits a 15% fatality rate.
Explaination: The 15% fatality rate from coronavirus (2019-nCoV) applied only to the initial cluster of 41 patients with confirmed infection and severe symptoms, as reported in The Lancet. coronavirus infections can also produce mild symptoms, which likely went undetected. The mortality rate based on a group of more than 800 patients with laboratory-confirmed infection suggests that the fatality rate is closer to 3%.
Label: False

Claim: A person with COVID-19 died in a hospital in Taiwan. His body was burned on 1/26. (Jan. 30)
Explaination: As to Jan. 30., the alleged hospital didn't have a novel coronavirus confirmed case, according to the health authority as well as the hospital.
Label: False

Claim: Strong garlic soup can cure the “Wuhan Virus”.
Explaination: There is no evidence that garlic soup cures new coronavirus (COVID-19). To date, there is no specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat COVID-19.
Label: False

Claim: Don’t wear clothes with fur collar or fleece material. It is easy to be contaminated by the “Wuhan Virus”.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence.
Label: False

Claim: Bats are hidden in every households’ rooftop in Wuhan.
Explaination: The film was filmed in Indonesia, not Wuhan.
Label: False

Claim: Wuhan coronavirus is a cross between the bat virus and the pig virus
Explaination: The current analysis indicate that there is no pig element in the virus. The Wuhan coronavirus originated mostly from SARS and bats, not from pigs.
Label: False

Claim: A video that shows a market in Wuhan, China
Explaination: The wildlife market in the video is not the Wuhan Market in China, but the Langowan Market in Indonesia.
Label: False

Claim: China constructed an hospital for the epidemic in 48 hours.
Explaination: The construction started in 2018 and it can be seen on Baidu maps.
Label: False

Claim: A coronavirus case was diagnosed in Atasehir hospital, Istanbul (Jan. 30)
Explaination: The announcement was put on the entrance of the emergency service just in case. But the Facebook post indicates the diagnosis. There is no diagnosed case at this date in Turkey.
Label: False

Claim: A bowl of freshly boiled garlic water can cure the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV)
Explaination: The World Health Organization (WHO) said that while eating garlic is healthy, it is not proven to protect humans against 2019-nCoV.
Label: False

Claim: Philippines’ “local mainstream media” reported that the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) has a low mortality rate.
Explaination: The media has reported on the low fatality rate of 2019-nCoV.
Label: False

Claim: Video of “the market of terror, where the coronavirus originated”.
Explaination: The video was transmitted by most of the Macedonian media, although it is false. The truth is that this video is not of a market in Wuhan, nor anywhere in China, but it is of a market in Indonesia. When you play the video you can see the name of the market in large letters, i.e. Pasar Estream Langowan, and when you search, if you do not know where Langowan is, you will find out that it is in Indonesia, not in China. The falseness of this video was also noted by the AFP FactCheck and Faktly.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 is a weapon developed in a chinese lab.
Explaination: The rumors mix false and true information, but give no evidence its claim would be correct.
Label: Conspiracy theory

Claim: People lying in the street in China because of the new coronavirus.
Explaination: It was an artistic performance in 2014 in Germany.
Label: False

Claim: All the soldiers in South Korea cannot go on leave because of the novel coronavirus(2019-nCoV) outbreak.
Explaination: South Korea's ministry of national defense said, "The restrictions on all soldiers are not true at all. However, we only partially limited the area where there were confirmed cases."
Label: Misleading

Claim: The Chinese government announced that “garlic is a preventative food for the the novel coronavirus.”
Explaination: The official document is not from China's central government. It's from Shanghai city government. On this original document, there is no mention about garlic or preventive food.
Label: False

Claim: Novel coronavirus can be transmited by packages and/or imported goods shipped from China to Korea.
Explaination: Currently there is no evidence to support transmission of novel coronavirus by imported goods. Also there have not been such cases in Korea.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus was made in a lab, with pre existing patents for a vaccine. The Bill and Melinda Gates foundation is involved in spreading the coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Picture of the first new Wuhan coronavirus hospital.
Explaination: This is a stock picture of a modular construction from a Chinese import-export company.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A man collapses in a staircase because of the CoV.
Explaination: The authorities and building management said he fainted for other reasons.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The Chinese company Ruilan Bao Hu San Biotech Limited is the origin of the novel coronavirus. Its logo resemble the Umbrella Corporation, from the video game Resident Evil.
Explaination: The company is based in Shanghai, 840 km away from Wuhan. Virus origin still unknown.
Label: False

Claim: WHO advises population to avoid having unprotected sex with animals.
Explaination: Posts presented an edited version of an image posted by WHO on Twitter in January 27. In the original publication, the organization advised people to avoid contact with wild and farm animals.
Label: False

Claim: Doctors recommend vitamin C and fennel seed tea to help avoid the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence to support the claim that vitamin C or fennel seed tea are effective in the treatment or prevention of the novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Vitamin C with zinc prevent and treat the coronavirus infection.
Explaination: According to WHO, there is still no remedy to treat the 2019-nCoV virus and preventive measures include washing your hands frequently and avoiding contact with infected people, not taking vitamin C with zinc.
Label: False

Claim: Government of India recommends homeopathy and other alternative medicines for preventing coronavirus.
Explaination: THe World Health Organization has stated that there are no proved preventions and treatments for this virus. The mechanisms mentioned by the AYUSH ministry are not scientifically proven to help in tackling coronaviruses.
Label: Misleading

Claim: This video shows a seafood market in Wuhan, China.
Explaination: This video is of the Langowan market in Indonesia and not of the Wuhan seafood market.
Label: False

Claim: Video of a girl dying of coronavirus in a shopping mall.
Explaination: The video is from Malaysia where the girl died due to a heart failure and not coronavirus. BOOM corroborated the theory with a family member of the deceased
Label: False

Claim: Chinese people rush to Japan to abuse Japanese health insurance system.
Explaination: According to Ministry of Health, this information is mostly false.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: A tweet entitled “Risk of novel coronavirus and countermeasures” saying “The virus stays alive for 48 hours.” “The clothes need to be disinfected with alcohol and goggles to prevent corneal infection.” “Die without fever.”
Explaination: According to the Virology Expert; Inactivation will not take 48 hours. No cases have been reported of death without fever. It is difficult to completely disinfect outerwear with alcohol. Goggles are not generally needed. Not an artificial virus.
Label: FALSE

Claim: The first patient diagnosed in Ecuador with COVID-19 died. (Jan. 29)
Explaination: The patient was still alive.
Label: False

Claim: Person infected with coronavirus bit a doctor’s jugular.
Explaination: The fake news was a reproduction of a Twitter post allegedly from brazilian media outlet O Globo. In fact, the news media did not post no news of that kind.
Label: False

Claim: The article includes a compilation of different false claims and manipulative photos: 1) false claim saying that there was identified infected person in Georgia, 2) false claim about banana being a source of spread of coronavirus, 3) false claim saying that chinese passengers getting fever medication, 4) false claim about Georgian doctors refusing to screen passengers on the coronavirus in the airport
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: Fake news

Claim: Ministry of health’s emergency notified the public about the new coronavirus outbreak. (Jan. 29)
Explaination: The advisory message has not been issued by the Health Ministry. Also, in the precautions released by the Ministry, there is nothing related to keeping the throat moist.
Label: False

Claim: Video of a girl dying of coronavirus.
Explaination: The girl in the video has not died due to coronavirus. The family of the girl and the Malaysian Health Ministry have confirmed that the rumours about the girl’s death are FALSE.
Label: False

Claim: Video of a market in Wuhan (China), the suspected origin of the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The video was taken at an animal market in Langowan (Indonesia). It is not related to Wuhan (China).
Label: False

Claim: Statistics are predicting millions of dead people and billions of infected people in a few days.
Explaination: There is no modelization of the virus yet. So it's impossible to predict anything about the epidemic.
Label: Misleading

Claim: “Japan has sent many masks to Wuhan, China. But China hasn’t supported Japan ever before.”
Explaination: China sent their rescue team and many goods at Great East Japan earthquake (2011), donated a lot of money to Japan at the 2016 Kumamoto Earthquake, and the Heavy Rain of July, 2018.
Label: False

Claim: A team from @WorldPopProject has heat mapped the highest risk counties for the #Wuhancoronavirus. “Japan is the second country in the list because Abe’s administration doesn’t enforce immigration restrictions.”
Explaination: The ranking is based on Lunar New Year travel prior to the holiday in 2018. This report does not refer to any countries immigration restrictions in this year. Japan has the second highest risk country but it's not related to the immigration policy.
Label: False

Claim: The Korean Government pay travellers’ medical expense for coronavirus without legal basis.
Explaination: According to IHR 2005, government is responsible for paying medical treatment expense to travellers. Accordingly, related Act also defines it.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Coronavirus is in Des Moines. (Jan. 29)
Explaination: The story came from a prank website where it got over 9000 Facebook engagements
Label: False

Claim: Scripps urgent care in San Diego is on lockdown, two people with the new coronavirus are isolated.
Explaination: Scripps denied it was true through their Twitter account, there was one person with the flu but no coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Bill Gates patented the coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: No evidence

Claim: A video taken in Wuhan (China), where the coronavirus outbreak started.
Explaination: This is not a video from Wuhan (China), is a video from Indonesia recorded in July 2019.
Label: False

Claim: The WHO has recommended to avoid unprotected sex with live wild or farm animals
Explaination: It is a manipulated image of a real advice image from the WHO.
Label: False

Claim: Emergency notification issued by the Spanish Health Ministry about coronavirus
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus killed 10,000 people in Wuhan.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article.
Label: False

Claim: China constructed a hospital for the new coronavirus in 48 hours.
Country: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia, Croatia, Montenegro
Explaination: The building has been in construction since 2018. What China has done is accomodate the building with 1.000 beds for coronavirus patients.
Label: False

Claim: The Umbrella Corporation, from the video game Resident Evil, is linked to the Chinese company RLSW.
Explaination: The Chinese company RLSW is engaged in genetic testing and advanced scientific research. However, the address on Google Maps could not be corroborated and the official site does not offer much information.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Posts saying that, for several centuries, there have been pandemics in the 20’s.
Explaination: The information in the post are inaccurate because de pandemics mentioned in the posts occurred years before of years after the 20's of those centuries.
Label: Partially false

Claim: A person died of hematemesis in Beitou. He was then diagnosed with 2019n-Cov. Wear a mask in Taipei.
Explaination: There was no death case in Taiwan (1/28/2020).
Label: False

Claim: Chinese panic video over coronavirus.
Explaination: The video shows that Yulin residents working in Guangdong returned to their hometown to celebrate the spring festival.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Prevent coronavirus by drinking warm water.
Explaination: The message did not come from the Indonesian Ministry of Health. And there is no research that supports that drinking warm water can prevent transmission of the virus.
Label: False

Claim: Death toll in Wuhan due to coronavirus reaches 10,000 people
Explaination: Death toll from the 2019-nCoV virus in China reached 132 people at the time of publication.
Label: False

Claim: The virus is entirely different from all the known virus forms. It activates all bacterias and other viruses in human body.
Explaination: The nCOV virus is genetically related with the other coronaviruses detected before. All infections can activate other infections in humans. In this epidemic only four case reported as secondary infections.
Label: False

Claim: The virus is entirely different all the known virus forms. It activates all bacterias and other viruses in human body.
Explaination: The nCOV virus is genetically related with the other coronaviruses detected before. All infections can activate other infections in humans. In this epidemic only four case reported as secondary infections.
Label: FALSE

Claim: The Simpsons predicted the epidemic.
Explaination: Osaka flu came from Japan in the related Simpsons episode with a package, not from China.
Label: False

Claim: The movie Venom predicted the epidemic.
Explaination: The movie is not based on an epidemic at all. The character is not infected after eating snake in a marketplace and attack people.
Label: False

Claim: This is the picture of the first new Wuhan coronavirus hospital.
Explaination: This is a stock picture of a modular construction from a Chinese import-export company.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A photograph that shows people on the floor demonstrates the impact of the new coronavirus in China.
Explaination: The claim along with the photo is false and it is in no way related to the outbreak of coronavirus. It is actually an old photo from Germany dated to 2014. Moreover, the people in the photo are not dead, but were lying down on the road as part of an art project.
Label: False

Claim: MMS can be very effective in both preventing and eradicating the coronavirus.
Explaination: There is still no cure for COVID-19, and health authorities have warned that MMS is dangerous to health.
Label: False

Claim: There is a “positive” case of the novel coronavirus (nCoV) in a hospital in Banlic, Cabuyao City, Laguna, Philippines in January 2020.
Explaination: There was no coronavirus case at the Global Medical Center of Laguna around the time the claim was spread.
Label: False

Claim: Bill Gates predicted and simulated the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explaination: Bill Gates' foundation worked on the possibility that a coronavirus could spread and be responsible of a pandemia. It can't be taken as a prediction because multiple coronavirus have been known for decades. It didn't foresee the current pandemia.
Label: False

Claim: Bats and snakes are responsible of the spread of SARS-CoV-2
Explaination: This theory is far from proven, it should still be taken with caution.
Label: No evidence

Claim: Health Ministry fired the doctor that diagnosed some coronavirus patients.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: A coronavirus patient has bitten a doctor in the USA.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: 25 million infected and 40,000 died in the new coronavirus epidemic.
Explaination: The figures in the claim can't be found in any official announcement.
Label: False

Claim: A “Wuhan super virus” was created in a Chinese biosecurity lab and has infected more than 100,000 people in Wuhan.
Explaination: There is no evidence that the 2019 Novel coronavirus came from a Chinese laboratory. The WHO says the virus most likely originated in an animal. The number of cases of infection with the coronavirus in Wuhan has not reached 100,000 as claimed in the video.
Label: False

Claim: Keeping your throat moist by drinking water prevents contamination.
Explaination: It's not part of official health recommandations.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus patient bites a doctor’s jugular in the USA.
Explaination: The screenshot was doctored. O Globo never published the story, URL redirects to a non-related story, URL was shortened with a t.co domain, whereas O Globo uses glo.bo in their tweets.
Label: False

Claim: Video showsing a larva being extracted from a person’s lip and its relation to the new coronavirus.
Explaination: The viral video has no relation to coronavirus as it is an old video which can be traced back to October 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Avoid ice-creams, cold drinks, and sweets for 90 days to prevent coronavirus.
Explaination: No scientific backing to say that the virus spreads through food items like ice creams and cold drinks. The virus has not even emerged in India.
Label: False

Claim: New coronavirus information: “15% fatality rate, 83% infection rate” and “the worst in human history”.
Explaination: According to Ministry of Health, this information is absolutely false.
Label: False

Claim: 10,000 people have died because of coronavirus in Wuhan.
Explaination: WHO data listed only 170 deaths in China at the time of publishing
Label: False

Claim: China earned 20 billion dollars on coronavirus.
Explaination: Zombie-fake. For the first time, such a text with a sum of 20 billion and a link (inactive) to the website Faktxeber appeared in 2014 after the annexation of the Crimea, and it featured not China and the leader of the Chinese Communist party, but Russia and Vladimir Putin. As for the Chinese stock markets, they are generally closed until February 3 and transactions are not conducted there.
Label: False

Claim: “Bill and Melinda gates Foundation & others predicted up to 65 million deaths via coronavirus – in simulation ran 3 months ago”
Explaination: InfoWars distorted the facts about an emergency preparedness exercise for a fictional pandemic exercise.
Label: False

Claim: 4 people died in Hyderabad (India) due to the 2019 coronavirus.
Explaination: No cases of coronavirus have been reported in India at this time.
Label: False

Claim: KNUST students discover vaccine for coronavirus and cure patient in Côte d’Ivoire.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus was spread via bananas
Explaination: Coronavirus has transmitted from living organisms - animals - and any evidence, as if bananas or other food products transmit it, has not yet been revealed. Moreover, bananas have been a source of various conspiracies for years, and was considered to be a source of spreading the Ebola, then AIDS and swine flu groundlessly and without any scientific justification. 'Myth Detector's developed banana 'timeline' reflecting the conspiracies that were inspired by a banana and banana-caused viruses at different times.
Label: Conspiracy theory

Claim: A video that claims to feature one of the victims of the new coronavirus.
Explaination: The same video was posted YouTube on October 24th, 2019, which was before the first case of coronavirus got reported in China in December 2019.
Label: False

Claim: Video that shows a animal market in Wuhan.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article.
Label: False

Claim: There is an alert of coronavirus in Madrid, Barcelona and Valencia (January 28).
Explaination: There are no cases of coronavirus detected in Spain.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus in China: 2.8 million infected and 112,000 dead.
Explaination: It's not true that in China there are 2.8 million people infected and 112,000 dead.
Label: False

Claim: A video that has been linked to the new coronavirus for showing a wholesale market in China and exposing its low–hygiene environment.
Explaination: The video is highly misleading: the market is located in Indonesia and not in China.
Label: False

Claim: Drinking a bleach solution will prevent you from getting the coronavirus.
Explaination: Officials have repeatedly warned consumers against ingesting it, saying doing so could cause severe vomiting and liver failure.
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: “Clorox bottle claimed it could kill (the 2019 coronavirus)… before it was developed.”
Explaination: There is no evidence that the 2019 coronavirus was "developed" prior to the outbreak.
Label: False

Claim: Garlic can cure patients infected with the coronavirus
Explaination: There has been no research or evidence that garlic can cure patients infected with the coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Grape vinegar is the antidote of the coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no scientific evidence the benefits of vinegar to fight with the disease. The virus is not poison, an antidote would not be useful at all.
Label: False

Claim: The animals in the list in the photo were served at a meeting for 40 thousand people in China, and the virus spread after that day.
Explaination: The animal list, which presented with the prices in the photo, belongs to the list of animals sold in live animal markets in China. And there is no information regarding a meeting of 40 thousand people in this city.
Label: FALSE

Claim: The studies initiated by the “Military Research Institute” transformed the form of virus in 2018.
Explaination: The claim that the virus was developed by a "military institute" is based on an article authored by Dan Hu, who works for Third Military Medical University in China. However, the article does not mention the experiments changed the genetics of the virus. Again, the examples used in the article are stored in the gene bank with a code and these codes are also included in the study. This allows scientists to work on the virus.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Turkish doctor allegedly found coronavirus vaccine.
Explaination: There is no doctor called "Tamer Yirmiüçoğlu." The doctor in the photo is gynecologist Op. Dr. Tamer Gültekin who became famous in 2016 with the vagina bleaching operations.
Label: False

Claim: “Coronavirus, nasa Pilipinas na (coronavirus, already in the Philippines)” – (Jan. 28)
Explaination: Kabisnes’s false and clickbait headline does not reflect its content. In the video’s first 10 seconds, the show host reads the phrase “Coronavirus, nasa Pilipinas na (coronavirus, already in the Philippines)” then proceeds to say that it was a claim circulating on social media, currently being debunked by Malacanang and DOH.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A positive case of the 2019 novel coronavirus was “confirmed” to be found in Cebu province.
Explaination: The Department of Health announced on Jan. 28 there remains to be no positive case of the 2019 nCoV in the country, only that there are 27 people under investigation for suspected infection.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A video shows the effects of coronavirus and suggest people avoid ice cream and cold drinks for 90 days.
Explaination: Video shown in the viral post showing a person removing larvae from the lips using a pair of tweezers is old and unrelated to coronavirus. The claim in the viral post is also refuted by medical professionals.
Label: False

Claim: The novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) “will not last long” in the Philippines because of its warm climate.
Explaination: The World Health Organization (WHO) has not said that temperature affects the spread of 2019-nCoV and they don't recommend exposure to heat as protection or a treatment for the virus.
Label: False

Claim: Two Filipinos ate bat soup in Wuhan, China, the epicenter of the 2019 novel coronavirus (nCoV), as seen in a video uploaded on Facebook.
Explaination: The original video was taken in Palau and was uploaded on YouTube on July 17, 2019 – at least 5 months before a case of the 2019-nCoV was first reported in Wuhan, China.
Label: False

Claim: The following statement by a Wuhan nurse: “Don’t go out, don’t go to parties, don’t eat out, there are 98.000 infected not 2.700″”
Explaination: On 28 January 2020 official figures as of day before were about 4,500 infected in China, not 2,700. Official figures are published by Johns Hopkins University, which has no connection to the Chinese government propaganda and is trying to objectively monitor the outbreak of the new coronavirus. A relevant source for an epidemic situation is always a health institution or operational headquarters to fight the epidemic, not an individual.
Label: False

Claim: Video footage of dead animals such as dogs, rats, bats and snakes being sold in a market in Wuhan.
Explaination: The recording was shot in Langowan, Indonesia, not in Wuhan.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus firstly appeared in June 2019.
Explaination: The virus was detected in Wuhan, China in late December, not in June 2019 according to Lancet paper, WHO and other sources.
Label: False

Claim: The studies initiated by the “Military Research Institute” transformed the form of virus in 2018.
Explaination: The claim that the virus was developed by a "military institute" is based on an article authored by Dan Hu, who works for Third Military Medical University in China. However, the article does not mention the experiments changed the genetics of the virus. Again, the examples used in the article are stored in the gene bank with a code and these codes are also included in the study. This allows scientists to work on the virus.
Label: False

Claim: The animals in the list in the photo were served at a meeting for 40 thousand people in China, and the virus spread after that day.
Explaination: The animal list, which presented with the prices in the photo, belongs to the list of animals sold in live animal markets in China. And there is no information regarding a meeting of 40 thousand people in this city.
Label: False

Claim: Bill Gates predicted that the coronavirus pandemic would kill 65 million people and created a vaccine to eradicate Africans.
Explaination: The Bill Gates foundation funded a simulation which was not a prediction of the current pandemic and Bill Gates did not create a vaccine for coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: A Saudi Arabian study for a MERS vaccine is linked to the outbreak of coronavirus.
Explaination: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be false. The Saudi clinical trial is investigating a vaccine for the MERS coronavirus strain, not the 2019 Novel coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Post claims food products such as rice, fortune cookies, mi goreng noodles, ice tea and “Chinese red bull” are contaminated with coronavirus in Australia. Also some areas of Sydney are supposedly identified as contaminated.
Explaination: AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be false. A viral infectious diseases expert says there is no evidence of food being a source of any coronavirus transmission. The Facebook post also lists information from the “Department of Diseasology Parramatta” conducting tests showing “positive readings” for the virus at train stations in four Sydney suburbs. NSW Health confirmed to AAP Fact Check there is no such organisation as the “Department of Diseasology Parramatta” and there have been no “positive readings” at train stations.
Label: FALSE

Claim: There are several new confirmed cases in several French cities.
Explaination: Hospitals and authorities denied such claims in various cities.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Food and locations are contaminated in Australia.
Explaination: Authorities denied those claims.
Label: False

Claim: This woman in Malaysia died of coronavirus.
Explaination: Family says no evidence of Cov.
Label: False

Claim: Water used in an islamic ablution ritual can kill the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Health experts warn that water alone cannot kill the virus and recommend that people wash their hands with soap and water for effective protection.
Label: False

Claim: “How to prevent the coronavirus: Drink fennel tea twice a day. Fennel tea has the same component as Tamiflu medicine, used to treat H1N1”.
Explaination: Fennel tea doesn't has the same component as Tamiflu and Tamiflu is not recommended by WHO to treat the new coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Raúl Rodolfo Abhduz Khan, biochemical engineer from Karmalah Laboratories, is the creator of the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The person in the image is a YouTuber from Spain named Raúl Álvarez, aka AuronPlay. His image is commonly used to create disinformation, i.e. he was blamed for the fire in Notre Dame and in the Amazonas. The image is manipulated in order to show that is a news from CNN en Español.
Label: False

Claim: The Indian health department has issued a notification advising people to drink only 50-80 ml of water, avoid spicy food, and not travel in crowded spaces till March 2020.
Explaination: There has been no notification suggesting drinking only a certain amount of water, avoiding spicy food and improving the intake of vitamin C prevent coronavirus. The children are more vulnerable theory is also not scientifically backed. At the time of the story, there were no confirmed cases in India and the death toll had reached 106 in China.
Label: Partially false

Claim: New strain of virus was already patented; Bill Gates funds institute which holds patent; Bill Gates predicted the outbreak and 65 Million Deaths.
Explaination: There are many patents for coronaviruses, but those are for different strains, not the one that recently broke out in China. Bill Gates has not predicted the outbreak.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: Everything is much worse than reported; the current virus is worse than SARS; it causes red rashes on the skin, media is not reporting enough; people are falling over from the virus in the streets.
Explaination: The video is spreading unproven, misleading and partly false claims about the outbreak of the new coronavirus.
Label: Partially false

Claim: A seafood market is the source of the novel coronavirus, strange animals and foods were sold there, such as batsoup and snakes.
Explaination: It is possible that animals transmitted the virus to people. Many of the first patient had visited the market. However, a direct link has not yet been proven.
Label: No evidence

Claim: 156,000 people died in China due to the coronavirus, 90,000 only in Wuhan.
Explaination: Article was based on Russian YouTube video, which was based on another article written by infamous conspiracy fake-news website. Figures had no reliable source of information.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus spreads in Ecuadorian cities (Quito – Guayaquil).
Explaination: The Ministry of Public Health analyzes a suspicious case. There is no confirmation about the presence of the virus in Ecuador.
Label: False

Claim: The Health Authority confirmed 3 cases of the 2019 coronavirus in the country.
Explaination: There were no confirmed cases at that time.
Label: False

Claim: A doctor in the Wuhan hospital was seen collapsing and later lost his life as a result of being infected from the coronavirus 2019-nCoV in front of patients and hospital staff.
Explaination: "The incident which was captured in the video in question was a violent attack in the public hospital at the city of Quzhou, at the Hejing county in China. The doctor and two of his colleagues were injured by the relative of a patient who lost his life after an acute myocardial infarction."
Label: False

Claim: American radio host spreads misinformation about number of deaths and infected with coronavirus; rumors get to Brazil.
Explaination: The text on Facebook only quotes Hal Turner radio show. The american states having worked 15 years on FBI. In fact, Hal Turner never worked on FBI, only as a consultant between 2003 and 2007. Furthermore, his radio show has already spread other fake news checked by american fact-checking agency Lead Stories.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Coronavirus may have originated in a lab linked to China’s biowarfare program.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: Misleading

Claim: 10,000 people have died in Wuhan, China.
Explaination: As of early Jan. 27, the estimated death toll is 81 — all of them in China.
Label: False

Claim: A “Chinese spy team” working in a Canadian government lab sent “pathogens to the Wuhan facility” prior to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: Eric Morrissette, a spokesman for the Public Health Agency of Canada, told us by email, “this is misinformation and there is no factual basis for claims being made on social media.”
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus has an effect on a person’s lips.
