Explaination: The video shared a effect of coronavirus on a patient lip is found to be on the internet at least since November-2019 i.e. before the recent epidemic broke out. So, it is not related to the recent coronavirus epidemic.
Label: False

Claim: BIll Gates contributed to the spread of coronavirus.
Explaination: The work that Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation does on healthcare has in no way contributed to the spread of coronavirus.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Video of Wuhan market with dogs, snakes, rats and bats…
Explaination: Video taken in Indonesia (Langowan)
Label: FALSE

Claim: Close-up of a bat soup bowl that is eaten in Wuhan, or elsewhre in China.
Explaination: A local source in Palau said he recognized a specific local restaurant. Table, room setting and plates' decorations match with other pictures found online showing tourist dining in unspecified restaurant in Palau. Not enough elements for us to call it false but pretty close.
Label: Unverified

Claim: This video shows a woman eating a bat soup in Wuhan.
Explaination: Video shot in Palau in 2016.
Label: FALSE

Claim: This video shows a man eating a bat soup in a restaurant in China.
Explaination: With identified many elements in the video that matched pictures published by Chinese bloggers who visited Palau and documented their trip.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Filipinos are eating a bat soup in Wuhan.
Explaination: YouTubers made the video last July in Palau.
Label: FALSE

Claim: Bat market and bat meat being sold in Wuhan.
Explaination: Video taken in Indonesia (Manado)
Label: FALSE

Claim: A package from AliExpress sent from China can spread the new coronavirus.
Explaination: The coronavirus need a living host to grow. This kind of virus lives only a few days in a liquid and only a few hours on an object. The virus would die during the long transport from China to France, for example. The scientist never observed this king of contamination before with any kind of coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus was created and patented by an American lab two years before the pandemic.
Explaination: These pre-existing patents are referring to other viruses and coronaviruses.
Label: False

Claim: An explosion that occurred in Wuhan, China, is tied to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: It was a video supposedly of an explosion in Wuhan, China. A search showed it was actually footage of the first of several explosions in Tianjin, China, from 2015.
Label: False

Claim: Spreading coronavirus is the interest of the USA, because American laboratories are operating not only around Russia but in the surroundings of Asian countries and in Georgia (Lugar lab).
Explaination: There are several conspiracy narratives developed in the report, including on US Labs artificially linked to the coronavirus. In the context of conspiracy narrative, the story author names Tbilisi-based Lugar Laboratory of biological research, making an unreasonable parallel between virus found in China and Tbilisi Laboratory. Moreover, the story features the archive material from 2018, in which former Georgian Minister of Security Igor Giorgadze talks about the threats coming from the Lugar Lab. Lugar Laboratory is a part of the National Center for Disease Control and Public Health of Ministry of Health of Georgia. For years, Lugar Lab has been a target of Kremlin, Russia affiliated media, Russian politicians and high officials. Except for US-financed C Hepatitis Treatment program, there are other conspiracies linked to the lab.
Label: False

Claim: Event 201 “gave out stuffed souvenir coronavirus toys” to “commemorate” novel coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: Event 201 used a fictionalized coronavirus outbreak as its pandemic scenario but did not "predict" the outbreak of a strain that would be detected two months later in December 2019 in Wuhan, China.
Label: Mostly false

Claim: 10,000 people have died in Wuhan, China.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: Pants on Fire!

Claim: China “stole coronavirus from Canada and weaponized it into a Bioweapon.”
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: The Chinese Communist Party “will finally admit that the real source of the coronavirus is from ‘a lab in Wuhan’ linked to its covert biological weapon programs.”
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: A post says the coronavirus can be slowed or stopped with the “immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.”
Explaination: The claim was originally shared on an alternative medical website that promotes nutritional supplementation.
Label: FALSE

Claim: A “patient tested positive” for the 2019 novel coronavirus (nCoV) at the Makati Medical Center.
Explaination: There is still no confirmed case of the 2019 nCoV in the Philippines as of January 28, according to the Department of Health (DOH).
Label: False

Claim: Videos of people infected with the new coronavirus in China.
Explaination: In both cases, it can't corroborate the origin of the material. Besides, does not exist an official pronouncement of any Chinese authority in health matter.
Label: No evidence

Claim: The coronavirus is related to the treatment given to Uighur Muslims by China
Explaination: The claim that the emergence of the Corona 2019 virus is related to Chinese treatment of Uighur Muslims is a misleading claim. There is no link at all between the emergence of the coronavirus with how China treats Muslim Uighurs. The spread of the coronavirus has become a global health challenge after the advent of SARS in 2002 and MERS in 2013.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The novel coronavirus has reached Cebu province and Boracay Island, which are popular tourists destinations.
Explaination: There is no confirmed positive case of the newly-detected 2019 nCoV in the Philippines at this time. This was clarified by Health Secretary Francisco Duque III in a Jan. 27 interview with CNN Philippines. He emphasized this in a separate press conference in Malacanang, where he also reported that the five-year-old boy suspected of having the disease tested negative.
Label: False

Claim: Ukrainian media registred the first confirmed case of the new coronavirus.
Explaination: We have described that this is not the case and indicated that there are several strains.
Label: False

Claim: “In ‘Resident Evil’ the Umbrella Corporation releases a virus that infects the people of Raccoon City. A biological research lab with the exact same logo as the Umbrella Corporation can be found in the city where the coronavirus outbreak originated.”
Explaination: There’s no evidence that the 2019 coronavirus that was first detected in Wuhan was created in a lab. It likely has its origins in bats, according to the CDC.
Label: False

Claim: An Israeli analyst suggests that the coronavirus might be a biological weapon created in a laboratory.
Explaination: Analyst Dany Shoham told FactCheck.KZ that he was indeed interview by Washington Times, but the website published only a part of his answer. He said there is no evidence that such thing happened.
Label: Partially false

Claim: “Coronavirus in China: more than 30 million quarantined, 2.8 million infected; 112,000 dead! People falling on the streets and trains! Supermarkets without food!”
Explaination: "No official source has confirmed these numbers. There were 81 dead and 2,840 cases confirmed until January 27th. Hal Turner never worked at the FBI. He was only an informer".
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus killed 112,000 people in China.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Video shows a woman eating a bat soup in Wuhan.
Explaination: We tracked the girl's social media accounts, confirmed they were authentic. She claims the video was taken over the summer but wouldn't tell were. The setup and meal look like Palau traditional bat soup but we couldn't confirm.
Label: No evidence

Claim: Close-up of a bat soup bowl eaten in Wuhan, or elsewhere in China.
Explaination: A local source in Palau said he recognized a specific local restaurant. Table, room setting and plates' decorations match with other pictures found online showing tourist dining in unspecified restaurant in Palau. Not enough elements for us to call it false but pretty close.
Label: No evidence

Claim: This video shows a woman eating a bat soup in Wuhan.
Explaination: Video shot in Palau in 2016.
Label: False

Claim: This video shows a man eating a bat soup in a restaurant in China.
Explaination: With identified many elements in the video that matched pictures published by Chinese bloggers who visited Palau and documented their trip.
Label: False

Claim: Filipinos are eating a bat soup in Wuhan.
Explaination: YouTubers made the video last July in Palau.
Label: False

Claim: Bat market and bat meat are being sold in Wuhan.
Explaination: Video taken in Indonesia (Manado)
Label: False

Claim: Video of Wuhan market with dogs, snakes, rats and bats.
Explaination: Video taken in Indonesia (Langowan)
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus can be slowed or stopped with the “immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.”
Explaination: There’s currently no vaccine or medicine recommended to treat the current coronavirus, and there’s no evidence high doses of vitamin C has any effect.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus can be slowed or stopped with the “immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.”
Explaination: The claim was originally shared on an alternative medical website that promotes nutritional supplementation.
Label: False

Claim: This video shows the Wuhan market where the virus comes from.
Explaination: It's a market in Indonesia.
Label: False

Claim: Queensland issued travel warning for Wuhan and Chinese-populated areas in Australia.
Explaination: Queensland said they did not.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus is a type of rabies.
Explaination: Authorities say it's a hoax, the two viruses are different.
Label: False

Claim: The first infected person in Kazakhstan is in Almaty.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False

Claim: Indian nurse in Jeddah (Saudi Arabia) has been detected with novel coronavirus(2019-nCOV).
Explaination: Official Government handles have clarified that The Indian Nurse is not suffering from the deadly 2019-Ncov.
Label: False

Claim: There is a Chinese patient at the Hi-Precision Diagnostics clinic in Alabang, Philippines, who was tested positive for the novel coronavirus or 2019 nCoV.
Explaination: In a press briefing on Tuesday, January 28, the Department of Health (DOH) announced that there was still no confirmed case of 2019 nCoV in the country. The patient at Asian Hospital and Medical Center in Alabang, Muntinlupa City is among the 24 persons under investigation (PUIs) for the possible 2019 nCoV infection.
Label: False

Claim: The 2019 novel coronavirus (nCoV) is a “type of rabies” that can be contracted by eating bats.
Explaination: In a press briefing on Tuesday, January 28, Health Secretary Francisco Duque III clarified that the 2019 nCoV belongs to the Coronaviridae family of viruses. Meanwhile, rabies is from Rhabdoviridae.
Label: False

Claim: “Wuhan Virus” is named SARI. Steroid is the medicine to cure it. Acetic acid can be used to prevent it.
Explaination: 1."Wuhan Virus" is named as "2019n-Cov".2.Steroid is not used for curing it. 3. Spraying acetic acid in air can not help prevent it.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Coronavirus dies at 56°C, so eat cooked food and turn on AC. Plus, Ethanol can kill the “Wuhan Virus”.
Explaination: Turning on the heater can not kill coronavirus. Both alcohol and chlorine can be useful to disinfect surfaces, but they can not cure COVID-19 and need to be used under appropriate recommendations.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Chinese doctor Zhong Nanshan advised to rinse your mouth with salty water to prevent 2019n-Cov.
Explaination: Nan-shan Zhong hasn't had such a comment. There is no evidence that rinsing the mouth with salty water can prevent COVID-19, either.
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus is patented by Pirbright University.
Explaination: Coronaviruses are a group of similar looking viruses. The patent by Pirbright University is for the Avian Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) which is found in fowls, pheasants and turkeys. This patent is not linked to the current 2019-novel coronavirus.
Label: Partially false

Claim: A salesman in Medellín’s El Hueco market was sent to a hospital with coronavirus symptoms.
Explaination: Colombia's Ministry of Health reports no confirmed cases of coronavirus infections in Colombia. Medellín's Secretary of Health also reports no cases in their city.
Label: False

Claim: The virus was created by humans and patented.
Explaination: The patents exist but are not for the current coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Chinese scientists expelled from a Canadian microbiology lab took the novel coronavirus strain with them to China.
Explaination: The two scientists at the National Microbiology Lab (Winnipeg, Canada) are suspected to have sent live Ebola and Henipah viruses to Beijing in March 2019, but it has nothing to do with the coronavirus. They were expelled from the lab, but are not considered spies.
Label: False

Claim: A CBC news report would said that Chinese scientists from a Canadian lab sent the coronavirus to Wuhan.
Explaination: Nothing in the CBC report (and 2 subsequent reports) said anything about "spies", or even coronavirus, and no link is done between the expulsion of these two scientists in July 2019 and the virus.
Label: False

Claim: Authorities have identified that the international chemical-warfare terrorist ‘Samuel Whitcomb Hyde’ is behind the deadly China ‘coronavirus.’”
Explaination: It's a long-running internet hoax. Sam Hyde is a comedian who is the frequent target of such hoaxes
Label: False

Claim: DailyMail reported that a virus leaked from the Wuhan National Biosafety Laboratory was responsible for the pandemic.
Explaination: The DailyMail article didn’t report that. Rutgers University microbiologist Dr Richard Ebright told DailyMail that "at this point there’s no reason to harbour suspicions" that the facility had anything to do with the outbreak, besides being responsible for the crucial genome sequencing that lets doctors diagnose it.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A spray could protect against the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The product being hawked by the Genesis Church 2 is essentially bleach.
Label: No evidence

Claim: A tabletop exercise using a model of the current outbreak “predicted” 65 million people could die from the coronavirus.
Explaination: There was no prediction made at the tabletop exercise. It was held in October of 2019 and used a different model of the coronavirus, and no predicted death toll was estimated by the groups.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus has been originated in a laboratory linked to China’s biowarfare program.
Explaination: There is no evidence that the coronavirus 2019-nCoV was born in a China laboratory.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A French member of parliament, Dominique Da Silva, said he hopes the coronavirus will kill people older than 70.
Explaination: The deputy's speech was meant to be satire, but it was misleading and shocked some people.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The SARS-CoV-2 was created in 2003 in the United States.
Explaination: The patent that some people shared isn't related to the SARS-Cov-2 but to another coronavirus.
Label: False

Claim: Doctors said the entire Wuhan population will die of the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Authorities never said that and US CDC said most people will recover on their own.
Label: False

Claim: “They create diseases to offer vaccines. There is already a patent for an attenuated coronavirus.”
Explaination: The Pirbright Institute has a patent for an attenuated form of a different strain of coronavirus, the infectious bronchitis virus (IBV). It only affects poultry.
Label: False

Claim: Coronavirus may have spread due to the consumption of bat soup, according to scientists.
Explaination: There is no evidence to support the claim that the consumption of bat soup is connected to the transmission of the 2019-nCoV. One recent study indicates that the new virus does share genetic information with other kinds of coronaviruses that infect bats, but it is still unclear which animals may have transmitted the virus to humans. Analysing a genetic database, researchers concluded that Chinese snakes are the most likely reservoir for the new pathogen, but the hypothesis has yet to be tested experimentally.
Label: False

Claim: A Chinese person, who was taken from Kansai airport (in Osaka, Japan) to a hospital, has run away before they could be tested.
Explaination: According to the Kansai Airport Quarantine Station, this information is absolutely false.
Label: False

Claim: A new case of novel coronavirus was registered in Saudi Arabia. A nurse from India was diagnosed with the specific strain of the virus.
Explaination: "According to Dr. Tarik Al Azraqi, head of the committee for infectious diseases in Saudi Arabia, the nurse was diagnosed and received treatment for MERS not 2019-nCoV."
Label: False

Claim: “So let me get this straight about this virus. It’s “new” yet it was lab created and patented in 2015 (in development since 03’).”
Explaination: All of the posts link to patents that are related to two different viruses in the coronavirus family. There is no patent related to the new virus
Label: (Org. doesn't apply rating)

Claim: “So let me get this straight about this virus. It’s “new” yet it was lab created and patented in 2015 (in development since 03’).
Explaination: All of the posts link to patents that are related to two different viruses in the coronavirus family. There is no patent related to the new virus
Label: (Org. doesn't apply rating)

Claim: A Chinese woman from Wuhan arrived in France with suspected symptoms of coronavirus.
Explaination: The Chinese embassy in France confirmed the presence of this Chinese woman in France and said that she gave reassuring news. According to French authorities, investigations are underway, but this suspicious case has never been officially reported.
Label: Misleading

Claim: A 2015 research article about a lab-made coronavirus referred to the current outbreak.
Explaination: It was an opinion piece, and while facts used in the article appear accurate, it did not refer to the current coronavirus outbreak.
Label: Misleading

Claim: That the China-centered coronavirus had infected 2.8 million people and killed 112,000.
Explaination: This was a wild exaggeration of the facts. It supposedly relied on reporting from "covert intelligence sources." At the time of the story, some 900 people had been infected and 26 had died.
Label: False

Claim: There’s a ‘coronavirus patent’, FEMA ‘proposes martial law’, Gates Foundation predicted virus, ‘funded group who owns virus patent’, coronavirus was ‘created in a lab’ as a ‘bioweapon for population control’.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE

Claim: “Confirmed cases” of the novel coronavirus or 2019 nCoV were recorded at the Philippine Bank of Communications (PBCom) Tower in Makati City, according to a message that circulated Friday, Jan. 24.
Explaination: Speaking to reporters on January 24, Health Undersecretary Eric Domingo maintained that there is still no confirmed case of the 2019 nCov in the Philippines. The management of PBCom Tower also said there is “no truth” to the information.
Label: False

Claim: “The new fad disease called the ‘coronavirus’ is sweeping headlines. Funny enough, there was a patent for the coronavirus was filed in 2015 and granted in 2018.”
Explaination: All of the posts link to patents that are related to two different viruses in the coronavirus family. There is no patent related to the new virus
Label: (Org. doesn't apply rating)

Claim: “So let me get this straight about this virus. It’s ‘new’ yet it was lab created and patented in 2015 (in development since 03’).”
Explaination: All of the posts link to patents that are related to two different viruses in the coronavirus family. There is no patent related to the new virus
Label: (Org. doesn't apply rating)

Claim: The first case of new coronavirus in Venezuela has been registered. It comes from the Bolivar state.
Explaination: The Association of Doctors in the State of Bolivar has publicly denied the information.
Label: False

Claim: “[The coronavirus is] ‘new’ yet it was lab-created and patented in 2015”.
Explaination: The post references the Wuhan coronavirus, but the patent filed is clearly stated to be for the SARS coronavirus, which caused the 2003 outbreak. Neither the SARS nor Wuhan coronavirus is lab-created; evidence points to an animal reservoir as the source of infection.
Label: Misleading

Claim: Saline solutions can kill the new coronavirus.
Explaination: Doctor and WHO deny this claim.
Label: False

Claim: You have to wear a disposable mask with the blue side out if you are sick and the white side out if you are not.
Explaination: The only way to wear a mask is with blue face out, experts say to AFP.
Label: False

Claim: “There’s magically already a vaccine available.”
Explaination: Anthony S. Fauci, a top official at the National Institutes of Health (NIH), told Bloomberg Law that a potential vaccine "could move into early-stage human testing in the next three months."
Label: Not true

Claim: Warning: the virus is spreading in Italy (January 22).
Explaination: This news is not confirmed by any national or local newspaper nor by the Italian government.
Label: False

Claim: Russian scientists have found a cure for the new Chinese virus.
Explaination: There has been no new information on Trizivir drug testing or its results. By the date of publication of this analysis, Triazavirin had not been confirmed as a cure for the new coronavirus. Because the title of Sputnik's article claims that the Russian drug Triazavirin for COVID-19 is "ready", although the article does not contain this claim, the article receives clickbait and misinformation ratings.
Label: Misleading

Claim: The new coronavirus outbreak is linked to eating bats.
Explaination: Bats are known natural reservoirs for coronaviruses. However, many other animals, such as civet cats and snakes, can also carry these viruses. There is currently not enough evidence to conclude that the 2019 coronavirus outbreak resulted from people eating bats in Wuhan, China.
Label: No evidence

Claim: Chinese influencer caused the new coronavirus outbreak after eating bat soup.
Explaination: The footage was filmed in 2016 in Micronesia, and not in China.
Label: False

Claim: “A patent on this ‘new’ coronavirus expired on the 22nd (of January), today”.
Explaination: As noted above, the patent for the vaccine for this new Wuhan strain did not expire on January 22, 2020. That patent is related to the SARS epidemic, which killed more than 800 people after it broke out in China in 2002.
Label: False

Claim: “There’s magically already a vaccine available.”
Explaination: Anthony S. Fauci, a top official at the National Institutes of Health (NIH), told Bloomberg Law that a potential vaccine "could move into early-stage human testing in the next three months."
Label: False

Claim: The coronavirus was created in a lab and patented.
Explaination: The patents circulating are linked to other coronaviruses and a patent for a virus does not mean it's man made.
Label: False

Claim: The peak of the new coronavirus will happen in two weeks (from Jan 18). During those two weeks, all the infections will occur, then there will be two very calm weeks and another two until it will all go down.
Explaination: The chance of getting SARS-CoV-2 only comes down to the next two weeks. What lasts two weeks or less is the incubation period.
Label: Partially false

Claim: Stores and supermarkets in Veracruz (Mexico) will close due to the new coronavirus. The local government has asked people to buy supplies.
Explaination: Authorities ask not to make panic purchases. As of March 18, stores have not said they will close.
Label: False

Claim: A chain message circulated on Tuesday, Jan. 14, warning people to avoid going to Shangri-La Plaza (a mall in Mandaluyong City) because of a supposed case of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) reported in one of the mall’s medical clinics.
Explaination: The Department of Health (DOH) and Healthway Medical both issued advisories denying the claim in the chain message.
Label: False

Claim: WhatsApp text that says the Chinese created the coronavirus and that the main cities in China did not suffer from the pandemic.
Explaination: The cities of Shanghai and Beijing registered cases of COVID-19 and even adopted restrictive measures against the coronavirus. The Chinese economy has indeed felt the economic effects of the outbreak, differently from what the piece of disinformation states. The country's main stock exchange indices, CSI 300 and compound Shanghai, fell 8.7% and 6.4% only in March, respectively.
Label: False
